[[I Love Me (Demi Lovato song)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 songs, R&B songs, Pop songs

"I Love Me" is a song by American entertainer Demi Lovato. It was released on March 6, 2020, as the second single from her upcoming seventh studio album.  She co-wrote the song with Anne-Marie, Jennifer Decilveo, Sean Douglas, and its producers, Oak, Keith Sorrells, and Alex Niceforo.

The song entered the Billboard Hot 100 at number 18.

[[Glenwood Springs, Colorado]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Colorado, County seats in Colorado

Glenwood Springs is the Home Rule Municipality that is the county seat of Garfield County, Colorado, United States.  Glenwood Springs is located near Roaring Fork River and the Colorado River. As of the 2010 census it had a population of 9,614.

[[Carlos Falcó, 5th Marquess of Griñón]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish royalty, Spanish businesspeople

Carlos Falcó y Fernández de Córdoba, 5th Marquess of Griñón, GE (3 February 1937 – 20 March 2020) was a Spanish peer. He was best known for one of his titles, Marquess of Griñón. He also held another higher-ranking title, Marquess of Castel Moncayo, with Grandeeship attached. He was born Palacio de las Dueñas, in Seville.

Falcó died on 20 March 2020 at a hospital in Madrid from COVID-19, aged 83.

[[Lady of the Dunes]]

CATEGORIES: Unexplained deaths

Lady of the Dunes (also known as Lady in the Dunes) is the nickname for an unknown woman whose dead body was discovered on July 26, 1974 in the Race Point Dunes, Provincetown, Massachusetts. Her body was exhumed in 1980, 2000, and 2013 in efforts to identify her and her murderer. The murder is currently unsolved. 

The case was featured on the television series Haunting Evidence in 2006.

[[Provincetown, Massachusetts]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Massachusetts

Provincetown ˈ is a New England town located on the tip of Cape Cod in Barnstable County, Massachusetts, in the United States. It is a small coastal resort town with a year-round population of just under 3,000, Provincetown has a summer population of as high as 60,000. 

[[Danny Ray Thompson]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Musicians from New York City, American saxophonists, American jazz musicians

Danny Ray Thompson (October 1, 1947 – March 12, 2020) was an American jazz saxophonist. He played baritone saxophone with the Sun Ra Arkestra and managed the band for a period of time. He was born in New York City. He made his first live appearance with the Arkestra in April, 1968 at Carnegie Hall.

Thompson died on March 12, 2020 under hospice care in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania at the age of 72.

[[Sun Ra]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 1993 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Deaths from respiratory failure, Deaths from stroke, American jazz musicians, American composers, American bandleaders, American pianists, American poets, People from Bessemer, Alabama, Musicians from Birmingham, Alabama, Writers from Birmingham, Alabama

Le Sony'r Ra (born Herman Poole Blount, May 22, 1914 – May 30, 1993), better known as Sun Ra, was an American jazz composer, bandleader, piano, synthesizer player, and poet. He was known for his experimental music. For much of his career, Ra led "The Arkestra", an ensemble with an ever-changing name and flexible line-up. 

From the mid-1950s until his death, Ra led the musical band known as The Arkestra. Its performances often included dancers and musicians dressed in  futuristic costumes inspired by Ancient Egyptian.

Ra died of a stroke caused from heart and respiratory failure at a hospital in Birmingham, Alabama on May 30, 1993 at the age of 79.

[[Marshall Allen]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, Living people, American saxophonists, American jazz musicians, Musicians from Louisville, Kentucky

Marshall Belford Allen (born May 25, 1924) is an American free jazz and avant-garde jazz alto saxophone player. He also performs on flute, oboe, piccolo, and EVI (an electronic valve instrument made by Steiner, Crumar company). Allen is best known for his work with Sun Ra.

[[Alto's Adventure]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 video games, IOS games, Android (operating system) games

Alto's Adventure is a 2015 snowboarding platformer video game. It was made in 2015 for iOS devices. It was made in February 2016 for Android devices. It is best known for winning many awards. The game is about a boy's llamas running off and he goes snowboarding to get the llamas back. There are levels in the game which the player can get higher levels by completing tasks. There is a currency in the game which are coins which can let the player buy things in the game. It was released on Windows on May 25, 2016.

A sequel, titled Alto's Odyssey was released on February 21, 2018 on iOS.

[[After Hours (album)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 albums, The Weeknd, R&B albums

After Hours is the seventh studio album by Canadian recording artist The Weeknd. It was released on March 20, 2020, by XO and Republic Records.

The album broke the record for most pre-adds on Apple Music before release, with over one million pre-adds on the streaming service.

[[Origin story]]

CATEGORIES: Literature

In entertainment, an origin story is a story that tells how a character or group of characters became the way they are. Very often, it adds to the main story. In comic books, an origin story explains how certain characters obtained the powers they have (often superpowers), or how they became a hero or villain.  When the comic or book is successful and grows older, origin stories are often rewritten and extended.  

[[The Powerpuff Girls (2016 TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s American comedy television series, The Powerpuff Girls, American sitcoms, Comedy television series, American satirical television series, American children's television series, English-language television programs, 2016 television series debuts, Television series about siblings, Cartoon Network series, Flash animation, Parodies

The Powerpuff Girls (2016) is an American animated superhero action-comedy sitcom children's television series and a sequel of the loosely based on the Cartoon Network original series of the same name created by Craig McCracken. It was first announced in June 2014. A year later, it was announced that it would feature new voice actors for the main characters. The series premiered on April 4, 2016 in the United States and Latin America, 19 April 2016 in Italy, and 25 April 2016 in the United Kingdom. 

[[Brotherhood of Evil Mutants]]

The Brotherhood of Mutants, originally called the Brotherhood of Evil Mutants is a group of supervillains from Marvel Comics who fight against the X-Men. Their leader is the supervillain Magneto. Most members are mutant whose origin story involves being treated very badly by normal humans and who want revenge.  

In the 2000 movie X-Men, Magneto tells the mutant-hating Robert Kelly “My dear Senator, we aren’t here to kill you, we’re here to welcome you to the Brotherhood of Mutants”. Within that movie, Mystique, a naturally blue shape-shifter who is in love with Magneto, Sabretooth, who is strong and has fangs and Toad, a mutant with the powers of a toad.   In the sequel, X2, an X-Man named Pyro who can control fire leaves the X-Men to join Magneto and Mystique and they become the new Brotherhood of Mutants. 

In the next movie X-Men:The Last Stand, Magneto frees a number of dangerous mutants captured by the government and makes them part of the new Brotherhood of Mutants. They include Juggernaut, who is very strong and cannot be stopped once he starts moving, Gemini who can clone himself and once robbed six banks at the same time, the Phoenix, a female X-Man once called Jean Grey a male mutant with the powers of a porcupine, a female mutant who can sense other mutants and what their powers are and Pyro. 

In the movie X-Men:First Class, Erik Leshnerr convinces mutants who worked for the supervillain Sebastian Shaw to leave his army, the Hellfire Club and become the First Brotherhood of Mutants.  

In X-Men:Days of Future Past, Magneto tells all the mutants in the world to “form a new Brotherhood of our kind” to take over from the humans.

[[Powerpuff Girls Z]]

CATEGORIES: The Powerpuff Girls, 2000s anime television series

Powerpuff Girls Z (Japanese:出ましたっ！パワパフガールズZ, Hepburn: Demashita! Pawapafu Gāruzu Zetto, lit. They're Here! Powerpuff Girls Z) or PPGZ is a 2006 Japanese magical girl comedy anime series directed by Megumu Ishiguro and  based on the American animated television series The Powerpuff Girls. It ran from July 2006 to June 2007 on TV Tokyo in Japan, with reruns airing on Cartoon Network's Japanese channel starting in 2008. An English language version was released on Cartoon Network in The Philippines sometime in 2008.

[[Izakaya]]

CATEGORIES: Japanese culture, Asian restaurants

An izakaya (izakaya) is a type of bar in Japan where many people go to drink and have snacks. Unlike bars or pubs which are western-style, izakayas are Japanese-style and sell things like beer, chūhai and sake, and have a bigger variety of foods than bars and pubs. 

[[Malaysian Han Studies]]

Malaysian Han Studies, abbreviated as MAHANS, is a non-profit, private educational institution in Malacca, Malaysia.

[[Équateur]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, 2015 establishments in Africa

Équateur Province is one of the twenty-six provinces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Its capital is Mbandaka.

The province of Équateur made in 1917 was much larger than today. Over time it had a number of border and name changes. In 2015 the new province was made from the old Équateur District together with the city of Mbandaka.

Équateur has seven territories:

[[Jacques Oudin]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, French politicians, Legion of Honour, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France

Jacques Oudin (7 October 1939 – 20 March 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the Senate of France from 1986 to 2004, representing the department of Vendée. 

Oudin died on March 20, 2020 as a result of COVID-19.

[[Marouane Fellaini]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people, Belgian footballers, Manchester United F.C. players, Premier League players, Sportspeople from Brussels, 2008 Summer Olympics, 2014 FIFA World Cup players, UEFA Euro 2016 players, 2018 FIFA World Cup players

Marouane Fellaini-Bakkioui (born 22 November 1987) is a Belgian professional footballer. He plays as a midfielder for Chinese club Shandong Luneng Taishan. 

[[Wu Lei]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 births, Living people, Chinese footballers, People from Nanjing

Wu Lei (武磊; born 19 November 1991) is a Chinese professional footballer. He plays as a left winger for La Liga club RCD Espanyol and the China national team.

Wu was born in Nanjing, Jiangsu to a Hui family. He is the all-time top goalscorer for Shanghai SIPG with 169 goals. He is the second all-time top goalscorer in Chinese Super League history with 102 goals. At 14 years and 287 days, Wu became the youngest to play in a professional league match in China. He joined Spanish side Espanyol in 2019. He has also played over 60 times for China since 2010.

In March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Wu tested positive to COVID-19..

[[Italo De Zan]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Italian cyclists, Sportspeople from Veneto, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy

Italo De Zan (1 July 1925 – 9 March 2020) was an Italian racing cyclist. He won the tenth Giro d'Italia in 1948. He was born in San Fior.

De Zan died of COVID-19 in Treviso on 9 March 2020 at the age of 94.

[[Nasser Shabani]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth missing, 2020 deaths, Iranian military people, Generals, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Iran

Nasser Shabani (ناصر شعبانی; died 13 March 2020) was an Iranian general. He was a senior commander of Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC). He took credit for using Houthi rebels to target Saudi oil tankers.

[[Aileen Baviera]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Filipino scientists, Political scientists, Academics, People from Manila, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines

Aileen San Pablo Baviera (August 26, 1959 – March 21, 2020) was a Filipino political scientist and sinologist. She was one of the leading China experts in her country.

Baviera died of pneumonia caused by the COVID-19 virus in the early morning of March 21, 2020 at San Lazaro Hospital, Manila, Philippines. She returned from Paris on March 12, where she was infected as a congressman. Wife of the late Villegas Baviera who died of heart attack in 2018, Baviera left after three surviving children, Vita Amalya (born 1985), Mara Yasmin (born 1986) and Jorge Vittorio (born 1991).

[[Dov Ben-Meir]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Former Members of Knesset, Hebrew University of Jerusalem alumni, Israeli trade unionists, Jewish Israeli politicians, Naturalized citizens of Israel, Polish Jews

Dov Ben-Meir (דב בן-מאיר, 11 August 1927 – 21 March 2020) was a Polish-born Israeli politician and trade unionist. He was a member of the Knesset for the Alignment between 1981 and 1988. Ben-Meir was born in Ciechocinek, Poland.

Ben-Meir died on 21 March 2020 in Tel Aviv, Israel at the age of 92.

[[Vicenç Capdevila]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Mayors, Spanish politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain

Vicenç Capdevila Cardona (28 October 1936–21 March 2020) was a Spanish lawyer and politician. He was mayor of Hospitalet de Llobregat from 1973 to 1977. He also was a Deputy of Congress from 1977 to 1979, representing Barcelona and a member of member parliament of Catalonia from 1980 to 1984, representing Barcelona.

He died on 21 March 2020 of COVID-19 in Barcelona at the age of 83.

[[Hellmut Stern]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Jewish German musicians, Jewish Israeli musicians, Musicians from Berlin, Naturalized citizens of Israel, Refugees from Nazism, Violinists

Hellmut Stern (21 May 1928 – 21 March 2020) was a German violinist of Jewish descent. He played principal violin with the Berlin Philharmonic. He published his autobiography in 1990. He talked about his life in exile in China, Israel, and the U.S., and his return to Berlin.  He was a member of the orchestra's board (Orchestervorstand). He played with leading conductors of the time, especially with Herbert von Karajan.

Stern died on 21 March 2020 in Berlin of Parkinson's disease, aged 91.

[[Petru Bogatu]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Editors, Journalists, Essayists, Political writers, Educators, Moldovan people

Petru Bogatu (12 July 1951 – 22 March 2020) was a Moldovan journalist, essayist, political analyst and writer. He was an editor at the National Newspaper. He was a professor at the State University of Moldova, Faculty of Journalism and Communication Sciences.

He died on 22 March 2020 of cancer, aged 68.

[[Serena Liu]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from surgical complications, Dancers, Taiwanese movie actors, Taiwanese actors

Serena Liu (born Liu Chen; 劉真; 9 June 1975 – 22 March 2020) also known as Serina Liu, was a Taiwanese dancer and actress. Her best known roles were as Yao Niang in How Much Sorrow Do You Have (2005) and as Pipa Lady in The Rise of the Tang Empire (2006).

Liu died on 22 March 2020 from heart valve repair surgery-related problems in Taipei, aged 44.

[[Carmen de Mairena]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, LGBT actors, LGBT singers, Politicians from Barcelona, LGBT pornographic actors, Prostitutes, Spanish LGBT people, Spanish movie actors, Spanish singers, Spanish television actors, Spanish television personalities, Transgender and transsexual people

Miguel Brau i Gou, better known as Carmen de Mairena (15 March 1933 – 22 March 2020) was a Spanish cuplé singer and popular television personality. She was born in Barcelona. Beginning in the 1990s, she gained national popularity for her comedic television appearances alongside presenter Javier Cárdenas. She was a transgender woman  and worked as a prostitute for a time.

She also made a brief career in politics in 2010 as a candidate for the Parliament of Catalonia for the mock political party Coordinadora Reusenca Independent (CORI) which did not obtain any seats.

De Mairena died on 22 March 2020 of natural causes at a hospital in Barcelona. She was 86.

[[Richard Jewell (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s biographical movies, 2019 drama movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Clint Eastwood, Movies set in the 1990s

Richard Jewell is a 2019 American biographical drama movie directed and produced by Clint Eastwood, and written by Billy Ray. 

It is based on the 1997 Vanity Fair article "American Nightmare: The Ballad of Richard Jewell" by Marie Brenner, and the 2019 book The Suspect: An Olympic Bombing, the FBI, the Media, and Richard Jewell, the Man Caught in the Middle by Kent Alexander and Kevin Salwen. 

The movie is about the July 27 Centennial Olympic Park bombing and its aftermath, as security guard Richard Jewell finds a bomb during the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, Georgia, and tells the police officers to evacuate, only to later be wrongly accused of having placed the device himself. 

The movie stars Paul Walter Hauser as Jewell, alongside Sam Rockwell, Kathy Bates, Jon Hamm, and Olivia Wilde.

[[Bhopal district]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Madhya Pradesh

Bhopal District is a district of the state of Madhya Pradesh in central India. The city of Bhopal is the district headquarters. The district is part of Bhopal Division.

[[The Gambler (song)]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 songs

"The Gambler" is a song written by Don Schlitz, recorded by several artists, most famously by American country music singer Kenny Rogers.

Don Schlitz wrote this song in August 1976 when he was 23 years old. Kenny Rogers who made the song a success. His version was a No. 1 Country hit and made its way to the Pop charts at a time when Country songs rarely crossed over. It won him the Grammy award for best male country vocal performance in 1980.

It was one of five consecutive songs by Rogers to hit No. 1 on the Billboard country music charts. On the pop chart, the song made it No. 16 and No. 3 on the Easy Listening chart. It's become one of Rogers's most known hits and a signature song. 

In 2018, it was selected for preservation in the National Recording Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically, or artistically significant."

[[Paul Walter Hauser]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from Michigan, Comedians from Michigan, People from Saginaw, Michigan

Paul Walter Hauser (born October 15, 1986) is an American actor and comedian. He played supporting roles in the movies I, Tonya and BlacKkKlansman, and in 2019 had his breakout performance as the main character in the movie Richard Jewell. It won him the National Board of Review to award him for best Breakthrough Performance.  

[[Lee Cha-su]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, South Korean politicians, Activists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic

Lee Cha-su (李且壽; also written as Lee Cha-soo, 6 June 1957 – 9 March 2020) was a South Korean politician and social activist who called for the resettlement of the K-2 Air Force Base used at Daegu International Airport. He was the chairman of the Buk-gu Council.

Lee died in Chilgok, Buk District, Daegu at the age of 62 due to coronavirus (COVID-19) on 9 March 2020.

[[Daegu International Airport]]

CATEGORIES: Airports in Asia, Buildings and structures in South Korea, Transport in South Korea, 1937 establishments in Asia, 20th century establishments in South Korea

Daegu International Airport (Hangul: 대구국제공항; Hanja: 大邱國際空港; Revised Romanization: Daegu Gukje Gonghang; McCune-Reischauer: Taegu Kukche Konghang) TAE is an airport in Daegu, South Korea. It is at 35.

[[Nutri Ventures – The Quest for the 7 Kingdoms]]

CATEGORIES: Fantasy television series, American children's television series, Animated television series, Nickelodeon television series, 2012 television series debuts, 2010s American comedy television series, 2020s American comedy television series, English-language television programs, Parodies, Television series set in California, PBS Kids shows, German television series, Mockumentaries, Satirical television series, Fictional European people, Spy television series, Sitcoms, Fictional extraterrestrial characters, Flash animation, Television series set in Portugal, TV shows involved in plagiarism controversies, HBO Max, Parody television shows

Nutri Ventures (also known as Nutri Ventures – The Quest for the 7 Kingdoms) or Nutri Ventures: The Series is an  animated television series aired in originally from 2012 and rest of the English-language episodes in 2012-2021, produced by Nutri Ventures Corporation and Lionsgate Television and Entertainment One Television. As an English-language version of an original Portuguese animated series attempt to cash-in of the upcoming Powerpuff Girls (2016) series taken from a modified was based on a blatant rip-off parody adaptation version from Powerpuff Girls and Indiana Jones using elements as a primary source material made as a parody, done by Bob Boyle and Cam Clarke in 2012. the parody English-dubbed produced in 2012 as a pilot episode and rest of the seasons from 2012 to 2021 were scripted by then-unknown Vivienne Medrano, Chris Savino, Rob Renzetti, Boyle and Clarke themselves. the plot as a between political satire and spy content, about an Theo Angelo or Tam King Man an alien/humanoid being last of the clan and a young spy, along with Lena/Manta, Ben and Nina takes attacked by arch-nemesis named Alex Grand an terrorist boss, businessman and a evil capitalist whose responsible creating Genex-100 conspiracies involved by 'A.L.P.H.A.' stands for (Annilhation-Legion-Pragmatic-Hegemonic-Aliens) to try for destroy the kingdoms and earth.

[[Pam Bondi]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, American lawyers, American lobbyists, Attorneys general, Politicians from Tampa, Florida, US Republican Party politicians

Pamela Jo Bondi (born November 17, 1965) is an American attorney, lobbyist and politician. She is a Republican. She served as the 37th Attorney General of Florida from 2011 to 2019.

Bondi was born in Tampa, Florida. She grew up in nearby Temple Terrace. She has been married twice. Each marriage ended in divorce.

[[Aerial Acres, California]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in California, Settlements in Kern County, California

Aerial Acres is an unincorporated community in Kern County, California. It is at an elevation of 2428.

[[Arvin, California]]

Arvin is a city in Kern County, California. It lies at an elevation of 449.

[[Zeebo Sports]]

CATEGORIES: Video games

Zeebo Sports is a series of video games for the Zeebo system that only came out in Brazil.

The series used to be named Boomerang Sports because the games were designed to only be used with Zeebo's "Boomerang" motion-sensitive controller. However, in August 2010, Zeebo released new versions of the games that can use the Boomerang or the standard Zeebo gamepad. Because of this, the series was renamed to Zeebo Sports.

[[Zeeboids]]

CATEGORIES: Software

Zeeboids is an application that allows avatars to be created. It was developed by Zeebo Interactive Studios in Brazil, and was only released for the Zeebo. Zeeboids works with Zeebo Football Club (F.C.) games such as Zeebo F.C. Foot Camp, allowing players to create custom characters ("avatars") and participate in online rankings.

[[List of Zeebo games]]

This is a list of video games that came out for the Zeebo. All of these were distributed via digital download.

[[Lower Bavaria Government Region]]

Lower Bavaria (Niederbayern, ˈniːdɐbaɪ̯ɐn; Niedabayern, Niadabayern) is one of the seven government regions in Bavaria, Germany.

The Upper Palatinate (Oberpfalz, ˈoːbɐˌp͡falt͡s, Obapfoiz, Owerpfolz) is one of the seven government regions in Bavaria, Germany.

Lower Franconia (Unterfranken, ˈʊntɐfraŋkn̩; Main-Franconian: Unnärfränkä, Unnerfrangn, Unnärfrônkä, Unnerfrangä, Unnäfrangn) is one of the seven government regions in Bavaria, Germany.

[[Liang Wudong]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese scientists, Physicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in China

Liang Wudong (Liáng Wǔdōng; March 1959 – 25 January 2020) was a physician at Xinhua Hospital in Hubei who was the first physician to die of coronavirus pandemic due to nosocomial infections.

[[Zhou Qunfei]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, Chinese businesspeople

Zhou Qunfei (周群飞; born 1970) is a Chinese female entrepreneur who founded Lens Technology the large touchscreen. After her company entered the Shenzhen ChiNext market in March 2015, her net worth reached US$10 billion, making her the richest woman in China. In 2018, she was named as the richest woman in her own world-class business, with a net worth of $9.8 billion.

Jill Talley or Jillian Ann Jill Talley (December 19, 1962) is an American television actress and voice actress.                                                                                                                               

==Works==                                                                                                                                 

[[Francesco Saverio Pavone]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Jurists, People from Apulia, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy

Francesco Saverio Pavone (25 March 1944 – 16 March 2020) was an Italian magistrate. He was the chief of the Procura di Venezia for many years.

[[Germà Colón]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish writers, Philosophers, People from the Community of Valencia

Germà Colón i Doménech (30 November 1928 – 22 March 2020) was a Spanish speaker of Roman philosophy and Catalan lexicology. He was a professor at the University of Basel, Switzerland. He was born in Castellón de la Plana.

Colón died in Barcelona on 22 March 2020, at the age of 91, reportedly due to COVID-19.

[[Attnang-Puchheim]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Upper Austria

Attnang-Puchheim is a town in Vöcklabruck in the state of Upper Austria in Austria. It is between Vöcklabruck and Schwanenstadt. Its partner city is Puchheim in Bavaria, Germany.

[[Richard Tracey]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Conservative MPs (UK), British journalists, British television presenters, Politicians from London, Writers from London, UK MPs 1983–1987, UK MPs 1987–1992, UK MPs 1992–1997

Richard Patrick Tracey JP (8 February 1943 – 19 March 2020) was a British Conservative politician, journalist, presenter, and reporter. He was the MP for Surbiton from 1983 to 1997, and was Minister for Sport between 1985 and 1987. 

From 2008 to 2016, when he retired, he was a Member of the London Assembly, in which he represented Merton and Wandsworth. He was the Deputy Leader of the Conservative group.

Tracey died peacefully at home on 19 March 2020, aged 77.

[[Minions (Despicable Me)]]

CATEGORIES: Despicable Me, Fictional characters introduced in the 2010s

Minions are characters that are yellow and have glasses. They appear in all Despicable Me movies. Some minions have different eyes and sizes. There are some that are small and have 2 eyes, some that are large-sized and also have 2 eyes, and some that are medium-sized that have one eye. They like to eat bananas. They can turn purple and then transform to an evil minion.

They are also the official mascots of Illumination, the movie studio that created the Despicable Me movies.

[[Branko Cikatić]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Croatian sportspeople, Croatian actors, Boxers

Branko Cikatić (4 October 1955 – 22 March 2020) was a Croatian heavyweight kickboxer and actor. He was the first Croatian-born fighter to have  international success. He was the first K-1 World Grand Prix Champion. The tournament was held on April 30, 1993 in Japan. He played a villain in a 1997 B-movie Skyscraper.

In 2018, Cikatić had a pulmonary embolism and later sepsis. He was later diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.

[[Alberto Arbasino]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Italian politicians, Italian essayists

Nino Alberto Arbasino (22 January 1930 – 23 March 2020) was an Italian writer, essayist, and politician. He was a Member of the Chamber of Deputies from 1983 to 1987. Arbasino was a member of the Italian Republican Party. Arbasino was born in Voghera, Lombardy, Italy.

Arbasino died of a long-illness on 23 March 2020 Voghera, Lombardy at the age of 90.

[[Wolfgang Hofmann]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, German Olympic silver medalists

Wolfgang Hofmann (30 March 1941 – 12 March 2020) was a West German judoka. He competed in the 1964 Summer Olympics in Tokyo in 1964, where he won the silver medal in the middleweight class representing the United Team of Germany.

Hofmann died on 12 March 2020 about two weeks shy of his 79th birthday.

[[Jürg Zeltner]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Swiss people, Bankers

Jürg Zeltner (4 May 1967 – 22 March 2020) was a Swiss corporate executive. He was Group CEO and member of the Board of Directors at KBL European Private Bankers. 

He was earlier the President of UBS Wealth Management from November 2014 to December 2017. He stepped down from the Group Executive Board at the end of 2017, and retired from the firm as of 2018. He had served as a member of the UBS Group Executive Board since February 2009. 

From February 2009 to January 2012 he was co-CEO of Wealth Management and Swiss Bank. In February 2016, Zeltner ranked first among the best global private banking CEOs, according to a 2016 Euromoney private banking survey.

In 2019, he was diagnosed with brain cancer. He died on 22 March 2020.

[[Harkishan Singh]]

CATEGORIES: Indian scientists, Chemists, 2020 deaths, 1928 births

Professor Harkishan Singh (25 November 1928 – 20 March 2020) was an Indian chemist. He was a Professor Emeritus at the Panjab University. He was a well known pharmaceutical academic, medicinal chemistry researcher and science historian. He had worked at the Banaras Hindu University, University of Saugar, and the Panjab University in India, and abroad at the University of Maryland, University of Mississippi and the University of London.

[[Julie Felix]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, British singers, American folk singers, American folk musicians, American guitarists, Musicians from California, Singers from California, People from Santa Barbara, California

Julie Ann Felix (14 June 1938 – 22 March 2020) was an American-born, British-based folk singer and guitarist. She became successful in the late 1960s and early 1970s. 

She later performed and released albums on her own record label. In 1966, Felix became the resident singer on the BBC television programme The Frost Report, presented  by David Frost. She hosted her own shows for the BBC from 1967 to 1970, including the series Once More With Felix (the first episode was transmitted on 9 December 1967).

Felix lived in Chorleywood, Hertfordshire, England, until her death, still recording and performing, appearing on stage on her 80th birthday in 2018.

[[Robert H. Scarborough]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, American military people, People from Georgia (U.S. state)

Robert Henry Scarborough, Jr. (March 12, 1923 – March 20, 2020) was an American military personnel. He was Vice Admiral in the United States Coast Guard who was the 13th Vice Commandant from 1978 to 1982. Scarborough was born in Hawkinsville, Georgia.

Scarborough died on March 20, 2020 in Arlington, Virginia at the age of 97.

[[Lili Elbe]]

CATEGORIES: 1882 births, 1931 deaths, Danish painters, Transgender and transsexual people, Deaths from surgical complications, Deaths from cardiac arrest

Lili Ilse Elvenes (28 December 1882 – 13 September 1931), better known as Lili Elbe, was a Danish painter and transgender woman. She was among the early recipients of sex reassignment surgery.

Elbe died of cardiac arrest caused by a uterus transplant surgery at the age of 48.

[[Congress of Deputies]]

CATEGORIES: Spain

The Congress of Deputies (Congreso de los Diputados; Diputatuen Kongresua; Congrés dels Diputats; Congreso dos Deputados) is the lower house of the Cortes Generales, Spain's legislative branch. The Congress meets in the Palace of the Parliament (Palacio de las Cortes) in Madrid.

[[Say So]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 songs, Disco songs, R&B songs, Doja Cat songs, Nicki Minaj songs

"Say So" is a song recorded by American rapper and singer Doja Cat. It was sent to pop radio on January 28, 2020, as a single from her album, Hot Pink. The song became viral when it was used on the social media app TikTok. It was written by Doja Cat and Lydia Asrat, along with its producers, Dr. Luke and Yeti Beats.

So far, it reached the top ten in the US, UK, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada.

On May 1, 2020, a remix of the song with Trinidadian-born American rapper Nicki Minaj was released, containing hip hop beats.  Another Minaj remix was released May 8 (called the "original version"), which keeps the disco beat of the song.

On May 11, 2020, Billboard announced that “Say So” had topped the Hot 100.  It became both Doja’s and Minaj’s first number-one single in the US. The solo version of the song reached the top of the Mainstream Top 40/Pop Songs airplay chart.

[[José Folgado]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish politicians, Mayors, Spanish businesspeople

José Folgado Blanco (1944 – 23 March 2020) was a Spanish businessman and politician. He was a member of the People's Party. Folgado was born Morales de Rey, Spain. Folgado was President of Red Eléctrica de España from 2012 to 2018. He was a Deputy in 2000 and again from 2004 to 2008. From 2007 to 2012, he was Mayor of Tres Cantos.

Folgado died on 23 March 2020 of COVID-19 in Tres Cantos at the age of 75.

[[Stephen Schwartz (pathologist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American educators, Researchers, Scientists from Washington

Stephen M. Schwartz (January 1, 1942 – March 17, 2020) was an American pathologist. He worked at the University of Washington. He researched vascular biology, investigating the structure of blood vessels and smooth muscle cells. Schwartz was an assistant professor of pathology from 1974 to 1979, an associate professor from 1979 to 1984, and then a full professor from 1984 until his death.

Schwartz died of COVID-19 on March 17, 2020, aged 78.

[[The Danish Girl (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2015 romance movies, 2015 drama movies, 2010s romantic drama movies, 2010s biographical movies, British romantic drama movies, British biographical movies, Danish movies, Belgian movies, Japanese movies, German romance movies, German drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Tom Hooper

The Danish Girl is a 2015 biographical romantic drama movie directed by Tom Hooper. It is based on the 2000 novel of the same name by David Ebershoff. It is inspired by the lives of Danish painters Lili Elbe and Gerda Wegener.

[[Democrats Abroad]]

CATEGORIES: United States Democratic Party

Democrats Abroad is the official organization of the Democratic Party for United States citizens living permanently or temporarily abroad. The organization is given state-level recognition by the Democratic National Committee.

Democrats Abroad currently has members in more than 190 countries, with more than 41 organized country committees. There are committees in Europe, Asia, Africa, the Americas, and Oceania.

[[Gabi Delgado-López]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Bisexual people, German composers, German LGBT people, German singers, German writers, LGBT composers, LGBT producers, LGBT singers, LGBT writers, Record producers, Singer-songwriters, Spanish composers, Spanish LGBT people, Spanish singers, Spanish writers

Gabriel "Gabi" Delgado-López (18 April 1958 – 22 March 2020), commonly known as Gabi Delgado, was a Spanish-born German singer-songwriter, composer, lyricist and producer. He was best known as singer and co-founder, with Robert Görl, of the electronic band Deutsch Amerikanische Freundschaft. He was born in Córdoba, Andalusia, Spain.

Delgado-López was bisexual. He died on 22 March 2020 at the age of 61.

[[Dubrovnik-Neretva County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia, Exclaves

Dubrovnik-Neretva County is the southernmost Croatian county. The county seat is Dubrovnik. 

The northern part of the Mljet island is a national park. The Lastovo archipelago has a nature park.

[[Istria County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Istria County is the westernmost county of Croatia. It includes the largest part of the Istrian peninsula.

The national park Brijuni and nature park Učka are in the county.

[[Hyperossification]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Biology

Hyperossification is when there is much more bone material on a bone than usual.  Hyperossification is found in frogs.  Many frogs have smooth skulls, but some frogs have skulls that only look smooth from the outside.  Under their skins, their skulls have spikes, ridges, flanges, or unusual neck joints.

Even frogs that did not come from the same ancestor evolved big, spiky skulls if they ate the same other animals: usually animals almost as big as they were, like birds and mice.  Scientists say this is because big, strong skulls let the frogs have big mouths and strong jaws that are good for catching big prey.

Other frogs have spikes inside their skin to protect from predators.  When a bigger animal bumps into the frog's head, the spikes break open sacs full of venom under the frog's skin, and this protects the frog from being eaten.

[[Karlovac County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Karlovac County is a county in central Croatia. Its county seat is Karlovac.

Bjelolasica mountain is in the county. It has the largest winter sport recreation center in the country.

[[Koprivnica-Križevci County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Koprivnica-Križevci County is a county in northern Croatia. Its county seat is Koprivnica.

[[Krapina-Zagorje County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Krapina-Zagorje County is a county in northern Croatia. The county seat is Krapina.

The county borders Slovenia. It encompasses most of the historic region called Hrvatsko Zagorje. 

[[Međimurje County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Međimurje County is a county in the northernmost part of Croatia. The county seat is Čakovec. Other cities are Prelog and Mursko Središće.

Međimurje County covers the plains between two rivers – the Mura and the Drava. There are two reservoir lakes on the Drava – Lake Varaždin and Lake Dubrava. Lake Dubrava is the biggest artificial lake in Croatia and the second largest lake overall in the country.

[[Osijek-Baranja County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Osijek-Baranja County is a county in Croatia. The county seat is Osijek.

==Administrative divisions== 

[[Požega-Slavonia County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Požega-Slavonia County is a county in Croatia. The county seat is Požega.

[[Sisak-Moslavina County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Sisak-Moslavina County is a county in Croatia. The county seat is Sisak.

The natural park Lonjsko polje is in the Moslavina part of the county. It is near the rivers Lonja, Ilova and Pakra.

[[Primorje-Gorski Kotar County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Primorje-Gorski Kotar County is a county in western Croatia. The county seat is Rijeka. 

The county includes the Bay of Kvarner, the surrounding Northern Croatian Littoral, and the mountainous region of Gorski kotar. It also has the islands Krk, Cres, Lošinj and Rab. 

[[Split-Dalmatia County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Split-Dalmatia County is a county in Croatia. The county seat is Split.

[[Varaždin County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Varaždin County is a county in northern Croatia. The county seat is Varaždin.

The Drava river is along the northern border of the county. There are three reservoirs on the river – Lake Ormož, Lake Varaždin and Lake Dubrava. There are also the mountains of Ivanščica (also known as Ivančica) and Kalnik.

[[Virovitica-Podravina County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Virovitica-Podravina County is a county in Croatia. The county seat is Virovitica. Other notable towns are Slatina and Orahovica.

[[Vukovar-Srijem County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Vukovar-Srijem County is the easternmost Croatian county. The county seat is Vukovar. The biggest town is Vinkovci. Other towns are Ilok, Otok and Županja. 

[[Zadar County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Zadar County is a county in Croatia. The county seat is Zadar.

The Velebit, Telaščica and Paklenica national parks are in the south of the county.

[[Zagreb County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Croatia

Zagreb County is a county in central Croatia. It surrounds – but does not contain – the nation's capital Zagreb.

[[Artemisa Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Cuba, Establishments in Cuba, 2011 establishments in North America

Artemisa Province is a province of Cuba. The capital is Artemisa. It was made in 2011 from the former La Habana Province.

[[Mayabeque Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Cuba

Mayabeque Province is a province of Cuba. The capital is San José de las Lajas. The province was made in 2011 from the former La Habana Province.

[[Ahmose (queen)]]

CATEGORIES: 16th century BC births, 15th century BC deaths, Ancient Egyptian queens

Ahmose was an Ancient Egyptian queen in the Eighteenth Dynasty. She was the Great Royal Wife of the dynasty's third pharaoh, Thutmose I, and the mother of the queen and pharaoh Hatshepsut. Her name means "Born of the Moon".

[[Engine knocking]]

CATEGORIES: Motors, Engineering

Engine knocking is the sound produced in an internal combustion engine when the fuel does not ignite properly. The mixture of petrol and air is meant to be ignited only by the spark plug at the right moment in the stroke of the piston in the engine. If there is a problem with the engine, this fuel and air mixture can be ignited at the wrong time by pressure and heat. The explosion of the mixture makes a destructive knocking sound. This uncontrolled explosion can damage the engine and may even destroy it.

[[Benito Joanet]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish association football goalkeepers, Spanish football managers, Sportspeople from Catalonia, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain

Benito Joanet Giménez (16 September 1935 – 22 March 2020) was a Spanish football player and manager.

[[Luciano Federici]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy, Italian footballers, Sportspeople from Tuscany

Luciano Federici (16 May 1938 – 18 March 2020) was an Italian professional footballer. He played as a defender. 

Federici was born in Carrara, Tuscany. He played for for Carrarese, Cosenza and Pisa during the 1950s and 1960s. On 18 March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Federici died of COVID-19 in Carrara. He was 81.

[[Carlo Casini]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from motor neurone disease, Disease-related deaths in Italy, Former MEPs, MEPs for Italy, People from Florence, Politicians from Tuscany

Carlo Casini (4 March 1935 – 23 March 2020) was an Italian politician. He was a member of the European Parliament (MEP) from 1984 to 1999 and again from 2006 to 2014. He was also a member of Italy's Chamber of Deputies from 1979 to 1994. He was born in Florence.

On 23 March 2020, Casini died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in Rome. He was 85.

[[Innocenzo Donina]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Italian footballers, Association football midfielders, Sportspeople from Lombardy, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy

Innocenzo Donina (16 July 1950 – 19 March 2020) was a professional Italian football player.

[[Jamie Bell]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, Actors from County Durham, BAFTA Award winning actors, English child actors, English dancers, English movie actors, English television actors, English voice actors

Andrew James Matfin Bell (born 14 March 1986) is an English actor and dancer. He first became known for his role in Billy Elliot (2000). He won the BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role for this role. He is also known for his roles in the movies King Kong (2005), Jumper (2008), The Adventures of Tintin (2011), Snowpiercer (2013), Fantastic Four (2015) and Rocketman (2019). He starred as Abraham Woodhull in the TV series Turn: Washington's Spies (2014).

Bell was born in Billingham, County Durham. He has one child through his marriage to actress Evan Rachel Wood from 2012 to 2014. Bell married actress Kate Mara in 2017. The couple have one child.

[[Sergio Bassi]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Italian singers, Italian writers, Singer-songwriters, Folk musicians, Rock musicians, People from Lombardy, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy

Sergio Bassi (23 June 1951 – 16 March 2020) is an Italian singer-songwriter.

Sergio was raised by his grandparents in a small hamlet in Codogno, Lombardy. After growing up, he moved to Legnano, then to Piacenza, and lived in San Francesco al Campo for seven years. Then, he returned to his hometown.

During the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy, he had SARS-CoV-2. Later, on March 16, he died of an infection in Crema. 

[[Kuyachinsky Village Council]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Russia

The Kuyachinsky Village Council is a municipality in Altaysky District, Altai Krai, Russia. It has the status of a rural settlement and an administrative-territorial entity. The administrative center is the village of Kuyacha.

[[Kabanovsky Village Council]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Russia

Kabanovsky Village Council is a municipality in the Ust-Kalmansky District of the Altai Krai in Russia. It has the status of a rural settlement and an administrative-territorial entity. The administrative center is the village of Kabanovo. 

[[Rodinsky District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts, Russia, 1924 establishments

Rodinsky District is an administrative and municipal district in the Altai Krai of Russia. Its administrative center is Rodino.

[[West Siberian Railway]]

CATEGORIES: Novosibirsk, Transport in Asia

West Siberian Railway - one of the 16 branches of the OJSC " Russian Railways ".  It is part of the Trans-Siberian Railway .

[[Goliathon (1977 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 horror movies, Giant gorilla movies, 1970s adventure movies, Hong Kong movies, Mockbuster movies, Monster movies, Movies set in Asia, Buena Vista International movies, Lionsgate movies, Movies about primates

The Mighty Peking Man or Goliathon is a 1977 Hong Kong adventure monster movie produced by Shaw Brothers Studio to capitalize on the attempted surrounding the King Kong (1976). The film was originally released in the US in March 19, 1980 as Goliathon dubbed by Les Filmes Jacques Willemetz-Paris. as the critics entry for Infra-Man. as a mockbuster of King Kong probably made by Hong Kong cinema and Japanese special effects.

[[Alison Pill]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people, Actors from Toronto, Canadian child actors, Canadian movie actors, Canadian stage actors, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors

Alison Pill (born November 27, 1985) is a Canadian actress. She started her career at the age of twelve. In 2006, she was nominated for a Tony Award for Best Featured Actress in a Play for her performance in The Lieutenant of Inishmore (2006). Her movies credits include Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004), Plain Truth (2004), Milk (2008), Scott Pilgrim vs. the World (2010), Midnight in Paris (2011), Zoom (2015) and Vice (2018). Her TV roles include the series The Book of Daniel (2006), In Treatment (2009), The Pillars of the Earth (2010), The Newsroom (2012–14),  American Horror Story (2017) and Star Trek: Picard (2020).

Pill was born in Toronto, Ontario. Her father is Estonian. She married actor Joshua Leonard in 2015. The couple have one child.

Famagusta District is one of the six districts of Cyprus. Its main town is the island's most important port, Famagusta.

Most of the district has been under Turkish control since the Turkish invasion of Cyprus.

Famagusta District has 8 municipalities and 90 communities. The municipalities are:

[[Krystal (restaurant)]]

CATEGORIES: American fast food restaurants, 1932 establishments in the United States

Krystal is an American fast food restaurant chain headquartered in Dunwoody, Georgia. It is known for its small, square hamburger sliders. It was founded in 1932.

[[Kyrenia District]]

CATEGORIES: Republic of Cyprus, Northern Cyprus

Kyrenia District is one of the six districts of Cyprus. Its main town is Kyrenia.

It is the only district completely controlled by the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. There are three municipalities and 44 communities. The municipalities are: Karavas, Kyrenia, and Lapithos.

[[Jack Jones (Australian rules footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Australian rules footballers, Cancer deaths in Australia, Sportspeople from Melbourne

Jack Jones (7 November 1924 – 23 March 2020) was an Australian rules footballer. He played in the Victorian Football League (VFL) for the Essendon Football Club between 1946 and 1954. He was born in Ascot Vale, Melbourne, Victoria.

Jones died of cancer on 23 March 2020, at the age of 95.

[[Chromatica]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 albums, Lady Gaga albums

Chromatica is the sixth studio album by American recording artist Lady Gaga. It was originally set for release on April 10, 2020, but was postponed by Gaga for later that year. This is due to the worldwide coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. Gaga later revealed that the album would be released on May 29, 2020.

[[Proprioceptive writing]]

CATEGORIES: Literary terms

Proprioceptive writing is a method for exploring the psyche through writing developed since 1976 by Linda Trichter Metcalf and Tobin Simon. It is practiced to music in 25-minute sessions, alone or in groups, under conditions that are designed to promote relaxation and reflection. Through a process the method’s creators call “inner hearing”  students learn to listen to their thoughts with empathy and curiosity and reflect on them in writing.

Proprioceptive Writing is widely recognized as an adjunct to the healing arts and as a form of meditation and is also used by people who wish to write and writers facing impediments to their work.

[[University of Chittagong]]

University of Chittagong is a public research university in Fatehpur Union of Hathazari Upazila, 22 kilometres north of Chittagong, Bangladesh. The campus is on a 2110-acre hilly area. It is the largest campus in Bangladesh.

[[Ethiopian Semitic languages]]

CATEGORIES: Semitic languages

Ethiopian Semitic (also called Ethio-Semitic, Ethiosemitic, Ethiopic or Abyssinian) is a family of languages. These languages are spoken in Ethiopia, Eritrea and Sudan. They are a part of the South Semitic languages.

Amharic is the most used Ethiopian Semitic language. It is the official working language of Ethiopia and has about 62 million speakers (including second language speakers). Tigrinya has 7 million speakers and is the most spoken language in Eritrea. The Ge'ez language is a religious language that is used in the Ethiopian and Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo Churches. There is writing in this language that is as old as the first century AD. It is no longer spoken in daily life.

The modern Ethiopian Semitic languages all have the subject–object–verb (SOV) word order. Ge'ez had the verb-subject-object (VSO) order.

[[Hand-to-hand combat]]

Hand-to-hand combat (sometimes abbreviated as HTH or H2H) is a physical confrontation between two or more persons at very short range (grappling distance, or in the physical reach of a handheld weapon) that does not include the use of ranged weapons. While "hand-to-hand" appears to be to unarmed combat, the term is generic and may include use of melee weapons such as knives, sticks, batons, spears, or improvised weapons such as entrenching tools.
