Limassol District is one of the six districts of Cyprus. The capital city is Limassol.

Limassol District has 6 municipalities and 106 communities. The municipalities are:

[[Paphos District]]

CATEGORIES: Republic of Cyprus

Paphos District is one of the six districts of Cyprus. The capital city is Paphos.

There are four municipalities in Paphos District: Paphos, Yeroskipou, Peyia, and Polis Chrysochous.

[[Maiko]]

CATEGORIES: Entertainment in Japan, Japanese culture

A Maiko is a beginner Geisha. They are usually around 15 to 20 years old. The training to become a Maiko is usually around 10 months long.

[[Limassol]]

CATEGORIES: Republic of Cyprus

Limassol is a city on the southern coast of Cyprus. It is the capital city of Limassol District. In 2011, about 184,000 people lived in the urban area.

Limassol Castle is one of the ten castles of Cyprus. It was built by the Byzantines around 1000 AD.

[[Larnaca]]

CATEGORIES: Republic of Cyprus

Larnaca is a city on the southern coast of Cyprus. It is the capital of the Larnaca District.

Larnaca is home to the country's primary airport, Larnaca International Airport. It also has a seaport and a marina.

[[South Bohemian Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic, 2001 establishments in Europe, Bohemia

South Bohemia is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is České Budějovice.

The Bohemian Forest is in the south-west. The region is located in the drainage basin of Vltava river. Other significant rivers are Malše, Lužnice, Otava, Nežárka and Lomnice. South Bohemia is famous for its countless ponds. Rožmberk Pond is the largest one. Much of Šumava National Park is also in the region.

The region is divided into 7 districts:

[[Plzeň Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic, 2001 establishments in Europe, Bohemia

Plzeň Region is a region in the Czech Republic. The capital city is Plzeň.

The southern part of the region has the drainage basin for the Otava River. The northern part, especially around Plzeň, is more industrial.

[[Bandung]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Indonesia, Java, West Java

Bandung is the capital city of West Java, Indonesia and one of the largest city in Indonesia. In 2015, Bandung is also the fourth most populous city in Indonesia after Jakarta, Surabaya, and Bekasi with 2,5 million inhabitants. Bandung is found 140 km from Jakarta. Bandung known by some historical events, such as Bandung Conference (Asia-Africa Conference), a big meeting by a lot of country that voiced anti-colonialism spirit. Bandung is known by its nickname "Kota Kembang" (City of Flowers), because there's so many beautiful trees and flowers that grow there. Beside that, Bandung is also known by Parijs van Java ("The Paris of Java") name because its scenery beauty.

[[Lucien Braun]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, French historians, French philosophers

Lucien Braun (24 February 1923 – 13 March 2020) was a French philosophy historian. His works focused in Paracelsus. Braun wrote his version of Histoire de l'histoire de la philosophie.

He was President of the Presses universitaires de Strasbourg and the Université populaire européenne, also in Strasbourg. He was a professor emeritus of Marc Bloch University, of which he was President from 1978 to 1983.

Braun was a Commander of the Ordre des Palmes académiques.

[[Mariano Puga]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lymphoma, Human rights activists, People from Santiago, Roman Catholic priests

Mariano Puga Concha  (25 April 1931 – 14 March 2020) was a Chilean Roman Catholic priest and a human rights activist. He was born in Santiago de Chile. 

He was pastor of the university parish of La Legua. He was a defender of Human Rights during the military dictatorship of that country. In June 1974 Puga was arrested while preaching and taken to infamous prisons of Villa Grimaldi and Tres Álamos.

Puga died of lymphoma in Santiago on 14 March 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Sol Kerzner]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, South African businesspeople, People from Johannesburg

Solomon (Sol) Kerzner, K.C.M.G. (23 August 1935 – 21 March 2020) was a South African accountant and business magnate.  He founded both of South Africa's largest hotel groups, the Southern Sun Hotel Group and Sun International. He was also the Founder, Chairman, and CEO of Kerzner International. His career spanned more than 45 years in the resort industry.

Kerzner died on 21 March 2020, aged 84.

[[Mariko Miyagi]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1927 births, Deaths from lymphoma, Japanese movie actors, Japanese television actors, Japanese singers, Activists, Actors from Tokyo

Mariko Miyagi (宮城 まり子) (March 21, 1927 – March 21, 2020) was a Japanese actress, singer, and activist. She was born in Tokyo. She was known for her roles in  Panda and the magic serpent (1958), Ten dark women (1961) and in Barefoot Gen (1977).

In 2012 Miyagi was awarded the Order of the Sacred Treasure.

Miyagi died of lymphoma on March 21, 2020 in Tokyo on her 93rd birthday.

[[Ciprian Foias]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Mathematicians, Researchers, Romanian people

Ciprian Ilie Foiaș (20 July 1933 – 22 March 2020) was a Romanian mathematician. He was awarded the Norbert Wiener Prize in Applied Mathematics in 1995. He was known for his works in operator theory. Foias was born in Reșița, Caraș County, Kingdom of Romania. The Foias constant is named after him. Foias is listed as an ISI highly cited researcher.

He died in Tempe, Arizona on March 22, 2020.

[[James Martin Munley]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, American lawyers, Politicians from Pennsylvania, People from Scranton, Pennsylvania, US Democratic Party politicians

James Martin Munley (June 28, 1936 – March 22, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was born in Scranton, Pennsylvania. He was a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania from 1998 to 2009 after being nominated by President Bill Clinton.

Munley died on March 22, 2020, aged 83.

[[Daniel Edward Pilarczyk]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Archbishops, American Roman Catholics, People from Dayton, Ohio, People from Cincinnati, Ohio

Daniel Edward Pilarczyk (August 12, 1934 – March 22, 2020) was an American prelate of the Roman Catholic Church. He was Archbishop of Cincinnati, Ohio from 1982 to 2009. Pilarczyk was born in Dayton, Ohio. From 1989 to 1992, he was President of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops.

Pilarczyk died on March 22, 2020 in Cincinnati at the age of 85.

[[Maurice Berger]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American historians, American columnists, American art critics, LGBT writers, Gay men, LGBT people from New York City, American essayists, Writers from New York City

Maurice Berger (May 22, 1956 – March 23, 2020) was an American cultural historian, curator, and art critic. He was born in New York City. Berger was research professor and chief curator at the Center for Art, Design and Visual Culture, University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Berger wrote the monthly Race Stories column for the Lens Section of the New York Times.

Berger died on March 23, 2020, from heart failure caused by COVID-19 in Copake, New York at the age of 63.

[[Copake, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Copake is a town in Columbia County, New York, United States. The population was 3,615 at the 2010 census. 

[[Hudson, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New York, County seats in New York

Hudson is a city located along the west border of Columbia County, New York, United States. As of the 2010 census it had a population of 6,713. It is the second-largest in the county.

Hudson is the county seat of Columbia County.

[[Tres Cantos]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in the Community of Madrid, Municipalities in the Community of Madrid

Tres Cantos is a Spanish city in the province and Community of Madrid, located 22 km to the north of the capital. It was created by urban planners in the 1970s, making it the youngest incorporated municipality in the Community of Madrid. It has a population of 46,046 people.

[[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops]]

CATEGORIES: American Roman Catholics

The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB) is the episcopal conference of the Catholic Church in the United States.  It was founded in 1966 as the joint National Conference of Catholic Bishops (NCCB) and United States Catholic Conference (USCC). 

It is made up of all active and retired members of the Catholic hierarchy (i.e., diocesan, coadjutor, and auxiliary bishops and the ordinary of the Personal Ordinariate of the Chair of Saint Peter) in the United States and the Territory of the U.S. Virgin Islands. 

2019, the president is Los Angeles's archbishop, Archbishop José Horacio Gómez.

[[Anthony Pilla]]

CATEGORIES: People from Cleveland, Ohio, American Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops, 1932 births, 2021 deaths

Anthony Michael Pilla (November 12, 1932 – September 21, 2021) was an American bishop. He was a bishop of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.  He was auxiliary bishop of the Diocese of Cleveland from 1979 to 1980 and Bishop of Cleveland from 1980 to 2006. He was born in Cleveland, Ohio.

From 1995 to 1998, he was President of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops. He died on September 21, 2021 at the age of 88.

[[Joseph Fiorenza]]

CATEGORIES: People from Beaumont, Texas, People from San Angelo, Texas, American Roman Catholics, Archbishops, 1931 births, Living people

Joseph Anthony Fiorenza (born January 25, 1931) is an American prelate of the Catholic Church. He was the seventh Bishop and the first Archbishop of Galveston-Houston from 1985 to 2006. He was Bishop of San Angelo from 1979 to 1984.

He was born in Beaumont, Texas. 

[[William S. Skylstad]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, American Roman Catholics, Bishops, People from Spokane, Washington

William Stephen Skylstad (born March 2, 1934) is an American Roman Catholic Bishop. He is Bishop Emeritus of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Spokane in Washington retiring June 30, 2010. He is a former President of the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB). Skylstad was appointed Apostolic Administrator of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Baker, in Oregon on January 24, 2011. Skylstad was born in Methow, Washington.

[[Wait Until Tomorrow]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 songs

"Wait Until Tomorrow" is a song by the Jimi Hendrix Experience from their album Axis: Bold as Love. The song was written by Jimi Hendrix. The song is about a male protagonist trying to get with a girl, only to be shot dead by her father. The song was never released as a single.

[[Methow, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Washington (state)

Methow (ˈ MET), is an unincorporated community in Okanogan County, Washington, United States.  The community had a population of 262 at the 2000 census.

[[David Collings]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, People from Brighton, English movie actors, English stage actors, English radio actors, English television actors, English voice actors

David Collings (4 June 1940 – 23 March 2020) was an English actor. He was known for his roles in Doctor Who, Sapphire & Steel and Blake's 7, as well as voicing the main character in the series Monkey and Legolas in the classic BBC Radio 4 adaptation of Tolkien's The Lord of the Rings.

[[Lorenzo Acquarone]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy, Italian politicians

Lorenzo Acquarone (25 February 1931 – 24 March 2020) was an Italian lawyer and politician. He was born in Ventimiglia. Between 1987 and 2006, he served as a member of the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies.

On 24 March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Acquarone died in Genoa due to COVID-19. He was 89.

[[Terrence McNally]]

CATEGORIES: Tony Award winners, 1938 births, 2020 deaths, American playwrights, American screenwriters, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Gay men, Infectious disease deaths in Florida, LGBT people from Florida, LGBT playwrights, LGBT screenwriters, People from St. Petersburg, Florida, Writers from Florida

Terrence McNally (November 3, 1938 – March 24, 2020) was an American playwright, librettist and screenwriter. He was award the Tony Award for Best Play for Love! Valour! Compassion! and Master Class. He also won the Tony Award for Best Book of a Musical for Kiss of the Spider Woman and Ragtime. His other awards included an Emmy Award, two Guggenheim Fellowships, a Rockefeller Grant, four Drama Desk Awards, two Lucille Lortel Awards, two Obie Awards and three Hull-Warriner Awards.

McNally was born in St. Petersburg, Florida. He was openly gay. He married theater producer Tom Kirdahy in 2003.

On March 24, 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, McNally died in Sarasota, Florida due to COVID-19. He was 81.

[[Bill Rieflin]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, American keyboard players, American rock drummers, American rock singers, Cancer deaths in the United States, Musicians from Seattle, Washington

William Frederick Rieflin (September 29, 1960 – March 24, 2020) was an American musician. He first became well-known in the 1990s for his work mainly as a drummer with groups such as Ministry, the Revolting Cocks, Lard, KMFDM, Pigface, Swans and Nine Inch Nails. He worked often with R.E.M. following the retirement of Bill Berry in 1997. He was also a member of King Crimson until his death in 2020. He was born in Seattle, Washington.

On March 24, 2020, Rieflin died of cancer at the age of 59.

[[Tristan Garel-Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Former Conservative MPs (UK), Privy Councillors (UK), UK MPs 1979–1983, UK MPs 1983–1987, UK MPs 1987–1992, UK MPs 1992–1997, Welsh politicians

William Armand Thomas Tristan Garel-Jones, Baron Garel-Jones PC (28 February 1941 – 23 March 2020) was a British politician. He was a member of the Conservative Party. He served as the Member of Parliament (MP) for Watford from 1979 to 1997. He was made a life peer in 1997. He also held office as Vice-Chamberlain of the Household (1986–1988), Comptroller of the Household (1988–1989), Treasurer of the Household (1989–1990) and Minister for Europe (1990–1993).

Garel-Jones was born in Gorseinon, Wales. In 1966, he married Catalina Garrigues Carnicer. The couple had five children. He died on 23 March 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Juan Padrón]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Animators, Cuban writers, Deaths from lung disease, Movie directors, Screenwriters

Juan Manuel Padrón Blanco (29 January 1947 – 24 March 2020) was a Cuban animation director and comics artist. He is best as the creator of the comic strip Elpidio Valdés. He also directed and wrote the animated movie Vampires in Havana (1985). Padrón directed six animated feature movies. He was born in Matanzas.

On 24 March 2020, Padrón died due to lung disease in Havana. He was 73.

[[Jimi Hendrix Experience]]

The Jimi Hendrix Experience was an American-English rock band that formed in London, England, in 1966. The band comprised of singer, songwriter, and guitarist Jimi Hendrix, drummer Mitch Mitchell, and bassist Noel Redding. 

They were highly influential in popularizing hard and psychedelic rock. All of the band's albums, Are You Experienced (1967) , Axis: Bold as Love (1967) , and Electric Ladyland (1968), were featured in the top 100 of Rolling Stone's list of The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time. 

[[Stanley Sporkin]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, US Republican Party politicians

Stanley Sporkin (February 7, 1932spaced ndashMarch 23, 2020) was an America politician and lawyer. He was director of enforcement for the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). He was a judge of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia from 1985 to 1999. He was nominated by President Ronald Reagan. Sporkin was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Sporkin died on March 23, 2020 in Rockyville, Maryland of congestive heart failure at the age of 88.

[[Pyotr Lysenko]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Archaeologists, Belarusian people

Pyotr Fyodorovich Lysenko (Пё́тар Фё́даравіч Лысе́нка, Пё́тр Фё́дорович Лысе́нко; 16 September 1931 – 23 March 2020) was a Belarusian archaeologist. He was the author of over 110 scientific works, including many monographs. He is also known for opening the Berestye Archeological Museum in Brest.

Lysenko died on 23 March 2020 in Minsk. He was 88.

[[Stuart Gordon]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from multiple organ failure, Deaths from kidney disease, American playwrights, Movie directors from Chicago, Movie producers from Chicago, Screenwriters from Chicago

Stuart Gordon (August 11, 1947 – March 24, 2020) was an American filmmaker, theater director and playwright. He first became known for his controversial work in experimental theater. He later became known for his horror movies. In 1969, he founded the Organic Theater Company with his wife Carolyn Purdy. His movies include Re-Animator (1985), From Beyond (1986), Honey, I Shrunk the Kids (1989), Robot Jox (1990), Fortress (1992), The Wonderful Ice Cream Suit (1998) and Dagon (2001).

Gordon was born in Chicago, Illinois. He had three daughters. Gordon died on March 24, 2020 in Van Nuys, California, at the age of 72. The cause of death was multiple organ failure caused by kidney disease.

[[Tony Rutter]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, British sportspeople, Motorcycle racers

Tony Rutter (24 September 1941 – 24 March 2020) was a British professional motorcycle road racer. He was a street circuit specialist. He competed in the Grand Prix motorcycle world championships from 1969 to 1976. He won seven Isle of Man TT races between 1973 and 1985. Rutter was the TT Formula Two World Champion each year from 1981 to 1984. His son, Michael Rutter, also became a motorcycle racer.

Rutter died on 24 March 2020 at the age of 76.

[[Stanford, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois

Stanford is a village in McLean County, Illinois, United States. The population was 596 at the 2010 census.

[[Vusamazulu Credo Mutwa]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, South African writers

Vusamazulu Credo Mutwa (21 July 1921 – 25 March 2020) was a South African Zulu sangoma (traditional healer). He is known for writing books about African mythology, traditional Zulu folklore and extraterrestrial encounters. His works include Indaba my Children and Tree of Life Trilogy. He was born in the Colony of Natal (present day KwaZulu-Natal).

Mutwa believed in using traditional African medicines for the treatment of HIV/AIDS, cancer and tuberculosis. He also agreed with David Icke's "reptilian" theory.

Mutwa died on 25 March 2020 at the age of 98.

[[Nemai Ghosh (photographer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from surgical complications, Indian artists, Photographers, People from Kolkata

Nemai Ghosh (8 May 1934 – 25 March 2020) was an Indian photographer. He was most known for working with Satyajit Ray, as a still photographer for over twenty years. His best works include Goopy Gyne Bagha Byne (1969) and Agantuk (1991). He was awarded the Padma Shri by Government of India in 2010.

Ghosh died on 25 March 2020 at a hospital in Kolkata from surgery-related problems, at the age of 85.

[[Jon Atle Gaarder]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Ambassadors of Norway

Jon Atle Gaarder (27 November 1934 – 14 March 2020) was a Norwegian diplomat. He was a counsellor for the Norwegian delegation to NATO from 1975 to 1979.

In 1984, Gaarder was named ambassador to Saudi Arabia, as well as representing Norway in the United Arab Emirates, Yemen and Oman. From 1990 to 1994, he was ambassador to India. During this time, he also represented Norway in Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal and the Maldives. In 1996, he became the ambassador to the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. He was also Norway's representative in Bulgaria, Republic of Macedonia and Albania. He also served as the ambassador to Lithuania from 1999 to 2001.

Gaarder was born in Årnes, Hedmark and grew up in Skarnes. He died on 14 March 2020 at the age of 85.

[[Kåre Dæhlen]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, Ambassadors of Norway

Kåre Dæhlen (born 23 October 1926) is a Norwegian diplomat. He started working for the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1955. He served as the Norwegian ambassador to Greece (1974–1976), Poland (1981–1986), India (1986–1990) and Austria (1990–1994).

[[Phil Phillips]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, African-American singers, American singer-songwriters, Singers from Louisiana, Writers from Louisiana

John Philip Baptiste (March 14, 1926 – March 14, 2020), better known as Phil Phillips, was an American singer and songwriter. He is best known for his 1959 song, "Sea of Love". The song went to No. 2 in the US Billboard Hot 100 pop chart. It also spent 14 weeks in the top 40, as well as reaching No. 1 on the R&B chart. In 1959, it sold over one million copies and was awarded a gold disc. The single has had notable covers by Del Shannon (which reached No. 33 on the pop chart in 1982), the Honeydrippers (which peaked at No. 3 spending 14 weeks in the top 40 in 1984) and Tom Waits. Phillips' version was featured most notably in the movie Sea of Love (1989), starring Al Pacino.

Phillips was born in Crowley, Louisiana. He was married and had seven children. On March 14, 2020, Phillips died on his 94th birthday in Lake Charles, Louisiana.

[[Antiviral drug]]

CATEGORIES: Drugs

Medication used to treat a viral infectionViruses are the ultimate expression of parasitism. They not only take nutrition from the host cell but also direct it metabolic machinery to synthesize new virus particles. viral chemotherapy was considered impossible, as it would require interference with cellular metabolism in the host.

[[Viktor Josef Dammertz]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, German Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops

Viktor Josef Dammertz (8 June 1929 – 2 March 2020) was a German bishop of the Roman Catholic Church. He was born in Schaephuysen, Rheurdt. He became a priest in 1957. He served as bishop of Augsburg from 1993 until his retirement in 2004.

Dammertz died on 2 March 2020 in Eresing, at the age of 90.

[[Viral infection]]

CATEGORIES: Virology, Infectious diseases

A viral infection (or viral disease, or infectious disease) occurs when a living thing's body is entered in an unwanted way by disease-causing viruses, and able to be caught from others virus particles (virions) attach to and enter susceptible cells.

[[Animaniacs (2020 TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: American animated television series, 2020s American comedy television series, American children's television series, English-language television programs

Animaniacs is an American animated series made Wellsley Wild and Steven Spielberg. It first started showing on Hulu in 2020. It is a revival of the 1993 television show Animaniacs.

[[Soundaraj Periyanayagam]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Indian people, Roman Catholic bishops

Soundaraj Periyanayagam (6 June 1949 – 21 March 2020) was an Indian bishop of the Roman Catholic Church. He was born in Periya Kozhappalur. He became a priest in 1983. He served as bishop of Vellore from 2006 until his death in 2020.

Periyanayagam died on 21 March 2020 in Chetpet, Tamil Nadu, at the age of 69.

[[Antimicrobial]]

CATEGORIES: Microbiology

An antimicrobial is an agent that kills microorganisms or stops their growth. Antimicrobial medicines can be grouped according to the microorganisms they act primarily against. For example, antibiotics are used against bacteria, and antifungals are used against fungi. They can also be classified according to their function. Agents that kill microbes are microbicidal, while those that merely stop their growth are called biostatic. The use of antimicrobial medicines to treat infection is known as antimicrobial chemotherapy, while the use of antimicrobial medicines to prevent infection is called antimicrobial prophylaxis.

The main types of antimicrobial agents are disinfectants (such as bleach), which kill a wide range of microbes on non-living surfaces to prevent the spread of illness, antiseptics (which are applied to living tissue and help reduce infection during surgery), and antibiotics (which kill microorganisms within the body). The term "antibiotic" originally described only those creations that came from living microorganisms but is now also applied to synthetic agents, such as sulfonamides or fluoroquinolones. The term also used to be only applied to antibacterials, but its meaning has widened to include all antimicrobials. Antibacterial agents can be further grouped into bactericidal agents, which kill bacteria, and bacteriostatic agents, which slow down or stall bacterial growth. In response, further advancements in antimicrobial technologies have resulted in solutions that can go past simply stopping germ growth. Instead, certain types of porous media have been made to kill microbes on contact.

[[Pharmacotheraphy]]

CATEGORIES: Pharmacology, Therapy, Drugs

Pharmacotherapy is therapy using medication, as separate from therapy using surgery (surgical therapy), radiation (radiation therapy), movement (physical therapy), or other methods. Among physicians, sometimes the term medical therapy refers specifically to pharmacotherapy as separate to surgical or other therapy; for example, in oncology, medical oncology is differentiated from surgical oncology. Pharmacists are experts in pharmacotherapy and are responsible for ensuring the safe, appropriate, and economical use of pharmaceutical drugs. The skills required to function as a pharmacist require knowledge, training and experience in biomedical, pharmaceutical and clinical sciences.  Pharmacology is the science that aims to continually improve pharmacotherapy. The pharmaceutical industry and academia use basic science, applied science, and translational science to create new pharmaceutical drugs.

[[Inna Makarova]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Disease-related deaths in Moscow, Russian movie actors, Russian television actors, Soviet movie actors, Soviet television actors

Inna Vladimirovna Makarova (И́нна Влади́мировна Мака́рова; 28 July 1926 – 25 March 2020) was a Russian actress. She is best known for her role as Lyubov Shevtsova in  The Young Guard (1948). Her other movie credits include It Happened in the Donbass (1945), The Return of Vasili Bortnikov (1953),The Rumyantsev Case (1956), The Height (1957), Balzaminov's Marriage (1964), Russian field (1971), It Is Not Evening Yet (1973) and Dead Souls (1984). In 1985, she was made a People's Artist of the USSR.

Makarova was born in Tayga and grew up in Novosibirsk. She was married to Sergei Bondarchuk. Her daughter was actress Natalya Bondarchuk. She died in Moscow on 25 March 2020 at the age of 93.

[[Farzaneh Taidi]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in London, Iranian actors, Movie actors, People from Tehran, Stage actors

Farzaneh Taidi (فرزانه تأییدی‎; 1945 – 25 March 2020) was an Iranian actress. She was born in Tehran. She appeared in a number of Persian language movies starting in the 1970s. Her movie credits include Hell + Me, The Eighth Day of the Week and The Journey of the Stone. She also appeared in Not Without My Daughter (1991).

On 25 March 2020, Taidi died in London, United Kingdom of cancer. She was 74 or 75.

[[Detto Mariano]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy, Italian composers, Lyricists, Italian pianists, Record producers, Movie score composers

Detto Mariano (born Mariano Detto; 27 July 1937 – 25 March 2020) was an Italian musician. He was also a composer, arranger, lyricist, pianist and record producer. His career started in 1958. He is best known as a member of I Ribelli. He was born in Monte Urano, Marche.

On 25 March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Mariano died in Milan due to COVID-19. He was 82.

[[Adriano Celentano]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Italian singers, Italian musicians, Italian writers, Italian movie directors, Songwriters, Actors from Milan

Adriano Celentano (adriˈaːno tʃelenˈtaːno; born 6 January 1938) is an Italian singer-songwriter, musician, actor and movie director. He is known as "il Molleggiato". He was born in Milan. In 1962, Celentano founded the Italian record label Clan Celentano. His best known works are "24.000 Baci", "Il Tuo Bacio e’ Come un Rock" and "Si e’ Spento il Sole".

[[Eric Weissberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, American guitarists, American country musicians, American country singers, Singers from New York City, Musicians from New York City

Eric Weissberg (August 16, 1939 – March 22, 2020) was an American singer, banjo player, and multi-instrumentalist. He was known for his banjo solo in "Dueling Banjos". It was released as a single that reached number 2 in the United States and Canada in 1973. Weissberg was a member of the folk group The Tarriers. Weissberg was born in New York City.

Weussberg died on March 22, 2020 in Detroit, Michigan of Alzheimer's disease-related problems, aged 80.

[[ICQ]]

CATEGORIES: Microsoft Windows software, Social networking

ICQ is a cross-platform instant messaging and VoIP client. The name ICQ derives from the English phrase "I Seek You". Originally developed by the Israeli company Mirabilis in 1996, the client was bought by AOL in 1998, and then by Mail.Ru Group in 2010.

The ICQ client application and service were initially released in November 1996, freely available to download. ICQ was among the first stand-alone instant messenger (IM)—while real-time chat was not in itself new (Internet Relay Chat (IRC) being the most common platform at the time), the concept of a fully centralized service with individual user accounts focused on one-on-one conversations set the blueprint for later instant messaging services like AIM, and its influence is seen in modern social media applications. ICQ became the first widely adopted IM platform.

At its peak around 2001, ICQ had more than 100 million accounts registered. At the time of the Mail.Ru acquisition in 2010, there were around 42 million daily users. Since 2013, ICQ has 11 million monthly users.

[[List of people who have walked on the Moon]]

CATEGORIES: Apollo astronauts

Twelve people have walked on Earth's Moon, starting with Neil Armstrong and ending with Gene Cernan. All crewed lunar landings took place between July 1969 and December 1972 as part of the United States Apollo program. All twelve people who have walked on the Moon are American men.

[[List of Apollo astronauts]]

CATEGORIES: Apollo astronauts, Lists of people

NASA assigned 32 American astronauts to the Apollo lunar landing program, and 24, flying on nine missions between December 1968 and December 1972, orbited the Moon.

During six two-man landing missions twelve astronauts walked on the lunar surface, and six of those drove Lunar Roving Vehicles. Three flew to the Moon twice, one orbiting both times and two landing once apiece. From these 24 men, no human being has gone beyond low Earth orbit.

[[Thomas P. Stafford]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, Living people, Apollo astronauts, Scientists from Oklahoma

Thomas Patten Stafford (born September 17, 1930; Lt Gen, USAF, Ret.) is an American former Air Force officer, test pilot, and NASA astronaut.

Stafford commissioned in the United States Air Force, flying the F-86 Sabre prior becoming a test pilot.  

He was selected to become an astronaut in 1962, and flew aboard Gemini 6A and Gemini 9. 

In 1969, Stafford was the Commander of Apollo 10, the second crewed mission to orbit the Moon and the first to fly a Lunar Module in lunar orbit, descending to an altitude of nine miles.

In 1975, Stafford was the commander of the Apollo-Soyuz Test Project flight, the first joint U.S.-Soviet space mission.

[[Lunar Roving Vehicle]]

CATEGORIES: Apollo program

The Lunar Roving Vehicle (LRV) is a battery-powered four-wheeled rover used on the Moon in the last three missions of the American Apollo program (15, 16, and 17) during 1971 and 1972. They are popularly known as  "Moon buggies", a play on the words "dune buggy".

These three LRVs remain on the Moon.

[[List of The Loud House episodes]]

CATEGORIES: Lists of animated television series episodes, Lists of Nickelodeon television series episodes

The Loud House is an American animated television series created by Chris Savino for Nickelodeon. The series premiered on May 2, 2016.

[[Stuart Roosa]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 1994 deaths, Deaths from pancreatitis, Apollo astronauts, American aviators, Engineers from Colorado, Scientists from Colorado

Stuart Allen "Stu" Roosa (August 16, 1933 – December 12, 1994), (Col., USAF), was an American aeronautical engineer, United States Air Force pilot, test pilot, and NASA astronaut. He was the Command Module Pilot for the Apollo 14 mission. He was the third mission to land astronauts (Alan Shepard and Edgar Mitchell) on the Moon. 

While Shepard and Mitchell spent two days on the lunar surface, Roosa made experiments from orbit in the Command Module Kitty Hawk. 

He was one of 24 men to travel to the Moon, which he orbited 34 times.

Roosa died of pancreatitis in Falls Church, Virginia on December 12, 1994 at the age of 61.

[[Durango, Colorado]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Colorado, County seats in Colorado

Durango is the county seat and the most populous city of La Plata County, Colorado, United States.  It is home to Fort Lewis College. The United States Census Bureau reported a population of 16,887 in the 2010 census.

[[Bellwood, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois, Settlements in Cook County, Illinois, Suburbs of Chicago, Illinois

Bellwood is a village in Proviso Township, Cook County, Illinois, United States. It is located 13 west of Chicago's downtown Loop. The population was 19,071 at the 2010 census.

[[Proviso Township, Cook County, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Illinois, Settlements in Cook County, Illinois

Proviso Township is one of 29 townships in Cook County, Illinois, United States.  As of the 2010 census, its population was 151,704. 

It was organized in 1850 and originally named "Taylor".

[[Hillside, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois, Suburbs of Chicago, Illinois, Settlements in Cook County, Illinois

Hillside is a village in Cook County, Illinois, United States. As of the 2010 census it had a population of 8,157.

[[Maywood, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois, Suburbs of Chicago, Illinois, Settlements in Cook County, Illinois

Maywood is a village in Proviso Township, Cook County, Illinois, United States. It was founded on April 6, 1869. The population was 24,090 at the 2010 United States Census.

[[Fellows of the Royal Society]]

CATEGORIES: 1663, Awards, Royal Society

Fellowship of the Royal Society (FRS, ForMemRS and HonFRS) is an award granted by the judges of the Royal Society of London to individuals who have made a 'substantial contribution to the improvement of natural knowledge, including mathematics, engineering science, and medical science.

Isaac Newton was one of the earliest fellows of the Royal Society, elected in 1672

Fellowship of the Society, the oldest known scientific academy in continuous existence, is a significant honor. It has been awarded to many eminent scientists throughout history, including Isaac Newton (1672), Charles Darwin (1839), Michael Faraday (1824), Ernest Rutherford (1903), Srinivasa Ramanujan (1918), Albert Einstein (1921), Winston Churchill (1941), Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar (1944), Dorothy Hodgkin (1947), Alan Turing (1951) and Francis Crick (1959). More recently, fellowship has been awarded to Stephen Hawking (1974), Tim Hunt (1991), Elizabeth Blackburn (1992), Tim Berners-Lee (2001), Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (2003), Atta-ur Rahman (2006), Andre Geim (2007), James Dyson (2015), Ajay Kumar Sood (2015), Subhash Khot (2017), Elon Musk (2018), and around 8,000 others in total, including over 280 Nobel Laureates since 1900. As of October 2018, there are approximately 1689 living Fellows, Foreign and Honorary Members, of which over 60 are Nobel Laureates.

Fellowship of the Royal Society has been described by The Guardian newspaper as “the equivalent of a lifetime achievement Oscar” with several institutions celebrating their announcement each year.

[[Boil (infection)]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases caused by bacteria

A boil is a type of infection. It can cause a skin infection. Most boils can hurt a little bit when touched.

Boils can be treated by putting a hot washcloth on it and will pop after a couple of days.

[[Hugh Conaghan]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Irish politicians

Hugh Conaghan (6 May 1926 – March 2020) was an Irish Fianna Fáil politician. He was elected to Dáil Éireann as Fianna Fáil Teachta Dála (TD) for the Donegal constituency at the 1977 general election.

He was a losing candidate at the Donegal North-East by-election on 10 June 1976. He was elected at the 1981 general election for the Donegal North-East constituency and was re-elected for this constituency until he lost his seat at the 1989 general election. He was a losing candidate at the 1992 general election.

Conaghan died in March 2020, aged 93.

[[João Teixeira de Faria]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1942 births, Surgeons, Spirituality, Brazilian writers, People convicted of assault, Sex offenders

João Teixeira de Faria (born June 24, 1942), known also as João de Deus (John of God), is a Brazilian medium , "psychic surgeon" and convicted sex offender. His business is set in Abadiânia, Brazil, where he runs the Casa de Dom Inácio de Loyola, a "spiritual healing center". 

He has had media coverage on CNN, ABC News and The Oprah Winfrey Show. James Randi and Joe Nickell had criticized him for his healing procedures as "nothing more than carnival tricks" and there is no evidence that the benefits of patients are placebo effects. 

In 2018, after over 600 people accused him of sexual abuse, he turned himself in to police. In December 2019 he was sentenced to 19 years and four months for the rapes of four different women. On January 20, 2020, Faria was sentenced to another 40 years in prison for rape against 5 women. The sentences add up to 63 years and 4 months.

[[Dubravka Jurlina Alibegović]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Croatian politicians, Economists, Independent politicians, People from Zagreb

Dubravka Jurlina Alibegović (born 5 November 1963) is a Croatian economist and politician. She was an independent in the cabinet of Tihomir Orešković. She was the Minister of Public Administration from January to October 2016.

Alibegović was born in Zagreb. She graduated from the Faculty of Economics and Business, University of Zagreb. She was the director of the Institute of Economics, Zagreb from 2013 to 2016.

[[Joe Nickell]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, American critics, Writers from Kentucky

Joe Nickell (born December 1, 1944) is an American skeptic and investigator of the paranormal. 

He helped find out that the diary of Jack the Ripper was a hoax. In 2002 he was one of a number of experts asked by scholar Henry Louis Gates, Jr. to see if the manuscript of Hannah Crafts' The Bondwoman's Narrative (1853–1860), possibly the first novel by an African-American woman, was real. 

Nickell is senior research fellow for the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry (CSI) and  writes regularly for their journal, the Skeptical Inquirer. 

He is also an associate dean of the Center for Inquiry Institute. He is the author or editor of over 30 books.

[[Suzanne Dekker]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Democrats 66 politicians, Dutch women politicians, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Former MEPs, MEPs for the Netherlands, Politicians from Amsterdam

Suzanne Dekker (born 31 October 1949) is a former Dutch politician. She was born in Amsterdam. She is a member of Democrats 66 (D66). She sat as a member of the European Parliament (MEP) from the Netherlands between 1979 and 1981. Dekker also served in the Dutch House of Representatives from 1981 to 1982.

[[Elsa Lára Arnardóttir]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, Icelandic politicians

Elsa Lára Arnardóttir (born 30 December 1975) is an Icelandic politician. She is a member of the Progressive Party. From 2013 to 2017, she was a member of the national parliament for the Northwest constituency.

[[Joe Lycett]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, British comedians, British television personalities, British activists, British LGBT people, LGBT comedians, LGBT rights activists, Bisexual people, People from Birmingham

Joe Harry Lycett (born 5 July 1988) is a British comedian. He has appeared on television shows including Live at the Apollo, Taskmaster, Never Mind the Buzzcocks, 8 Out of 10 Cats and QI.

He is the announcer on Saturday BBC One show Epic Win, and as the presenter on BBC Two's The Great British Sewing Bee.

He has his own show on Channel 4 titled, Joe Lycett's Got Your Back.

He is openly bisexual.

On 1 March 2020, he announced that he had changed his legal name to Hugo Boss in protest against the company of the same name.

[[William Dufris]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, American voice actors, Actors from Maine

William Dufris (February 1, 1958 – March 24, 2020) was an American voice actor and Audiobook narrator. He was born in Houlton, Maine. He was known for English dubbing many foreign language cartoons and animes. His best known work include dubbing Kataoka in Patlabor: The Movie (1989) and its sequel (1993), as Elvis and Dougan in Rocky and the Dodos and as Bob the Builder in the animated children's program.

Dufris died on March 24, 2020 of cancer at the age of 62.

[[Houlton, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maine, County seats in Maine

Houlton is a town in Aroostook County, Maine, on the Canada–US border, located at 46.1256. As of the 2010 census, the town's population was 6,123. Houlton is the county seat of Aroostook County, and as such its nickname is the "Shire Town".

[[Aroostook County, Maine]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Maine, 1839 establishments in the United States, Maine counties

Aroostook County (Comté d'Aroostook) (ə ə) is a county in the U.S. state of Maine along the Canada–U.S. border. As of the 2010 census, the population was 71,870. Its seat is Houlton.

[[Doug Emhoff]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, American lawyers, Second Spouses of the United States, Businesspeople from New York City, Businesspeople from Washington, D.C.

Douglas Craig Emhoff (born October 13, 1964) is an American entertainment lawyer. He is the Second Gentleman of the United States, the first ever man to be Second Gentleman. He is the husband of Vice President of the United States Kamala Harris.

He is also the first Jewish spouse to a United States Vice President.

Emhoff is an entertainment litigator and began his career at Pillsbury Winthrop’s litigation group.

Emhoff worked with DLA Piper at their Washington, D.C. and California offices.

Emhoff and Harris have homes in Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Washington, D.C.

[[Uncut Gems]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 movies, Movies set in New York City, American mystery movies, American thriller movies, American sports movies, Netflix movies

Uncut Gems is a 2019 American thriller movie directed by Josh and Benny Safdie, who co-wrote the screenplay with Ronald Bronstein.

The movie stars Adam Sandler as Howard Ratner, a Jewish jeweler and gambling addict in New York City, who must get an expensive gem he purchased to pay off his debts. The movie also stars Kevin Garnett, Idina Menzel, Lakeith Stanfield, Julia Fox, and Eric Bogosian.

Uncut Gems had its world premiere at the Telluride Film Festival on August 30, 2019. It had a wide release on December 25, by A24. The movie strong good reviews, with its screenplay, direction, editing and Sandler's performance.

It was chosen by the National Board of Review as one of the top ten movies of 2019.

[[Carlo Collodi]]

CATEGORIES: 1826 births, 1890 deaths, Italian journalists, Children's writers, People from Florence

Carlo Lorenzini (24 November 1826 – 26 October 1890), better known by the pen name Carlo Collodi (ˈkarlo kolˈlɔːdi), was an Italian author, humorist, and journalist, widely known for his fairy tale novel The Adventures of Pinocchio.

[[Alfred Gomolka]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls, Former MEPs, MEPs for Germany

Alfred Gomolka (21 July 1942 – 24 March 2020) was a German politician. He was a Member of the European Parliament for Mecklenburg-Vorpommern from 1994 to 2008. He was a member of the conservative Christian Democratic Union of Germany, part of the European People's Party. He was the first Minister President of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern from 1990 to 1992 and was the President of the Bundesrat from 1 November 1991 to 19 March 1992.

Gomolka died on 24 March 2020 from a fall in Schwerin, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, aged 77.

[[Blinding Lights]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 songs, New wave, The Weeknd

“Blinding Lights” is a song by Canadian recording artist The Weeknd, taken from his seventh studio album, After Hours.  The song was released on November 24, 2019, two days after the album’s lead single, “Heartless”.  “Blinding Lights” was written and produced by The Weeknd, Max Martin, and Oscar Holter. DaHeala and Belly also contributed to writing the song.

The song has topped charts in thirteen countries. It became his fifth number-one single on the US Billboard Hot 100.

[[James Otis (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, Actors from New York City, 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Actors from Stamford, Connecticut

James Patrick Otis (March 16, 1948 – March 3, 2020) was an American actor. He was born in Stamford, Connecticut. Otis began his career in the 1970s. His first movie role was in Dragonfly. On television, he was known for his role in Profiler.

In 1999, Otis appeared in three episodes of Star Trek: Deep Space Nine. In 2006, Otis appeared in the true story movie The Black Dahlia. Otis also appeared in The Prestige.

Otis died in Stamford on March 3, 2020 at the age of 71.

[[David Greetham (textual scholar)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, Writers from Cheshire, 1941 births, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American literary critics, American essayists, Writers from Massachusetts, People from Lenox, Massachusetts

David Greetham (October 21, 1941 – March 24, 2020) was an English-American literary critic. He was known as the founder of the Society for Textual Scholarship. He was the Society's President from 1999 to 2001. He worked at the Graduate Center at City University New York. Greetham was born in Cheshire, England.

Greetham died on March 24, 2020 from a long-illness at the age of 78.

[[Peter Green (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Blues guitarists, English rock guitarists, English rock singers, Jewish British musicians, Singer-songwriters from London, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees

Peter Green (born Peter Allen Greenbaum; 29 October 1946 – 25 July 2020) was a British blues rock singer-songwriter and guitarist. He is one of the founders of Fleetwood Mac. He was added to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1998. Green's writing credits include Fleetwood Mac songs such as "Albatross", "Black Magic Woman", "Oh Well", "The Green Manalishi (With the Two Prong Crown)" and "Man of the World". Rolling Stone ranked Green at number 58 in its list of the "100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time".

Green was born in Bethnal Green, London. His family were Jewish. Green was married to Jane Samuels from 1978 to 1979. The couple had one daughter.

Green lived on Canvey Island in Essex. On 25 July 2020, Green died in his sleep at the age of 73.

[[John Davies (swimmer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in California, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Australian Olympic gold medalists, Australian swimmers, American judges, American lawyers, Sportspeople from New South Wales, Politicians from Los Angeles, California, US Republican Party politicians

John Griffith Davies (17 May 1929 – 24 March 2020) was an Australian-American breaststroke swimmer and politician.

Davies won a gold medal in the 200-metre breaststroke at the 1952 Summer Olympics in Helsinki and set a world record in the 200 yard breaststroke (short course) and tied the world record in the 200 m breaststroke (long course). 

After retiring from competition swimming, he became a lawyer in California. He was appointed a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Central District of California by President Ronald Reagan in 1986.r He presided over the trial of the Los Angeles Police Department officers charged with assaulting Rodney King. He retired from the court in 1998.

Davies was born in Willoughby, New South Wales, Australia. He studied at the University of Michigan and at the University of California at Los Angeles. He moved to the United States in 1955.

Davies was added into the International Swimming Hall of Fame in 1984, and the Sport Australia Hall of Fame in 1992.  He received an Australian Sports Medal in 2000.

Davies died of cancer in Pasadena, California on 24 March 2020, aged 90.

[[Lawrence Pressman]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Kentucky

Lawrence Pressman (born David M. Pressman; July 10, 1939) is an American actor. He is best known for roles on Doogie Howser, M.D., Ladies' Man, Profiler, Mulligan's Stew and in the 1971 movie The Hellstrom Chronicle.

[[Lucien Sève]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, French philosophers, Political writers, Political activists, Communists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France

Lucien Sève (9 December 1926 – 23 March 2020) was a French philosopher, communist and political activist. He was born in Chambéry, France. He was an active member of the French Communist Party from 1950 through 2010. He was elected as a member of the Central Committee in 1961, and stayed elected until 1994. His 1969 work Marxisme et théorie de la personnalité (Marxism and theory of personality) has been translated into 25 different languages. 

Sève died on 23 March 2020 of COVID-19 in Clamart, France, aged 93.

[[Clamart]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hauts-de-Seine

Clamart (kla.maʁ) is a commune in the southwestern suburbs of Paris, France. It is located 8.7 from the center of Paris.

[[Ann Wilson]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, American rock singers, Musicians from San Diego, California, Musicians from Washington, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees, Singer-songwriters from California

Ann Dustin Wilson (born June 19, 1950) is an American musician. She rose to fame as the lead singer and songwriter rock band Heart. Her younger sister, Nancy Wilson, is Heart's guitarist. As a member of Heart, Wilson was added to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2013.

Wilson was born in San Diego, California. Her family later settled in Bellevue, Washington. She has two children. She married Dean Wetter in 2015.

[[Nancy Wilson (rock musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, American rock guitarists, American rock singers, Musicians from San Francisco, Musicians from Washington, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees

Nancy Lamoureaux Wilson (born March 16, 1954) is an American musician and singer. She is best known as a guitarist and backing vocalist for the rock band Heart. Her older sister, Ann Wilson, is Heart's lead singer. As a member of Heart, Wilson was added to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2013.

Wilson was born in San Francisco, California. Her family moved to Federal Way, WA then later settled in Bellevue, Washington. She has two children with her first husband Cameron Crowe. She is now married to Geoff Bywater.

[[Self-help]]

CATEGORIES: Books

A self-help book  is written in a way that its reader can relate to himself/herself and solve his/her problems as guided by the author of the book.

A self-help book is written to counsel its readers on solving their personal issue or problems in life. The phrase "Self-Help" comes from an 1859 best-seller by Samuel Smiles.  "Self-improvement" is a modernized version of the term self-help.

[[BC Transit]]

CATEGORIES: Companies of Canada

BC Transit is a transit company run by the British Columbian government that gives bus services to many towns and areas in the province.

Before 1979, the power company, BC Hydro, ran the buses. In 1979, the province made the transit company into a separate agency called the Urban Transit Authority which became BC Transit in 1983.

BC Transit transit plans the routes and schedules but doesn't run the buses in most of the province. In 1999, a new company called TransLink was made to run the buses, metro, and trains in Vancouver. BC Transit might give more areas to TransLink one day.

Eventually, the scene where Arthur punched D.W. becomes a very popular meme.

[[Bethalto, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois

Bethalto is a village in Illinois in the United States.

[[Bradford, Illinois]]

[[Unclaimed person]]

CATEGORIES: People

An unclaimed person is someone who is dead and none of their family members have seen the dead body or if the dead person have no family members who are alive.

In most states, almost 40,000 unclaimed bodies have been found and put in a morgue.

[[Mark Mothersbaugh]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, American movie score composers, Living people, Musicians from Akron, Ohio

Mark Allen Mothersbaugh (born May 18, 1950) is an American singer-songwriter, composer, multi-instrumentalist, record producer, music programmer, author and visual artist.

[[Bernie Geoffrion]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2006 deaths, New York Rangers players, Montreal Canadiens players, Calder Trophy winners, Art Ross Trophy winners, Ice hockey coaches, Hart Memorial Trophy winners, Hockey Hall of Fame inductees, Stanley Cup champions, Sportspeople from Montreal, Cancer deaths in the United States, Disease-related deaths in Georgia (U.S. state)

Joseph Bernard André Geoffrion (February 14, 1931 – March 11, 2006) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player and coach. His  nickname was Boom Boom.

Geoffrion was considered an innovator of the slapshot. He was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1972. He played for the Montreal Canadiens and New York Rangers in the National Hockey League. In 2017 Geoffrion was named one of the '100 Greatest NHL Players' in history.

[[Edman Ayvazyan]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Painters, Armenian people, People from Tehran

Edman Ayvazyan (Էդման Այվազյան, 10 August 1931 – 25 March 2020) was an Iranian-Armenian painter. He was born in Tehran.

[[Disappearance of Robert Levinson]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Missing American people, People declared dead in absentia, Spies, People from New York City

Robert Alan Levinson (March 10, 1948 – date of death unknown) was an American former Drug Enforcement Administration and Federal Bureau of Investigation agent.

Levinson disappeared mysteriously on March 9, 2007 in Kish Island, Iran while on a mission for the CIA. Levinson's family received $2.5 million annuity from the CIA in order to stop a lawsuit revealing details of his work in Iran. He may have been held captive by the government of Iran. 

On November 26, 2013, Levinson, if he was still alive, became the longest-held American in history, passing Terry A. Anderson. According to his family, he suffered from type 1 diabetes, gout, and hypertension.  

His passport has never shown up in any other country. 

On March 25, 2020, Levinson's family announced his death, and although the date is unknown, it has been determined that he likely died while in Iranian custody.

[[Nimmi]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Indian movie actors

Nawab Banoo (18 February 1933 – 25 March 2020), better known by her stage name Nimmi, was an Indian actress. Nimmi was born in Agra, United Provinces of Agra and Oudh, British India, (present-day Uttar Pradesh, India).

She became known in the 1950s and early 1960s in Hindi movies. Her best roles were in Sazaa (1951), Aan (1952), Uran Khatola (1955), Bhai-Bhai (1956), Kundan (1955), Mere Mehboob (1963), Pooja Ke Phool (1964), Akashdeep (1965), and Love and God (1986). 

Nimmi died on 25 March 2020 at her home in Mumbai of a heart attack at the age of 87.

[[Mike Stratton]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, American football linebackers, Buffalo Bills players, San Diego Chargers players, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States

David Michael Stratton (April 10, 1941 – March 25, 2020) was an American professional football player. He was a linebacker in the American Football League (AFL) and National Football League (NFL) for 12 seasons. He played professionally for the Buffalo Bills and San Diego Chargers. He played college football for the Tennessee Volunteers.

Stratton was born in Vonore, Tennessee. He studied at the University of Tennessee. Stratton died on March 25, 2020 of a heart attack caused by a fall at the age of 78.

[[Vonore, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Tennessee

Vonore is a town in Monroe and Blount counties, in the U.S. state of Tennessee. The population was 1,474 as of the 2010 census.

[[Monroe County, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Tennessee counties

Monroe County is a county located in the U.S. state of Tennessee. As of the 2010 census, the population was 44,519. Its county seat is Madisonville.

[[Madisonville, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

Madisonville is a city in and the county seat of Monroe County, Tennessee, United States. The population was 3,939 at the 2000 census and 4,577 at the 2010 census.

[[Karlovy Vary Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic, 2001 establishments in Europe, Bohemia

The Karlovy Vary Region or Carlsbad Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Karlovy Vary. The region is world-famous for its spas, including Karlovy Vary and Mariánské Lázně.

The Karlovy Vary Region is divided into 3 districts:

[[Disappearance of Zebb Quinn]]

CATEGORIES: Missing people

Zebb Wayne Quinn (May 12, 1981 - missing since January 2, 2000) was an American missing person.

On July 10, 2017, it was announced that Zebb was murdered. His killer was charged.

[[Ústí nad Labem Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic, 2001 establishments in Europe

Ústí nad Labem Region or Ústecký Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Ústí nad Labem.

The area along the German border has the Ore Mountains and Lužice Mountains. The Elbe River is the largest watercourse in the region. Other main rivers in the region include Ohře, Bílina, Ploučnice and Kamenice.

[[Liberec Region]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 establishments in Europe, Regions of the Czech Republic, Bohemia

Liberec Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Liberec.

The region's landscape includes the Jizera Mountains, part of the Krkonoše Mountains and part of the Lusatian Mountains. Lake Mácha is near the town of Doksy. 

[[Hradec Králové Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic

Hradec Králové Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Hradec Králové.

Krkonoše and Orlické mountains are in the north of the region. Two thirds of the area of the Krkonoše National Park is within the region.

[[Richard Reeves (American writer)]]

CATEGORIES: American political writers, American columnists, 2020 deaths, American educators, Deaths from cardiac arrest, 1936 births

Richard Furman Reeves (November 28, 1936 – March 25, 2020) was an American political writer, syndicated columnist and correspondent. He was a lecturer at the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles. He was born in New York City.

From 1961–1965, Reeves co-founded and worked for the Phillipsburg Free Press (New Jersey), then worked for Newark Evening News and the New York Herald Tribune. He was the Chief Political Correspondent for The New York Times in 1966.  In 1971, Reeves left the Times to lecture at Hunter College.

Reeves died on March 25, 2020 in Los Angeles from cardiac arrest, aged 83.

[[Pardubice Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic, 2000 establishments in Europe, Bohemia

Pardubice Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Pardubice.

Králický Sněžník (1,424 m) is the highest point in the region. The European Watershed runs through the region, where it separates the basins of the North Sea and the Black Sea.

[[Robert Munsch]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, American children's writers, American educators, Canadian educators, People with bipolar disorder, Writers from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Writers from Ontario

Robert Norman Munsch CAN  (born June 11, 1945) is an American-born Canadian children's author. He is best known for his books The Paper Bag Princess and Love You Forever.

In 1975, he moved to Canada to work at the preschool at the University of Guelph in Guelph, Ontario.

Munsch has publicly talked about his bipolar disorder, manic depression, alcoholism and cocaine addiction issues.

[[Olomouc Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic

Olomouc Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Olomouc.

The Jeseníky mountains are in the north of the region. The Morava river flows through the region.

[[Moravian-Silesian Region]]

CATEGORIES: 2001 establishments in Europe, Regions of the Czech Republic

The Moravian-Silesian Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Ostrava.

[[South Moravian Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic

The South Moravian Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Brno.

The region is famous for its wine production. The area around the towns of Mikulov, Znojmo, Velké Pavlovice along with the Slovácko region provide 94% of the Czech Republic's vineyards.

Podyjí National Park is in the south-eastern part of the region.

[[Zlín Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic, 2000 establishments in Europe

Zlín Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Zlín.

[[Vysočina region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of the Czech Republic

The Vysočina Region is an administrative unit (kraj) of the Czech Republic. The capital city is Jihlava.

The region is the location of two mountain ranges, Žďárské vrchy and Jihlavské vrchy. It also has three UNESCO World Heritage Sites: the historical centre of Telč, the Pilgrimage Church of Saint John of Nepomuk in Žďár nad Sázavou, and the Jewish Quarter and St Procopius' Basilica in Třebíč.

[[Capital Region of Denmark]]

CATEGORIES: Region Hovedstaden, 2007 establishments in Denmark, Regions of Denmark

The Capital Region of Denmark is an administrative region of Denmark. The capital city is Hillerød.

Denmark's largest lake, Arresø, is in the region. It is also home to the deepest lake, Furesø.

[[Central Denmark Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Denmark, 2007 establishments in Denmark

Central Denmark Region is an administrative region of Denmark. The capital city is Viborg. The city with the most people is Århus.

[[North Jutland Region]]

CATEGORIES: Region Nordjylland, Regions of Denmark, 2007 establishments in Denmark

The North Jutland Region is an administrative region of Denmark. The capital city is Aalborg.

One of Denmark's five universities, Aalborg Universitet, is in the region. Most of the region's museums are in Aalborg such as Nordjyllands Historiske Museum,  KUNSTEN, Musikkens Hus, Utzon Center and Aalborg Zoo.

[[Region Zealand]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Denmark, 2007 establishments in Denmark

Region Zealand is an administrative region of Denmark. The capital city is Sorø. The city with the most people is Roskilde.

The region is named after the island of Zealand.

[[Region of Southern Denmark]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Denmark, 2007 establishments in Denmark

The Region of Southern Denmark is an administrative region of Denmark. The capital city is Vejle. 

Odense is the region's largest city. It is home to the main campus of the University of Southern Denmark with branch campuses in Esbjerg, Kolding and Sønderborg.

[[Benee]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 births, Entertainers from North Island, Living people, New Zealand singers, People from Auckland, Singer-songwriters

Stella Rose Bennett (born 30 January, 2000), known professionally as Benee is a New Zealand singer-songwriter from Grey Lynn, Auckland. She is best known for her songs "Soaked", "Glitter", and "Supalonely" and has released two extended plays Fire on Marazz and Stella & Steve.  In 2019, Benee won Best Solo Artist and Best Pop Artist at the New Zealand Music Awards.

According to the Straits Times, people like to think of "Supalonely" as a song for the COVID-19 pandemic, even though Benee says she wrote it as a breakup song.

[[French Bulldog]]

CATEGORIES: Dog breeds

The French Bulldog  is a breed of domestic dog. They are a cross between Toy Bulldogs imported from England and local ratters in Paris, France, in the 1800s.

The breed is popular as a pet; in 2018, they were the most popular registered dog in the United Kingdom, and in the U.S., the fourth-most popular AKC-registered dog breed.

[[Adam Bandt]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Politicians from South Australia, People from Adelaide

Adam Paul Bandt (born 11 March 1972) is an Australian politician and former industrial lawyer. He is the leader of the Australian Greens and federal MP for Melbourne. 

He was co-deputy leader of the Greens from 2012 to 2015 and 2017 to 2020. He was elected leader after the resignation of Richard Di Natale in February 2020.

[[Robbie Katter]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Politicians from Queensland

Robert Carl Ignatius Katter (born 3 March 1977) is an Australian politician. He was the member of the Legislative Assembly of Queensland for Traeger. He represented Mount Isa from 2012 to 2017. He is the leader of Katter's Australian Party, having taken over from his father, Bob Katter in February 2020.

[[Marlin Fitzwater]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, American journalists, American novelists, White House Press Secretaries, Writers from Kansas

Max Marlin Fitzwater (born November 24, 1942) is an American author and journalist. He is a Republican. He was the White House Press Secretary from 1987 to 1993. He served under U.S. Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush.

Fitzwater was born in Salina, Kansas. He has two children. He married Melinda Andrews in 1999.

[[Ron Nessen]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, American political commentators, Politicians from Washington, D.C., Writers from Washington, D.C., White House Press Secretaries, US Republican Party politicians

Ronald Harold Nessen (born May 25, 1934) is an American government official. He was the thirteenth White House Press Secretary for President Gerald Ford from 1974 to 1977.  He replaced Jerald terHorst. Nessen was born in Washington, D.C.. 

Nessen, who also worked NBC News as a war correspondent during the Vietnam War, was seriously wounded by grenade fragments while on patrol outside Pleiku in July 1966. He was with cameraman Peter Boultwood when he was wounded.

[[Michel Hidalgo]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, French footballers, French football managers

Michel Hidalgo (22 March 1933 – 26 March 2020) was a French football player and manager. He was the coach of the French national team from 1976 to 1984. He coached the nation to a UEFA Euro victory in 1984, as well as a fourth place finish at the 1982 FIFA World Cup.

Hidalgo was born in Leffrinckoucke. He played as a midfielder. He played for Le Havre, Stade de Reims and AS Monaco. He scored Stade de Reims third goal in the 1956 European Cup Final. He made one appearance for the national team in 1962.

Hidalgo died in Paris on 26 March 2020, at the age of 87.

[[Magnetic pole]]

CATEGORIES: Geography

Magnetic poles are special places in the magnetic field of the earth. On a magnetic pole, the magnetic field points vertically down (towards the earth).  As the magnetic field of the earth changes over time, so do the magnetic poles. Note that the magnetic north pole is not at the location of the geographic north pole.

[[Floyd Cardoz]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, American chefs, Indian businesspeople, Writers, Restaurateurs, Reality show winners, Businesspeople from New York City, People from Mumbai, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

Floyd Cardoz (October 2, 1960 – March 25, 2020) was an Indian-American chef. He was born in Mumbai. He was well known for his ownership and executives at his New York City in Poowalla and Tabla restaurants and his victory over Top Chef Masters in 2011.

[[Flag of Northern Cyprus]]

CATEGORIES: National flags, Northern Cyprus

The flag of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (TRNC) (Kuzey Kıbrıs Türk Cumhuriyeti Bayrağı) has a red crescent and a star between two horizontal red stripes on a white background.

[[Ángel Maturino Reséndiz]]

CATEGORIES: Murders, 2006 deaths

Ángel Maturino Reséndiz was an Canadian, Mexican, and American serial killer. He was born on August 1, 1959. He died on June 27, 2006. He murdered at least 16 or 15 people. Some people he murdered included: Norman J. Sirnic and Karen Sirnic (May 2, 1999), Fannie Whitney Byers (December 10, 1998), and Claudia Benton (December 17, 1998).

He was executed on June 27, 2006.

[[Ali Sabieh Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Djibouti

Ali Sabieh Region is a region in southern Djibouti. The capital city is Ali Sabieh.

The region is along the national border with Somalia and Ethiopia. The Arrei Mountains are the highest point.

[[Arta Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Djibouti

Arta Region is one of the six regions of Djibouti. The capital city is Arta.

Other towns include We`a, Damerjog and Loyada. The Hemed mountain is the highest point. The country of Somalia is to the east.

[[Dikhil Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Djibouti

The Dikhil Region is a region in southern Djibouti. The capital city is Dikhil.

Dikhil Region is best known for its desert landscape.

[[Djibouti Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Djibouti

Djibouti Region is one of six regions in Djibouti. It was named Djibouti District.

Djibouti Region is the smallest in the country but has the most people. The Gulf of Tadjoura is to the north.

[[Obock Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Djibouti

The Obock Region is a region in northern Djibouti. The administrative centre is Obock. Other towns are: Khôr ‘Angar, Alaili Dadda`, and Medeho.

It is bordered by Eritrea to the north, the Tadjourah Region to the southwest, and the Red Sea and Gulf of Aden to the east. There are several salt-lakes on the road to Tadjoura.

[[Tadjourah Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Djibouti

The Tadjourah Region is a region in north-central Djibouti. The capital city is Tadjourah.

The region has active salt and fisheries industries. It is served by the Tadjoura Airport. Mousa Ali, the highest point in Djibouti, is in the northern part of the region.

[[Districts of Djibouti]]

CATEGORIES: Djibouti

Djibouti is divided into six administrative regions. The regions are then divided into twenty administrative districts.

[[Saint Andrew Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint Andrew is one of Dominica's 10 administrative parishes.

[[Saint David Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint David is one of Dominica's ten administrative parishes. It is on the eastern side of the island.

[[Saint George Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint George is one of Dominica's 10 administrative parishes.

[[Saint John Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint John is one of Dominica's 10 administrative parishes. The capital city is Portsmouth.

The highest peak is Morne aux Diables, with a height of 861 m (2827 ft). The best known tourist attractions in St. John's are the Indian River and the Cabrits National Park.

St. John is home to Ross University School of Medicine in Picard.  Other settlements include:

[[Parishes of Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Dominica is divided into ten parishes.

[[Saint Joseph Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint Joseph is one of Dominica's 10 administrative parishes. Saint Joseph Village is the largest settlement in the parish.

The parish is home to the Layou River, the longest river on the island. 

[[Digital marketing]]

CATEGORIES: Marketing

Digital marketing is advertising delivered through digital channels. It is type of marketing that is done online and has a effect on offline business. It is done online, using things like search engines, social media, email, and other websites to connect with current and potential customers. 

Because computers and cell phones are used more now, marketing has changed. Now businesses are using the Internet to market their product or services. Consumers heavily rely on digital means to research products. For example, Think with Google marketing insights found that 48% of consumers start their inquiries on search engines, while 33% look to brand websites and 26% search within mobile applications.

Digital Marketing is different from traditional marketing. Traditional marketing uses offline channels, while digital marketing uses online channels. A traditional marketing campaign, for example, may use billboards, radio ads, and news stories, while a digital marketing campaign may use social media, blog posts, and email to promote a business and its offerings.

Digital marketing targets a specific segment of the customer base and is interactive. Digital marketing is on the rise and includes search result ads, email ads, and promoted tweets – anything that incorporates marketing with customer feedback or a two-way interaction between the company and customer.

[[Barbara Neely]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, American novelists, American activists, Writers from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

Barbara Ann Neely  (often self-stylized as BarbaraNeely; November 30, 1941 – March 2, 2020) was an African-American novelist, short story writer and activist. She was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. She wrote murder mysteries. Her first novel, Blanche on the Lam (1992) was her best known work. 

The Mystery Writers of America named her their 2020 Grand Master winner.

Neely died on March 2, 2020 at the age of 78 after a short illness in Philadelphia.

[[Vera Pless]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American mathematicians, American educators, Researchers, Scientists from Chicago

Vera Pless (née Stepen, March 5, 1931 – March 2, 2020) was an American mathematician. She worked in combinatorics and coding theory. She was professor emerita at the University of Illinois at Chicago. She was born in West Side, Chicago, Illinois. She began working in physics at the University of Chicago, but soon won a fellowship to study at Northwestern University. Later she worked at military researching at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where she worked as a research associate for Project MAC.

Pless died at her home in Oak Park, Illinois on March 2, 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Hiroshi Masuoka (voice actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Japanese voice actors

Hiroshi Masuoka was a Japanese actor and narrator. He voiced the roles of Masuo Fuguta in Sazae-san and Jam Ojisan in Soreike! Anpanman. He also voiced Kame-Sennin during the last episodes of Dragon Ball Z and all of Dragon Ball GT. He worked for the Tokyo Actor's Consumer's Cooperative Society. He retired in August 2019.

Masuoka died on March 21, 2020 from rectal cancer, aged 83.

[[Edward Tarr]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from surgical complications, People from Norwich, Connecticut, Musicians from Connecticut, Trumpeters, Grammy Award winners

Edward Hankins Tarr (June 15, 1936 – March 24, 2020) was a Grammy-winning American trumpet player and musicologist. Tarr was born in Norwich, Connecticut. In 1953 he was a student of Roger Voisin. Tarr taught trumpet at the Rheinische Musikschule in Cologne (1968–70). He was director of the Trumpet Museum in Bad Säckingen, Germany from 1985 to 2004. 

Tarr died on March 24, 2020 at a hospital in Rheinfelden, Germany of heart surgery-related problems at the age of 83. 

[[Terry Tausch]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Minnesota Vikings players, Sportspeople from Texas, San Francisco 49ers players

Terry Wayne Tausch  (February 5, 1959 – March 25, 2020) was an American football guard in the National Football League. He was born in New Braunfels, Texas. Tausch played for Minnesota Vikings from 1982 to 1988 and for San Francisco 49ers in 1989. 

On March 25, 2020 he died at his home in Plano, Texas at the age of 61.

[[Jean-Yves Veillard]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, French historians, Researchers

Jean-Yves Veillard (19 February 1939 – 25 March 2020) was a French historian. He was born in Rennes, France. He was one of the Bleimor Scouts. Veillard was the author of a thesis on Rennes during the 19th Century. He was one of the founding members of the Breton Democratic Union in 1964. He was Curator of the Musée de Bretagne from 1967 to 2000, and opened the exhibition on Seiz Breur.

Veillard died on 25 March 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Michael Sorkin]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, American critics, American architects, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Writers from Washington, D.C., Businesspeople from Washington, D.C.

Michael D. Sorkin (August 2, 1948 – March 26, 2020) was an American architect, author, and educator.

Sorkin received a bachelor's degree from the University of Chicago in 1970, and a masters in architecture from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Sorkin also held a master's degree in English from Columbia University (MA '70).

Sorkin was house architecture critic for The Village Voice in the 1980s, and he wrote many articles and books on the subjects of contemporary architecture, design, cities, and the role of democracy in architecture.

Sorkin was the co-president of the Institute for Urban Design and vice- president of the Urban Design Forum in New York.

In 2013, Sorkin was awarded the Design Mind award by the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum.

On March 26, 2020, Sorkin died from COVID-19 in New York City, aged 71.
