[[Mark Blum]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Actors from Newark, New Jersey

Mark Blum (May 14, 1950 – March 25, 2020) was an American actor. He was born in Newark, New Jersey. 

He co-starred in Sweet Surrender in 1987. He also appeared on the following programs; Capital News in 1990, Frasier in 1997, and NYPD Blue in 1999. From 2014 to 2018, he appeared in Mozart in the Jungle.

He won an Obie Award for his performance as Al in the Playwrights Horizons production of Albert Innaurato's play, Gus and Al, during the 1988–1989 season.

In 2018, Blum was cast in a recurring role as Ivan Mooney in the former Lifetime thriller series You.

Blum died at a hospital in New York City on March 25, 2020, from COVID-19 at the age of 69.

[[Analytics]]

CATEGORIES: Statistics

Analytics is the systematic procession of data or statistics. The process of discovering, interpreting, and communicating significant patterns in data to get meaningful information.

In simple language, analytics is turning raw data into useful one for making better decisions. Analytics uses the application of statistics, computer programming, and operations research to gain information from meanings of data.

[[Satish Gujral]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Indian writers, Indian painters, Sculptors

Satish Gujral (25 December 1925 – 26 March 2020) was an Indian painter, sculptor, muralist and writer. His works focused on the post-independent era. 

He was awarded the Padma Vibhushan, the second-highest civilian award of the Republic of India, in 1999. His elder brother, Inder Kumar Gujral, was the Prime Minister of India between 1997 and 1998. 

From 1952 to 1974, Gujral organised shows of his sculptures, paintings and graphics in many cities across the world such as New York City, New Delhi, Montreal, Berlin and Tokyo, among others.

Gujral was  also an architect and his design of the Belgium Embassy in New Delhi.

[[Rade Mihaljčić]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Serbian people, Historians

Rade Mihaljčić (Раде Михаљчић; 21 January 1937 – 26 March 2020) was a Serbian historian and academic. His works deal with medieval Serbia, especially the Serbian empire and the Battle of Kosovo.

[[Curly Neal]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, African-American basketball players, Sportspeople from North Carolina, People from Greensboro, North Carolina, American basketball players

Frederick "Curly" Neal (May 19, 1942 – March 26, 2020) was an American basketball player. He played with the Harlem Globetrotters from 1963 to 1985. Neal became the Trotters' featured ballhandler, a key role in the team's act. Neal was born in Greensboro, North Carolina.

On March 26, 2020, Neal died at his home outside Houston, Texas at the age of 77.

[[Alto Paraguay]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of Paraguay

The Alto Paraguay Department (ˈalto paɾaˈɣwai̯; Upper Paraguay; Departamento de Alto Paraguay) is a department of Paraguay. The capital is the town of Fuerte Olimpo.

[[Boquerón Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of Paraguay

The Boquerón Department (bokeˈɾon; Departamento de Boquerón) is a department in the west of Paraguay. The capital is Filadelfia.

[[Bastani sonnati]]

CATEGORIES: Ice cream, Iranian culture

Bastani sonnati (Persian: بستنی سنتی, also called: "saffron ice cream" or "Flower and

nightingale ice cream") is an Iranian ice cream with a sticky and elastic texture with high fat content similar to mastic ice creams or "Kulfi (Indian ice cream)". This ice cream is made from milk, sweet cream, eggs, sugar, rose water (or "rose leaves"), saffron, vanilla, and pistachios. It is best known as Persian ice cream. Sometimes it is also customary to add to this ice cream: "Salep (orchid powder)" and even a bit of gum like gum ice cream to give it a more sticky and elastic look.

[[Liesbeth List]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch singers, Dutch stage actors, Dutch television personalities

Elisabeth Dorathea List, generally known as Liesbeth List (December 12, 1941 – March 25, 2020) was a Dutch pop singer, stage actress and television personality. List was born in Bandoeng, Dutch East Indies. She became popular during the 1960s and worked with Ramses Shaffy many times. She also sang Jacques Brel's chansons in Dutch translation. In the 1970s, she recorded albums with Charles Aznavour.

List died on March 25, 2020 in Soest, Netherlands at the age of 78.

[[Jimmy Wynn]]

CATEGORIES: Houston Astros players, Los Angeles Dodgers players, Atlanta Braves players, New York Yankees players, Milwaukee Brewers players, African-American baseball players, Sportspeople from Ohio, 1942 births, 2020 deaths

James Sherman Wynn (March 12, 1942 – March 26, 2020), nicknamed "The Toy Cannon", was an American professional baseball player. He had a 15-year career with the Houston Colt .45s / Astros and four other teams. He played as a center fielder. He was born in Hamilton, Ohio. He also played for the Los Angeles Dodgers, Atlanta Braves, New York Yankees and the Milwaukee Brewers.

Wynn died on March 26, 2020 in Houston, Texas at the age of 78.

[[Elyes Fakhfakh]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1972 births, People from Tunis, Prime Ministers of Tunisia

Elyes Fakhfakh (إلياس الفخفاخ; born 1972) is a Tunisian politician. He was the Minister of Tourism and, starting on 19 of December 2012, as the Minister of Finances as well, under Prime Minister Hamadi Jebali. He was the Prime Minister from 28 February 2020 until 2 September 2020.

[[Bensenville, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois, Suburbs of Chicago, Illinois, Settlements in Cook County, Illinois, Settlements in DuPage County, Illinois, 1880s establishments in Illinois, 1884 establishments in the United States

Bensenville is a village in Illinois in the United States. It is near O'Hare International Airport. It is in DuPage County, Illinois, with a part of the town in Cook County.

[[Jean-Louis Bernard]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, French mayors, People from Bourgogne-Franche-Comté

Jean-Louis Bernard (31 March 1938 – 26 March 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the National Assembly of France and represents the Loiret department from 1993 to 2012.  He was a member of the Radical Party. He was the mayor of Orléans from 1988 to 1989. Bernard was born in Saulieu, Côte-d'Or.

Bernard died on 26 March 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Glassdoor]]

CATEGORIES: 2008 establishments in California, American websites, Companies based in California, Marin County, California

Glassdoor is a website where employees review their current or previous company. While reviewing their identity is not disclosed to other people by Glassdoor. The website was launched in 2008.

In 2018, the company was bought by the Japanese firm, Recruit Holdings, for US$1.2 billion. The company is headquartered in Mill Valley, California, with more offices in cities around the world, including Chicago, Dublin, London and São Paulo.

[[Vändåtberget]]

CATEGORIES: Protected areas, Geography of Sweden, 1989 establishments in Sweden

Vändåtberget is a nature reserve in Västernorrland County in Sweden. It is 50 kilometres northwest of the town Örnsköldsvik. The reserve was established in 1989 and has an area of 3.45 km2.

The old-growth forest of Vändåt is a habitat for the highly endangered beetle Pytho kolwensis, in the genus Pytho and the family Pythidae. It is also a habitat for a longhorn beetle, Nothorhina muricata.

The meaning of the name “Vändåt” is not known.

[[Arthur (book series)]]

CATEGORIES: Series of books

Arthur is a book series made by Marc Brown. It's first book was Arthur's Nose, which was made in 1976.

[[Grímsvötn]]

CATEGORIES: Volcanoes of Iceland

Grímsvötn is a volcano in southeast Iceland. It has an elevation of 1725.

Grímsvötn is a basaltic volcano which has the highest eruption frequency of all the volcanoes in Iceland. It has a southwest-northeast-trending fissure system. The massive climate-impacting Laki fissure eruption of 1783–1784 was a part of the same fissure system.

[[Steradian]]

CATEGORIES: SI units

The steradian (symbol: sr) or square radian is an SI unit. It is like a radian, but for smooth 3D objects, for example, a sphere. A steradian is about one twelfth the surface area of a sphere, regardless of how big the sphere is.

[[Lumen (unit)]]

CATEGORIES: SI units

The lumen (symbol: lm) is the SI derived unit for brightness. It is defined as 1 candela times 1 steradian.

One lumen is about a twelfth the brightness of a candle, so a candle has a brightness of around 12 lumens.

[[Postcards from Buster]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s children's television series, 2010s children's television series, Arthur (TV series), PBS Kids shows, Television shows about rabbits and hares, 2004 television series debuts, 2012 television series endings

Postcards from Buster is a 2004 TV show. It first aired on October 11, 2004 on PBS. It is the spin-off of Arthur. It ended on February 20, 2012. The show is about a rabbit that is a child that likes to eat junk food, watch Bionic Bunny, and play video games.

A 2005 episode of Postcards from Buster, called “Sugartime!” was banned because it contained a gay couple said by children Buster was talking to.

Buster is voiced by Daniel Brochu.

[[Directed-energy weapon]]

CATEGORIES: Weapons

A directed-energy weapon is a weapon used from a distance that damages the target with focused energy. Directed-energy weapons could use lasers, microwaves, or particle beams. Directed-energy weapons can be used against personnel, missiles, vehicles, and optical devices.

The author of the books is Christine L'Heureux.

[[Saint Luke Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint Luke is one of Dominica's 10 administrative parishes. The capital city, and only town, is Pointe Michel.

The parish is Dominica's smallest in area and population. 1,668 people live in its 7.77 km² (3 mi²) of area.

[[Saint Mark Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint Mark is one of Dominica's ten administrative parishes. The main settlements in the parish are Soufrière and Scotts Head. Another village in the parish is Galion.

[[USS Abraham Lincoln (CVN-72)]]

The USS Abraham Lincoln (CVN-72) is an aircraft carrier in the American Navy. It is the second ship to have the name Abraham Lincoln. It is also the fifth ship in the Nimitz class line of aircraft carriers.

[[Saint Patrick Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint Patrick is one of Dominica's 10 administrative parishes. Berekua is the capital city. La Plaine is another large town. 

[[Grand Bay, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Dominica, Villages in North America

Grand Bay is a village in the south of Dominica. It is known officially as Berekua or Berricoa. 2,288 people lived in the town in 2010. It is the capital city for St. Patrick Parish.

[[Saint Paul Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint Paul is one of Dominica's 10 administrative parishes. The capital city is Pont Cassé. The largest settlements are Canefield (where the island's second airport is located) and Mahaut.

[[Saint Peter Parish, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Parishes of Dominica

Saint Peter is one of Dominica's 10 administrative parishes. The capital city is Colihaut. Dublanc and Bioche are its only other settlements.

The French name Marigot is given to several places in the Caribbean:

[[Marigot, Dominica]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Dominica, Villages in North America

Marigot  is the largest settlement of Saint Andrew Parish in northeastern Dominica. The village has a population of 2,676 people.

It is home to a Fisheries Complex as well as the island's main airport.

[[Absheron Economic Region]]

CATEGORIES: Economic regions of Azerbaijan

Absheron Economic Region is in the eastern part of the Republic of Azerbaijan. It includes Baku and Sumgait cities, the administrative regions of Absheron and Khizi districts.

Due to the huge oil-gas reserve of the region, Absheron Economic Region is mainly specialized in oil-gas production and relevant areas such as petrochemistry and chemistry.

[[Ganja-Gazakh Economic Region]]

CATEGORIES: Economic regions of Azerbaijan

The Ganja-Gazakh Economic Region is one of ten economic regions in Azerbaijan. It is in the western part of the country. It consists of Agstafa, Dashkesen, Gadabay, Goranboy, Goygol, Gazakh, Samukh, Shamkir, Tovuz administrative districts and cities such as Ganja and Naftalan. 

[[Shaki-Zagatala Economic Region]]

CATEGORIES: Economic regions of Azerbaijan

The Shaki-Zagatala economic-geographical region is one of ten regions in Azerbaijan. The region includes Sheki, Zagatala, Balakan, Oghuz, Gakh and Gabala administrative districts.

It borders Dagestan, Russia, in the north, Georgia (at the Mazim River) to the west, and the Girdiman Valley to the east and south.

[[Lankaran Economic Region]]

CATEGORIES: Economic regions of Azerbaijan

Lankaran economic region or Lankaran is one of the ten economic regions of Azerbaijan. 

Lankaran-Astara economic region includes 6 administrative districts – Astara, Jalilabad, Lerik, Lankaran, Masally and Yardimli. The economic region has 8 cities, 6 districts 13 settlements and 642 villages.

[[Guba-Khachmaz economic region]]

CATEGORIES: Economic regions of Azerbaijan

The Guba-Khachmaz economic region is one of ten regions of Azerbaijan. It is to the north of the Absheron Peninsula, between the shores of the Caspian Sea and the Greater Caucasus mountains. 

Administrative districts of the economic region include Shabran, Khachmaz, Guba, Gusar, and Siyazan.

CATEGORIES: Economic regions of Azerbaijan

[[Mountainous Shirvan economic region]]

CATEGORIES: Economic regions of Azerbaijan

The Mountainous Shirvan Economic Region is one of ten economic regions in Azerbaijan. The region includes the Agsu, Ismaili, Gobustan, and the Shemakha regional administrative districts.

[[Stevo Pendarovski]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Current national leaders, Presidents of North Macedonia

Stevo Pendarovski (Стево Пендаровски; born 3 April 1963) is a Macedonian politician. He is serving as the President of North Macedonia since 12 May 2019.

[[President of North Macedonia]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of North Macedonia

The president of the Republic of North Macedonia (Претседател на Република Северна Македонија; is the head of state of North Macedonia. The presidency of the modern North Macedonia state began after the Macedonian declaration of independence on 8 September 1991. 

Its first president was Kiro Gligorov, the oldest president in the world until his resignation in 1999. 

North Macedonia's presidency is largely a ceremonial post and the prime minister of North Macedonia is the country's main political figure.

The president must be a citizen of North Macedonia, be over 40 years of age and have lived in North Macedonia for at least ten of the last fifteen years.

[[Kiro Gligorov]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2012 deaths, Presidents of North Macedonia

Kiro Gligorov (Киро Глигоров, ˈkirɔ ˈɡliɡɔrɔf; May 3, 1917 – January 1, 2012) was the first President of the Republic of Macedonia from 1991 to 1999.

[[Stojan Andov]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, Presidents of North Macedonia

Stojan Andov (Стојан Андов; born 30 November 1935) is a Macedonian politician. He is a founding member of the Liberal Party of Macedonia. He was a president of Parliament from 1993 to 1997. From October to November 1995, he was Acting President of North Macedonia.

[[Boris Trajkovski]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2004 deaths, Aviation deaths, Presidents of North Macedonia

Boris Trajkovski GCMG (Борис Трајковски ˈbɔris ˈtrajkɔfski; 25 June 1956 – 26 February 2004) was a Macedonian politician who was the president and Supreme Commander of the Republic of Macedonia from 1999 to 2004. He died in a plane crash.

[[Ljupčo Jordanovski]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2010 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Legislative speakers, Ambassadors, Presidents of North Macedonia

Ljupčo Jordanovski (Љупчо Јордановски, ʎupt͡ʃɔ jɔrdanɔfski; 13 February 1953 – 7 October 2010) was a Macedonian seismologist and politician. He was a member of the Social Democratic Union of Macedonia party. He took office as Speaker of the Assembly on 18 November 2003. When President Boris Trajkovski was killed in a plane crash on 26 February 2004, Jordanovski was sworn in as Acting President.

[[Branko Crvenkovski]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, Living people, Presidents of North Macedonia, Prime Ministers of North Macedonia

Branko Crvenkovski (Бранко Црвенковски ˈbraŋkɔ tsr̩ˈvɛŋkɔfski; born 12 October 1962) is a Macedonian politician. He was Prime Minister of Macedonia from 1992 to 1998 and again from 2002 to 2004, and as President of Macedonia from 2004 to 2009. He decided not to run for re-election in 2009. Crvenkovski was also leader of the Social Democratic Union of Macedonia.

[[Gjorge Ivanov]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Presidents of North Macedonia

Gjorge Ivanov (Ѓорге Иванов, ˈɟɔrɡɛ ˈivanɔf; born 2 May 1960) is a Macedonian politician. He was President of North Macedonia from 2009 to 2019.

In March 2016 Ivanov stated that the European Union had failed the Republic of Macedonia and other Balkan countries in the European migrant crisis.

[[Oliver Spasovski]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of North Macedonia

Oliver Spasovski (Оливер Спасовски; born 21 October 1976) is a Macedonian politician. He was the Prime Minister of North Macedonia.

Until 3 January 2020, Spasovski was Minister of Internal Affairs. 

He is general secretary of the Social Democratic Union of Macedonia (SDSM). 

[[Thelma Todd]]

CATEGORIES: 1906 births, 1935 deaths, Deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning, Unexplained deaths, American silent movie actors, Businesspeople from Massachusetts, Actors from Massachusetts, People from Lawrence, Massachusetts

Thelma Alice Todd (July 29, 1906 – December 16, 1935) was an American actress and businesswoman. She was known as "The Ice Cream Blonde", also "Hot Toddy". Todd was born in Lawrence, Massachusetts.

Todd was in 120 feature movies and shorts  between 1926 and 1935. She is best remembered for her comedic roles in movies such as Marx Brothers' Monkey Business and  Horse Feathers. She co-starred with Buster Keaton and Jimmy Durante in Speak Easily. She also had roles in many  Wheeler and Woolsey and Laurel and Hardy movies.

Todd was found dead on December 16, 1935 in her car at her Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles garage. She was 29 years old. Her death was caused by carbon monoxide poisoning, however it is unknown if she was murdered or if it was a suicide.

[[Carbon monoxide poisoning]]

CATEGORIES: Poisons

Carbon monoxide poisoning happens from breathing in carbon monoxide (CO) at large levels. 

Symptoms are often described as "flu-like" and commonly include headache, dizziness, weakness, vomiting, chest pain, and confusion. Large exposures can result in loss of consciousness, arrhythmias, seizures, or death.

Carbon monoxide poisoning can be accidental, like if the oven's gas is left on by accident or a gas leak. However, it can often be used as a suicide method such as keeping the car on while in a closed garage.

[[Dizziness]]

CATEGORIES: Medical signs

Dizziness is a disability in spatial perception and stability. The term dizziness is not specific: it can mean vertigo, presyncope, disequilibrium, or a non-specific feeling such as being drunk or funny.

Dizziness is a common medical complaint, affecting 20-30% of persons. 

Dizziness is broken down into 4 main subtypes: vertigo (~25-50%), disequilibrium (less than ~15%), presyncope (less than ~15%) and nonspecific dizziness (~10%).

[[John L. Pickitt]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, American generals, Military people from Texas

John L. Pickitt (July 30, 1933 – March 14, 2020) was an American lieutenant general in the United States Air Force. He was director of the Defense Nuclear Agency from 1985 to 1987. He attended the United States Military Academy. He was born in Teague, Texas.

Pickitt died on March 14, 2020 2020 in Charlotte, North Carolina at the age of 86.

[[Teague, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Teague is a city in Freestone County, Texas, United States. The population was 3,560 at the 2010 census.

[[Henri Richelet]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, French painters, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France

Henri Richelet (16 June 1944–18 March 2020), was a French painter. Inspired by the tradition of Caravaggio, or of Georges de La Tour in his Saint Jérôme pénitent. He used dark backgrounds to make livid and pallid flesh of tense, hunched up bodies stand out.

During the 2020 coronavirus pandemic, he died of COVID-19 on 18 March 2020 in Paris, aged 75.

[[Harry Aarts]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Catholic People's Party politicians, Christian Democratic Appeal politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, Dutch Roman Catholics, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, People from 's-Hertogenbosch, Politicians from North Brabant

Henricus Johannes Bernardus "Harry" Aarts (9 March 1930 – 25 March 2020) was a Dutch politician. He was in the House of Representatives for the Catholic People's Party and later the Christian Democratic Appeal from 23 January 1973 until 1 October 1993. Aarts was born in 's-Hertogenbosch, Netherlands.

Aarts died of COVID-19 on 25 March 2020 in Tilburg, Netherlands, aged 90.

[[Joseph Lowery]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, American civil rights activists, American LGBT rights activists, Writers from Huntsville, Alabama, Writers from Atlanta, Georgia, Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients

Joseph Echols Lowery (October 6, 1921 – March 27, 2020) was an American minister in the United Methodist Church and leader in the Civil Rights Movement. He later became the third president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, after Martin Luther King Jr.. He was president from 1977 to 1997. He was born in Huntsville, Alabama. In 2009, President Barack Obama honored him with the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

Lowery died on March 27, 2020 in Atlanta, Georgia at the age of 98.

[[MaryAnn Black]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, African American politicians, Cancer deaths in North Carolina, People from Manhattan, Politicians from New York City, Politicians from North Carolina, US Democratic Party politicians

MaryAnn Eaddy Black (October 3, 1943 – March 25, 2020) was an American clinical social worker and politician. She was a Democrat. She served as a member of the North Carolina House of Representatives from 2017 until her death in 2020. She was born in Manhattan, New York City.

Black died of cancer in Durham, North Carolina on March 25, 2020. She was 76.

[[Naomi Munakata]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, People from Hiroshima, Brazilian musicians, Japanese musicians, Composers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil

Naomi Munakata was a Japanese-born Brazilian conductor. 

Munakata was born in Hiroshima, Japan, and her parents emigrated to Brazil when she was very young. Her work was set in the city of São Paulo. She was director of the Municipal School of Music of São Paulo, and conductor and artistic director of the State Youth Choir. She directed the Osesp Choir for two decades, and ran a radio program. Her last position was as principal conductor of Coral Paulistano Mário de Andrade.

She was hospitalized on 16 March 2020 at the Hospital Alemão Oswaldo Cruz with symptoms of COVID-19. She died on 26 March 2020 at age 64.

[[Bob Andy]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Jamaican singers, Reggae musicians, Movie actors, Songwriters

[[Mirna Doris]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Deaths from heart failure, Deaths from diabetes, People from Naples, Pop singers, Italian singers, 2020 deaths

Mirna Doris (28 September 1940 – 27 March 2020) was an Italian Canzone Napoletana singer. She was mainly successful in the second half of the 1960s. Doris was born in Naples. Between 1963 and 1970 Doris entered the main competition at the Festival di Napoli, winning the competition in 1968 and in 1969 with the songs "Core spezzato" and "Preghiera a 'na mamma".

Doris died in Naples on 27 March 2020 of heart failure caused by diabetes, aged 79.

[[Les Hunter (basketball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in the United States, Washington Wizards players, New York Yankees players, Sportspeople from Nashville, Tennessee

Leslie "Big Game" Hunter (August 16, 1942 – March 27, 2020) was an American professional basketball player. He was born in Nashville, Tennessee.

Hunter played professionally in the  National Basketball Association (NBA) and the American Basketball Association (ABA). Hunter was a two-time ABA All-Star. He played for the Baltimore Bullets from 1964 to 1965, Minnesota Muskies/Miami Floridians from 1967 to 1969, New York Yankees from 1969 to 1970, Kentucky Colonels from 1970 to 1972, and for Memphis Sounds from 1972 to 1973.

Hunter died on March 27, 2020 of cancer at the age of 77.

[[John O'Leary (golfer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Golfers, Sportspeople from Dublin

John Eudes O'Leary (18 August 1949 – 26 March 2020) was an Irish professional golfer. He played on the European Tour through the 1970s and 1980s. He was born in Dublin.

In 1976 he won his first European Tour event, the Greater Manchester Open, and in 1982 he became only the third Irishman to win the Irish Open. He played in a number of team competitions, representing Great Britain and Ireland in the 1975 Ryder Cup. He played for Ireland three times in the World Cup.

After retiring as a tournament golfer he was an active administrator, being a director of the European Tour from 1985 to 2019 and being on the Ryder Cup committee.

O'Leary died on 26 March 2020 in Esher, Surrey, England at the age of 70.

[[John Sears (political strategist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American lawyers, Richard Nixon, American political commentators, Writers from New York, People from Syracuse, New York

John Patrick Sears (July 3, 1940 – March 26, 2020) was an American attorney and a Republican political strategist. He was Deputy Counsel to President Richard M. Nixon from 1969 to 1970. He assisted both Nixon and Ronald Reagan in their presidential campaigns. He was born in Syracuse, New York. Some people believed that he was Deep Throat during the Watergate Scandal.

Sears died of a heart attack on March 26, 2020 in Miami, Florida at the age of 79.

[[William Colby]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 1996 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in the United States, Directors of the Central Intelligence Agency, Politicians from Saint Paul, Minnesota

William Egan Colby (January 4, 1920 – April 27, 1996) was an American intelligence officer. He was Director of Central Intelligence (DCI) from September 1973 to January 1976.

Colby was DCI under President Richard Nixon and President Gerald Ford until January 30, 1976 after which time he was replaced by George H. W. Bush.

Colby died on April 27, 1996 died from a stroke or a heart attack while canoeing in Rock Point, Maryland at the age of 76.

[[Rock Point, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Maryland, Census-designated places in Maryland

Rock Point is an unincorporated community and census-designated place located near Cobb Island at the mouth of the Wicomico River in Charles County, Maryland, United States. As of the 2010 census, it had a population of 107.

[[Charles County, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Maryland counties

Charles County is located in the southern central portion of the U.S. state of Maryland. As of the 2010 census, the population was 146,551. The county seat is La Plata.

[[UEFA European Championship]]

CATEGORIES: UEFA European Championship

The UEFA European Football Championship, commonly known as the UEFA European Championship and as the Euros, is the main association football competition played by the senior men's national teams of the members of the Union of European Football Associations (UEFA). It has been held every four years since 1960, in the even-numbered year between FIFA World Cup tournaments. It was first called the European Nations' Cup. It changed to the current name in 1968.

Italy are the current European champions after winning the 2020 tournament.

[[Nancy Carell]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Living people, Actors from Massachusetts, American movie actors, American television actors, American television producers, American television writers, Comedians from Massachusetts, Screenwriters from Massachusetts

Nancy Ellen Carell (née Walls; born July 19, 1966) is an American actress, comedian and writer. She is best known for her work on Saturday Night Live, The Daily Show and The Office. In 2016, she co-created the TBS comedy series Angie Tribeca with her husband, Steve Carell.

In 1995, she married Steve Carell.

[[Fabio Lanzoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, Actors from Milan, American models, American movie actors, American television actors, Italian models, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States

Fabio Lanzoni (born 15 March 1959), known simply as Fabio, is an Italian-American actor, fashion model and spokesperson. He is for known his appearances as spokesman for I Can't Believe It's Not Butter! and the American Cancer Society. He was also a romance novel cover model throughout the 1980s and 1990s. His acting credits include the movies Death Becomes Her (1992), Eddie (1996), Dude, Where's My Car? (2000) and Zoolander (2001).

Lanzoni was born in Milan, Lombardy. He became a citizen of the United States in 2016.

[[Anna Dewdney]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, 2016 deaths, American children's writers, Artists from New York City, Cancer deaths in Vermont, Deaths from brain cancer, People from Englewood, New Jersey, Writers from New Jersey, Writers from New York City

Anna Elizabeth Dewdney (née Luhrmann; December 25, 1965 – September 3, 2016) was an American author and illustrator of children's books. The first book she wrote and illustrated, Llama Llama Red Pajama (2005), was given positive reviews. She also wrote many other books in the Llama Llama series. Her works have been made into stage plays, dance performances, musicals and an animated television series for Netflix.

Dewdney was born in New York City. She spent her early childhood in Englewood, New Jersey. She had two children with her partner, Reed Duncan. 

On September 3, 2016, Dewdney died of brain cancer in Chester, Vermont. She was 50.

[[Anthony Mason (judge)]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, Living people, Australian judges, Chief justices, People from Sydney, Knights and Dames Commander of the Order of the British Empire, Order of Australia

Sir Anthony Frank Mason AC KBE QC (born 21 April 1925) is an Australian judge. He served as the ninth Chief Justice of Australia, in office from 1987 to 1995. He became a justice of the High Court of Australia in 1972. He was born in Sydney, New South Wales.

[[Geometric mean]]

CATEGORIES: Arithmetics

The geometric mean is a number, which is used to represent a set of numbers. It is calculated by taking the n-th root of the product of these numbers. What most people refer to when they talk about mean or average is the arithmetic mean. The geometric mean is almost always smaller than the arithmetic mean. In some cases, it is equal. The geometric mean is often used in finance and in statistics.

Because there's a product, it does not make sense to calculate the geometric mean if one of the numbers is zero. It generally also does not make much sense to calculate it when one of them is a negative number. It isn't used for complex numbers, because calculating the root of a complex number has more than one result.

[[Jimmi Simpson]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, Actors from New Jersey, American movie actors, American television actors

James Raymond Simpson (born November 21, 1975) is an American actor. He is best known for his roles in television series such as It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, The Late Show with David Letterman, Psych, Breakout Kings, House of Cards, Hap and Leonard, Westworld, Black Mirror and Unsolved. His movie credits include Loser (2000), Herbie: Fully Loaded (2005), Zodiac (2007), The Invention of Lying (2009), Date Night (2010), Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter (2012), White House Down (2013) and Under the Silver Lake (2018).

Simpson was born in Hackettstown, New Jersey. He was married to New Zealand actress Melanie Lynskey from 2007 to 2014. He married British actress Sophia Del Pizzo in 2019.

[[Mongar District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Bhutan

Mongar District is one of the 20 districts in Bhutan. The administrative centre is Mongar.

Mongar is noted for its lemon grass, a plant that can be used to produce an essential oil. It also has a hydroelectric power-plant on the Kuri Chhu river. Parts of both the Thrumshingla National Park and Bumdeling Wildlife Sanctuary are in the district.

[[Mastic ice creams]]

CATEGORIES: Mastic ice creams

Mastic ice creams (resin based ice cream) is popularly termed for stretchy and sticky textured ice cream, named after the spice - "Mastic (Pistacia lentiscus resin)". These ice creams are based on of Salep or cornflower, rose water, and the "Mastic resin" that contributes to the texture (as opposed to the texture of other ice creams that have a more airy texture) and are commonly used in Middle Eastern cuisine. Today, due to the very high price of the gum spice and the difficulty of obtaining it, there are ice cream sellers who usually replace it with glucose or other ice cream conducive to appear as a sticky dish.

[[Definite description]]

CATEGORIES: Logic

In logic, a definite description is a term of the form 'the ...'. It is used to describe something. This is more difficult than it first appears, because:

Unfortunately, language allows to construct sentences, where the thing or person talked about is not unique, or it doesn't exist

Definite descriptions are called 'empty', if they violate one of the conditons above:  Bertrand Russell used the sentence "The present king of Freance is bald.".  When Russel wrote this, in the early 20th century, France was a republic, and had no king. 

Other famous  mathematicians who wrote about it include  Gottlob Frege, and Peter Strawson.

[[Multibrot set]]

CATEGORIES: Fractals

In mathematics, the multibrot set is a set of numbers. These numbers are in the complex plane. These numbers have special traits that and are defined by a special function. The Multibrot set is similar to the Mandelbrot set. Other things similar to the multibrot set are the Buddhabrot set and the Nebulabrot set.

[[Beni Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of Bolivia, 1840s establishments in South America, 1842 establishments

Beni is a department in Bolivia. The capital city is Trinidad.

The department is mainly covered by rainforest and pampa. In the region's many rivers over 400 species of fish have been found. Trinidad has an entire museum, the Museo Ictícola, dedicated to Beni's fish fauna. It is the third largest of its type in South America.

[[Chuquisaca Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of Bolivia

Chuquisaca is a department in Bolivia. The capital city is Sucre, which is also the capital of Bolivia.

El Palmar Integrated Management Natural Area is in the department.

[[Roberto Alemann]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine academics, Argentine journalists, Argentine politicians, Argentine economists, Argentine lawyers, People from Buenos Aires

Roberto Teodoro Alemann (22 December 1922 – 27 March 2020) was an Argentine lawyer, economist, politician, writer and academic. He served twice as Argentina's Minister of the Economy from 1961 to 1962 and from 1981 to 1982. He was born in Buenos Aires.

On 27 March 2020, Alemann died in Buenos Aires at the age of 97.

[[Edoardo Vesentini]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Italian academics, Italian mathematicians, Politicians from Rome

Edoardo Vesentini (31 May 1928 – 28 March 2020) was an Italian mathematician and politician. He helped introduce the Andreotti–Vesentini theorem. He was awarded the Caccioppoli Prize in 1962. He was the director of the Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa from 1978 to 1987. He also served as a Senator between 1987 and 1992. He was born in Rome.

Vasentini died in Pisa on 28 March 2020. He was 91.

[[Thomas Schäfer]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2020 deaths, People from Hesse, Politicians of the Christian Democratic Union of Germany, Politicians who committed suicide, Suicides in Germany

Thomas Schäfer (22 February 1966 – 28 March 2020) was a German politician. He was a member of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). He served as the Minister of Finance of Hesse between 2010 and 2020. He  was born in Hemer and grew up in Biedenkopf.

On 28 March 2020, Schäfer was found dead at a railway line near Hochheim am Main. Police ruled his death a suicide. He was 54.

[[John Eriksson (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish football managers, Sportspeople from Stockholm, Swedish footballers

John Rune "Jompa" Eriksson (12 March 1929 – 24 March 2020) was a Swedish footballer and manager. He played as a forward.

Eriksson was born in Stockholm. He played club football for Värtans IK, Djurgårdens IF and Vällingby AIK. With Djurgården, he won the Allsvenskan in 1954–55 and 1959. He also made ten appearances for the Swedish national team.

Eriksson died on 24 March 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Matthew Faber]]

CATEGORIES: American movie actors, American television actors, 2020 deaths, 1973 births

Matthew Faber (January 31, 1973 – March 28, 2020) was an American actor. He was best known for his roles in movie and television series such as Welcome to the Dollhouse, Natural Born Killers, Law & Order  and Palindromes.

Faber died at his apartment in Van Nuys, California on March 28, 2020, at the age of 47.

[[John Callahan (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, American television actors, Deaths from stroke, 2020 deaths, Actors from Brooklyn

John Kevin Callahan (December 23, 1953 – March 28, 2020) was an American actor. He was known for his work as Edmund Grey on the daytime soap opera All My Children. He was born in Brooklyn, New York. Callahan portrayed Leo Russell on the daytime soap General Hospital from 1984 to 1985, then as Eric Stavros on the prime time series Falcon Crest from 1986 to 1988, and Craig Hunt on the daytime soap Santa Barbara from 1989 to 1991.

Callahan died on March 28, 2020 in Rancho Mirage, California from a stroke, aged 66.

[[Mohammad Alavi Tabar]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Iran, Iranian politicians

Mohammad Alavi Tabar (محمد علوی‌تبار, 1930–10 March 2020), also known as Kiyavash, was an Iranian politician. He was born in Zanjan. In August 1978, he took part in torching Abadan's Cinema Rex, killing at least 420 people. Tabar was a member of the Iranian Parliament representing Ahvaz between 1980 and 1984, representing Abadan between 1984 and 1988.

Tabar died from COVID-19 on 10 March 2020 in Tehran, aged 89–90.

[[Joe Baltake]]

CATEGORIES: People from Camden, New Jersey, Writers from New Jersey, American movie critics, American historians, Deaths from multiple myeloma, Cancer deaths in New Jersey, 2020 deaths, 1945 births

Joseph John Baltake Jr. (September 16, 1945 – March 26, 2020) was an American movie critic, movie historian, author of the movie blog The Passionate Moviegoer. His work has been seen on Knight-Ridder, Scripps Howard News Service, and the McClatchy wire services. Baltake was born in Camden, New Jersey.

Baltake died of multiple myeloma on March 26, 2020 in Haddonfield, New Jersey at the age of 74.

[[Haddonfield, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey

Haddonfield is a borough located in Camden County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the borough had a total population of 11,593.

[[Princess María Teresa of Bourbon-Parma]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish royalty, Writers from Paris, Writers from Madrid

Princess Maria Teresa of Bourbon-Parma (28 July 1933 – 26 March 2020) was a member of a cadet branch of the Spanish royal family. She was a socialism activist. She earned the nickname "Red Princess", and a monarchist who supported the Carlist movement. 

In the 1960s and 1970s, Maria Teresa supported her brother, Carlos Hugo, in his fight to make the Spanish Carlist party more liberal. She was supportive of André Malraux, François Mitterrand, Yasser Arafat and Hugo Chávez.

Maria Teresa died in Paris on 26 March 2020 of COVID-19, aged 86. She is the first royal to have died from the pandemic. Her funeral took place on 27 August 2021 at Basilica di Santa Maria della Steccata in Parma.

[[Martinho Lutero Galati]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Brazilian writers, Conductors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil

Martinho Lutero Galati de Oliveira (29 September 1953 – 26 March 2020) was a Brazilian conductor. He was born in Alpercata, Brazil. 

Galati wrote the book Do gesture à gestão: um diálogo sobre maestros e liderança. He was director of the Coral Paulistano do Theatro Municipal de São Paulo from 2013 to 2016. He was elected president of the Associação Brasileira de Regentes Corais in 2018. He was a professor at the Free University of Languages and Communication and at the Institute of Musicology of Milan.

Galati died on 26 March 2020 from COVID-19 in São Paulo, aged 66.

[[Joan Didion]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, American novelists, American political writers, American essayists, American critics, Writers from Sacramento, California

Joan Didion (ˈ; born December 5, 1934) is an American writer. She was born in Sacramento, California. In the 1960s, she released a collection of essays titled Slouching Towards Bethlehem (1968). In 1970, she released Play It as It Lays.

In 1991, she wrote the earliest mainstream media article to suggest the Central Park Five had been wrongfully convicted.

In 2005, she won the National Book Award for Nonfiction and was a finalist for both the National Book Critics Circle Award and the Pulitzer Prize for Biography/Autobiography for The Year of Magical Thinking. 

In 2017, a Netflix documentary about her career, The Center Will Not Hold, was released.

[[Central Park jogger case]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 in the United States, 1980s crimes in the United States, 1980s in New York (state), 20th century in Manhattan, April events, Crime in New York, Rape

The Central Park jogger case was a criminal case in the United States based on the assault and rape of Trisha Meili, a 28-year-old white woman who was jogging in the park, and attacks on eight other people, in areas ranging from the North Woods to the Reservoir of Manhattan's Central Park, on the night of April 19, 1989. 

Three of the victims were black or Latino. Meili was so badly injured that she was in a coma for 12 days. 

The New York Times in 1990 described the attack on her as "one of the most widely publicized crimes of the 1980s".

This case is also called the Central Park Five case because of the five suspects accused of rape. The Central Park jogger case famous because it reflects how racial minorities are treated unfairly in the American legal system.

[[Catholic Archdiocese of Boston sex abuse scandal]]

CATEGORIES: 2002 in the United States, 21st century in Boston, Massachusetts, Roman Catholics

The Catholic Archdiocese of Boston sex abuse scandal was part of many cases of Catholic Church sexual abuse cases in the United States that revealed many crimes in the American Roman Catholic Church. 

In early 2002, The Boston Globe published results of an investigation that led to the criminal prosecutions of five Roman Catholic priests and pushed the sexual abuse of minors by Catholic clergy into the national spotlight. 

Another accused priest who was involved in the Spotlight scandal also pleaded guilty. The Globe's coverage encouraged other victims to come forward with allegations of abuse, resulting in numerous lawsuits and more criminal cases.

Later investigations and allegations revealed a pattern of sexual abuse and cover-ups in a number of large dioceses across the United States.

The investigation of the scandal by The Boston Globe was titled "Spotlight Investigation: Abuse in the Catholic Church". Its reporting was made into a movie in 2015, which won two Academy Awards including Best Picture.

[[Notre Dame College, Dhaka]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in Asia, Schools in Bangladesh, Dhaka, 20th century establishments in Bangladesh, 1949 establishments in Asia

Notre Dame College (নটর ডেম কলেজ) is a Catholic higher secondary school as well as a degree college,  in Dhaka. A society of priests named Congregation of Holy Cross started it in 1949. According to the result of HSC exam, it is one of the best colleges of Bangladesh.

[[Patrick Devedjian]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, French mayors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France

Patrick Devedjian (Պատրիկ Դևեջյան; 26 August 1944 – 29 March 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the Union for a Popular Movement (UMP) party. He was a close adviser of Nicolas Sarkozy, starting in the 1990s. 

From 1983 to 2002, he was Mayor of Antony. He was Minister under the Prime Minister in charge of the Implementation of the Recovery Plan beginning in December 2008. In 2007, Devedjian became President of the General Council of Hauts-de-Seine.

Devedjian was born in Fontainebleau, Seine-et-Marne. He died on 29 March 2020 of COVID-19 in Antony, aged 75.

[[Sergiy Vilkomir]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American computer scientists, Ukrainian scientists, Scientists from North Carolina

Sergiy A. Vilkomir (born November 19, 1956) is a Ukrainian-born American computer scientist. His career focused in software testing.

He worked at the Ukrainian Polytechnic Institute (1979–82), the Central Institute of Complex Automation (1985–91), the Institute of Safety and Reliability of Technological Systems (1992–93), the Ukrainian State Scientific and Technical Centre on Nuclear and Radiation Safety (part of the Nuclear Safety Regulatory Authority of Ukraine, 1993–2000).

In 2000, Vilkomir moved to the Centre for Applied Formal Methods at London South Bank University, becoming a Research Fellow there. He then joined the University of Wollongong in Australia, also as a Research Fellow.

He was a Research Associate Professor and the University of Tennessee during 2007–8. Later becoming an associate professor position at East Carolina University, which he joined in 2008.

[[Rennes School of Business]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in France, 1990 establishments in Europe, Education in France, Rennes

Rennes School of Business is an European higher studies establishment. The school is in Rennes, France. It has been established in 1990. 

Rennes SB is specialist in the fields of economics, social sciences and management.

[[Delocalized electron]]

CATEGORIES: Chemical bonding

In chemistry, a delocalized electron is an electron in a molecule, ion or solid metal that is not associated with a single atom or a covalent bond.

The term delocalization is general and can have slightly different meanings in different fields.

[[Lou Whittaker]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Businesspeople from Seattle, Washington, Sportspeople from Seattle, Washington, Writers from Seattle, Washington, Twin people from the United States, Living people

Lou Whittaker (born February 10, 1929) is an American mountaineer, mountain guide, and businessman. He and his twin brother, Jim Whittaker are known mountain climbers.

Known for his mountain climbing experience, Whittaker became the most experienced glacier-travel guide by climbing Mount Rainier with over 250 summits.  He created Rainier Mountaineering, developed a group of successful climbing-related businesses. He also led the first American ascent of the North Col of Mount Everest in 1984.

He has also written about his experiences in Lou Whittaker - Memoirs of a Mountain Guide.

== References == 

[[Enrique del Portal]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from influenza, Accidental deaths from falls, Spanish stage actors, Spanish singers, Actors from Madrid, Tenors

Enrique Ruiz del Portal González (3 July 1932 – 20 March 2020) was a Spanish tenor and actor. He was born in Madrid. His career began in 1959 in Teatro de la Zarzuela. He retired in 2014.

He played the role of Caramello in Carnival in Venice. He also played Cardona in Doña Francisquita, Governor in Don Gil de Alcalá, Espejo in Chorizos y Poles, Españita and Ansúrez in different productions of La patria chica, Atenedoro in La revoltosa and Intendente in El rey que rabió. 

On 5 March 2020, Portal suffered a fall at his home in Madrid. He was unable to be hospitalized due to the coronavirus pandemic. His health got worse and died on 20 March from gastroenteritis, aged 87.

[[Bill Anderson (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, American singer-songwriters, American television personalities, American radio personalities, American country singers, American country musicians, American guitarists, Singers from South Carolina, Musicians from South Carolina, Writers from South Carolina, Singers from Nashville, Tennessee, Writers from Nashville, Tennessee, Musicians from Nashville, Tennessee, People from Columbia, South Carolina

James William Anderson III (born November 1, 1937), known as Whisperin’ Bill Anderson, is an American country music singer-songwriter and television personality. He has been a member of the weekly Grand Ole Opry radio program and stage performance in Nashville, Tennessee, beginning in 1961.

He has released more than 40 studio albums and has reached No. 1 on the country charts seven times: "Mama Sang a Song" (1962), "Still" (1963), "I Get the Fever" (1966), "For Loving You" (with Jan Howard, 1967), "My Life (Throw It Away If I Want To)" (1969), "World of Make Believe" (1973), and "Sometimes" (with Mary Lou Turner, 1976). 

In 2018, Anderson was added into the Songwriters Hall of Fame.

In June 2019, The New York Times listed Anderson among hundreds of artists whose material was destroyed in the 2008 Universal Studios fire.

[[2008 Universal Studios fire]]

CATEGORIES: 2008 in the United States, 2000s disasters in North America, 2000s fires, 2000s in Los Angeles, California, Building and structure fires in the United States, June events

On June 1, 2008, a fire broke out on the backlot of Universal Studios Hollywood, an American movie studio and theme park in the San Fernando Valley area of Los Angeles County, California, United States. 

The fire began when a worker used a blowtorch to warm shingles. He left before checking that all spots had cooled, and a three-alarm fire broke out. 

Nine firefighters and a Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy sustained minor injuries. The fire ended after 12 hours.

Universal Pictures said that the fire destroyed a three-acre (3) portion of the Universal backlot, including the ride King Kong Encounter and 40,000 to 50,000 archived digital video and movie copies. 

A 2019 New York Times article said that the fire also destroyed 118,000 to 175,000 audio master tapes belonging to Universal Music Group (UMG). This included original recordings belonging to some of the best-selling artists worldwide.

[[Sergei Sokurov]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, Russian writers, Russian novelists

Sergei Sokurov  (Сергей Анатольевич Сокуров, born 9 April 1940) is a Russian writer and journalist.

Sergey  Anatolyevich Sokurov was born in Siberia on 9 of April in 1940, his parents were teachers. He graduated from the Lvov State University, 30 years worked as a geologist in the Carpathian region. At the same time he wrote works of fiction, poetry and journalism, which  were included in 29 of his books published in Lviv and Moscow in 1975 – 2019. The main of them are “Stone Sea”, “Sign of the pure sun”,  “Black hussar”, “Istoriada”.

His works also  were  published in the newspapers  “Izvestia”, “Literary newspaper”, “Soviet culture”, “The New Medical Gazette”  and in magazines “Young Naturalist”, “Chemistry and life”, “Bratina”.

Sokurov is a member of the Union of Russian writers. He was the founder of the Russian society named after A. Pushkin in the Carpathians, the Russian cultural center in Lviv.

Now Sokurov lives near Moscow.

[[Charlie Tahan]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 births, Living people, Actors from New Jersey, American child actors, American movie actors, American television actors

Charles Tahan (born June 11, 1998) is an American actor. His notable TV roles include Wyatt Langmore in the Netflix crime drama Ozark (2017–present), Ben Burke in the Fox dystopian mystery thriller Wayward Pines (2015–2016) and the young Jonathan Crane / Scarecrow in the Fox/DC Comics superhero drama Gotham (2014–2017). His movie credits include Charlie St. Cloud (2010), Frankenweenie (2012) and Blue Jasmine (2013).

Tahan was born in Glen Rock, New Jersey. His sister is actress Daisy Tahan.

[[Alan Merrill]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Actors from the Bronx, American pop singers, American rock guitarists, American rock singers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Models from the Bronx, Musicians from the Bronx, Singer-songwriters from New York City, Writers from the Bronx

Alan Merrill (born Allan Preston Sachs; February 19, 1951 – March 29, 2020) was an American singer, guitarist, songwriter, actor and model. In the early 1970s, he became was the first westerner to become a pop star in Japan. He was the lead singer of the first ever released version and writer of the song "I Love Rock 'n' Roll" by the Arrows in 1975.

Merrill was born in the Bronx, New York City. His parents were jazz musicians, singer Helen Merrill and saxophone and clarinet player Aaron Sachs.

On March 29, 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Merrill died due to COVID-19 in Manhattan. He was 69.

[[José Luis Capón]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Madrid, Spanish footballers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain

José Luis Capón González (6 February 1948 – 29 March 2020) was a Spanish footballer. He was born in Madrid. He played for Atlético Madrid between 1970 and 1980. He won the Spanish League in 1973 and 1977. He played in the European Cup Final in 1974, which Atlético lost. From 1973 to 1977, he played for the national team.

During the coronavirus pandemic, Capón died of COVID-19 on 29 March 2020 at the age of 72.

[[Chato Galante]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish politicians, Political activists, Human rights activists, Communists, Writers from Madrid

José María Galante Serrano (1948 – 28 March 2020) was a Spanish political prisoner and human rights activist. He was born in Madrid. 

In 1969, he was arrested by the Franco regime-dictated Political-Social Brigade and was tortured at Puerta del Sol. After joining the Revolutionary Communist League (RCL), Galante was arrested again in 1971. He was released in 1977 after the amnesty law that freed all Franco-era political prisoners. 

In 1979 and 1983, he unsuccessfully ran for the Madrid local elections under the RCL. 

In 2018, he was part of a Spanish documentary titled El silencio de otros, which was about the Franco regime. It was shortlisted for the Academy Awards.

During the coronavirus pandemic, Galante died on 28 March 2020 in Madrid of COVID-19.

[[Glen Rock, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey

Glen Rock is a borough in Bergen County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 census, the borough had a population of 11,601.

[[Hackettstown, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New Jersey

Hackettstown is a town in Warren County, New Jersey in the United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the town's population was 9,724. The town is located in the eastern region of the Lehigh Valley.

It is believed that Hackettstown was named after Samuel Hackett, an early settler and large landowner. 

Hackettstown was named #72 of the top 100 towns in the United States to Live and Work In by Money Magazine in 2005.

[[Warren County, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in New Jersey, 1824 establishments in the United States, New Jersey counties

Warren County is a county in the U.S. state of New Jersey. As of the 2018 Census estimate, the county's population was 105,779. Its county seat is Belvidere. 

It is thought to be part of the New York-Newark, NY-NJ-CT-PA Combined Statistical Area, and of the New York City Metropolitan Area.

[[Belvidere, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New Jersey, County seats in New Jersey

Belvidere is a town in Warren County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the town's population was 2,681. It is the county seat of Warren County.

Phillipsburg is a town in Warren County, New Jersey, United States. As of 2010 United States Census, the town's population was 14,950.

Hardwick Township is a township in Warren County, New Jersey, United States.  As of the 2010 United States Census, the township's population was 1,696.

[[Cape May County, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: 17th-century establishments in New Jersey, 1680s establishments in the Thirteen Colonies, 1685 establishments, New Jersey counties

Cape May County is the southernmost county in the U.S. state of New Jersey. Its county seat is the Cape May Court House section of Middle Township.

[[Cape May Court House, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: County seats in New Jersey, Census-designated places in New Jersey, Unincorporated communities in New Jersey

Cape May Court House is an unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) located within Middle Township in Cape May County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the CDP's population was 5,338. It is the county seat of Cape May County. 

[[Vineland, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New Jersey

Vineland is a city in Cumberland County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the city had a total population of 60,724. Vineland, Millville and Bridgeton are the three main New Jersey cities of the Vineland–Millville–Bridgeton Primary Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Bridgeton, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New Jersey, County seats in New Jersey

Bridgeton is a city in Cumberland County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the city's population was 25,349. It is the county seat of Cumberland County. 

Bridgeton, Millville, and Vineland are the three main cities of the Vineland-Millville-Bridgeton Primary Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Millville, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New Jersey

Millville is a city in Cumberland County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the city's population was 28,400. Millville, Bridgeton and Vineland are the three main New Jersey cities of the Vineland-Millville-Bridgeton Primary Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Anne Helm]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American movie actors, American television actors, American children's writers, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Actors from Toronto, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Writers from Los Angeles, California, Writers from Toronto

Anne Helm (born September 12, 1938) is a Canadian-born American actress and children’s author. She played Elvis Presley's love interest in the 1962 movie Follow That Dream. Helm had a two recurring role, playing Molly Pierce in five episodes of the mid-1960s series Run for Your Life and playing the minor role of nurse Mary Briggs in the daily soap opera General Hospital from 1971 to 1973.

[[Art Buchwald]]

CATEGORIES: American columnists, American political commentators, American political writers, 1925 births, 2007 deaths, Pulitzer Prize winners, Deaths from renal failure, Deaths from diabetes, Writers from New York City, Writers from Washington, D.C.

Arthur Buchwald (October 20, 1925 – January 17, 2007) was an American humorist. He was best known for his column in The Washington Post. His columns were published nationwide in more than 500 newspapers.  His columns focused on political satire and commentary.

He received the Pulitzer Prize in 1982 for Outstanding Commentary, and in 1991 was elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.

Buchwald was born in New York City. He studied at the University of Southern California. He had a cameo appearance in Alfred Hitchcock's 1955 movie To Catch a Thief.

In 1988 Buchwald sued Paramount Pictures in over the Eddie Murphy movie Coming to America. Buchwald said Paramount had stolen his script. He won, was awarded damages, and accepted a settlement from Paramount.

In 2000, Buchwald had a stroke. In 2006, he had one leg amputated because of bad blood circulation caused by diabetes. Buchwald died on January 17, 2007 in Washington, D.C. of kidney failure, aged 81.

[[Yuri Bondarev]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Russian novelists, Russian screenwriters, Essayists, Soviet writers

Yuri Vasilyevich Bondarev (Ю́рий Васи́льевич Бо́ндарев, 15 March 1924 – 29 March 2020) was a Soviet-born Russian novelist, essayist, and screenwriter. He was born in Orsk, Soviet Union. His best known novels were novels The Battalions Request Fire (1957) and The Last Salvoes (1959). He was best known for writing the scripts of the Liberation movie series (1968–71). He was twice honored with the Order of Lenin.

Bondarev died on 29 March 2020 in Moscow at the age of 96.

[[Kulfi]]

CATEGORIES: Ice cream, Indian culture

Kulfi is kind of ice cream dessert that originated in India from 16th century. Sometimes the kulpi is called "traditional Indian ice cream". The Indian food in India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, Nepal, Myanmar, Middle East and in Indian restaurants around the world. The texture of this ice cream is hard and similar to "Bastani sonnati (Persian ice cream)" and Mastic ice creams aim to delay melting.

The shellfish is similar in texture and taste to ice cream but it is thicker and creamier than today's ice cream. The confetti can be found in a variety of flavors: cream (Malay), rose, mango, cardam, saffron and pistachio. In the past, it was also customary to feel peeled in more modern flavors apple, orange, strawberry, peanut and avocado. Unlike modern ice cream, the Kulfi is not whipped with thicker Marco and is reminiscent of traditional pudding ice cream. Its texture and main compressibility make the pulpy edible Cold Our man melts in a theme and quickly like modern western ice cream.

[[Dirweyn]]

CATEGORIES: Somali people, Ethnic groups in Africa

Dirweyn is one of the four big tribes in Somalia. Dirweyn means greater Dir. Dirweyn is made up of two tribes called Isaaq and Dir. The other three big tribes in Somalia are the bulshada Koofur Orsi, the Darood and the Hawiye. Isaaq borders Warsangeli and reer darawiish to the east, the Ogaden to the south and the Gadabuursi to the west.

[[Southern District (Botswana)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

Southern is one of the districts of Botswana. The capital city is Kanye.

There are three sub-districts: Barolong, Ngwaketse and Ngwaketse West.

[[South-East District (Botswana)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

South-East is one of the districts of Botswana. The capital city is Ramotswa. The capital city of Botswana, Gaborone, is surrounded by this district.

Mokolodi Nature Reserve, Gaborone Game Reserve and Manyelanong Game Reserve are the major tourist places in the district.

There are two sub-districts: Ramotswa and Tlokweng. The villages under each sub-district are:

[[Kweneng District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

Kweneng is one of the districts of Botswana. The capital city is Molepolole.

There are two sub-districts: Kweneng East and Kweneng West. Towns are: Gabane, Kopong, Mogoditshane, and Thamaga.

[[Kgatleng District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

Kgatleng is one of the districts of Botswana. The capital city is Mochudi.

The tourist and game reserves in the region are Oodi Weavers and Matsieng footprints.

The district has no sub-districts.

[[Central District (Botswana)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

Central is a district in Botswana. The capital city is Serowe. It is the largest district and has the most people of any other district in Botswana.

Some important tourist attractions are: Francistown, Selebi-Phikwe, Solomon's Wall, Moremi Gorge, and Mashatu Game Reserve.

The six sub-districts of Central are: Bobonong, Boteti, Mahalapye, Orapa, Serowe Palapye and Tutume.

[[North-East District (Botswana)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

The North-East District is a district of Botswana. Its capital is Francistown.

There are two sub-districts - the Francistown Subdistrict and the North-East Subdistrict. In the 2011 census, 43 villages were listed for the district.

[[North-West District (Botswana)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

The North-West District or Ngamiland is a district in Botswana. The capital city is Maun.

Ngamiland is subdivided into Ngamiland East, Ngamiland West and Ngamiland Delta (Okavango).

Important tourist attractions include Tsodilo Hills, the Moremi Game Reserve, and the Gchwihaba (Drotsky's) Caves.

[[Browning, Illinois]]

Browning is a village in Illinois in the United States.

[[Kgalagadi District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

Kgalagadi is a district in southwest Botswana. The administrative center is Tsabong.

Kgalagadi covers a large part of the Kalahari Desert. More than one-third of the district is covered by the Kgalagadi Transfrontier Park. Other tourist attractions include Central Kalahari Game Reserve, Deception Valley, and Khutse Game Reserve.

There are two sub-districts - Kgalagadi North and Kgalagadi South.

[[Chobe District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

Chobe District is a district in Botswana. The capital city is Kasane.

Chobe National Park is in the Chobe District. Other tourist attractions are Pandamatenga Farms, Lesoma Memorial Monument, Kasane Hot Springs and Chobe River.

Chobe district was established in July 2008 and is not sub-divided.

[[Districts of Botswana]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

Botswana is divided into 17 administrative districts: 10 rural districts and 7 urban districts. These are administered by 16 local authorities (district councils, city councils or town councils).

[[Ilagan]]

CATEGORIES: 17th century establishments in Asia, 1686 establishments, Establishments in the Philippines, Cities in the Philippines

Ilagan (Siudad nat Ilagan; Siudad ti Ilagan; Lungsod ng Ilagan), officially the City of Ilagan, and simply referred to as Ilagan City, is the capital of the province of Isabela, Philippines. According to the population_as_of, it has population_total people living there.current

[[Ghanzi District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Botswana

Ghanzi (sometimes Gantsi) is a district in western Botswana. The capital city is also named Ghanzi.

Most of the eastern half of Ghanzi is the Central Kalahari Game Reserve. Deception Valley, Ghanzi Craft, and Khutse Game Reserve are other major tourist attractions.

Ghanzi is divided into Charles Hill Sub-District and Ghanzi Sub-District.

Clallam County is a county in Washington in the United States. The county seat is Port Angeles. 71,404 people lived there at the 2010 census. 

The name Clallam means "the strong people" in Klallam.

[[Port Angeles, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Washington (U.S. state), County seats in Washington

Port Angeles is a town in the state of Washington. It is the county seat of Clallam County, Washington, and is it's largest settlement.

[[De Land, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois

De Land is a village in Illinois in the United States.

Jennings is a town in Hamilton County, Florida in the United States.

[[White Springs, Florida]]
