White Springs is a town of Florida in the United States.

[[Baker, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Baker is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Fallon County. In 2010, 1,714 people lived there.

Nearby Medicine Rocks State Park has many unusual sandstone rock formations.

[[Belgrade, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana

Belgrade is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Gallatin County. In 2010, 7,389 people lived there.

It is the largest city in Montana that is not a county seat.

Bozeman Yellowstone International Airport is located there.

[[Chinook, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Chinook is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Blaine County. About 1,200 people lived there in 2010.

[[Harlem, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana

Harlem is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Blaine County. About 800 people lived there in 2010.

The Fort Belknap Indian Reservation is just south of the town, across the Milk River.

[[Choteau, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Choteau is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Teton County. About 1,700 people lived there in 2010.

It is named for French fur-trapper and explorer Pierre Chouteau, Jr.

[[Colstrip, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, 1924 establishments in the United States

Colstrip is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Rosebud County. About 2,200 people lived there in 2010.

Colstrip was established by the Northern Pacific Railway in 1924. It was a company town to provide coal for their steam locomotives.

[[Billy Tauzin]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, American lobbyists, United States representatives from Louisiana, US Democratic Party politicians, US Republican Party politicians, American conservatives, Businesspeople from Louisiana, Politicians from Louisiana, Living people

Wilbert Joseph Tauzin II ('bɪli 'toʊzɛ̃; born June 14, 1943) is an American lobbyist and politician. He was the President and CEO of PhRMA, a pharmaceutical company lobby group. Tauzin was also a member of the United States House of Representatives from 1980 to 2005, representing Louisiana's 3rd congressional district.

[[John Prine]]

CATEGORIES: Grammy Award winners, 1946 births, 2020 deaths, American country singers, American country guitarists, American folk singers, American folk musicians, American activists, Businesspeople from Chicago, Cancer survivors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Infectious disease deaths in Tennessee, Musicians from Chicago, Singer-songwriters from Chicago

John Prine (October 10, 1946 – April 7, 2020) was an American country folk singer-songwriter and guitarist. He was born in Maywood, Illinois but raised in Chicago. His music was often seen as protest and social commentary. He began making music for Atlantic Records in 1971. In 1984 he co-founded Oh Boy Records, an independent record label. In 1992 and 2006, Prine won a Grammy Award.

In 1998, he was diagnosed with a form of melanoma in the neck. In 2013, he discovered he had lung cancer.

On March 26, 2020, Prine was hospitalized with COVID-19. Two days later, his health was reported as critical. On April 7, 2020, he died of the disease in Nashville, Tennessee. He was 73.

[[Lanny D. Schmidt]]

CATEGORIES: American chemists, 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Engineers from Illinois, American educators, Scientists from Illinois, People from Waukegan, Illinois

Lanny D. Schmidt (May 6, 1938 – March 27, 2020) was an American chemist, inventor and author. He was the Regents Professor of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science at the University of Minnesota. He was well known for his work in surface science, chemical reaction engineering, catalysis, and renewable energy. 

[[Grim Sleeper]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, American rapists, American people convicted of assault, American people convicted of murder, People who died in prison custody in the United States, Criminals from California, People from Los Angeles, California

Lonnie David Franklin Jr. (August 30, 1952 – March 28, 2020), better known by the nickname Grim Sleeper, was a convicted American serial killer. He was responsible for at least ten murders and one attempted murder in Los Angeles, California. He was also convicted for rape and sexual violence. Franklin earned his nickname when he appeared to have taken a 14-year break from his crimes, from 1988 to 2002.

In July 2010, Franklin was arrested as a suspect, and, after many delays, his trial began in February 2016. On May 5, 2016, the jury convicted him of killing nine women and one teenage girl. 

On June 6, 2016, the jury recommended the death penalty, and on August 10, 2016, the Los Angeles Superior Court sentenced him to death. On March 28, 2020, he was found unresponsive in his cell at San Quentin and pronounced dead at the age of 67.

[[National Council (Switzerland)]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Switzerland

The National Council (Nationalrat, Conseil national, Consiglio nazionale, Cussegl naziunal) is the lower house of the Federal Assembly of Switzerland, the upper house being the Council of States. With 200 seats, the National Council is the larger of the two houses.

Adult citizens elect the council's members, who are called National Councillors for four year terms. These members are apportioned to the Swiss cantons in proportion to their population.

Both houses meet in the Federal Palace of Switzerland in Berne.

[[Federal Assembly (Switzerland)]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Switzerland

The Federal Assembly (Bundesversammlung, Assemblée fédérale, Assemblea federale, Assamblea federala) is Switzerland's federal legislature. It meets in Bern in the Federal Palace.

The Federal Assembly is bicameral, being made-up of the 200-seat National Council and the 46-seat Council of States. The houses have same powers. Members of both houses represent the cantons.

[[Council of States (Switzerland)]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Switzerland

The Council of States (Ständerat, Conseil des États, Consiglio degli Stati, Cussegl dals Stadis) is the smaller chamber of the Federal Assembly of Switzerland. It is thought to be the Assembly's upper house, with the National Council being the lower house. It comprises 46 members.

[[Attilio Bignasca]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss politicians

Attilio Bignasca (1 November 1943 – 29 March 2020) was a Swiss politician. He was a member of the Ticino League. He was the brother of Giuliano Bignasca. He was elected to the National Council, and represented the Canton of Ticino between 1991 and 2019. He was born in Viganello, Switzerland.

Bignasca died on 29 March 2020 at the age of 76.

[[Jean-François Cesarini]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in France, French politicians

Jean-François Cesarini (30 September 1970 – 29 March 2020) was a French politician. He was a member of the La République En Marche! (LREM). He was elected to the French National Assembly on 18 June 2017, representing the department of Vaucluse. Cesarini was born in Avignon, France.

Cesarini died on 29 March 2020 of cancer in Paris at the age of 49.

[[Daïra]]

CATEGORIES: Arabic words and phrases, Districts

A daïra or daerah is an administrative division. Countries who use this term are Algeria and Western Sahara in West Africa, as well as Brunei, Indonesia and Malaysia in Southeast Asia. It is commonly translated in English as "district".

[[Joe Diffie]]

CATEGORIES: Grammy Award winners, 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American singer-songwriters, American country singers, American country guitarists, Musicians from Tulsa, Oklahoma, Singers from Tulsa, Oklahoma, Writers from Tulsa, Oklahoma

Joe Logan Diffie (December 28, 1958 – March 29, 2020) was an American country music singer-songwriter and guitarist. He was best known for his singles "Home", "If the Devil Danced (In Empty Pockets)", "Third Rock from the Sun", "Pickup Man" (his longest-lasting number-one song, at four weeks) and "Bigger Than the Beatles". 

He also co-wrote singles for Holly Dunn, Tim McGraw, and Jo Dee Messina, and recorded with Mary Chapin Carpenter, George Jones, and Marty Stuart. He won a Grammy Award in 1998.

Diffie released seven studio albums, a Christmas album, and a greatest-hits package under the Epic label. He also released one studio album each through Monument Records, Broken Bow Records, and Rounder Records. 

During the coronavirus pandemic, Diffie was diagnosed with COVID-19 on March 27, 2020. He died two days later of the infection at a Nashville, Tennessee hospital at the age of 61.

[[Ken Shimura]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Japan, Japanese television personalities, Japanese comedians, Actors from Tokyo

Ken Shimura (born Yasunori Shimura, February 20, 1950 – March 29, 2020) was a Japanese comedian. He co-starred with Masashi Tashiro, Nobuyoshi Kuwano in the Japanese variety show Shimura Ken no Bakatono-sama. He was known for starring in Hachiji Da Yo! Zen'in Shugo! with the comedy group The Drifters and Fun TV with Kato-chan and Ken-chan with Cha Kato. Shimura was born in Tokyo.

Shimura was diagnosed with COVID-19 on March 23, 2020 while hospitalized for pneumonia in Tokyo. He died six days later from the infection at the age of 70.

[[Zach Woods]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from New Jersey, Comedians from New Jersey, People from Trenton, New Jersey

Zachary Woods (born September 25, 1984) is an American actor and comedian. He is best known for his roles as Gabe Lewis for three seasons on the NBC sitcom The Office and as Jared Dunn on the HBO comedy series Silicon Valley. 

[[Mukim]]

CATEGORIES: Towns

A mukim is a type of administrative division. It is used in Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore. The closest English translation for mukim is township.

[[Belait District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Brunei

Belait District is a district in Brunei. The capital city is Kuala Belait. It is the largest district in Brunei.

The South China Sea is to the north. The Belait River flows through Belait and it is the longest river in Brunei.

The district is further divided into 8 mukims or subdistricts, namely:

[[Brunei-Muara District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Brunei

Brunei-Muara is a district in Brunei. The capital city is Bandar Seri Begawan, which is also the capital of the country. It is the smallest district but has the most people.

The largest and deepest port in Brunei is the Muara Port.

As of July 2007, there are 18 mukims, or subdistricts.

The mukims are:

¹ - Water village mukims

[[Temburong District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Brunei

Temburong District is a district in Brunei. The capital city is Bangar.

Temburong is an exclave. It is separated from the rest of Brunei by Malaysia and Brunei Bay. The Temburong River flows through the district, and the Sungai Pandaruan river forms the western border. Brunei's first national park, the Ulu Temburong National Park, is in the south of the Temburong district.

Temburong is divided into five mukim (subdistricts):

[[Tutong District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Brunei

Tutong District is a district in Brunei. The capital city is Pekan Tutong.

The Tutong River flows through the district. Tutong has the largest lake in Brunei, Tasek Merimbun. It has the Tasek Merimbun Heritage Park.

[[Yves Poilane]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, French engineers, 1959 births, Alumni of the École Polytechnique

Yves Poilane (born 11 December 1959) is a French manager and President of universities. He is the current Manager of IONIS Education Group, the first group in France for private higher education.

Drillech graduated from École Polytechnique. He also graduated from Télécom ParisTech with a Master's degree. He has a career in telecommunications.

In 1989, he moved to higher education by joining Telecom Bretagne as Deputy Manager.

Then, he became CEO of Télécom ParisTech 2007 before joining IONIS Education Group in 2019.

[[Turkwel River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Africa, Geography of Kenya

The Turkwel River (sometimes spelled Turkwell River) is a river flowing from Mount Elgon in the border of Kenya and Uganda to Lake Turkana. The river is called the Suam River from its source to the border with the West Pokot County of Kenya. The name Turkwel is derived from the Turkana name for the river, Tir-kol, which means translates to a river that "withstands the wilderness".

[[Brachial artery]]

CATEGORIES: Blood vessels

The brachial artery is the major blood vessel of the upper arm.

[[Apoplexy]]

CATEGORIES: Pathology, Blood

Apoplexy means bleeding from an internal organ. Apoplexy used to be used to describe a stroke. It can also be used to say someone is very mad. The word "apoplexy" comes from the Greek "apoplexia" meaning a seizure, in the sense of being struck down. In Greek "plexe" is "a stroke.

[[Ogre]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional animals

An ogre is fictional monster. A female ogre is called ogres. Most stories say ogres eat humans, including small children and babies. The word originally comes from French: Charles Perrault mentioned an Ogre in his fairy tale, Little thumbling, published in 1697. In that story, the word has also been translated as giant. 

[[Boulder, Montana]]

Boulder is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat for Jefferson County. About 1,200 people lived there in 2010.

It is on the north bank of the Boulder River.

East Helena is a town in Montana in the United States.

[[Columbia Falls, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana

Columbia Falls is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Flathead County. About 4,700 people lived there in 2010.

Hungry Horse Dam is nearby. It is also near Glacier National Park.

[[Conrad, Montana]]

Conrad is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Pondera County. About 2,500 people lived there in 2010.

[[Glendive, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Glendive is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Dawson County. Almost 5,000 people lived there according to census in 2010.

The Yellowstone River flows through the town. Makoshika State Park is to the east.

[[Hamilton, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Hamilton is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Ravalli County. Almost 13,000 people lived there in 2013.

Hamilton was founded by copper king Marcus Daly in the late 19th century. The town is in the Bitterroot Valley.

[[Hobson, Montana]]

Hobson is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Judith Basin County. About 200 people lived there in 2010.

[[Deer Lodge, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Deer Lodge is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Powell County. About 3,100 people lived there in 2010. 

Deer Lodge is home to the Montana State Prison. Grant–Kohrs Ranch National Historic Site is also nearby.

[[Judith Gap, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana

Judith Gap is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Wheatland County. The population was 126 at the 2010 census.

It is named for the gap it forms between the Big Snowy Mountains and Little Belt Mountains.

[[Plentywood, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana, 1912 establishments in the United States

Plentywood is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Sheridan County. About 1,700 people lived there in 2010.

The first business in Plentywood opened in 1900, and a post office was established two years later. The city incorporated in 1912, following the arrival of a Great Northern Railway branch line.

[[Polson, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Polson is a city in the U.S. state of Montana. It is the county seat of Lake County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 4,488 people. It is on the southern shore of Flathead Lake.

[[Ronan, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana

Ronan is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Lake County. About 1,900 people lived there in 2010. 

Ronan on the Flathead Indian Reservation about 12 miles south of Flathead Lake.

[[Columnist (media)]]

CATEGORIES: Columnists

A columnist is a person who writes for publication in a series, creating an article that usually offers commentary and opinions.

[[Poplar, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana

Poplar is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Roosevelt County. About 800 people lived there in 2010.

Poplar is the seat for the Fort Peck Sioux and Assiniboine Tribes. This includes the tribal law enforcement agency, courthouse, and the Fort Peck Reservation correctional facility.

The Poplar River joins the Missouri River near town.

[[Red Lodge, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Red Lodge is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Carbon County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 2,125 people.

Red Lodge is a gateway to Yellowstone National Park via the Beartooth Highway.

[[Scobey, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Scobey is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Daniels County. About 1,000 people lived there in 2010.

[[Three Forks, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana

Three Forks is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Gallatin County. About 1,900 people lived there in 2010.

Nearby Missouri Headwaters State Park is where the Jefferson, Madison, and Gallatin Rivers come together to form the Missouri River.

[[Sidney, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana, 1911 establishments in the United States

Sidney is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Richland County. About 5,200 people lived there in 2010.

Sidney is along the Yellowstone River. It was incorporated in 1911.

[[Troy, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana

Troy is a city in Montana in the United States. It is in Lincoln County. About 900 people lived there in 2010.

The Kootanai River flows along the town.

[[Roundup, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Roundup is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Musselshell County. About 1,800 people lived there in 2010.

The Musselshell River runs through the city. The Bull Mountains are to the south.

[[White Sulphur Springs, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

White Sulphur Springs is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Meagher County. About 900 people lived there in 2010.

The town is named for its mineralized hot springs.

[[Brent Crude]]

CATEGORIES: Oils

Brent Crude is a major trading classification of crude oil. It is one of the two main benchmark prices for purchases of oil worldwide, the other being West Texas Intermediate. This is described as light because of its low density, and sweet because of its low sulphur content.

[[West Texas Intermediate]]

CATEGORIES: Oils

West Texas intermediate (WTI), also known as Texas light sweet, is a grade of oil used as a benchmark in oil pricing. This grade is described as light crude oil because of its relatively low density, and sweet because of its low sulfur content. It is the underlying commodity of New York Mercantile Exchange's oil futures contracts.

The price of WTI is often included in news reports on oil prices, alongside the price of Brent crude from the North Sea.

[[Daniel Azulay]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, People with cancer, Brazilian artists, Comics artists, Brazilian educators, People from Rio de Janeiro

Daniel Azulay (May 30, 1947 – March 27, 2020) was a Brazilian visual artist, comic book artist, and  educator. He was known for the children's franchise Turma do Lambe-Lambe. He was born in Rio de Janeiro. In 1968, he created the newspaper strip Capitão Cipó, published in the newspaper Correio da Manhã and in 1975, launched the Turma do Lambe-Lambe. In 2013, he created the Diboo website (www.diboo.com.br), an online drawing course for children.

Azulay died of COVID-19 on March 27, 2020, aged 72, in Rio de Janeiro, after being hospitalized for leukemia.

[[William Stern (businessman)]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, British businesspeople, Hungarian businesspeople, People from Budapest, British Jews, Hungarian Jews

William George Stern (born Vilmos György Stern, 2 July 1935 –  March 2020) was a Hungarian-born British businessman. He was known as the owner of the British Stern Group of companies. When the company fell in 1973, Stern became Britain's biggest bankrupt with debts of £118 million. Stern was the reason for the creation of Britain's first Policyholders' Protection Act.

He died in March 2020 from COVID-19.

[[Mohamed Farah (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2020 deaths, Somali people, Footballers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom

Abdulkadir Mohamed Farah (15 February 1961 – 24 March 2020) was a Somali footballer. He was born in Beledweyne, Somalia. Farah began his career in 1976. He played at the regional level before playing club football for Batroolka. He also represented the Somali national team.

Farah died in a hospital in London from COVID-19 on 24 March 2020, aged 59.

[[Hamish Wilson]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, Actors from Glasgow, Scottish television actors, BBC people

Hamish Wilson (13 December 1942 – 26 March 2020) was a Scottish actor and radio producer. He was born in Glasgow. He was best known for briefly playing the role of Jamie McCrimmon for part of two episodes in the 1968 Doctor Who serial "The Mind Robber". He replaced Frazer Hines for a short period. His other work includes include Softly, Softly and Monarch of the Glen.

Wilson became a radio producer, working with Radio Forth and Radio Clyde before moving to BBC Radio Scotland in 1989; he later also became a senior producer for BBC Radio 3 and BBC Radio 4.

Wilson died from COVID-19 near his home in Rutherglen, Lanarkshire on 26 March 2020, aged 77.

[[Robert H. Garff]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Salt Lake City, Utah, Businesspeople from Salt Lake City, Utah, US Republican Party politicians

Robert Heiner Garff (September 15, 1942 – March 29, 2020) was an American businessman and politician. He was chair of the Ken Garff Automotive Group. He was a member of the Utah House of Representatives from 1978 to 1987, where from 1985 to 1987 he was Spekaer. Garff was a member of the Republican Party. He was chairman of the Salt Lake Organizing Committee for the 2002 Winter Olympics. He was born in Salt Lake City, Utah.

Garff died of COVID-19 in Salt Lake City on March 29, 2020 at the age of 77.

[[Francis Rapp]]

CATEGORIES: People from Strasbourg, 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, Editors, French educators, French historians

Francis Rapp (27 June 1926 – 29 March 2020) was a French medievalist historian. His works focused in the history of Alsace and Medieval Germany. He was an Emeritus professor at University of Neuchâtel. He was a member of the Academy of Inscriptions and Fine Letters, beginning in 1993. Rapp was also a member of the editorial board of the review Archiv für Reformationsgeschichte.

Rapp was born in Strasbourg, France. He died of COVID-19 on 29 March 2020 in Angers, aged 93.

[[Joe Ashton]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, UK MPs 1966–1970, UK MPs 1970–1974, UK MPs 1974, UK MPs 1974–1979, UK MPs 1979–1983, UK MPs 1983–1987, UK MPs 1987–1992, UK MPs 1992–1997, UK MPs 1997–2001, Former Labour MPs (UK), Politicians from Yorkshire, People from Sheffield

Joseph William Ashton GBR (9 October 1933 – 30 March 2020), usually known as Joe Ashton, was a British Labour Party politician. He was a Member of Parliament from 1968 to 2001 representing Bassetlaw. He was born in Sheffield, West Riding of Yorkshire. In 2007, Ashton was appointed an OBE.

Ashton died on 30 March 2020, aged 86.

[[Max Engman]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Finnish writers, Historians, Translators, Editors, 2020 deaths, People from Helsinki

Max Robert Engman (27 September 1945 – 19 March 2020) was a Finnish historian and translator. He was born in Helsinki. 

Engman worked at the Finnish national archives in Helsinki from 1968 to 1973. He was appointed professor 1985 in general history at Åbo Akademi. His works focused in Finnish–Russian relations and the European empires. 

He was known as a subeditor for Historisk Tidskrift för Finland from 1971 to 1982 and the journals editor in chief 1982 to 2000.

Engman died on 19 March 2020 in Helsinki at the age of 74.

[[Al Green]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, American singer-songwriters, American soul singers, American R&B singers, American gospel singers, American blues singers, Record producers, Businesspeople from Arkansas, Singers from Arkansas, Writers from Arkansas, Businesspeople from Grand Rapids, Michigan, Singers from Grand Rapids, Michigan, Writers from Grand Rapids, Michigan

Albert Leornes Greene (born April 13, 1946), often known as The Reverend Al Green, is an American singer-songwriter and record producer. He is best known for recording a series of soul hit singles in the early 1970s, including "Take Me to the River", "Tired of Being Alone", "I'm Still in Love with You", "Love and Happiness", and his signature song, "Let's Stay Together".

[[Schöndorf, Rhineland-Palatinate]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Rhineland-Palatinate, Trier-Saarburg

Schöndorf is a municipality in the Trier-Saarburg district, in Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany. As of 31 December 2018, 773 people lived there.

[[Have You Seen This Snail?]]

CATEGORIES: SpongeBob SquarePants episodes, 2005 in American television, 2005 television episodes

"Have You Seen This Snail?" is the third episode of the fourth season of SpongeBob SquarePants. It was first shown on television on November 11, 2005. The episode guest starred Amy Poehler as a granny in the episode. The episode was watched by 8 million viewers, being the most rated program on television for the year of 2005 behind the Super Bowl.

[[Playdate (console)]]

CATEGORIES: Video game consoles

April 2020

and with the crank tucked away into the side slot (below)

Playdate is an handheld video game console by Panic that will come out in 2020. It was first introduced on May 22, 2019 on the cover of Edge magazine. Panic worked with Teenage Engineering, a Swedish consumer electronics company, to design the Playdate.

The Playdate has a black-and-white 1-bit screen, 4 way directional pad, two game buttons, and a mechanical crank on the side.

[[To SquarePants or Not to SquarePants]]

CATEGORIES: SpongeBob SquarePants episodes, 2009 television episodes

"To SquarePants or Not to SquarePants" is the second part of the sixteenth episode of the sixth season of SpongeBob SquarePants. It was first shown on television on July 17, 2009 as a part of the television marathon called "The Ultimate SpongeBob SpongeBash Weekend." A DVD version of the episode was made on July 21, 2009 and has other season six episodes in it.

[[Apocalypse Cow]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons episodes, 2008 in American television, 2008 television episodes, Television episodes about marriage

"Apocalypse Cow" is the seventeenth episode of the nineteenth season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on television on April 27, 2008 on the Fox network. 7.69 million people watched the episode. In the episode, Bart joins 4-H and saves a cow named Lou. He gives it to a girl named Mary and her father, Cletus Spuckler, thinks that Bart wants to marry her. Jeff Westbrook won a Writers Guild of America Award for writing the episode.

[[Blagoevgrad Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Blagoevgrad Province is a province (oblast) of southwestern Bulgaria. The administrative centre is Blagoevgrad.

The province has 14 municipalities with 12 towns. Significant towns include Bansko, Gotse Delchev, Melnik, Petrich, Razlog, Sandanski, and Simitli.

There are several mountains, or parts of mountains, in the province. These are Rila, Pirin, the Rhodopes, Slavyanka, Belasitsa, Vlahina, Maleshevo, Ograzhden and Stargach. There are two major rivers, Struma River and Mesta River.

[[Burgas Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Burgas Province is a province in southeastern Bulgaria. The capital city is Burgas.

[[Dobrich Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Dobrich Province is a province in northeastern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Dobrich.

[[Gabrovo Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Gabrovo Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Gabrovo.

Places of interest in Gabrovo province include architectural reserve Bozhentsi. Hiking is widely available in the Central Balkan National Park and in the Bulgarka Nature Park.

[[Haskovo Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Haskovo Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Haskovo.

[[Kardzhali Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Kardzhali Province is a province of Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Kardzhali.

[[Kyustendil Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Kyustendil Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Kyustendil.

The province includes the Dragovishtitsa and Bistritsa rivers. The southern part of the region includes massifs of the Osogovo, Vlahina and Rila mountains.

[[Qi]]

CATEGORIES: Pseudoscience, Spirituality

The Creation of Qi ("Chi" or "Ki") is a process in which consciousness pulls energy from the planet & channels it through the human body. This process amplifies the intensity of the "human bio-magnetic field" surrounding an individual. Multiple studies showing evidence for a QI force have been conducted, some studies have shown that humans grasp the potential to increase their bio-magnetic field by 1,000 times the average strength. However, scientists are still unable to determine the origin of the large bio-magnetic field surrounding Qi Users, and thus, Qi must be considered a pseudoscience until it can be proven.

[[Maura Tierney]]

CATEGORIES: Golden Globe Award winning actors, 1965 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Breast cancer survivors, Actors from Boston, Massachusetts

Maura Lynn Tierney (born February 3, 1965) is an American actress. She is best known for her roles as Lisa Miller on the sitcom NewsRadio (1995–1999), Abby Lockhart on the medical drama ER (1999–2009), and Helen Solloway on the mystery drama The Affair (2014–2019). She won a Golden Globe Award.

Tierney was born in Boston, Massachusetts. She had surgery to remove a tumor from her breast in 2009.

[[Cody Horn]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Models from Los Angeles, California

Cody Harrell Horn (born June 12, 1988) is an American actress and model. She was born in Los Angeles, California. 

She has appeared on Rescue Me and guest starred on three episodes of The Office. She also played Lynetta Loski in the 2010 movie Flipped and starred as Michelle, in the James Wan produced horror thriller movie Demonic.

[[Lindsey Broad]]

CATEGORIES: American movie actors, American television actors, Living people, Actors from Pennsylvania, Year of birth missing (living people), American stage actors

Lindsey Broad is an American actress. She is best known for her role as flirtatious temp Cathy Simms on the NBC series The Office. Her movie credits include 21 Jump Street, Don Jon, and Get Him to the Greek. She also starred on the Fox sitcom, 'Til Death, and appeared opposite Stephen Merchant on the HBO series Hello Ladies.

She starred as Karen Rosenberg on the IFC series Benders, which was cancelled in 2015.

[[Robert California]]

CATEGORIES: The Office (U.S. TV series) characters

Robert California, also known as Bob Kazamakis, is a fictional character on the U.S. comedy television series The Office, played by James Spader. In the eighth season, Robert becomes CEO of Saber. In the eighth-season finale, California leaves the company after David Wallace buys Dunder Mifflin.

[[List of presidents of the Republic of the Congo]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of the Republic of the Congo

This is a list of presidents of the Republic of the Congo since the creation of the post of president in 1960, to the present day.

A total of six people have been President of the Republic of the Congo.

[[List of prime ministers of the Republic of the Congo]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of the Republic of the Congo

This is a list of prime ministers of the Republic of the Congo since the formation of the post of prime minister in 1963, to the present day.

A total of sixteen people have been the Prime Minister of the Republic of the Congo (not counting one acting prime minister).

[[President of Syria]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Syria

The President of Syria is the head of state of the Syrian Arab Republic. He appoints and can fire the Prime Minister and other members of the Council of Ministers (the cabinet) and military officers.

[[Prime Minister of Syria]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Syria

The Prime Minister of Syria is the head of government of the Syrian Arab Republic.  

The Prime Minister is appointed by the President of Syria. He works with other ministers and members of the government that the new Prime Minister recommends. In 2004, Arnous was selected to serve as executive director of the General Establishment for Road Transport. He then served as governor of Deir ez-Zor and Quneitra governorates. ... Arnous served as Minister of Public Works and Housing from 2013 until 2018 and as Minister of Water Resources since 26 November 2018. 

The People's Council of Syria then approve the legislative program of the new government, before the new government formally take office. There are no constitutional limits on a Prime Minister's term, and several of them served multiple non-consecutive terms.

[[Imad Khamis]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Syria

Imad Mohammad Deeb Khamis (عماد محمد ديب خميس; born 1 August 1961) is a Syrian politician. He was the Prime Minister of Syria from 2016 to 2020 under President Bashar al-Assad. He was Minister of Electricity from 2011 to 2016.

[[Rayo Vallecano]]

CATEGORIES: 1920s establishments in Spain, 1924 establishments in Europe, Spanish football clubs, Madrid

Rayo Vallecano de Madrid, S.A.D. (ˈraʝo βaʎeˈkano ðe maˈðɾið), often abbreviated to Rayo, is a Spanish football club which plays in Madrid, in the neighbourhood of Vallecas. Rayo was founded on 29 May 1924, and currently compete in Segunda División following relegation from La Liga. Home games are held at the 14,708-seater Campo de Fútbol de Vallecas stadium.

Rayo has competed in one European competition, the UEFA Cup in the 2000–01 season. The club made it to the quarter-finals before losing to fellow Spanish club Alavés 4–2 on aggregate.

[[Abdul Rauf al-Kasm]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Syria

Abdul Rauf al-Kasm (عبد الرؤوف الكسم) (born 1932) is a Syrian architect, academic and politician. He was Prime Minister of Syria during the 1980s during Hafez al-Assad. He was born in Damascus, Syria. 

[[Mahmoud al-Ayyubi]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2013 deaths, Prime Ministers of Syria

Mahmoud al-Ayyubi (محمود الأيوبي) (1932 – 11 October 2013) was a Syrian politician. He was Prime Minister of Syria from 21 December 1972 to 7 August 1976 under the presidency of Hafez Al-Asad.

He also was Vice President of Syria from February 1971 to August 1976.

[[Joachim Yhombi-Opango]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Prime Ministers of the Republic of the Congo, Presidents of the Republic of the Congo, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France

Jacques Joachim Yhombi Opango (12 January 1939 – 30 March 2020) was a Congolese politician. He was Head of State of the People's Republic of the Congo from 1977 to 1979. He was the President of the Rally for Democracy and Development (RDD). From 1993 to 1996, he was Prime Minister of the Republic of the Congo. Yhombi-Opango was born in Owando, Cuvette Region, French Equatorial Africa.

Yhombi-Opango died in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France of COVID-19 on 30 March 2020, aged 81.

[[Potassium citrate]]

CATEGORIES: Food ingredients, Potassium compounds, Citrus

Potassium citrate (also known as tripotassium citrate) is a chemical made from potassium bicarbonate and citric acid. This is usually used as either a food colourant or a medicine.

[[Roger Baens]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian cyclists

Roger Baens (18 August 1933 – 28 March 2020) was a Belgian cyclist. He was born in Molenstede, Belgium. Baens competed with Mercier, Carpano, Libertas, Peugeot, Flandria, Philco, and Faemino–Faema.

Baens died on 28 March 2020 in Rillaar, Belgium at the age of 87.

[[Maurice Bidermann]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, French businesspeople, Belgian businesspeople, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France

Maurice Bidermann, real name Maurice Zylberberg, (4 April 1932 – 30 March 2020) was a Belgian-born French businessman. His company worked in the textile sector. He was a Knight of the French National Order of Merit in 1991. Bidermann was born in Anderlecht, Belgium. Bidermann was sentenced to three years in prison, two suspended, and fined one million euros.

Bidermann died on 30 March 2020 of COVID-19 in Paris.

[[Colleen Ballinger]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Internet celebrities, People from Santa Barbara, California, Actors from California, Singers from California, Comedians from California, Writers from California

Colleen Mae Ballinger (born November 21, 1986) is an American YouTuber, comedian, actress, singer and writer. She is best known for her Internet character Miranda Sings, posting videos of the character on YouTube, performing her one-woman comedy act on tours and creating a Netflix original television show based on the character titled Haters Back Off. She was born in Santa Barbara, California.

She guest-starred as Miranda Sings on Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee with Jerry Seinfeld (2014) and has appeared twice on The Tonight Show. Ballinger has released two best-selling books, written in Miranda's voice, Selp-Helf and My Diarrhe.

[[Tomie dePaola]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, American children's writers, American illustrators, American television personalities, LGBT writers, Gay men, Writers from New Hampshire, Writers from Connecticut

Thomas Anthony "Tomie" dePaola ˈ; September 15, 1934 – March 30, 2020) was an American writer and illustrator. He created more than 260 children's books such as Strega Nona. He won the Children's Literature Legacy Award in 2011. dePaola was born in Meriden, Connecticut. DePaola appeared in several episodes of Barney & Friends as himself. In 2017 he also appeared as himself in the Jim Henson Company series Telling Stories with Tomie dePaola. DePaola was openly gay.

DePaola died of problems caused by a fall on March 30, 2020 in Lebanon, New Hampshire at the age of 85.

[[Lebanon, New Hampshire]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in New Hampshire

Lebanon local is the only city in Grafton County, New Hampshire, United States. The population was 13,151 at the 2010 census. Lebanon is in western New Hampshire, south of Hanover, near the Connecticut River. 

[[Haverhill, New Hampshire]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New Hampshire, County seats in New Hampshire

Haverhill is a town in Grafton County, New Hampshire, United States. The population was 4,697 at the 2010 census.

[[Arianne Caoili]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, 2020 deaths, Australian sportspeople, Chess players, People from Manila, Road accident deaths

Arianne Bo Caoili (22 December 1986 – 30 March 2020) was a Filipino-born Australian chess player. She was awarded the title of Woman International Master (WIM) by FIDE. She won the Oceania women's chess championship in 2009. She also took part in seven Women's Chess Olympiads. She was born in Manila. She represented Australia starting in 2004.

Caoili starting living in Armenia from 2013. She died on 30 March 2020 in Yerevan. Her death was from from injuries caused by a car crash she had in two weeks before.

[[William Sadler (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: Saturn Award winners, 1950 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Buffalo, New York

William Thomas Sadler (born April 13, 1950) is an American actor. He is known for his roles as Chesty Puller in The Pacific, Luther Sloan in Star Trek: Deep Space Nine, Sheriff Jim Valenti in Roswell and the Grim Reaper in Bill & Ted's Bogus Journey, Tales from the Crypt and Bill & Ted Face the Music. 

He played Colonel Stuart in Die Hard 2. He played the character of President of the United States, Matthew Ellis, in Iron Man 3, Marvel's Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D., and WHIH Newsfront.

[[Miriam Rodriguez Martinez]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, 2017 deaths, Mexican activists

Miriam Rodriguez Martinez (around 1967 - 10 May 2017) from San Fernando, Tamaulipas, Mexico. She is a Mexican human rights activist. She became a member of "Missing Child Parents" after her daughter was abducted and killed. Miriam was killed by militants who broke into her home on May 10, 2017.

[[Naziha al-Dulaimi]]

CATEGORIES: Iraq, Feminists

Naziha Jawdet Ashgah al-Dulaimi (1923, Baghdad – 9 October 2007, Herdecke). She was one of the pioneers of feminist movement in Iraq.  She was a co-founder and first president of the Iraqi Women League. She is the first woman minister in Iraq's modern history, and the first woman cabinet minister in the Arab world.

[[Giancarlo Ghironzi]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, European politicians, Heads of state, Sammarinese people

Giancarlo Ghironzi (25 February 1932 – 14 March 2020)  was a Sammarinese politician. He was twice Captain Regent of San Marino from 1 April 1961 to 1 October 1961, and from 1 October 1969 to 1 April 1970. He was a member of the Sammarinese Christian Democratic Party (PDCS).

Ghironzi died on 14 March 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Tom Pelphrey]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, Actors from New Jersey, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, Emmy Award winning actors

Thomas J. Pelphrey (born July 28, 1982) is an American actor. He is known for playing the TV roles of Jonathan Randall in CBS's Guiding Light (2004–2009), Mick Dante in As the World Turns (2009–2010) and Kurt Bunker in the Cinemax series Banshee (2015–2016). He has also acted in the Netflix shows Iron Fist (2017–2018) and Ozark (2020). He has won the Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Younger Actor in a Drama Series twice for Guiding Light in 2006 and 2008. 

Pelphrey was born in Howell, New Jersey. He graduated from Rutgers University in 2004.

[[Lisa Emery]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, Actors from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors

Lisa Emery (born January 29, 1952) is an American actress. Her stage credits include The Matchmaker, Dinner with Friends (1999), What the Butler Saw (2000), The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie (2006), Talley & Son, Burn This (1987), Rumors, Present Laughter, The Women (2001), Marvin's Room (1991), Abigail's Party (2005) and Relatively Speaking (2011).

Emery has appeared in movies such as A Map of the World, Unfaithful, The Night Listener and Margot at the Wedding. On television, she has appeared in episodes of Ed, Law & Order, Law & Order: Special Victims Unit, Law & Order: Criminal Intent, Third Watch, Fringe, Damages and Jessica Jones. Since 2017, she has starred as Darlene Snell in the Netflix drama series Ozark.

Emery was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. She was married to actor Josh Pais from 1990 to 2003. The couple have a son.

[[Tisbury, Massachusetts]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Massachusetts

Tisbury is a town located on Martha's Vineyard in Dukes County, Massachusetts, United States. The population was 3,949 at the 2010 census.

[[Clinton, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in South Carolina

Clinton  is a city in Laurens County, South Carolina, United States. The population was 8,490 as of the 2010 census. It is part of the Greenville–Mauldin–Easley Metropolitan Statistical Area. 

[[Laurens, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in South Carolina, County seats in South Carolina

Laurens is a city in Laurens County, South Carolina, United States. The population was 9,139 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Laurens County.

[[Mauldin, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in South Carolina

Mauldin is a city in Greenville County, South Carolina, United States. The population was 15,224 at the 2000 census and 22,889 in 2010. It is a principal city of the Greenville-Anderson-Mauldin Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Easley, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in South Carolina

Easley is a city in Pickens County (with parts going into Anderson County) in the State of South Carolina. It is a principal city of the Greenville–Mauldin–Easley Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Karla Avelar]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, LGBT rights activists, Living people

Karla Avelar (born 1978), she is a Salvadoran activist for the rights of transgenders. She is also the Executive Director of Comcavis Trans.

[[Riachão (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Brazilian singers, Composers

Clementino Rodrigues (14 November 1921 – 30 March 2020) was an Brazilian samba composer and singer. He was born in Salvador, Brazil. Riachão had several of his songs performed by national singers, one of the best known was "Vá Morar com o Diabo" and "Cada Macaco no Seu Galho ". Known for his samba music, other hits include "Retrato da Bahia" and "Bochechuda e Papuda".

Riachão died in his sleep at his home on 30 March 2020 in Salvador of a possible heart attack, aged 98.

[[Josefa Francisco]]

CATEGORIES: Feminists, Filipino people

Josefa "Gigi" Francisco (1954 -  22 July 2015), she was an advocate for the cause of gender equality and rights of women in the Philippines.  She help made a lot of programs to lessen the imbalance of gender and also made researches on many aspects of women's equality and their rights. She worked closely with the United Nations on various projects.

[[Nanfadima Magassouba]]

CATEGORIES: African people, Living people, Year of birth missing

Nanfadima Magassouba is an activist of women's rights and a politician from Guinea. She was the head of the National Coalition of Guinea for the Rights and Citizenship of Women (CONAG-DCF), and a member of Guinea's National Assembly since 2013.

[[Karina Pankievich]]

Karina Pankievich is an activist of  trans rights from Uruguay. She is the president of Asociación Trans del Uruguay.

[[Lysis]]

CATEGORIES: Cell biology

Lysis is when a cell's wall or membrane falls apart and kills the cell. It usually happens when the cell is attacked by a virus or enzyme.

[[Hans Rosenfeldt]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Swedish movie actors, Swedish novelists, Swedish radio personalities, Swedish screenwriters, Swedish television actors

Hans Rosenfeldt (born Hans Petersson; 13 July 1964) is a Swedish screenwriter, radio presenter, novelist and actor. He co-created the Swedish series De drabbade (2003) and Oskyldigt dömd (2008–2009). He also created the Swedish-Danish series The Bridge (2011–2018) and the British series Marcella (2016–present).

Rosenfeldt was born in Borås, Västergötland. At 2.06 tall, he wanted to have a basketball playing career. He is married and has three children. He lives in Täby.

[[Norman Kwong]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2016 deaths, Canadian businesspeople, Politicians from Alberta, Sportspeople from Calgary

Norman Lim Kwong (born Lim Kwong Yew; 林佐民; October 24, 1929 – September 3, 2016) was a Canadian football player, politician and businessman. He played in the Canadian Football League (CFL) for the Calgary Stampeders (1948–1950) and Edmonton Eskimos (1951–1960). He won the Grey Cup four times during his career (1948, 1954, 1955 and 1956). He served as the 16th Lieutenant Governor of Alberta from January 2005 to May 2010. He was also part owner of the Calgary Flames for a time.

Kwong was born in Calgary, Alberta. He was the son of Chinese immigrants from Taishan, Guangdong. He was the first Canadian professional gridiron football player of Chinese heritage. Kwong died in Calgary on September 3, 2016, at the age of 86.

[[John W. Drummond]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2016 deaths, Politicians from South Carolina, US Democratic Party politicians

John Willie Drummond (September 29, 1919 – September 3, 2016) was an American politician. He was a Democrat. He served as a member of the South Carolina Senate from 1966 to 2008. He represented the state 10th district during his time in office. He was also a member of the South Carolina House of Representatives from 1965 to 1966. He was born in Greenwood, South Carolina. 

Drummond died in Ninety Six, South Carolina, on September 3, 2016. He was 96.

[[Greenwood, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in South Carolina, County seats in South Carolina

Greenwood is a city in and the county seat of Greenwood County, South Carolina, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 23,222.

[[Ninety Six, South Carolina]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in South Carolina

Ninety Six is a town in Greenwood County, South Carolina, United States. As of the 2010 census, the town had a population of 1,998.

[[Salena Rocky Malone]]

CATEGORIES: Australian LGBT people

Salena Rocky Malone (died on May 2017), she was an Australian activist for human rights, and an active member of the LGBT community in Australia. She was one of the founders of IngiLez Leadership Support Group (ILSG), and the manager of Open Doors Youth Service.

She worked as an Aboriginals Liaison Officer and LGBTI Liaison Officer with the Queensland Police Service.Also, she was part of the PFLAG, Dykes on Bikes, the LGBTI Health Alliance.

[[Mark Meadows]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, Living people, White House Chiefs of Staff, United States representatives from North Carolina, Politicians from Florida, US Republican Party politicians

Mark Randall Meadows (born July 28, 1959) is an American politician. He was President Donald Trump's  White House chief of staff from March 31, 2020 to January 20, 2021.  Meadows was the U.S. representative for North Carolina's 11th congressional district from 2013 to 2020. He is a member of the Republican Party. He chaired the Freedom Caucus from 2017 to 2019.

[[Jim Jordan (American politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, United States representatives from Ohio, Sportspeople from Ohio, US Republican Party politicians

James Daniel Jordan (born February 17, 1964) is an American politician. He has been the U.S. representative for OH since 2007. He is a member of the Republican Party.

Jordan was the ranking member of the House Oversight Committee from 2019 to 2020. In February 2020, he left that committee to become the ranking member of the United States House Committee on the Judiciary.

In college, he was a wrestler.

[[H. Joel Deckard]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2016 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Texas, Politicians from Illinois, United States representatives from Indiana, US Republican Party politicians

Huey Joel Deckard (March 7, 1942 – September 6, 2016) was an American politician. For most of his political career, he was a Republican. He notably served as a member of the U.S. House of Representatives for IN from 1979 to 1983. He was also a member of the Indiana House of Representatives from 1966 to 1974. He was the Reform Party's nominee for U.S. Senator in 2000

Deckard was born in Vandalia, Illinois. He died due to an apparent heart attack in McKinney, Texas. He was 74.

[[Reimar Lüst]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, German physicists, German educators

Reimar Lüst (25 March 1923 – 31 March 2020) was a German astrophysicist. He was the president of the German Max Planck Society from 1972 to 1984 and the director general of the European Space Agency (ESA) from 1984 until 1990. Lüst was a professor at New York, MIT and Caltech before he became the director general of the ESA.

[[Howell Township, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in New Jersey

Howell Township is a township in Monmouth County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 census, the township had a population of 51,075.

[[Chester, Vermont]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Vermont

Chester is a town in Windsor County, Vermont, United States. As of the 2010 census, the town had a population of 3,154.

[[Isaac Robinson (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, State legislators of the United States, American lawyers, Politicians from Detroit, Michigan, US Democratic Party politicians

William Isaac Robinson (August 21, 1975 – March 29, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician. He was a member of the Michigan House of Representatives as a Democrat from 2019 until his death in 2020. He replaced his mother, Rose Mary Robinson in the state house.

On March 29, 2020, Robinson was taken to a Detroit hospital due to breathing problems. He died later that day from a suspected case of COVID-19. He was 44 years old. 

[[Nydia Velázquez]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Puerto Rican people, United States representatives from New York, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Nydia Margarita Velázquez Serrano (born March 28, 1953) is a Puerto Rican-American politician. She has been a member of the United States House of Representatives since 1993. Velázquez, a Democrat from New York was the chair of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus until January 3, 2011. 

Velázquez is the first Puerto Rican woman to serve in the United States Congress.

In March 2020, Velázquez was diagnosed with a possible case of COVID-19 during the coronavirus pandemic.

[[Montpellier Business School]]

CATEGORIES: Education in France

Montpellier Business School is an European higher studies establishment. The school is in Montpellier, France. It is one of the oldest business school in the world established in 1897. 

MBS is specialist in the fields of economics, social sciences and management.

[[Spider silk]]

CATEGORIES: Fibers

Most spiders can produce a natural fibre which they use for different purposes. This fibre is called spider silk. Depending on the type of spider, spider silk is uses for purposes of catching prey (either by weaving a net, or by throwing a sticky thread at prey), to get away from predators, and to protect the eggs and the young in a cocoon. Spider silk  is very resistant, and has a high tensile strength, it does not tear easily.

Unlike the silk from silkworms, spider silk cannot be produced in large quantities. 

[[Adam Schlesinger]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winners, Grammy Award winners, 1967 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American rock singers, American rock guitarists, Record producers, Singer-songwriters from New York City, Musicians from New York City, Businesspeople from New York City, Singers from New Jersey, Writers from New Jersey, Musicians from New Jersey, Businesspeople from New Jersey, People from Montclair, New Jersey

Adam Lyons Schlesinger (October 31, 1967 – April 1, 2020) was an American singer-songwriter, record producer, and guitarist. He won three Emmys, a Grammy, and the ASCAP Pop Music Award. He was nominated for an Oscar, Tony Award and Golden Globe for best original song in 1997.

His best known work was writing and co-producing the title song to That Thing You Do!. He composed "Master Of The Seas" for Ice Age: Continental Drift performed by Jennifer Lopez, Peter Dinklage and others. He wrote and produced three songs for Music and Lyrics. He also wrote "Stacy's Mom".

He was a founding member of the bands Fountains of Wayne, Ivy, and Tinted Windows. He is a key songwriter and producer for Brooklyn-based synth-pop duo Fever High.

Schlesinger grew up in Manhattan and Montclair, New Jersey. He studied at Williams College.

On March 31, 2020, Schlesinger was diagnosed with COVID-19 and hospitalized under critical condition. He died from the infection the following day in Poughkeepsie, New York at the age of 52.

[[Peter Singer]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, 20th century philosophers, 21st century philosophers, Australian academics, Australian Jews, Australian essayists, Jewish atheists, Writers from Melbourne

Peter Albert David Singer AUS (born 6 July 1946) is an Australian moral philosopher. He is the Ira W. DeCamp Professor of Bioethics at Princeton University. He is also laureate professor of the Centre for Applied Philosophy and Public Ethics at the University of Melbourne. In the area of applied ethics, he talks about ethical issues from a secular, utilitarian perspective. 

Singer is well-known for his book Animal Liberation (1975). The book argues in favour of veganism. His essay "Famine, Affluence, and Morality" argues in favour of donating to help the global poor. He has twice served as chair of the philosophy department at Monash University. In 1996, he ran as a Greens candidate for the Australian Senate. In 2004, he was named as the Australian Humanist of the Year by the Council of Australian Humanist Societies.

Singer was born in Melbourne, Victoria. His parents were Austrian Jews. They moved to Australia from Vienna in 1938–39, after Austria's annexation by Nazi Germany. Singer is an atheist.

[[IPadOS]]

CATEGORIES: IPad, Apple software, Operating systems

iPadOS is a mobile operating system made by Apple Inc. for iPad tablet computers. It was released on September 24, 2019. It replaced iOS 12. 

[[Manti, Utah]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Utah, County seats in Utah

Manti (ˈ MAN) is a city in and the county seat of Sanpete County, Utah, United States. The population was 3,276 at the 2010 United States Census.

[[Ephraim, Utah]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Utah

Ephraim is a city in Sanpete County, Utah, United States. The population was 6,135 at the 2010 census, making it the largest city in Sanpete County.

[[Mount Pleasant, Utah]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Utah

Mount Pleasant is a city in Sanpete County, Utah, in the United States. Mt. Pleasant is known for its 19th-century main street buildings. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 3,260.

[[Spencer Cox (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, American lawyers, Businesspeople from Utah, Governors of Utah, American mayors, US Republican Party politicians, Lieutenant Governors of Utah

Spencer James Cox (born July 11, 1975) is an American attorney and politician. He is a member of the  Republican Party. In 2021, he became Governor of Utah. Cox was the eighth Lieutenant Governor of Utah from October 2013 to January 2021.

Cox was raised in Fairview, Utah. He was appointed to Fairview's city council, and later acted as the city’s mayor. 

In October 2013, Governor Gary Herbert picked Cox to replace Greg Bell as lieutenant governor. Cox ran for governor and won the November 2020 election.

[[Fairview, Utah]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Utah

Fairview is a city in northern Sanpete County, Utah, United States. The population was 1,247 at the 2010 census.

[[Scalar (physics)]]

CATEGORIES: Basic physics ideas

In physics, a scalar or scalar quantities are the physical quantity which are expressed only by their magnitude without detection. The contrary notion is vector.

[[Peter's Two Dads]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 television episodes, 2007 in American television, Family Guy (season 5) episodes, Television episodes about birthdays

"Peter's Two Dads" is the tenth episode of the fifth season of Family Guy. It was first shown on television on February 11, 2007 on the Fox network. 7.97 million people watched the episode when it was first shown on television. 

In the episode, Peter travels to Ireland to find his biological father after he accidentally kills his stepfather at his daughter's birthday party. While this happens, Lois hits Stewie and Stewie wants Lois to hit him more. The episode was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Original Music and Lyrics for it's song "Drunken Irish Dad," at the 59th Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards.

[[Louise Ebrel]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, French singers, Guitarists, French musicians

Louise Ebrel (27 July 1932 – 30 March 2020) was a French singer and guitarist. She was born at Treffrin in the Côtes-du-Nord. From 1991 to 2006 she worked with singer-poet Denez Prigent in concerts, both as a duo and with his musical group. 

Beginning in 1996 she performed with Ifig Flatrès in kan ha diskan at festoù noz. In 2006 she began performing on Breton stages with the punk group Les Ramoneurs de menhirs and the rockers of Red Cardell.

Ebrel died on 30 March 2020 at the age of 87.

[[Eva Krížiková]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Slovakian actors, Stage actors, Movie actors, Television actors

Eva Krížiková (ˈɛʋa ˈkɾiːʒikɔʋaː; July 15, 1934 – March 31, 2020) was a Slovak actress. She was seen as the best Slovak entertainer and The First Lady of Slovak Humor. She was born in Račišdorf, Czechoslovakia. Her first starring role came in Friday the 13th (1953). Her best known role was in In the Coat of Lioness' Arms (1994).

Krížiková died on March 31, 2020 in Malacky, Slovakia at the age of 85.

[[Kiyoshi Sasabe]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls, Japanese movie directors

Kiyoshi Sasabe was a Japanese movie director. He was born in Shimonoseki, Yamaguchi. 

Sasabe's movie Half a Confession won the best picture award at the 28th Japan Academy Prize. His other best known work include Hi wa mata noboru (2002), Chirusoku no natsu (2003), Half a Confession (2004), Deguchi no nai umi (2006), Town of Evening Calm, Country of Cherry Blossoms (2007) and Tsure ga Utsu ni Narimashite (2011).

Sasabe died on March 31, 2020 after falling at his hotel in Shimonoseki at the age of 62.

[[Andrew Jack (dialect coach)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, British voice actors, Actors from London, British movie actors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom

Andrew Jack (born Andrew Hutchinson; 28 January 1944 – 31 March 2020) was a British dialect coach and actor. He was born in London. He  had worked on over 80 movies beginning in 1982. He had worked with over 200 actors including Robert Downey Jr., Pierce Brosnan, Cate Blanchett, and Viggo Mortensen. He was a supervising dialect coach for The Lord of the Rings, he created the Middle-earth accents and taught them, along with Elvish and Black Speech, to the cast of the trilogy.

Jack can also be seen in the Star Wars movie series playing Resistance Major (later promoted to General) Caluan Ematt in Star Wars: The Force Awakens and Star Wars: The Last Jedi. He also voiced the character of Moloch in Solo: A Star Wars Story.

On March 31, 2020, Jack died from COVID-19 at the age of 76.

[[Nellie Bertram]]

CATEGORIES: The Office (U.S. TV series) characters, Fictional British people

Nellie Bertram is a fictional character on the U.S. comedy television series The Office, played by Catherine Tate. She first appears as a guest star in the seventh season, where she interviewed for the Regional Manager job at the Dunder Mifflin Scranton branch. 

She is an original character, and was not copied in the original British version of the series.

She was reportedly the top choice to replace Steve Carell, but was unable to join the series, due to her other work at the West End production of the Shakespeare play Much Ado About Nothing. 

However, Tate later returned to the role as a series regular for the second half of season eight and continued in the role for the final season.

[[Rafael Gómez Nieto]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, Spanish military people

Rafael Gómez Nieto (21 January 1921 – 31 March 2020) was a Spanish soldier. He was a veteran of the Spanish Civil War and World War II. He was born in Almería, Andalusia. He fought with "Lleva del Biberó" and was part of the Battle of the Ebro with Spanish Republican Army.

After the war, he went to France where he was kept in the Saint-Cyprien camp. Four months later he was able to reach Algeria with his father, who was in the Argelés internment camp. After the invasion of North Africa by the Allies during World War II, he became part of the 9th Company (La Nueve) of the 2nd Armored Division that. 

He died on 31 March 2020 in a nursing home in Strasbourg (France) from COVID-19 during the coronavirus pandemic. He was the last living survivor of La Nueve.

[[Mohamed Al-Fayed]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, Billionaires, Egyptian businesspeople, People from Alexandria

Mohamed Al-Fayed (محمد  شاكر عبد السيد الفايد; born Mohamed Fayed; 27 January 1929) is an Egyptian businessman. Fayed's business interests include ownership of Hôtel Ritz Paris and formerly Harrods. He sold Fulham Football Club to Shahid Khan in 2013. His son Dodi died in a car crash in Paris with Diana, Princess of Wales in 1997.

Fayed was born in Roshdy, Alexandria. Dodi was the child from his first marriage to Samira Khashoggi from 1954 to 1956. He later married Finnish socialite and former model Heini Wathén in 1985. The couple have four children, including Omar.

[[Gas, Kansas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Allen County, Kansas, 1890s establishments in Kansas, 1898 establishments in the United States

Gas is a city in the northwestern part of Allen County, in southeast Kansas, in the Central United States. In 2010, 564 people lived there.  The city was named for the natural gas that was found in the area.

[[Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers]]

CATEGORIES: Musicians

Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers was a group of musicians. They were making music from the 1980s decade to 2002. Starting in 1996, they started singing the theme song for the TV show for children, Arthur.

[[Circular orbit]]

CATEGORIES: Orbits

In astronomy, a circular orbit refers to an object (such as a planet or a star) which orbits around a central body in a fixed, circular motion. This motion follows Kepler's Laws. A circular orbit occurs when the eccentricity of its orbit is equal to 0.

Objects with a circular orbit are uncommon. The Moon moves in an elliptical orbit around the Earth, and the planets move in an elliptical orbit around the Sun.

Other types of motion in astronomy include elliptical orbit, parabolic trajectory, and hyperbolic trajectory.

[[Elliptical orbit]]

CATEGORIES: Orbits

In astronomy, an elliptical orbit refers to an object (such as a planet or star) which orbits around a central body in an elliptical motion. This motion follows Kepler's Laws. An elliptical orbit occurs when the eccentricity of its orbit is greater than 0, and less than 1.

The Moon moves around the Earth in an elliptical orbit, and the planets move around the Sun in an elliptical orbit.

Other types of motion in astronomy include circular orbit, parabolic trajectory, and hyperbolic trajectory.

[[Parabolic trajectory]]

CATEGORIES: Orbits

In astronomy, a parabolic trajectory (also known as parabolic orbit or parabolic escape trajectory) refers to an object (such as an asteroid) which follows a path similar to a parabola around another object. This motion follows Kepler's Laws. A parabolic trajectory occurs when the eccentricity of its orbit is equal to 1.

Other types of motion in astronomy include circular orbit, elliptical orbit, and hyperbolic trajectory.

[[Ekalaka, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Ekalaka is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Carter County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 332 people.

Known for its sandstone rock and open plains, Ekalaka is part of the Montana Dinosaur Trail. It is home to the Carter County Museum, which is known for its dinosaur collection. Nearby is the Custer National Forest.

[[Fort Benton, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana, 19th-century establishments in Montana, 1846 establishments in the United States

Fort Benton is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Chouteau County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 1,464 people.

Established in 1846, Fort Benton is the oldest settlement in Montana. The Missouri River flows along the town.

[[Jordan, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana, 20th-century establishments in Montana, 1951 establishments in the United States

Jordan is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Garfield County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 343 people.

A post office was opened in Jordan on July 11, 1899. Jordan was incorporated as a town in 1951.

[[Ryegate, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Montana, County seats in Montana

Ryegate is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Golden Valley County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 245 people.

Ryegate is on the north bank of the Musselshell River.

[[Stanford, Montana]]

Stanford is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Judith Basin County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 401 people.

Chester is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Liberty County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 847 people.
