Circle is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of McCone County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 615 people.

[[Superior, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Montana, County seats in Montana

Superior is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Mineral County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 812 people.

Superior is within the Bitterroot Range of mountains. The Clark Fork flows through downtown.

[[Winnett, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Montana, County seats in Montana

Winnett is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Petroleum County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 182 people.

[[Broadus, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Montana, County seats in Montana, 1900s establishments in Montana, 1900 establishments in the United States

Broadus is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Powder River County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 468 people.

The Broadus post office was created in 1900. Broadus became the county seat in 1920.

[[Terry, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana, 1910s establishments in Montana, 1910 establishments in the United States

Terry is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Prairie County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 605 people.

The town was incorporated in 1910.

[[Thompson Falls, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana, 1910s establishments in Montana, 1910 establishments in the United States

Thompson Falls is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Sanders County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 1,313 people.

Thompson Falls was named after British explorer, geographer and fur trader David Thompson. He founded a North West Company fur trading post. The town is next to natural waterfalls on the Clark Fork river.

Thompson Falls was established in 1910.

[[Columbus, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Columbus is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Stillwater County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 1,893 people living there.

The community started as a stagecoach station on the Yellowstone River.

[[Shelby, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Montana, County seats in Montana

Shelby is a city in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Toole County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 3,376 people living there.

Amtrak, the national passenger rail system, provides daily service to Shelby.

[[Hysham, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Montana, County seats in Montana

Hysham is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Treasure County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 312 people living there.

The Yellowstone River is to the north.

[[Wibaux, Montana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Montana, County seats in Montana

Wibaux is a town in Montana in the United States. It is the county seat of Wibaux County. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 589 people living there.

Beaver Creek runs through the town. It has been known to contain large Walleye and Northern pike.

[[Claude Frollo]]

Claude Frollo is a fictional character in The Hunchback of Notre Dame created by Victor Hugo.

[[Pape Diouf]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Senegalese writers, African businesspeople, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, Journalists

Mababa "Pape" Diouf (18 December 1951 – 31 March 2020) was a Senegalese journalist. He is best known for being the president of French football club Olympique de Marseille between 2005 and 2009. He has been noted by publications as the first black president of a top-tier football club in Europe. He moved to Marseille at the age of eighteen.

Diouf was born in Abéché, Chad, to Senegalese parents. His family moved back to Senegal shortly after Diouf's birth.

On 31 March 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, Diouf died in Dakar due to the disease. He was 68.

[[Wallace Roney]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, African American musicians, American jazz musicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Infectious disease deaths in New Jersey, Trumpeters, Musicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Wallace Roney (May 25, 1960 – March 31, 2020) was an American jazz (hard bop and post-bop) trumpeter. He took lessons from Clark Terry and Dizzy Gillespie. He studied with Miles Davis from 1985 until his death in 1991. He was the only trumpet player Davis personally mentored. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

On March 31, 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Roney died of COVID-19 in Paterson, New Jersey. He was 59.

[[Ivo Mahlknecht]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, 1964 Winter Olympics, 1968 Winter Olympics, Italian Olympians, Skiers

Ivo Oswald Mahlknecht (21 May 1939 – 31 March 2020) was an Italian alpine skier. He competed at the 1964 and 1968 Winter Olympics in the downhill, slalom and giant slalom events. He was born in Urtijëi.

On 31 March 2020, Mahlknecht died in Brixen at the age of 80.

[[Roy Gibson]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, Living people, English businesspeople, English scientists, People from Manchester

Roy Gibson (born 4 July 1924) is a British space official. He was born in Manchester. He served as a director-general of the European Space Research Organisation (ESRO). He was the first director-general of the European Space Agency (1975–1980) and the British National Space Centre (1985–1987).

[[Holliday Grainger]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, Actors from Manchester, English child actors, English movie actors, English radio actors, English stage actors, English television actors, English voice actors

Holliday Clark Grainger (born 27 March 1988) is an English actress. Her TV roles include Lucrezia Borgia in the Showtime series The Borgias (2011–2013), Bonnie Parker in Bonnie & Clyde (2013), Robin Ellacott in Strike (2017–present) and DI Rachel Carey in The Capture (2019). Her movie roles include Great Expectations (2012), Cinderella (2015), The Finest Hours (2016) and Tulip Fever (2017).

Grainger was born in Didsbury, Manchester. She has Italian ancestry through a grandfather.

[[Lily James]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, Actors from Surrey, English movie actors, English stage actors, English television actors, Singers from Surrey

Lily Chloe Ninette Thomson (born 5 April 1989), better known as Lily James, is an English actress and singer. Her acting career started with the TV series Just William (2010). Her breakthrough role was the title role in the romance fantasy movie Cinderella (2015). She also acted on television in Downton Abbey (2012–2015) and War & Peace (2016).

James has also starred in movies such as Baby Driver (2017), Darkest Hour (2017), The Guernsey Literary and Potato Peel Pie Society (2018), Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again (2018) and Yesterday (2019).

James was born in Esher, Surrey. Her father, James Thomson, died of cancer in 2008. She took her father's given name as her stage name when she learnt of an actress also named Lily Thomson. She has dated actor Matt Smith since 2014.

[[Konnie Huq]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, BBC television presenters, English children's writers, English television writers, ITV presenters, People from Ealing, People from Hammersmith, Television personalities from London, Writers from London

OOOAAAAAAHHHHH SEXY KONNIE

Kanak Asha "Konnie" Huq (born 17 July 1975) is a British television presenter and writer. She is the longest-serving female presenter of Blue Peter. She presented the children's programme from December 1997 until January 2008. She also presented the 2010 series of The Xtra Factor on ITV2. She co-wrote the Black Mirror episode "Fifteen Million Merits" with her husband Charlie Brooker.

Huq was born in Hammersmith, west London. Her parents are Bangladeshi Muslims. She grew up in Ealing, west London. She married Charlie Brooker in 2010. The couple have two sons. Her sister is Labour MP Rupa Huq.

She supports a sexy, brand-new, blue EU-army with compulsory military service for all males who are citizens of the EU. She wants them to wear sexy, tight, kaky leather outfits.

[[Deaths in May 2020]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, May 2020 events

The following is a list of deaths that should be noted in May 2020. For deaths that should be noted before the month that the world is in, please see "Months". Individuals listed must have notability. Names under each date are noted in the order of the alphabet by last name or pseudonym. Deaths of non-humans are noted here also if it is worth noting.

Each listing of a death must have a source. If no reference is included, the death notice will be removed. The following are the requirements of adding a name to the list in its order: name, age, where they came from, what the person is known for, cause of death (if known) and a source.

[[Bill Dubuque]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth missing (living people), Living people, American television writers, Screenwriters from Missouri, Writers from St. Louis, Missouri

Bill Dubuque is an American screenwriter. He is known for co-creating the Netflix crime drama series Ozark (2017–present). His movie credits include The Judge (2014), A Family Man (2016) and The Accountant (2016). In 2017, he scripted an upcoming DC Extended Universe Nightwing movie.

Dubuque was born in St. Louis, Missouri. He is married and has three children.

[[Emma Appleton]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 births, Living people, Actors from Oxfordshire, English models, English movie actors, English television actors

Emma Jill Appleton (born 11 December 1991) is an English actress and model. She is best known for her role as Feef Symonds in the Channel 4 spy thriller series Traitors (2019). She has also appeared in The End of the F***ing World, Genius and The Witcher.

Appleton was born in Witney, Oxfordshire.

[[Bill Pullman]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Actors from New York, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors

William James Pullman (born December 17, 1953) is an American actor. His first movie role was in Ruthless People (1986). He has since starred in movies such as Spaceballs (1987), The Accidental Tourist (1988), Singles (1992), Sleepless in Seattle (1993), While You Were Sleeping (1995), Casper (1995), Independence Day (1996), Lost Highway (1997), Lake Placid (1999) and Titan A.E. (2000).

Pullman's TV credits include 1600 Penn (2012–13) and The Sinner (2017–present). He has also had a long stage acting career. He has been on Broadway many times, including in Edward Albee's The Goat, or Who is Sylvia? in 2002.

Pullman was born in Hornell, New York. He married Tamara Hurwitz in 1987. The couple have three children, including actor Lewis Pullman.

[[Hornell, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Hornell is a town in Steuben County, New York, United States. As of the 2010 census, the town had a population of 8,563.

[[SpongeBob's Big Birthday Blowout]]

CATEGORIES: SpongeBob SquarePants episodes, 2019 television episodes, Television episodes about birthdays

"SpongeBob's Big Birthday Blowout" is an episode in season 12 of SpongeBob SquarePants. In the episode, SpongeBob celebrates his 20th anniversary. It first aired on July 12, 2019.

[[The Sinner (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s American drama television series, 2010s crime television series, American crime drama television series, Television series set in New York, English-language television programs

The Sinner is an American anthology crime drama mystery television series. The first season is based on the novel of the same name by German crime writer Petra Hammesfahr. The series was meant to be a "close-ended series" of eight episodes that aired on USA Network from January to August 2017. A second season aired in 2018. The show's third season aired in early 2020.

The series stars Bill Pullman as Detective Harry Ambrose. Other cast members of the show include Jessica Biel, Christopher Abbott, Carrie Coon, Natalie Paul, Elisha Henig, Tracy Letts, Matt Bomer and Chris Messina.

[[Nur Hassan Hussein]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Ambassadors of Somalia, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, Infectious disease deaths in London, Prime Ministers of Somalia

Nur Hassan Hussein (Nuur Xasan Xuseen Cadde, نور حسن حسين‎; 16 February 1937 – 1 April 2020) was a Somali politician. He served as Prime Minister of Somalia from November 2007 to February 2009. He was Somalia's ambassador to Italy from 2009 to 2013. He was born in Mogadishu.

On 1 April 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Hussein died in Camberwell, London of COVID-19. He was 83.

[[Jack Schofield (journalist)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, British journalists, British photographers, 1947 births

Jack Schofield (1947 – 31 March 2020) was a British technology journalist. He wrote the Ask Jack column for The Guardian and covered technology for the newspaper from 1983 to 2010. 

He edited photography and computing techniques and wrote many books on photography and on computing, including The Darkroom Book (1981).

He died on 31 March 2020 of a heart attack on 27 March 2020, aged 72.

[[Lou Gramm]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, American Christians, American rock singers, People from Rochester, New York, Singer-songwriters from New York

Lou Gramm (born Louis Andrew Grammatico; May 2, 1950) is an American rock singer-songwriter. He is best known for being the original lead singer of the British-American rock band Foreigner. He performed the main vocals of all of Foreigner's charted songs during the 1970s and 80s, including "Feels Like the First Time", "Cold as Ice", "Hot Blooded", "Dirty White Boy", "Urgent", "Juke Box Hero", "Waiting for a Girl Like You", "Break It Up", "I Want to Know What Love Is", "That Was Yesterday", "Say You Will" and "I Don't Want to Live Without You".

Gramm was born in Rochester, New York. He has five children. He is married to Robyn Grammatico. He is a born again Christian.

[[Steve Winwood]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, British keyboardists, English organists, English rock guitarists, English singer-songwriters‎, Grammy Award winners, Musicians from Birmingham, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees

Stephen Lawrence Winwood (born 12 May 1948) is an English singer, songwriter and musician. His music covers genres such as progressive rock, blue-eyed soul, rhythm and blues, blues rock, pop rock and jazz. He was a member of groups such as The Spencer Davis Group, Traffic, Blind Faith and Go. He had a successful solo career with hits including "While You See a Chance", "Valerie", "Back in the High Life Again" and two US Billboard Hot 100 number ones, "Higher Love" and "Roll with It". He was added into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame as a member of Traffic in 2004.

Winwood was born in Handsworth, Birmingham. He has been married twice and has four children.

[[List of The Powerpuff Girls episodes]]

The Powerpuff Girls is an American animated superhero comedy-adventure created by Craig McCracken aired on Cartoon Network, It aired from 1998 to 2009.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        

[[Martin Khor]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Economists, Journalists, Malaysian people

Martin Khor Kok Peng (9 November 1951 – 1 April 2020) was a Malaysian journalist and economist. He served as the executive director of the South Centre from 2009 to 2018. South Centre is an intergovernmental organisation of developing countries based in Geneva, Switzerland. He was also director of the Third World Network during his life. Starting in 1978, he was a columnist for The Star. He was born in Penang.

On 1 April 2020, Khor died of cancer in Penang. He was 68.

[[Touhou]]

CATEGORIES: Video game series, Action video games

Touhou or Touhou Project (Japanese:東方Project) is a series of space shooter bullet hell games developed by a single individual game developer Team Shanghai Alice. From the year 1995, the team leader, Jun'ya "ZUN" Ota, has made code, art, writing and music for the series, publishing 18 games and five spin-offs as of May 2021. He has also made similar print works and albums, and worked together with the developer Twilight Frontier on six Touhou fighting games.

The games are set in Gensokyo, a place sealed from the outside world where mostly humans and youkai live. Youkai creatures are from Japanese folklore that are represented as people in the game as female characters most of the time. Reimu Hakurei, the shrine maiden of the Hakurei Shrine and the main character of the series, is often involved in settling supernatural incidents in and around Gensokyo.

The first five games were developed for the Japanese NEC PC-9800 computer series, the first one, Highly Responsive to Prayers, was released in August 1997. 

The series' famous danmaku system was introduced in the second game, Story Of Eastern Wonderland, also in 1997. The release of Embodiment of Scarlet Devil was a change to Microsoft Windows. More sequels followed, including some spin-offs that were different from the normal bullet hell format.

[[José Enrique]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, Cancer survivors, Liverpool F.C. players, People from Valencia, Premier League players, Spanish footballers

José Enrique Sánchez Díaz (born 23 January 1986) is a Spanish former footballer. He played as a left back.

Enrique was born in Valencia. He started career with Levante before signing for rivals Valencia. He also made La Liga appearances for Celta and Villarreal. He then spent nine years in England with Newcastle United and Liverpool, totalling 161 Premier League appearances. With Liverpool, He won the League Cup and lost the FA Cup final in 2012. He retired because of injury in 2017, after a year back in Spain with Real Zaragoza.

Enrique was diagnosed with chordoma, a rare brain tumour, in May 2018. In April 2019, he was given the all-clear.

[[Chris Cuomo]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, CNN people, Journalists from New York City, People from Queens

Christopher Charles Cuomo (born August 9, 1970) is an American television journalist. He is best known as the presenter of Cuomo Prime Time, a weeknight news analysis show on CNN. He is the former ABC News chief law and justice correspondent and the co-anchor for ABC's 20/20. He was also one of two co-anchors of the weekday edition of New Day until May 2018.

Fredo is the youngest child of Mario Cuomo, the former Governor of New York, and Matilda Cuomo (née Raffa). His brother Andrew Cuomo is the current Governor of New York.

FREDO was born in the New York City borough of Queens. He married Cristina Greeven in 2001. The couple have three children. On March 31, 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Cuomo made it clear that he had tested positive to COVID-19.

[[Marcus Smart]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, African-American basketball players, Boston Celtics players, Sportspeople from Texas, American basketball players

Marcus Osmond Smart (born March 6, 1994) is an American professional basketball player. He plays for the Boston Celtics of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He played college basketball for the Oklahoma State Cowboys before being drafted with the sixth overall pick in the 2014 NBA draft. He was born in Lancaster, Texas.

In March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Smart tested positive to COVID-19. By the end of the month, he was given the all-clear.

[[Sean Payton]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, American football quarterbacks, Chicago Bears players, Football players from California, National Football League coaches, Sportspeople from Illinois, People from Naperville, Illinois

Patrick Sean Payton (born December 29, 1963) is an American football coach and former player. He is the current head coach of the New Orleans Saints of the National Football League (NFL). He has been the team's head coach since 2006. As coach of the Saints, he won the Super Bowl in 2010. During his playing career, Payton played for the Chicago Bruisers, Pittsburgh Gladiators, Ottawa Rough Riders, Chicago Bears and British team Leicester Panthers. He was born in San Mateo, California and grew up in Naperville, Illinois.

In March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Payton tested positive to COVID-19.

[[Branislav Blažić]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Serbia, Serbian politicians, Surgeons

Branislav Blažić (Бранислав Блажић; 1 April 1957 – 1 April 2020) was a Serbian surgeon and politician. He served many terms in the assemblies of FR Yugoslavia, Serbia and Vojvodina. He served as Minister of Environmental Protection from 1998 to 2000. He was a member of the far-right Radical Party before joining the Progressive Party in 2008. He was born in Kikinda, Vojvodina.

On 1 April 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Blažić died in Belgrade of COVID-19. He was 63.

[[Arvo Sarapuu]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Estonian politicians, Business people

Arvo Sarapuu (August 26, 1953 – March 17, 2020) was an Estonian businessman and politician. He was a member of the Estonian Centre Party. Sarapuu was the first post-independence County Governor of Järva County from 1989 until 1997. He then was the Deputy Mayor of Tallinn, the capital of Estonia, from April 2011 until his resignation on May 26, 2017.

Sarapuu died on March 17, 2020, at the age of 66. 

[[Stephen Murphy]]

CATEGORIES: American police officers, 1957 births, American people, Living people

Stephen "Steve" Murphy (born 1957) is an American federal agent who worked for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA). Murphy and another agent named Javier Peña are known for being the lead investigators of Pablo Escobar, the Colombian drug lord and leader of the Medellín Cartel.

[[Anti-Turkism]]

CATEGORIES: Turkey, Discrimination

Anti-Turkism or Turkophobia is a term of being fearful, racist and discriminative against the Turkish people or Turkic countries.

The term refers to intolerance not only against the Turks across all regions, but also against Turkic groups as a whole, including Azerbaijanis, Crimean Tatars and Turkmens. It is also applied on groups who developed in part under the influence of Turkish culture and traditions while converting to Islam, especially during Ottoman times, such as Albanians, Bosniaks and other smaller ethnic groups around Balkans during the period of Ottoman rule. It can also refer to racism against Turkish people living outside of Turkey following the Turkish diaspora.

The main historic enemies of Turkic people are considered to be Greeks, Armenians, Kurds and Serbians.

[[Maurice Delbez]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, French movie directors, French screenwriters

Maurice Delbez (28 July 1922 – 23 March 2020) was a French movie director. He was born in Bezons, France. His best known movie is On Foot, on Horse, and on Wheels. He also made many documentaries which were aired on France 3 and France 2. He wrote his autobiography, Ma vie racontée à mon chien cinéphile, in 2001. 

Delbez died on 23 March 2020 at the age of 97.

[[James A. Redden]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from Oregon, Politicians from Massachusetts, People from Springfield, Massachusetts, US Democratic Party politicians

James Anthony "Jim" Redden Jr. (March 13, 1929 – March 31, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician from Oregon. He was a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the District of Oregon from 1980 to 1995 after being nominated by President Jimmy Carter. He was a member of the Democratic Party. He was the state's Treasurer from 1973 to 1977 and Attorney General from 1977 to 1980.

Redden was born in Springfield, Massachusetts. He died in Beaverton, Oregon of congestive heart failure on March 31, 2020 at the age of 91.

Cowlitz County is a county in the U.S. state of Washington. The county seat is Kelso. 102,410 people lived there at the 2010 census.

[[List of prime ministers of Somalia]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Somalia

This is a list of prime ministers of Somalia. The Prime Minister of Somalia (Ra'iisul wasaaraha Soomaaliya) is the head of government of Somalia. There have been 18 official prime ministers since the office was created in 1956. 

The incumbent Prime Minister of the Federal Republic of Somalia is Mohamed Hussein Roble since 2020.

[[Skamania County, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Washington (state), 1854 establishments in the United States, Washington (state) counties

Skamania County is a county in the U.S. state of Washington. The county seat is Stevenson. 11,066 people lived there at the 2010 census.

[[Gamergate controversy]]

CATEGORIES: Internet culture, Video games, Journalism

The Gamergate controversy is a popular nickname for a controversy about women and video games as well as ethics in video game journalism.

[[Hassan Ali Khayre]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Somalia

Hassan Ali Khaire (Xasan Cali Khayre, حسن علي خيري; born 15 April 1968), popularly known as Hassan Khaire is a Somali-Norwegian activist, manager and politician. He was the Prime Minister of Somalia from 23 February 2017 to 25 July 2020.

Khaire is a former oil executive. He has been a regional director of the Norwegian Refugee Council charity and served as the director of the British oil company Soma Oil and Gas.

[[President of Somalia]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Somalia

The president of Somalia (Madaxaweynaha Soomaaliya) is the head of state of Somalia. The President is also commander-in-chief of the Somali Armed Forces. The president represents the Federal Republic of Somalia. 

The office of President of Somalia was created with the proclamation of the Republic of Somalia on 1 July 1960. The first president of Somalia was Aden Abdullah Osman Daar. 

The current office-holder is the 9th president Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed ‘Farmaajo’, since 16 February 2017.

[[Kirkel]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Saarland

Kirkel is a municipality in the Saarpfalz district in Saarland, Germany. As of 31 December 2018, 10,040 people lived there.

[[Kevin Duffy]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from New York City, Politicians from Connecticut, People from Greenwich, Connecticut, US Republican Party politicians

Kevin Thomas Duffy (January 10, 1933 – April 1, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician. He was a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York from 1972 to 1998 after being nominated by President Richard Nixon. Duffy was born in New York City. 

Duffy died from problems caused by COVID-19 at a hospital in Greenwich, Connecticut on April 1, 2020, at age 87.

[[Tom Tunney]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, Chicago City Council members, LGBT politicians, Gay men, LGBT people from Chicago, Businesspeople from Chicago, US Democratic Party politicians

Thomas M. Tunney (born August 22, 1955) is an American entrepreneur and politician. He has been an alderman on the Chicago City Council since 2003.  He represents the prominent 44th Ward of the city.

Tunney thought about running for mayor in 2019, but did not and endorsed Lori Lightfoot.

In May 2019, Mayor Lightfoot picked Tunney as Vice Mayor.

Tunney was the first openly gay Chicago Alderman.

[[Montaigne (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, Living people, Australian pop singers, Australian singer-songwriters, Musicians from Sydney, Singers from New South Wales

Jessica Alyssa Cerro (born 14 August 1995), better known as Montaigne, is an Australian art pop singer, songwriter and musician. Her first album, Glorious Heights, was released in 2016. It peaked at No. 4 on the ARIA Albums Chart. At the ARIA Music Awards of 2016, she won Breakthrough Artist – Release for the album and was nominated for three other categories. Also in 2016, she was a featured vocalist on the Hilltop Hoods track "1955". The single reached No. 2 on the ARIA Singles Chart.

Montaigne was meant to represent Australia at the Eurovision Song Contest 2020 with her song "Don't Break Me". However, due to the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, the contest was cancelled. She will instead represent her country in 2021.

Montaigne was born in Sydney, New South Wales. She grew up in the Hills District. She has said her ethnic background is a mixture of Argentine, Spanish, Filipino and French.

[[Vincent Marzello]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Disease-related deaths in London, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Brooklyn

Vincent Marzello (July 4, 1951 – March 31, 2020) was an American actor. He was born in New York City. He appeared on many movies such as The Spy Who Loved Me, Superman, Never Say Never Again, The Witches, Taggart, The House of Eliott, The Fragile Heart, Dalziel and Pascoe, Little Britain, Nuclear Secrets and Mile High. His best known role was as the voice of Farmer Pickles and Robert in Bob the Builder.

In 2009, after being treated for cancer, Marzello was diagnosed with dementia. He died on March 31, 2020 in London, aged 68.

[[Zoltán Peskó]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Conductors, Composers, People from Budapest

Zoltán Peskó (15 February 1937 – 31 March 2020) was a Hungarian conductor and composer. Peskó was born in Budapest. He studied at the Franz Liszt Academy of Music with Goffredo Petrassi and Franco Ferrara, as well as with Pierre Boulez in Switzerland in the 1960s. 

He became an assistant under Lorin Maazel at the German Symphony Orchestra, Berlin. Peskó was chief conductor of the Orquestra Sinfónica Portuguesa, the orchestra of the Teatro Nacional de São Carlos in Lisbon, from 2001 to 2004.

Peskó died on 31 March 2020 at age of 85.

[[Lovech Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Lovech Province is one of the 28 provinces of Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Lovech.

[[Michel Chodkiewicz]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, French educators, French writers

Michel Chodkiewicz (13 May 1929 – 31 March 2020) was a French author and a scholar of Sufism. He was Director-General then President and CEO of Editions du Seuil from 1977 to 1989. He became director of studies at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales where he conducted seminars on Ibn 'Arabi. 

Chodkiewicz died on 31 March 2020 at the age of 90.

[[James Ramsden (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Former Conservative MPs (UK), UK MPs 1951–1955, UK MPs 1955–1959, UK MPs 1959–1964, UK MPs 1964–1966, UK MPs 1966–1970, UK MPs 1970–1974, People from Liverpool

James Edward Ramsden  GBR  (1 November 1923 – 29 March 2020) was a British Conservative politician. He was the last person to hold the office of Secretary of State for War, being in the office from 1963 to 1964. In 1964, he was Minister for the Armed Forces. He worked under the Sir Alec Douglas-Home cabinet. From 1954 to 1964, he was a Member of parliament.

Ramsden was born in Liverpool. He died in Ripon, England on 29 March 2020 at the age of 96.

[[Montana Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Montana Province is a province in northwestern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Montana.

The province borders Serbia in the southwest and Romania in the north. It is between the Danube river and the Balkan Mountains.

[[David Schramm (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from Louisville, Kentucky

David Michael Schramm (August 14, 1946 – March 28, 2020) was an American actor. He was best known for playing the role of Roy Biggins in the TV series Wings. He was born in Louisville, Kentucky. Schramm appeared in the television movie, The Dreamer of Oz: The L. Frank Baum Story (1990), and the miniseries, Kennedy (1983), where he played Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara. Schramm played Vic Dumask in Johnny Handsome (1989).

Schramm died in New York City from a heart attack on March 28, 2020, at the age of 73.

[[Bob Lee (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Los Angeles Angels players, Los Angeles Dodgers players, Cincinnati Reds players, Sportspeople from Iowa

Robert Dean Lee (November 26, 1937 – March 25, 2020) was an American closer and spot starter in Major League Baseball. He played from 1964 through 1968 for the Los Angeles Dodgers, Los Angeles/California Angels, and the Cincinnati Reds. He was born in Ottumwa, Iowa.

Lee died on March 25, 2020, at his home in Lake Havasu City, Arizona at the age of 82.

[[Kingman, Arizona]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Arizona, County seats in Arizona

Kingman is a city in and the county seat of Mohave County, Arizona, United States. According to the 2010 census, the population of the city is 28,068.

[[Pazardzhik Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Pazardzhik Province is a province in southern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Pazardzhik.

The north has Sredna Gora mountain and the south has the Rhodope Mountains. Its main waterway is the river Maritsa.

[[Pernik Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Pernik Province is a province in western Bulgaria. Its main city is Pernik. Other municipalities are Breznik, Kovachevtsi, Radomir, Tran, and Zemen.

[[Pleven Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Pleven Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Pleven.

It is crossed from south to north by the rivers Iskar, Vit and Osam.

[[Plovdiv Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Plovdiv Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is Plovdiv.

The Central Balkan National Park is in the province.

[[Razgrad Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Razgrad Province is a province in northeastern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Razgrad.

[[Ruse Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Ruse Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Ruse.

The Danube Bridge, one of only two bridges opened over the Danube, is in the province.

[[Cristina (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, American pop singers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

Cristina Monet-Palaci (January 17, 1956 – March 31, 2020), better known as Cristina, was an American singer. She is best known for her new wave recordings made for Ze Records around the early 1980s in New York City. Her two studio albums were reissued in 2004. Notable singles by Cristina include "Disco Clone", "Is That All There Is?", "Drive My Car" and "Things Fall Apart".

On March 31, 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Cristina died of COVID-19. She was 64. 

[[Shumen Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Shumen Province is a province in northeastern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Shumen.

[[Silistra Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Silistra Province is a province of Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Silistra. Other municipalities are Alfatar, Dulovo, Glavinitsa, Kaynardzha, Sitovo, and Tutrakan.

[[Sliven Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Sliven Province is a province in southeastern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Sliven. Other municipalities are Kotel, Nova Zagora and Tvarditsa.

The Sinite Kamani Nature Park is in the province.

[[Smolyan Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Smolyan Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Smolyan.

[[Sofia Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Sofia Province is a province (oblast) of Bulgaria. The province does not include Sofia in its territories, but Sofia remains its administrative center.

With a territory of 7 020 km², Sofia Province is the second-largest in Bulgaria. Stara Planina, Sredna Gora and Rila are the main mountain ranges. Rila is the source of the Iskar, the longest river that runs entirely within Bulgarian territory.

[[Stara Zagora Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Stara Zagora is a province of Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Stara Zagora.

[[Targovishte Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Targovishte Province is a province in northeastern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Targovishte. Other municipalities are Popovo, Omurtag, Antonovo, and Opaka.

[[Varna Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Varna Province is a province in eastern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Varna.

Golden Sands Nature Park is in the province.

[[Veliko Tarnovo Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Veliko Tarnovo is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Veliko Tarnovo.

[[Vidin Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Vidin Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Vidin.

The Danube forms the border with Romania. Magura Cave, with its cave painting from 10,000 BC, is in the province.

[[Vratsa Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Vratsa Province is a province in Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Vratsa.

It is between the Danube in the north and Stara Planina mountain in the south. Vrachanski Balkan Natural Park and the cave Ledenika are both in the province.

[[Yambol Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Bulgaria

Yambol is a province in southeastern Bulgaria. The capital city is also named Yambol. Other municipalities are Bolyarovo, Elhovo, Straldzha, and Tundzha.

The Tundja River flows through the province.

[[Ellis Marsalis Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American jazz musicians, American educators, American pianists, Musicians from New Orleans, Louisiana

Ellis Louis Marsalis Jr. (November 14, 1934 – April 1, 2020) was an American jazz pianist and educator. Marsalis became known in the 1980s and 1990s. He was a member of a well known musical family in New Orleans, with sons Branford Marsalis and Wynton Marsalis becoming internationally known. He was born in New Orleans.

In the 1950s and 1960s he worked with Ed Blackwell, Cannonball Adderley, Nat Adderley, and Al Hirt. During the 1970s he taught at the New Orleans Center for Creative Arts. His students have included Terence Blanchard, Harry Connick Jr., Donald Harrison, Kent Jordan, Marlon Jordan, and Nicholas Payton.

In 2008, Marsalis was added into The Louisiana Music Hall of Fame.

On April 1, 2020, Marsalis died at the age of 85 after being hospitalized in New Orleans with COVID-19 symptoms.

[[David C. Driskell]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American painters, American educators, People from Georgia (U.S. state), People from Maryland

David C. Driskell (June 7, 1931 – April 1, 2020) was an American artist and scholar. His works focused in the field of African-American art. Driskell was emeritus professor at the University of Maryland, College Park. He was born in Eatonton, Georgia. In 2000, Driskell was honored by President Bill Clinton as one of 12 recipients of the National Humanities Medal. 

The David C. Driskell Center at the University of Maryland, College Park was named after him.

Driskell died at a hospital in Hyattsville, Maryland on April 1, 2020 of COVID-19 at the age of 88.

[[Eatonton, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

Eatonton is a city in and county seat of Putnam County, Georgia, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 6,480. It was named after William Eaton, an officer and diplomat involved in the First Barbary War. 

[[Putnam County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1807 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Putnam County is a county in the center of the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 21,218. The county seat is Eatonton.

[[Gerardo Ruiz Esparza]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Mexico, Deaths from stroke, Mexican lawyers, Politicians from Mexico City

Gerardo Ruiz Esparza (22 April 1949 – 1 April 2020) was a Mexican attorney and politician. From 2012 to 2018, he served as the Secretary of Communications and Transportation in the cabinet of Enrique Peña Nieto. He was born in Mexico City.

On 1 April 2020, Ruiz Esparza died of a stroke in Mexico City. He was 70.

[[Dagmar R. Henney]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, German mathematicians, American mathematicians, American educators, Scientists from Berlin, Writers from Berlin

Dagmar Renate Kirchner Henney (born May 6, 1931) is a German-born American mathematician and professor of calculus, finite mathematics, and measure and integration at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.. She is also known for her works to the study of additive set-values and Banach spaces. She was born in Berlin. 

[[Onward (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 comedy movies, 2020s animated movies, 2020s fantasy movies, Pixar movies, American animated movies, American fantasy-comedy movies

Onward is a 2020 American computer-animated urban fantasy comedy movie produced by Pixar Animation Studios for Walt Disney Pictures. The movie is directed by Dan Scanlon.

It stars Tom Holland, Chris Pratt, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, and Octavia Spencer.

It is set in a suburban fantasy world. The movie is about two elf brothers who go out on a journey to find an artifact that will bring back their dead father.

The movie  was released in the United States on March 6, 2020. It had positive reviews from critics. The movie did not make a lot of money because of the  2019–20 coronavirus pandemic. It was made available digitally two weeks after its theatrical release.

[[Matilda Cuomo]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, American activists, American philanthropists, People from New York City

Matilda Cuomo  (born September 16, 1931) is an American activist and philanthropist. She was the First Lady of New York from 1983 to 1994. She is the widow of Governor of New York Mario Cuomo and mother of current Governor of New York Andrew Cuomo and CNN presenter Chris Cuomo. She is the founder of the Child Advocacy Group Mentoring USA. 

Cuomo was added into the National Women’s Hall of Fame in 2017.

[[Dirceu Pinto]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrhythmia, Brazilian sportspeople

Dirceu José Pinto (10 September 1980 – 1 April 2020) was a Brazilian Paralympic boccia player. He had muscular dystrophy. He won an individual and pairs gold medals at the 2008 and 2012 Paralympics in the BC4 category. At the 2016 Olympics he placed second in the mixed pairs.

Pinto died from a heart arrhythmia on 1 April 2020 at the age of 39.

[[Andrew Parker Bowles]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, People from Wiltshire, British military people, People from Surrey

Brigadier Andrew Henry Parker Bowles GBR (born 27 December 1939) is a retired British Army officer. He is the former husband of Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, a member of the British royal family.

In 1981–1983, he was Commanding Officer of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment, and was commanding during the Hyde Park and Regent's Park bombings.

From 1987 to 1990, he was Colonel Commanding the Household Cavalry and Silver Stick in Waiting to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II. On 30 June 1990 he was promoted to brigadier, and was director of the Royal Army Veterinary Corps 1991–1994. He retired in 1994.

Bowles was diagnosed with COVID-19 on 1 April 2020.

[[Bernardita Catalla]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Lebanon, Filipino politicians, Ambassadors

Bernardita "Bernie" Leonido Catalla (February 18, 1958 – April 2, 2020) was a Philippine career diplomat. She was last appointed as the Philippine ambassador to Lebanon in 2017. She was also assigned to Hong Kong, Indonesia, and Malaysia. She was born in Makati, Philippines. Catalla was principal assistant and then acting director of the ASEAN office from 1994 to 1995. She became the Director of the Office of United Nations and International Organizations from 2001 to 2002 and Passport Director from 2002 to 2005. 

On April 2, 2020, she died of COVID-19 in Beirut, Lebanon at the age of 62.

[[Peter DeFazio]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, United States representatives from Oregon, Politicians from Massachusetts, US Democratic Party politicians

Peter Anthony DeFazio d (born May 27, 1947) is an American politician. He has been the U.S. Representative for OR since 1987. He is a member of the Democratic Party. He is one of the founders of the Congressional Progressive Caucus.

[[Syd Little]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, English television personalities, People from Blackpool

Syd Little (born Cyril John Mead on 19 December 1942) is an English comedian. He is known for his work with Eddie Large in the double act Little and Large.

In 2015, Little took part in BBC One's Celebrity MasterChef and made it through to the third round.

[[COVID-19 pandemic in Tunisia]]

CATEGORIES: COVID-19 pandemic in Tunisia, 21st century in Tunisia, COVID-19 pandemic by country

Tunisia confirmed its first case on 2 March 2020, with the victim being a 40-year-old Tunisian man from Gafsa returning from Italy. On 3 July 2020, a total of 1,181 cases of contamination were confirmed, as were 50 deaths and 1,045 people recovered.

[[Francesca Annis]]

CATEGORIES: BAFTA Award winning actors, 1945 births, Living people, English movie actors, English stage actors, English television actors, Actors from London

Francesca Annis (born 14 May 1945) is an English actress. She was born in Kensington, London, England.

She is known for television roles in Reckless (1998), Wives and Daughters (1999), Deceit (2000) and Cranford (2007). She won the 1979 BATA Best Actress for the ITV serial Lillie. 

Her movie appearances include Krull (1983), Dune (1984), The Debt Collector (1999) and The Libertine (2004).

From 1995 until 2006, she was in a domestic partnership with actor Ralph Fiennes.

[[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 establishments in Europe

PeaceThe International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies is a worldwide humanitarian aid organization that reaches 160 million people each year through its 192 member National Societies. 

It acts before, during and after disasters and health emergencies to meet the needs and improve the lives of vulnerable people. 

In 1963, it was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

[[Astrid Nøklebye Heiberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Norwegian politicians, Humanitarians

Astrid Nøklebye Heiberg (14 April 1936 – 2 April 2020) was a Norwegian politician. She was a member of the Conservative Party. She was the state secretary to the Minister of Social Affairs from 1981 to 1985, and Minister of Administration and Consumer Affairs in 1986.

Heiberg was vice-chairwoman of the Conservative Party from 1990 to 1991 and member of the Norwegian Parliament from 1985 to 1989. She was President of the Norwegian Red Cross from 1993 to 1999 and President of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies from 1997 to 2001.

She was also appointed as State Secretary in the Ministry of Health and Care Services, resigning in 2016. In 2018, she was once again elected to the Norwegian Parliament. 

Heiberg died on 2 April 2020 at the age of 83.

[[Daniel Davisse]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, German politicians, French mayors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, People from Hamburg

Daniel Davisse (born Daniel Herz; 7 July 1938 – 29 March 2020) was a German-born French politician. He was born in Hamburg, Germany to French parents. From 1996 to 2014, he was Mayor of Choisy-le-Roi, France. Davisse was a member of the General council of Canton of Choisy-le-Roi from 2004 to 2011. He was also President of the Agglomeration community Seine Amont from 2013 to 2014.

Davisse died on 29 March 2020 of COVID-19, aged 81.

[[Goyo Benito]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish footballers

Gregorio "Goyo" Benito Rubio (21 October 1946 – 2 April 2020) was a Spanish footballer. He played as a central defender. Benito was born in El Puente del Arzobispo, Toledo, Castile-La Mancha. He spent most of his 16-year professional career with Real Madrid from 1966 to 1982. He also played for the national team of Spain from 1971 to 1978.

Benito died of Alzheimer's disease and COVID-19-related problems in Madrid on 2 April 2020 at the age of 73.

[[Brian Stokes Mitchell]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, Actors from Seattle, Washington, African-American movie actors, African-American singers, African-American stage actors, African-American television actors, African-American voice actors, Tony Award winning actors

Brian Stokes Mitchell (born October 31, 1957) is an American actor and singer. He has been one of the main leading men of the Broadway theatre since the 1990s. He won the Tony Award for Best Actor in a Musical in 2000 for his performance in Kiss Me, Kate. On screen, his roles include Roots: The Next Generations, The Prince of Egypt and Mr. Robot.

Mitchell was born in Seattle, Washington. He has been married actress Allyson Tucker since 1994. The couple have a son.

On April 1, 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Mitchell made it clear that he had tested positive for COVID-19.

[[Barney Rosenzweig]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, American television producers, Businesspeople from Los Angeles, California

Barney Rosenzweig (born December 23, 1937) is an American television producer. He was born in Los Angeles, California. He produced the 1980s television series Cagney & Lacey written by his then wife Barbara Corday and Barbara Avedon. He also produced the 1960s series Daniel Boone, as well as many episodes of Charlie's Angels. He later created and produced The Trials of Rosie O'Neill and ran for two seasons in the early 1990s.

He studied at the University of Southern California.

From 1959 to 1969, he was married to JoAnne Lang. In 1979, Rosenzweig married producer Barbara Corday. They divorced in 1990. In 1991, he married actress Sharon Gless.

[[Charlie's Angels]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 television series debuts, 1981 television series endings, English-language television programs

Charlie's Angels is an American crime drama television series that aired on ABC from September 22, 1976 to June 24, 1981. It had five seasons and 115 episodes. The series was created by Ivan Goff and Ben Roberts and was produced by Aaron Spelling.

It is about the crime-fighting adventures of three women working in a private detective agency in Los Angeles, California. It originally starred Kate Jackson, Farrah Fawcett , and Jaclyn Smith in the leading roles and John Forsythe providing the voice of their boss, the unseen Charlie Townsend. David Doyle played John Bosley. After Fawcett and Jackson left, they were replaced by Cheryl Ladd, Shelley Hack, and Tanya Roberts.

[[Shelley Hack]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, American movie actors, American television actors, Living people, American models, American television producers, American stage actors, Businesspeople from Connecticut, Actors from Greenwich, Connecticut

Shelley Marie Hack (born July 6, 1947) is an American model, actress, producer, and political and media adviser. She is best known as the model of Revlon's Charlie perfume from the mid-1970s until the early 1980s. She is also known for playing Tiffany Welles in the fourth season of Charlie's Angels (1979–80).

[[Cos Cob, Connecticut]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Connecticut

Cos Cob is a neighborhood and census-designated place in the town of Greenwich, Connecticut. It is located at 41.033 north, 73.6 west, on the Connecticut shoreline in southern Fairfield County. It had a population of 6,770 at the 2010 census.

[[Georgetown, Connecticut]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Connecticut

Georgetown is a village and census-designated place in Fairfield County, Connecticut, United States. As of the 2010 census, the population of the CDP was 1,805.

Monroe is a town located in eastern Fairfield County, Connecticut, United States. The population was 19,479 at the 2010 census.

[[Ed Farmer]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from kidney disease, American League All-Stars, Baltimore Orioles players, Chicago White Sox players, Cleveland Indians players, Detroit Tigers players, Milwaukee Brewers players, Major League Baseball broadcasters, Oakland Athletics players, Philadelphia Phillies players, Texas Rangers players, Sportspeople from Chicago, People from Evergreen Park, Illinois

Edward Joseph Farmer (October 18, 1949 – April 1, 2020) was an American professional baseball pitcher. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Cleveland Indians, Detroit Tigers, Baltimore Orioles, Milwaukee Brewers, Texas Rangers, Chicago White Sox, and Oakland A's in the American League and the Philadelphia Phillies of the National League (NL). Farmer was the play-by-play broadcaster for ChiSox radio broadcasts. He was born in Evergreen Park, Illinois.

Farmer died of kidney disease on April 1, 2020 in Calabasas, California at the age of 70.

[[Self-denial]]

CATEGORIES: Altruism, Sacrifice, Psychology

Self-denial or self sacrifice, is denial or sacrifice of one's needs and desires.

[[Susie Silvey]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, English television actors, English dancers, English movie actors, Actors from London, Models from London, Living people

Susan Silvey (born 17 September 1956), known professionally as Susie Silvey or sometimes Suzie Silvey, is an English actress, dancer and model. She was active in the 1970s and 1980s. Silvey was born in London.

She also appeared in the movies Come Play with Me (1977), The Playbirds (1978), The Stud (1978), The World Is Full of Married Men (1979), Xtro (1983), Fanny Hill (1983), Blue Ice (1992), Shining Through (1992) and Splitting Heirs (1993). 

Silvey also appeared in music videos for Paul McCartney, the Cure and the Joe Cocker video for 'Civilized Man' (1984).

[[Carl Tacy]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from North Carolina

Carl Tacy (1933 – April 2, 2020) was an American college basketball coach at Wake Forest. He was the head coach from 1972 to 1985 where he had a 222-149 record, the second winningest record at that time. In 1985, he was added into the Wake Forest Hall of Fame. From 1971 to 1972, he was the head basketball coach at Marshall where he had a 23-4(.852) record.

Tacy died on April 2, 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Mario Chaldú]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine footballers

Mario  Norberto Chaldú (6 June 1942 – 2 April 2020) was an Argentine football forward. He played for Argentina in the 1966 FIFA World Cup. He also played for CA Banfield, San Lorenzo de Almagro, Racing Club and CA Kimberley in the Argentinian League system. He was born in Buenos Aires.

Chaldú died on 2 April 2020 at a hospital in Monte Grande, Argentina of a long-illness at the age of 77.

Shakopee (ˈ SHAH) is a city in and the county seat of Scott County, Minnesota. It is located southwest of downtown Minneapolis. The population of Shakopee was 37,076 at the 2010 census.

[[James Gordon, Baron Gordon of Strathblane]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, Scottish politicians, Scottish businesspeople, People from Glasgow

James Stuart Gordon, Baron Gordon of Strathblane CBE (17 May 1936 – 31 March 2020) was a Scottish businessman, politician and manager. He was born in Glasgow.

[[Maxim (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, Black English musicians, Electronic musicians, English singers, People from Cambridgeshire

Keith Palmer (born 21 March 1967), better known by his stage name Maxim (formerly Maxim Reality), is a British musician. He is known for being a vocalist of the electronic music band the Prodigy. His first solo album, Hell's Kitchen, was released in 2000.

Maxim was born in Peterborough. His parents are Jamaican.

[[Joseph A. O'Hare]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American editors, American educators, American Roman Catholics, Cancer deaths in New York City, Deaths from liver cancer, Jesuits, Roman Catholic priests, Writers from New York City

Joseph Aloysius O'Hare (February 12, 1931 – March 29, 2020) was a Jesuit priest, civic leader, educator and editor. He was president of Fordham University from 1984 to 2003. He was born in The Bronx, New York. O'Hare was associate editor of the Catholic weekly America from 1972 to 1975 and was editor in chief from 1975 to 1984.

O'Hare died on March 29, 2020 at a retirement home in The Bronx of liver cancer-related problems, aged 89.

[[Flicky]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 video games, 1991 video games, Sega arcade games, Sega Genesis games, SG-1000 games, MSX games, Platform games, Video games developed in Japan

Flicky is a platform video game made and published by Sega in 1984.

[[Wallace Rice]]

CATEGORIES: 1859 births, 1939 deaths, Chicago, Illinois, Deaths from uremia, Disease-related deaths in Chicago, Illinois, People from Hamilton, Journalists from Chicago

Wallace deGroot Cecil Rice (November 10, 1859 – December 15, 1939) was an American author and vexillographer. He is known for designing the flag of Chicago in 1917. He also wrote for the Chicago Tribune and the Chicago Herald American.

Rice was born in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada to American parents. He was divorced from his wife. The couple had two children. Rice died of uremia on December 15, 1939 in Chicago, Illinois. He was 80.

[[Charley Grapewin]]

CATEGORIES: 1869 births, 1948 deaths, American silent movie actors, American stage actors, Comedians from Ohio, Writers from Ohio, Actors from Ohio

Charles Ellsworth Grapewin (December 20, 1869 – February 2, 1948) was an American vaudeville and circus performer. He was known for playing Uncle Henry in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's The Wizard of Oz (1939), Grandpa Joad in The Grapes of Wrath (1940), Jeeter Lester in  Tobacco Road (1941), and California Joe in They Died With Their Boots On (1941).

[[Jack Bergman]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, United States representatives from Michigan, American generals, Politicians from Minnesota, Politicians from Louisiana, Politicians from Florida, US Republican Party politicians

John Warren "Jack" Bergman (born February 2, 1947) is a retired United States Marine Corps lieutenant general and politician. He has been the U.S. Representative for Michigan's 1st congressional district since 2017.

Bergman was commanding general of Marine Forces Reserve and Marine Forces North. He also was a naval aviator, flying rotary-winged aircraft such as the CH-46 and UH-1, as well as fixed-wing aircraft such as the T-28 and KC-130. 

He is a Republican and was elected to the U.S. House in the 2016 election. Bergman is the highest-ranking military official ever elected to the United States Congress.

In June 2017, Bergman was one of the Republican congressmen who were practicing on an Alexandria, Virginia, baseball field for the annual congressional baseball game when a man named James Hodgkinson began shooting at them, harming four people, including Cong. Steve Scalise (R-LA).

He calls himself a conservative but does not feel strongly about party.

[[Harold Thomas (activist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, Indigenous Australian activists, Indigenous Australian artists, People from Alice Springs

Harold Joseph Thomas (born 1947) is an Aboriginal Australian artist and activist. He is a Luritja man of Central Australia. He is best known for designing and copyrighting the Australian Aboriginal Flag. He created the flag in 1971 as a symbol for the Aboriginal land rights movement. In 1995, the flag was made an official flag of Australia.

Thomas was born in Alice Springs, Northern Territory. He lives in Darwin.

[[Gouldian finch]]

CATEGORIES: IUCN Red List near threatened species, Birds of Australia, Domesticated animals, Finches, Northern Territory, Queensland, Western Australia

The Gouldian finch (Erythrura gouldiae), also known as the Lady Gouldian finch, Gould's finch or the rainbow finch, is a species of passerine bird which is native to Australia. Both sexes are brightly coloured with black, green, yellow and red markings. The birds are found across northern Australia in the Northern Territory, Western Australia and Queensland. The species are listed as near-threatened.

The Gouldian finch was described by British ornithological artist John Gould in 1844 as Amadina gouldiae. It was named in honour of Gould's late wife Elizabeth.

[[Shining Force III Scenario 1]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 video games, 1998 video games, Sega Saturn games, Role-playing video games, Video games developed in Japan, Shining Force III

Shining Force III Scenario 1, also called Shining Force III in North America and Europe and Shining Force III Scenario 1: Outo no Kyoshin in Japan, is a fantasy role-playing video game in the Shining Force III series. It was made by Sonic! Software Planning and published by Sega for the Sega Saturn in 1997. It is followed by Shining Force III Scenario 2.

There are three scenarios and a bonus game in Japan. Only the first volume was released in North America and Europe.

[[Shining Force III]]

CATEGORIES: Shining Force III

Shining Force III is a series of fantasy role-playing video games. It was made by Sonic! Software Planning and published by Sega for the Sega Saturn in 1997.

[[Shining Force III Scenario 2]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 video games, Sega Saturn games, Role-playing video games, Video games developed in Japan, Video game sequels, Shining Force III

Shining Force III Scenario 2, also called Shining Force III Scenario 2: Nerawareta Miko, is a fantasy role-playing video game in the Shining Force III series. It was made by Sonic! Software Planning and published by Sega for the Sega Saturn in 1998. It was only released in Japan.

It is a sequel to Shining Force III Scenario 1 and it is followed by Shining Force III Scenario 3. There are three scenarios and a bonus game in Japan. Only the first volume was released in North America and Europe.

[[Shining Force III Scenario 3]]

CATEGORIES: 1998 video games, Sega Saturn games, Role-playing video games, Video games developed in Japan, Video game sequels, Shining Force III

Shining Force III Scenario 3, also called Shining Force III Scenario 3: Hyouheki no Jashinguu, is a fantasy role-playing video game in the Shining Force III series. It was made by Sonic! Software Planning and published by Sega for the Sega Saturn in 1998. It was only released in Japan.

It is a sequel to Shining Force III Scenario 2. There are three scenarios and a bonus game in Japan. Only the first volume was released in North America and Europe.

[[Boucle du Mouhoun Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso, 2001 establishments in Africa

Boucle du Mouhoun is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Dédougou. 

It was created on 2 July 2001. Six provinces make up the Boucle du Mouhoun region — Balé, Banwa, Kossi, Mouhoun, Nayala, and Sourou. There are three major rivers, the Red Volta, Black Volta and White Volta.

[[Cascades Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso, 2001 establishments in Africa

Cascades is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Banfora. 

It was created on 2 July 2001. Two provinces, Comoé and Léraba, make up the region. The Cascades de Karfiguéla give the region its name.

[[Centre Region (Burkina Faso)]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso

Centre is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Ouagadougou, which also serves as the national capital. Centre region has only one province, Kadiogo.

[[Centre-Est Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso

Centre-Est is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Tenkodogo. Three provinces make up the region — Boulgou, Koulpélogo, and Kouritenga. 

[[Centre-Nord Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso

Centre-Nord is a region of Burkina Faso. The capital city is Kaya. Three provincesmake up the region — Bam, Namentenga, and Sanmatenga.

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Washington (state), 1845 establishments in the United States, Washington (state) counties

Clark County is a county in the U.S. state of Washington. The county seat is Vancouver. 425,363 people lived there at the 2010 census.

[[Centre-Ouest Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso

Centre-Ouest is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Koudougou. Four provinces make up the region - Boulkiemdé, Sanguié, Sissili, and Ziro.

[[Centre-Sud Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso

Centre-Sud is a region of Burkina Faso. The capital city is Manga. Three provinces make up the region - Bazèga, Nahouri, and Zoundwéogo.

[[The Blue and the Gray]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons episodes, 2011 in American television, 2011 television episodes

"The Blue and the Gray" is the thirteenth episode of the twenty-second season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on television on the Fox network on February 13, 2011. The episode was watched by 5.618 million people when it was first shown on television.

[[Est Region (Burkina Faso)]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso, 2001 establishments in Africa

Est is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Fada N'gourma. It was created on 2 July 2001.

Five provinces make up the region—Gnagna, Gourma, Komondjari, Kompienga, and Tapoa.

[[Kruisem]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 establishments in Belgium, Municipalities of East Flanders

Kruisem is a municipality in the Belgian province of East Flanders. It was created on 1 January 2019 when the municipalities of Kruishoutem and Zingem joined together to become the new municipality of Kruisem.

The new municipality has an area of 70.70 and more than 15,000 people.

[[Hauts-Bassins Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso, 2001 establishments in Africa

Hauts-Bassins is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Bobo-Dioulasso. 

It was created on 2 July 2001. Three provinces make up the region — Houet, Kénédougou, and Tuy.

[[Nord Region (Burkina Faso)]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso, 2001 establishments in Africa

Nord is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Ouahigouya. 

It was created on 2 July 2001. Four provinces make up the region — Loroum, Passoré, Yatenga, and Zondoma.

[[Plateau-Central Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso, 2001 establishments in Africa

Plateau-Central is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Ziniaré. 

It was created on 2 July 2001. Three provinces make up the region—Ganzourgou, Kourwéogo, and Oubritenga.

[[Sahel Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso, 2001 establishments in Africa

Sahel is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Dori. 

It was created on 2 July 2001. There are four provinces — Oudalan, Séno, Soum, and Yagha.

[[Sud-Ouest Region (Burkina Faso)]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Burkina Faso, 2001 establishments in Africa

Sud-Ouest is a region in Burkina Faso. The capital city is Gaoua. 

It was created on July 2, 2001. There are four provinces — Bougouriba, Ioba, Noumbiel, and Poni.

[[List of Oswald episodes]]

[[Bubanza Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Burundi

Bubanza is one of the 18 provinces of Burundi.  The capital city is also named Bubanza.

[[Bujumbura Mairie Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Burundi, 2000 establishments in Africa

Bujumbura Mairie Province is one of the eighteen provinces of Burundi. It consists entirely of the city Bujumbura, Burundi's former capital.

In 2000, the province encompassing Bujumbura was separated into two provinces, Bujumbura Rural Province and Bunjumbura Mairie.

The city of Bujumbura is divided into three communes (as of 2014). The communes are then divided into 13 neighborhoods.  The communes are Muha, Mukaza and Ntahangwa.

[[Kodlamane Shree Vishnumurthy Temple]]

CATEGORIES: Hindu temples

Kodlamane Shree Vishnumurthy Temple of Serenity and Mystery, is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and is ancient Tirth Kshetra.

[[Bujumbura Rural Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Burundi, 2000 establishments in Africa

Bujumbura Rural Province is one of the 18 provinces of Burundi. The capital city is Isale.

The province surrounds the former national capital Bujumbura.  In 2000, the province encompassing Bujumbura was separated into two provinces, Bujumbura Rural Province and Bunjumbura Mairie Province.

Former President of Burundi Cyprien Ntaryamira was born here.

[[Bururi Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Burundi

Bururi Province is one of the eighteen provinces of Burundi. The capital city is Bururi.

Bururi Province is home to the Bururi Forest Nature Reserve. The Ruvyironza River starts in the province.

[[Cankuzo Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Burundi

Cankuzo Province is one of the 18 provinces of Burundi. The capital city is Cankuzo.

[[Cibitoke Province]]
