This is a list of sports stadiums in Azerbaijan, ranked in descending order of capacity.

[[Jonathan (tortoise)]]

CATEGORIES: 1830s births, Individual animals, Saint Helena

Jonathan (hatched 1832, 1833−1832 years old) is a Seychelles giant tortoise (Aldabrachelys gigantea hololissa), a subspecies of the Aldabra giant tortoise (Aldabrachelys gigantea). He is the oldest known living terrestrial animal in the world. Jonathan lives on the island of Saint Helena, a British Overseas Territory in the South Atlantic Ocean. A photograph taken in 1886 featuring Jonathan exists.

Jonathan was among three tortoises brought to Saint Helena from the Seychelles in 1882. He was named by Governor Spencer Davis during the 1930s.

[[Bullet Prakash]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver failure, Disease-related deaths in India, Indian comedians, Indian movie actors, Reality television participants

Bullet Prakash (ಬುಲೆಟ್ ಪ್ರಕಾಶ್; 2 April 1976 – 6 April 2020) was an Indian actor and comedian. He worked in Kannada cinema. He appeared in over 325 movies. His movie credits include Mast Maja Maadi (2008), Aithalakkadi (2010), Mallikarjuna (2011) and Aryan (2014). He took part in the second season of the Kannada reality television show Bigg Boss. He also appeared in a Tulu movie, Soombe. He was born in Bangalore.

Prakash died from acute liver failure on 6 April 2020. He was 44.

[[Peter Walker (cricketer, born 1936)]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, English cricketers, People from Bristol, Members of the Order of the British Empire

Peter Michael Walker MBE (17 February 1936 – 5 April 2020) was an English cricketer. He played for England in three Test matches against South Africa in 1960. He also played for Glamorgan. He was born in Clifton, Bristol.

Walker died of a stroke on 5 April 2020. He was 84.

[[Radomir Antić]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatitis, Disease-related deaths in Madrid, Serbian football managers, Serbian footballers

Radomir Antić (Радомир Антић; 22 November 1948 – 6 April 2020) was a Serbian football player and manager.

Antić was born in Žitište. He had a 17-year playing career as a defender from 1967 to 1984. He notably played for Partizan, Fenerbahçe, Real Zaragoza and Luton Town. He also played one game for Yugoslavia in 1973.

After retiring from playing, Antić coached a number of teams. In Spain, he coached Real Zaragoza, Real Madrid, Atlético Madrid, Real Oviedo, Barcelona and Celta Vigo. He won the double, both La Liga and the Copa del Rey, with Atlético Madrid in the 1995–96 season. He also coached the Serbian national team and Chinese sides Shandong Luneng and Hebei China Fortune.

On 6 April 2020, Antić died in Madrid of pancreatitis at the age of 71.

[[Social justice warrior]]

CATEGORIES: Politics

Social justice warrior (SJW) is a pejorative term for people who support feminism or have left-wing opinions. Originally the term Social Justice Warrior was used by people who generally supported left-wing politics to mean a person who was an activist for social justice and meant it as a good thing. After the Gamergate Controversy wherein Carl Benjamin and Milo Yiannopoulos accused people who didn’t think video game journalism was being used by feminists to spread political correctness of being Social Justice Warriors, the term became a pejorative for either someone who wanted video games and popular culture to be more politically correct or someone who was too easily offended.

[[André Citroën]]

CATEGORIES: 1878 births, 1935 deaths, Chief executives, French engineers, Freemasons, French Jews, Alumni of the Grandes écoles, Businesspeople from Paris, Deaths from stomach cancer

André-Gustave Citroën (ɑ̃dʁe ɡystav sitʁɔɛn; 5 February 1878 – 3 July 1935) was a French industrialist and freemason of Dutch and Polish Jewish origin. He was the founder of the car company Citroën, but also for his application of double helical gears.

Citroën was born on 5 February 1878 in Paris and died from stomach cancer on 3 July 1935 in Paris, aged 57. He had graduated the École Polytechnique.

[[Joppa, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois

Joppa is a village in Illinois in the United States.

[[Itzehoe]]

CATEGORIES: Steinburg (district)

Itzehoe (ɪtsəˈhoː; Itzhoe) is a town in the German state of Schleswig-Holstein. It is the capital of the district Steinburg.

[[Pentti Linkola]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, People from Helsinki, Philosophers, Environmentalists, Finnish scientists, Finnish writers

Kaarlo Pentti Linkola (7 December 1932 – 5 April 2020) was a Finnish radical deep ecologist, ornithologist, polemicist, naturalist, writer, and fisherman. 

He wrote mainly about his ideas and in Finland was a well known free-thinker.271 Linkola was a fisherman from 1959 to 1995. He fished on Keitele, Päijänne and Gulf of Finland, and beginning in 1978 he fished on Vanajavesi.

Linkola blamed humans for the ongoing degradation of the environment. He promoted rapid population decline to fight the problems commonly seen in overpopulation.271

[[M. K. Arjunan]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Indian writers, Composers

M. K. Arjunan (എം.കെ. അർജുനൻ) (fondly called as Arjunan Master) (1 March 1936 – 6 April 2020) was an Indian Malayalam music composer. He was known for composing many melodies for Malayalam cinema. He was born in Kerala, India. Arjunan made around 800 songs for 300 plays. 

Arjunan died on 6 April 2020 at his home in Kochi, India at the age of 84.

[[Black the Ripper]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, 2020 deaths, British rap musicians, British activists, Singer-songwriters from London, Musicians from London, Businesspeople from London

Dean West (yes – yes), better known by his stage name Black the Ripper, was a British grime MC, rapper, businessman and a cannabis activist. He ran his own record label, Dank of England (formerly known as Black Magic Entertainment). It was soon made into a clothing line and marijuana accessory company.

He was also known for his viral stunts of smoking cannabis in public places in which he hoped would help legalised cannabis in the U.K.

[[Ha Seung Moo]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people

Ha Seung Moo (born born October 13, 1963; also spelled Ha Seung moo) is a Korean poet, pastor, educator and historical theologian.

[[Busan Social Information Forum]]

CATEGORIES: South Korea, Non-profit organizations of Asia, 2003 establishments in South Korea

Busan Social Information Forum (abbreviation: BSIF, Korean: 부산사회정보포럼) was founded on March 1, 2003, at Busan Forum, led by Chairman Seung-Moo Ha. Following the Busan Forum, it is the second non-profit forum organization founded in the Busan area.

[[Lissie]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, American country musicians, American folk musicians, American pop musicians, American singer-songwriters, Singers from Illinois, Living people

Elisabeth Corrin Maurus (born November 21, 1982), better known by her stage name Lissie, is an American country musician and singer-songwriter. 

Lissie was raised in Rock Island, Illinois. 

[[Jim Jonsin]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, American DJs, American record producers, American songwriters, Musicians from Brooklyn, Living people

James Scheffer (born June 8, 1970), better known by his stage name Jim Jonsin, is an American record producer, songwriter, businessman and DJ. He has collaborated numerous times with artists, including Akon, B.o.B, Pitbull, Rico Love, and Sean Paul.

[[Breakfast Club (band)]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s establishments in New York (state), 1979 establishments in the United States, Musical groups established in 1979, 1970s American music groups, Musical groups from New York City

Breakfast Club were an American dance-pop band. It used to be Madonna and Randy Jackson. Their hit single "Right On Track" topped #7 on the UK Pop Chart.

[[The Dungeon Family]]

CATEGORIES: American R&B bands, Hip hop bands, 1990s American music groups, 1991 establishments in the United States

 The Dungeon Family are an R&B/hip hop music band. The group was based in Atlanta, Georgia and consists of rappers Andre 3000, Big Boi, Cee-Lo Green, Future, Witchdoctor, Sleepy Brown, Cool Breeze, Backbone, Killer Mike, and Big Rube. It specializes in Southern hip hop and alternative hip hop. The members were also in Organized Noise and Goodie Mob respectively.

[[Taboo (rapper)]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, American DJs, American hip hop musicians, American rap musicians from California, American songwriters, Musicians from Los Angeles, California

Jamie Luis Gomez (born 14 July 1975), better known by his stage name Taboo, is an American rapper, songwriter, actor and DJ. He is best known as a member of the hip hop music group The Black Eyed Peas.

[[Maejor]]

CATEGORIES: American hip hop musicians, American pop singers, American rap musicians, American record producers, American R&B singers, American songwriters, Electronic musicians, Living people, 1988 births

Brandon Michael Green (born 23 July 1988), better known by his stage name Maejor (formerly Bei Maejor and later Maejor Ali) is an American record producer, singer and songwriter. He is one half of the duo AREA21 alongside Dutch DJ Martin Garrix. Maejor has co-produced and written songs for artists, including Justin Bieber and Ne-Yo, amongst others.

[[Jason Orange]]

CATEGORIES: Twin people from England, Musicians from Manchester, English pop musicians, English pop singers, English songwriters, Living people, 1970 births

Jason Thomas Orange (born 10 July 1970) is a retired English singer-songwriter, dancer, musician and actor. He was a member of Take That during their original run from 1990 to 1996 and again following their reunion in 2005. He left the group in 2014.

[[Ryogo Hirota]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2015 deaths, Japanese mathematicians, Waseda University faculty

Ryogo Hirota (1932-2015) is a Japanese mathematician and a former professor at Waseda University. He investigated about nonlinear differential equations and their discrete versions. He invented a method to solve nonlinear differential equations, and it is currently known as the "Hirota's direct method".

[[Peter Deuflhard]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2019 deaths, German mathematicians

Peter Deuflhard (1944-2019) was a German mathematician who is recognized as an expert of numerical analysis. He is known for his books about computing solutions of differential equations and the Newton's method.

[[Educational video game]]

CATEGORIES: Types of video games, Video game genres

An educational video game is a type of video game that focuses on educating or training the player. They can be more enjoyable for the player than other methods of education. One example is Basic Math.

[[Steven C. Beering]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1932 births, American academics, American physicians, Naturalized citizens of the United States, People from Berlin, People from Hamburg

Steven Claus Beering (August 20, 1932 – April 6, 2020) was a German-born American physician and academic. He most notably served as the president of Purdue University from 1983 to 2000. During his leadership, Purdue's main campus in West Lafayette, Indiana grew by more than 20 buildings. 

Beering was born in Berlin. He spent his early years in Hamburg. He moved from Germany to the United States in 1948. He died on April 6, 2020, at the age of 87.

[[Sports game]]

CATEGORIES: Sports video games, Types of video games, Video game genres

A sports game is a type of video game that simulates playing sports. Most sports have been recreated as video games. Some sports games are more about sport management than playing sports. One example is FIFA 07, which simulates playing football.

[[Earl G. Graves Sr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, African-American people, American company founders, American philanthropists, Businesspeople from New York City, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, People from Brooklyn

Earl Gilbert Graves Sr. (January 9, 1935 – April 6, 2020) was an American businessman, publisher and philanthropist. He was an advocate of African-American businesses. He was the founder of Black Enterprise magazine and chairman of the media company Earl G. Graves, Ltd. He was the director for Aetna and an Executive Board member of the Boy Scouts of America. He was the father of Earl G. Graves Jr.

Graves was born in Brooklyn, New York City. He grew up in Brooklyn's Bedford–Stuyvesant neighborhood. Graves died on April 6, 2020 due to Alzheimer's disease in White Plains, New York. He was 85.

[[Jack Hill (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Politicians from Georgia (U.S. state), US Republican Party politicians

Jack Hill (July 15, 1944 – April 6, 2020) was an American politician. He was a member of the Republican Party. He represented Georgia's 4th district in the Georgia State Senate from 1991 until his death. At the time of his death in 2020, he was the longest-serving Georgia State Senator.

Hill was born in Reidsville, Georgia. He died on April 6, 2020, at the age of 75.

[[Jean Little]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Autobiographers, Blind people, Canadian novelists, Children's writers, Order of Canada, Writers from Ontario

Jean Little CM (January 2, 1932 – April 6, 2020) was a Canadian writer. Her work was mainly children's literature. Her notable works include Mine for Keeps (1962), From Anna (1972) and Orphan at My Door (2001). She also wrote two autobiographies, Little by Little and Stars Come Out Within. Little was partially blind since birth as a result of scars on her cornea.

Little was born in Formosa, Japan (now Taiwan). On April 6, 2020, she died in Guelph, Ontario at the age of 88.

[[Jean-Laurent Cochet]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, French movie actors, French movie directors

Jean-Laurent Cochet (28 January 1935 – 7 April 2020) was a French actor and director. He is known for his roles in A Thousand Billion Dollars (1982) and Fort Saganne (1984). He was born in Romainville, Seine-Saint-Denis.

On 7 April 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Cochet died on COVID-19 in Paris. He was 85.

[[Mishik Kazaryan]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Armenian people, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Russia, Disease-related deaths in Moscow, Russian physicists

Mishik Ayrazatovich Kazaryan (Мишик Айрозатович Казарян; 28 February 1948 – 7 April 2020) was an Armenian-born Russian physicist. His main area was in laser physics and optics. 

He was a creator of the brightest repeatedly pulsed laser in the visible region of the spectrum. He was the winner of the USSR State Prize in the field of science and technology. He was also a member of the Armenian National Academy of Sciences. He was born in Hrazdan, Armenian SSR, Soviet Union.

On 7 April 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Kazaryan died in Moscow. He was 72.

[[Action game]]

CATEGORIES: Types of video games, Video game genres

An action game is a type of video game that focuses on physical challenges, such as hand–eye coordination and reaction time. Many types of video game, such as fighting games, beat 'em ups, shooters, platformers, MMOs and some real-time strategy games, are types of action game. One example of an action game is Super Mario Bros.

[[Sasi Kalinga]]

CATEGORIES: Year of birth missing, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver disease, Disease-related deaths in India, Indian movie actors

V. Chandrakumar (1960 – 7 April 2020), better known as Sasi Kalinga, was an Indian actor. He worked in Malayalam cinema. His acting credits include Paleri Manikyam: Oru Pathirakolapathakathinte Katha (2009), Pranchiyettan & the Saint (2010), Indian Rupee (2011), Adaminte Makan Abu (2011) and in Amen (2013).

Kalinga died from liver disease in Kozhikode on 7 April 2020. He was reportedly 59.

[[Strategy video game]]

CATEGORIES: Real-time strategy video games, Types of video games, Video game genres

A strategy video game is a type of video game that focuses on skillful thinking and planning to achieve victory. They are usually categorized into four types: if the game is turn-based or real-time, and whether the game focuses on strategy or tactics. One example is Age of Empires III.

[[Maple, North Dakota]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in North Dakota, North Dakota townships

Maple, North Dakota is a township in Dickey County, North Dakota, United States. The population was 49 at the 2010 census.

[[Star of Nanchang]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in China, Ferris wheels

The Star of Nanchang (Chinese:南昌之星 or Chinese:南昌之星摩天轮) is a 525 ft (160-metre) tall giant Ferris wheel. It is in the eastern Chinese city of Nanchang, which is the capital of Jiangxy Province.

Debi Derryberry (born September 27, 1967) is a voice actress. She worked in the voices of green aliens in Toy Story and Toy Story 2.

Craig Bartlett (born October 18, 1956) is a voice actor.

[[Kayleigh McEnany]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, White House Press Secretaries, American political commentators, CNN people, American political writers, Writers from Tampa, Florida, Politicians from Florida, US Republican Party politicians

Kayleigh McEnany (born April 18, 1988) is an American spokesperson, political commentator, and writer. McEnany was the 31st White House Press Secretary from 2020 to 2021. She was a former CNN contributor. She was made national spokesperson for the Republican National Committee in 2017. 

In February 2019, she was named national press secretary for Donald Trump's 2020 presidential campaign. On April 7, 2020, she was appointed White House Press Secretary.

On October 5, 2020, McEnany tested positive for COVID-19.

[[Bloomfield Hills, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan

Bloomfield Hills is a city in Metro Detroit's northern suburbs in Oakland County in the U.S.. It is about 20.2 miles (32.5 km) northwest of downtown Detroit. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 3,869.

[[Fred Singer]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American physicists, American educators, Researchers, American critics, American political writers, Writers from Vienna, Scientists from Vienna

Siegfried Fred Singer (September 27, 1924 – April 6, 2020) was an Austrian-born American physicist and climate change denier. He was an emeritus professor of environmental science at the University of Virginia. 

Singer trained as an atmospheric physicist and was known for his criticism of scientific evidence between UV-B and melanoma rates the health risks of smoking, and for supporting climate change denial. 

He was the author or editor of many books including Global Effects of Environmental Pollution (1970), The Ocean in Human Affairs (1989), Global Climate Change (1989), The Greenhouse Debate Continued (1992), and Hot Talk, Cold Science (1997). 

He also co-authored Unstoppable Global Warming: Every 1,500 Years (2007) with Dennis Avery, and Climate Change Reconsidered (2009) with Craig Idso.

Singer died on April 6, 2020 at a nursing home in Rockville, Maryland at the age of 95.

[[Klagenfurt-Land District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Carinthia (state)

The Klagenfurt-Land District (German: Bezirk Klagenfurt-Land, Southern Austro-Bavarian: Beziak Klognfuat-Laund) is a district in the state of 

Carinthia in Austria. The capital is Klagenfurt.

[[Neusiedl am See District]]

The Neusiedl am See District (Bezirk Neusiedl am See; Nezsideri járás; Kotar Niuzal) is a district in the state of 

Burgenland in Austria.

[[Timothy Brown (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Disease-related deaths in California, American football running backs, American movie actors, American television actors, Indianapolis Colts players, Green Bay Packers players, Philadelphia Eagles players, Actors from Indiana, Sportspeople from Indiana, Singers from Indiana, People from Richmond, Indiana

Thomas Allen Brown (May 24, 1937 – April 4, 2020), known also as Timothy Brown and Timmy Brown, was an American singer, professional American football player, and actor. He was born in Richmond, Indiana. He played Capt. Spearchucker Jones in M*A*S*H. As a football player, he played for the Green Bay Packers, Philadelphia Eagles, and Baltimore Colts. 

Brown died on April 4, 2020 in Palm Springs, California of dementia-related problems at the age of 82.

[[Livingston County, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: 1836 establishments in Michigan Territory, Michigan counties

Livingston County is a county in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 census, the population was 180,967. It is part of the Detroit-Warren-Dearborn, MI Metropolitan Statistical Area.

The county seat and most populous city is Howell. 

[[Howell, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan, County seats in Michigan

Howell is a city in the U.S. state of Michigan.  It is the largest city and county seat of Livingston County.  As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 9,489.

[[Marion, Pennsylvania]]

Marion is an unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) in Franklin County, Pennsylvania, United States. As of the 2010 census the population was 953.

[[Districts of Austria]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Austria

In Austria, a district is a second-level division of the country's government. The first-level division are States of Austria.

District offices are the main point of contact for things like: marriage licenses, driver licenses, passports, assembly permits, hunting permits, or dealings with public health officers.

As of 2017, there are 94 districts. Of these 79 are districts headed by district commissions and 15 are statutory cities. Statutory cities are not usually referred to as "districts" outside government publications and the legal literature. A district headed by a district commission typically covers somewhere between ten and thirty municipalities.

[[Mount Ashibetsu]]

CATEGORIES: Mountains of Japan

Mount Ashibetsu is a mountain that is on the border between Ashibetsu and Furano, Hokkaidō, Japan. It is a part of the Yūbari Mountains.

[[Rust, Burgenland]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Burgenland, Cities and towns in Burgenland

Rust is a city in Burgenland, Austria. It is on the western shore of Lake Neusiedl near the border with Hungary.

The city is famous for its wines, especially for Beerenauslese, ice wine and - especially - Ruster Ausbruch.

It was part of Hungary until 1921.

[[Jim Bailey (athlete)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, 1956 Summer Olympics, Australian athletes, Australian Olympians, Sportspeople from Sydney

James John Bailey (21 July 1929 – 31 March 2020) was an Australian middle-distance runner. He reached the semifinals of the 800 metres event at the 1956 Summer Olympics. While running for the University of Oregon under Bill Bowerman, he was the 1955 NCAA Champion in the mile. He was born in Sydney and grew up in Parkes, New South Wales.

Bailey lived in Bellingham, Washington, United States. He died in hospice care on 31 March 2020 at the age of 90.

[[Rex Patrick]]

CATEGORIES: 1967 births, Living people, Australian military people, Members of the Australian Senate, People from North Island, Politicians from South Australia

Rex Lyall Patrick (born 8 May 1967) is an Australian politician. He has served as a Senator for South Australia since 2017. He is a member of the Centre Alliance. He was born in Whakatane, New Zealand and moved to South Australia as a child. Patrick served in the Royal Australian Navy from 1983 to 1994.

In March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Patrick tested positive to COVID-19.

[[Hugh Anderson (motorcyclist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, Members of the Order of the British Empire, Motorcycle racers, Sportspeople from Auckland

Hugh Robertson Anderson NZL (born 18 January 1936) is a former New Zealand motorcyclist. He is a four-time Grand Prix motorcycle road racing World Champion and a 19-time New Zealand national champion. He is also a two-time Isle of Man TT winner. In 1995, he was added into the New Zealand Sports Hall of Fame.

Anderson was born in Auckland. He spent his early years in Huntly.

[[Consonant mutation]]

CATEGORIES: Linguistics, Language

Consonant mutation is a feature in languages when the sound of a consonant changes depending on morphology and syntax.

[[Broadly Applicable Tracking System]]

CATEGORIES: Bats, Technology

The Broadly Applicable Tracking System, also called BATS, is a very small, lightweight tool shaped like a backpack.  Scientists glue the BATS onto the back of a bat or other small animal and then use GPS and wireless internet to see where the animal goes.

The scientists who invented BATS say it is different from other systems because it is lighter, uses less power and can track animals even inside caves or hollow trees.

BATS can be made with a 3D printer, and it is so light that it does not slow down small bats when they fly.  It also falls off after about fourteen days.  Scientists can collect fallen BATS to reuse the parts.

Scientists used BATS to show that vampire bats can make social bonds when being kept by humans that they remember after being released.

[[Allen Garfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Actors from Newark, New Jersey, American movie actors, American television actors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Infectious disease deaths in Los Angeles, Jewish American actors

Allen Garfield (born Allen Goorwitz; November 22, 1939 – April 7, 2020) was an American actor. He appeared in over 100 movies and television shows. His movie credits include The Conversation (1974), Nashville (1975), The Stunt Man (1980), Beverly Hills Cop II (1987) and The Ninth Gate (1999).

Garfield was born in Newark, New Jersey, to a Jewish family. He survived at least two strokes, in 1999 and again in 2004.

On April 7, 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Garfield died of COVID-19 in Woodland Hills, Los Angeles, California. He was 80.

[[Richard Rush (director)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2021 deaths, Movie directors from New York City, Movie producers from New York City, Screenwriters from New York City

Richard Rush (April 15, 1929 – April 8, 2021) was an American movie director, screenwriter and producer. He was best known for his Academy Award-nominated movie The Stunt Man (1980). He also directed the erotic mystery thriller Color of Night (1994), which flopped at the box office. The movie won a Golden Raspberry Award as the worst movie of 1994. Maxim magazine has singled out the movie as having the best sex scene in movie history. His other movies include Too Soon to Love (1960), Hells Angels on Wheels (1967), Psych-Out (1968), Freebie and the Bean (1974) and Air America (1990).

Rush was born in New York City. He died on April 8, 2021 in Los Angeles, aged 91.

[[Robert Fuller (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York, Businesspeople from New York, People from Troy, New York

Robert Fuller (born Leonard Leroy "Buddy" Lee, July 29, 1933) is an American horse rancher and retired actor. His best known roles were in The Brain from Planet Arous; Teenage Thunder (both in 1957); Return of the Seven (1966); Incident at Phantom Hill (also 1966); and The Hard Ride (1971).

He also played Jess Harper and Cooper Smith on the popular 1960s Western series Laramie and Wagon Train, and was also well known for his starring role as Dr. Kelly Brackett in the 1970s medical /action drama Emergency!

[[Omar Quintana]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, Ecuadorian businesspeople, Sportspeople, Ecuadorian politicians, People from Quito, People from Guayaquil

Omar Quintana Baquerizo (March 22, 1944 – April 3, 2020) was an Ecuadorian politician and sports businessman. Quintana was born in Quito. He was a  member of the Ecuadorian Roldosist Party (PRE) and Institutional Renewal Party of National Action (PRIAN) political parties.

Quintana was in the former National Congress of Ecuador from 2003 to 2005, including as the President of the National Congress from January 5, 2005, until April 20, 2005. Quinata was the former director of C.S. Emelec, a professional football sports club based in Guayaquil.

Quintana died on April 3, 2020 in Guayaquil of COVID-19 at the age of 76.

[[Hal Willner]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Grammy Award winners, Record producers, American television producers, Businesspeople from New York City, Musicians from New York City, Musicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Businesspeople from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Hal Willner (April 5, 1956 – April 6, 2020) was an American music producer. His works focused on movies, TV and live events. He was best known for creating tribute albums and events featuring a wide variety of artists and musical styles. His first tribute album was Amarcord Nino Rota in 1981.

In the late 1970s he worked under record producer Joel Dorn. He was an Associate Producer on Leon Redbone's albums Double Time and Champagne Charlie, and The Neville Brothers' Fiyo on the Bayou.  Willner was the sketch music producer of Saturday Night Live, beginning in 1981.

He was also a producer of the TV program Sunday Night hosted by David Sanborn.

Willner died from problems of COVID-19 on April 6, 2020, at age 64.

[[Yaakov Perlow]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American rabbis, People from New York City

Yaakov Perlow (יעקב פרלוב, 1931 – April 7, 2020) was an American Hasidic rabbi and rosh yeshiva, and Rebbe of the Novominsker Hasidic dynasty. From 1998 until his death, he was president of Agudath Israel of America. He was also in charge of that organization's Moetzes Gedolei HaTorah (Council of Torah Sages). He was one of the most respected leaders of the American Orthodox Jewish community. Perlow was born in Brooklyn.

Perlow died on April 7, 2020 of COVID-19 in Brooklyn at the age of 89.

[[Andy Cohen]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, American game show hosts, American radio personalities, American television talk show hosts, Gay men, Jewish American LGBT people, LGBT writers, Writers from St. Louis, Missouri, American bloggers

Andrew Joseph Cohen (born June 2, 1968) is an American talk show host, producer and writer. He is the host and executive producer of Bravo's late night talk show, Watch What Happens Live with Andy Cohen. He also hosted the dating game show Love Connection.

Cohen was born in St. Louis, Missouri. He is Jewish. He is openly gay. He has a son. In March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Cohen tested positive to COVID-19.

[[Debi Mazar]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Actors from Queens, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Jewish American actors, Television personalities from New York City

Deborah Anne Mazar Corcos (born August 13, 1964) is an American actress. She is known for playing sharp-tongued women. Her movie credits include in Goodfellas (1990), Little Man Tate (1991), Singles (1992) and Lovelace (2013). Her TV appearances include Civil Wars, L.A. Law, Entourage and Younger. Since 2014, she has had a starring role in the Cooking Channel series Extra Virgin with her husband Gabriele Corcos.

Mazar was born in Jamaica, Queens, New York City. Her father was born in the Latvian SSR, Soviet Union, to a Jewish family, but raised Roman Catholic. During the 1990s, she dated actor Paul Reubens. She married Italian chef Gabriele Corcos in 2002. The couple have two daughters.

In March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Mazar tested positive to COVID-19.

[[Gifford, Florida]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Florida, Unincorporated communities in Florida

Gifford is an unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) in Indian River County, Florida, United States. As of the 2010 census, the settlement had a population of 9,590.

[[Slim Thug]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, Living people, African American musicians, American rap musicians from Texas, Musicians from Houston, Texas

Stayve Jerome Thomas (born September 8, 1980), better known by his stage name Slim Thug, is an American rapper. He was born in Houston, Texas. He first became known as a feature artist on the hit single by rapper Mike Jones, "Still Tippin'". He was also a feature artist on Gwen Stefani's "Luxurious" and the US Billboard Hot 100 No. 1 "Check on It" by Beyoncé. As of 2020, he has released 12 studio albums.

In March 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Slim Thug tested positive to COVID-19.

[[Bangalistan]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of India, Separatist movements of India

Bangalistan (বাঙালীস্তান) is the name of a proposed separate  land or state for the Bengalis in India and it is also a self-sufficient socio-economic zone promoted by the supporters of the political party  'Amra Bangali'. It is a social movement, based on the socio-economic and political theory "Progressive  Utilization Theory" (PROUT) given by Prabhat Ranjan Sarkar. Bengal or Bangalistan was divided several times in the past.  The Nellie Massacre,  Mandai Massacre, etc. are the examples of criminal activities done against the Bengalis in India. The Bengalis or the followers of Bangalistan movement protested the National Register of Citizens for Assam. The main demand of the movement is to reorganize Bangalistan to save the Bengalis from oppression and exploitation. The areas of Bangalistan in India  are: the whole of West Bengal, Andaman and Nicobar Islands,Tripura and some parts of Bihar, Jharkhand and Assam, etc. The Bengalis want to reorganize Bangalistan as per the Article 3(a) of Part 1 of the Constitution of India. 

[[Andrew O'Keefe]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, Living people, Australian lawyers, Australian television presenters, People from Sydney

Andrew Patrick O'Keefe (born 1 October 1971) is an Australian television presenter and former lawyer. He works for the Seven Network. He is known as the host of game show Deal or No Deal (2003–2013). Since 2015, he has hosted The Chase, based on the British program of the same name. He was also the co-host of Weekend Sunrise alongside Monique Wright between 2006 and 2017.

O'Keefe was born in Sydney, New South Wales. He was married to Eleanor until their divorce in 2019. The couple have three children.

[[Barbara Smoker]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Disease-related deaths in London, British activists, Writers from London

Barbara Smoker (2 June 1923 – 7 April 2020) was a British Humanist activist. She was also President of the National Secular Society from 1972 to 1996, Chair of the British Voluntary Euthanasia Society (now known as Dignity in Dying) from 1981 to 1985 and an Honorary Vice President of the Gay and Lesbian Humanist Association in the United Kingdom. Smoker was born in London.

Smoker died at a hospital in London on 7 April 2020, aged 96, after a long-illness.

[[Jazze Pha]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, American hip hop musicians, American rap musicians, African-American singers, African-American rappers, American record producers, American R&B musicians, American singer-songwriters, Musicians from Memphis, Tennessee, Musicians from Atlanta, Georgia, Businesspeople from Atlanta, Georgia, Businesspeople from Tennessee, Living people

Jazze Pha (pronounced JAZ-ee-phay; born Phalon Anton Alexander; April 15, 1974) is an American record producer, singer-songwriter, and rapper. He is a based in the south and worked with Nelly, Ludacris, Trick Daddy, T.I., David Banner, amongst others. Pha is credited for bringing R&B/crunk music artist Ciara national attention with her solo album Goodies. He is also jointly signed a production deal with Cash Money Records. His career began in 1988 and ended in 1990, and restarted in 1995. He is also best known for working with Cee Lo Green.

[[Donald May]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, Actors from Chicago, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors

Donald May (born February 22, 1927) is an American actor. He is best known for his role as Adam Drake in the soap opera The Edge of Night from 1967 to 1977. His movie appearances include The Crowded Sky (1960), Kisses for My President (1964) and Follow Me, Boys! (1966).

May's other TV acting credits include The West Point Story, Colt .45, Sugarfoot, Cheyenne, 77 Sunset Strip, Hawaiian Eye, Surfside 6, The Roaring 20's, Men into Space, Barnaby Jones, The Dukes of Hazzard, Dallas, Texas, Falcon Crest, Fantasy Island,  One Life to Live, All My Children and L.A. Law.

May was born in Chicago, Illinois. He had two children with his first wife. He later married actress Carla Borelli.

[[Mobb Deep]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 establishments in New York (state), Hip hop bands, Musical duos, Musical groups from New York City, Musical groups established in 1991, 1990s American music groups, 2000s American music groups, 2010s American music groups

Mobb Deep are an American gangsta rap duo, comprised of MCs and rappers Havoc and Prodigy, who died in 2017 at the age of 42. The duo was formed in 1991.

[[Ginuwine]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, American R&B singers, American songwriters, African-American singers, Singers from Washington, D.C., Living people

Elgin Baylor Lumpkin (born October 15, 1970), better known by his stage name Ginuwine, is an American singer, songwriter, dancer, and actor. He was born in Washington, D.C.. He rose to fame as a member of the band Swing Mob in 1991.

[[Graham Coxon]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, English singer-songwriters, Living people

Graham Leslie Coxon (born 12 March 1969 in West Germany) is a British musician and artist. He is best known as the actor/painter/singer-songwriter in the English band Blur. He contributed to the bands first six albums, including their famous 1994 album Parklife. Considered by the band members to be one of the singer-songwriters of rock music, his highly individual style is best showcased on songs such as Beetlebum (from Blur's 1997 album Blur) and Coffee, TV (from Blur's 13 extended play). He kept giggleing in the band in 2002.

Blur had already released at least three solo albums while Coxon was a member of the band. 

[[Dave Rowntree]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, British DJs, English rock drummers, Musicians from Essex, Living people

David Alexander De Horne Rowntree (born 8 May 1964) is an English musician. He is also the animator/solicitor/political activist/DJ in the band Blur. He owns his own company called Nanomation and is also a qualified pilot.

[[Michelle O'Neill]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Northern Ireland Assembly, Members, People from County Cork, Sinn Féin politicians

Michelle O'Neill (née Doris; born 10 January 1977) is an Irish politician. Since 2020, she has been the deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland. She has served as vice president of Sinn Féin since 2018 and has been the member of the Legislative Assembly (MLA) for Mid Ulster since 2007.

O'Neill was born in Fermoy, County Cork, in the Republic of Ireland. Her family are Irish republicans from Clonoe, County Tyrone. She has two children with Paddy O'Neill. The couple separated in 2014.

[[Numerical linear algebra]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics, Technology, Linear algebra, Computer science, Computing

In the field of numerical analysis, numerical linear algebra is an area to study methods to solve problems in linear algebra by numerical computation. The following problems will be considered in this area:

Numerical errors can occur in any kind of numerical computation including the area of numerical linear algebra. Errors in numerical linear algebra are considered in another area called "validated numerics".

[[Spittal an der Drau District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Carinthia (state)

Bezirk Spittal an der Drau is an administrative district in Carinthia, Austria. The administrative centre is also named Spittal an der Drau.

The highest point is the peak of the Grossglockner, Austria's highest mountain at 3798. The district also includes Millstätter See and Weissensee, two of the major Carinthian lakes.

[[Villach-Land]]

Villach-Land is a district in Carinthia, Austria. The administrative center is Villach.

Völkermarkt District is an administrative district in Carinthia, Austria. The administrative center is also named Völkermarkt.

Waidhofen an der Ybbs is an independent city in the Austrian state of Lower Austria. About 11,600 people lived there in 2001.

Korneuburg is an administrative district in Lower Austria. The administrative center is also named Korneuburg.

Hallein is an administrative district in the federal state of Salzburg, Austria. It is congruent with the Tennengau region.

The administrative center of the district is Hallein.

[[Helène Aylon]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American feminist writers, American artists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Writers from New York City

Helène Aylon (born Helene Greenfield; February 4, 1931 – April 6, 2020) was an American multimedia and ecofeminist artist. She was born in New York City. Her works were divided into three phases: process art (1970s), anti-nuclear art (1980s), and The G-d Project (1990s and early 2000s). She also created a feminist commentary on the Hebrew Bible.

In 2012 Aylon published Whatever Is Contained Must Be Released: My Jewish Orthodox Girlhood, My Life as a Feminist Artist.

Aylon died on April 6, 2020 of COVID-19 at the age of 89.

[[Henry Graff]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American historians, American educators, American political writers, Writers from New York City

Henry Franklin Graff (August 11, 1921 – April 7, 2020) was an American historian. He was on the faculty of Columbia University from 1946 to 1991. He was Chairman of the History Department there.

Graff's works focused in the history of the Presidency of the United States and of American foreign relations. He was known for his "Seminar on the Presidency" one of Columbia’s most popular courses, was attended by President Harry Truman in 1959 and President Gerald Ford in 1989.  Graff was Chairman of the Pulitzer Prize jury in American history.

In 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson made Graff in charge of the National Historical Publications Commission and in 1993 President Bill Clinton hired Graff to lead the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Review Board.

Graff died on April 7, 2020 in Greenwich, Connecticut at the age of 98. The cause of death was COVID-19.

[[Prime Minister of Moldova]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Moldova

The prime minister of Moldova is Moldova's head of government. The prime minister is formally appointed by the president and holds executive power along with the cabinet. They need to parliamentary support. 

[[Maia Sandu]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Presidents of Moldova, Current national leaders, Prime Ministers of Moldova

Maia Grigoryevna Sandu (born 24 May 1972) is a Moldovan politician. Sandu is the President of Moldova since 24 December 2020. She is the leader of the Party of Action and Solidarity (PAS). She was the Prime Minister of Moldova from 8 June 2019 until 14 November 2019. 

On 12 November 2019, Sandu's government fell after the vote of the censure motion. She defeated incumbent president Igor Dodon in the 2020 presidential election. Sandu is the country's first female president.

[[Ion Chicu]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Moldova

Ion Chicu (born 28 February 1972) is a Moldovan politician. He was the Prime Minister of Moldova from 14 November 2019 until 31 December 2020. He became Prime Minister after Maia Sandu was forced out of office in a motion of no confidence by the Parliament of Moldova.

Chicu resigned as Prime Minister in 23 December 2020 because of the protests in Moldova demanding early parliamentary elections.

[[Valeriu Muravschi]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Business people, Prime Ministers of Moldova

Valeriu Muravschi (31 July 1949 – 8 April 2020) was a Moldovan politician and businessman. He was the first Prime Minister of Moldova between 28 May 1991 and 1 July 1992. He also was Minister of Finance from 1990 to 1991. From 1998 to 2001, he was a member of Parliament.

Muravschi died on 8 April 2020 in Chișinău at the age of 70.

[[President of Moldova]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Moldova

The president of the Republic of Moldova (Președintele Republicii Moldova) is the head of state of Moldova. The current president of Moldova is Maia Sandu since 24 December 2020.

[[Mircea Snegur]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Presidents of Moldova

Mircea Ion Snegur (ˈmirt͡ʃe̯a iˈon ˈsneɡur; born 17 January 1940) is a Moldovan politician. He was the first President of Moldova from 1990 to 1997. Before that, he was Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet from 1989 to 1990 and Chairman of the Supreme Soviet from 27 April to 3 September 1990. 

[[Petru Lucinschi]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Presidents of Moldova

Petru Lucinschi (ˈpetru luˈt͡ʃinski; born 27 January 1940) is a Moldovan politician. He was Moldova's second President from 1997 to 2001.

[[Vladimir Voronin]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Presidents of Moldova

Vladimir Voronin (vladiˈmir voˈronin; born May 25, 1941) is a Moldovan politician. He was the third President of Moldova from 2001 until 2009 and has been the First Secretary of the Party of Communists of the Republic of Moldova (PCRM) since 1994. 

He was Europe's first democratically elected communist party head of state after the end of the Eastern Bloc.

[[Nicolae Timofti]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Judges, Presidents of Moldova

Nicolae Timofti (nikoˈla.e tiˈmofti; born 22 December 1948) is a Moldovan jurist and politician. He was President of Moldova from 23 March 2012 until 23 December 2016. He was head of Moldova's Supreme Magistrate Council and was elected President by parliament on 16 March 2012.

[[Mihai Ghimpu]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, Legislative speakers, Presidents of Moldova

Mihai Ghimpu  (born 19 November 1951) is a Moldovan politician. He was Speaker of Parliament and Acting President of Moldova from 2009 to 2010. He was member of Parliament of Moldova from 1990 to 1998 and from 2009 to 2019. 

Ghimpu was Leader of Liberal Party from 1998 to 2018.

[[Vlad Filat]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Moldova, Presidents of Moldova, Business people

Vladimir Filat (born 6 May 1969), commonly referred to as Vlad Filat (vlad fiˈlat), is a Moldovan businessman and politician. He was the founder of Liberal Democratic Party of Moldova. He was the Prime Minister of Moldova from 25 September 2009 to 25 April 2013. He also was appointed as the Interim President of Moldova in 2010.

Salzburg-Umgebung is an administrative district in the federal state of Salzburg, Austria. It is congruent with the Flachgau region. The administrative center of the district is Salzburg.

[[Marian Lupu]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Presidents of Moldova, Living people

Marian Lupu (mariˈan ˈlupu; born 20 June 1966) is a Moldovan politician. He was the President of the Parliament of Moldova between 2010 and 2013. From this position he was Acting President of the Republic from 2010 until 2012.

[[Nigerian Pidgin]]

CATEGORIES: Pidgins and creoles, Languages of Nigeria, English-based pidgins

Nigerian Pidgin or West African Pidgin is a pidgin language spoken in Nigeria. It is based on English. It has few first language speakers, but is used as a lingua franca by many Nigerians. 

Somewhat unusually for a pidgin language, it has got a written version.

Nigerian Pidgin is mostly used in informal conversations. It has no status as an official language. Nigerian Standard English is used in politics, the internet and some television programs.

[[Parliament of the Republic of Moldova]]

CATEGORIES: Moldova

The Parliament of the Republic of Moldova is the representative body of the Republic of Moldova, the only state legislative authority, being a unicameral. It is made up of 101 elected deputies on lists, for a period of 4 years. Parliament is elected by universal vote.

[[Igor Dodon]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, Presidents of Moldova

Igor Dodon (ˈiɡor doˈdon; born 18 February 1975) is a Moldovan politician. He was wthe President of Moldova from 23 December 2016 to 24 December 2020. He was the leader of the Party of Socialists of the Republic of Moldova. 

He was Minister of Trade and Economics in the governments of Vasile Tarlev and Zinaida Greceanîi from September 2006 to September 2009 and was a member of the Parliament of Moldova from 2009 to 2016.

He lost his re-election bid to former Prime Minister Maia Sandu on 15 November 2020.

[[Liezen District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Styria

Liezen is a district in Styria, Austria. 

It is by far the largest district in Austria, about three times the size of other large districts. It is divided into two "subdistricts": 

Bereich Liezen, and Expositur Gröbming. 

[[Montblanc, Tarragona]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Spain, Municipalities in Catalonia

Montblanc is a town in Catalonia, which is a nation inside Spain. It's the capital of its comarca (an administrative division), called Conca de Barberà.

[[Glenn Fredly]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from meningitis, Indonesian singers, Songwriters, Record producers, People from Jakarta

Glenn Fredly Deviano Latuihamallo (30 September 1975 – 8 April 2020), known professionally as Glenn Fredly, was an Indonesian R&B singer-songwriter, record producer and guitarist. He released more than 10 albums. He produced Cahaya Dari Timur: Beta Maluku. In 2013, he served as a coach for The Voice Indonesia. He was born in Jakarta. 

In 1995, he won the Cipta Pesona Bintang singing contest. In 1996, he was a finalist in the Asia Song Festival. In 2014, he produced the movie Cahaya Dari Timur: Beta Maluku. 

Fredly died on 8 April 2020 at the age of 44 in Jakarta of meningitis. 

[[Murau District]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Styria

Bezirk Murau is a district in Styria, Austria.

[[Dena Dietrich]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, American television actors, American movie actors, American stage actors, Actors from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, American voice actors

Dena Dietrich (December 4, 1928 – November 21, 2020)  is an American actress. She was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. 

She is known for playing Grace Peterson in Adam's Rib, Dena Madison in Karen, Estelle Milner in Paul Sand in Friends and Lovers, Molly Gibbons in The Practice Ethel Armbrewster in The Ropers, and Pearl Newman in 13 East. 

Dietrich also starred in The Wild Party (1975), Disney's The North Avenue Irregulars (1979) and the Mel Brooks movie History of the World, Part I (1981). She appeared on Broadway in The Rimers of Eldritch, Here's Where I Belong, and The Prisoner of Second Avenue. Dietrich was the voice of the grandmother narrator on the dark ride attraction Horizons at Epcot in Walt Disney World from 1983 until 1999.

Dietrich died of natural causes on November 21, 2020, at a health-care facility in Los Angeles. She was 91 years old.

[[Irene Hirano]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1948 births, Deaths from leiomyosarcoma, Cancer deaths in Los Angeles, American chief executives, American philanthropists, Businesspeople from Los Angeles, California, Disease-related deaths in Los Angeles

Irene Hirano Inouye (née Yasutake; October 7, 1948 – April 7, 2020) was an American business executive. She was a sansei, or a third-generation Japanese-American. She was the founding president of the U.S.-Japan Council from 2009 until her death in 2020. She also served as president and founding chief executive officer of the Japanese American National Museum in Los Angeles, California from 1988 to 2008.

Hirano was born in Los Angeles. She married Hawaii Senator Daniel Inouye in 2008. The couple were together until Inouye's death in 2012. Hirano died of leiomyosarcoma on April 7, 2020, in Los Angeles. She was 71.

[[Awajichō Station]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 establishments in Japan, Railway stations in Tokyo

Awajicho Station is a subway station on the Tokyo Metro Marunouchi Line in Chiyoda, Tokyo, Japan. Tokyo Metro runs this station.

[[The Experts (1989 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: English-language movies, American comedy movies, Canadian comedy movies, Movies set in New York City, Movies set in Russia, 1989 comedy movies

The Experts is a 1989 American Cold War comedy movie starring John Travolta, Arye Gross and Kelly Preston. It was written by Steven Greene, Eric Alter, and Nick Thiel and directed by Dave Thomas. The movie was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Marc Chardonnens]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, French politicians

Marc Chardonnens (1960 – 6 April 2020) was a Swiss government official. He worked at the Federal Office for Environmental Protection from 1987 to 2004, then at the Federal Office for the Environment, Forests and Landscape. In 2004, he was appointed as head of the environmental department of the Canton of Fribourg. He chaired the conférence des chefs des services de la protection de l'environnement from 2011 to 2015. 

On 27 January 2016, the Federal Council elected him Director of the Federal Office for the Environment. He took office on 11 April 2016, and resigned in late January 2020. 

Chardonnens died on 6 April 2020.

[[Stanislav Libenský and Jaroslava Brychtová]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2002 deaths, 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Czech artists, Sculptors

Stanislav Libenský (March 27, 1921 – February 24, 2002) and Jaroslava Brychtová (July 18, 1924 – April 8, 2020) were contemporary artists. Their works are included in many major modern art collections. Their works could be seen at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Victoria & Albert Museum. Jaroslava Brychtová, a sculptor, and Stanislav Libenský, originally a painter and later a glass artist, met in 1954. They married in 1963 and worked together until Libenský's death in 2002. Libenský painted and sketched the designs, and Brychtová made clay sculptures from his designs. 

[[Linda Tripp]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Businesspeople from New Jersey, Bill Clinton

Linda Rose Tripp (née Carotenuto; November 24, 1949 – April 8, 2020) was an American civil servant. She played an important role in the Lewinsky scandal of 1998. Tripp's action in secretly recording Monica Lewinsky's secret phone calls about her relationship with the president caused a sensation with their links to the earlier Clinton v. Jones lawsuit.

Tripp claimed that her motives were patriotic, and she was able to avoid a wiretap charge for handing in the tapes. She then claimed that her firing from the Pentagon at the end of the Clinton administration was because she leaked the phone calls, while the administration claimed it to be a standard routine.

From 2004, Tripp worked with her husband in a retail business in Middleburg, Virginia.

Tripp was born in Jersey City, New Jersey. She died from pancreatic cancer in Middleburg at the age of 70 on April 8, 2020.

[[Te Huirangi Waikerepuru]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Activists, Trade unionists, New Zealand Māori people

Huirangi Eruera Waikerepuru NZL (1 April 1929 – 8 April 2020) was a New Zealand Māori language activist and trade unionist. He was known for creating Māori language radio and television channels. He had a 30-year relationship with the Tertiary Education Union.

In 1995, Waikerepuru was awarded an Honorary Doctorate from the University of Waikato. In the 2014 Queen's Birthday Honours, he was appointed a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit. He was a life member of the Tertiary Education Union.

Waikerepuru died on 8 April 2020, aged 91.

[[Ballo dei diavoli]]

The "Ballo dei diavoli" which means The devils' dance in English, is dance from the province of Palermo. The ballo dei diavoli is usually danced during Easter.

[[Acaric]]

CATEGORIES: Technology companies, Companies of Japan, 2000s establishments in Japan

Acaric is a Japanese company based in Tokyo and they are providing educational services (including recruitment support) for graduate students and young researchers (such as postdoctoral fellows). They are also known for developing Cloud LaTeX, an online LaTeX compiler service which is considered as a Japanese counterpart of ShareLaTeX.

[[Haut-Mbomou]]

Kémo is one of the 16 prefectures of the Central African Republic. Its capital is Sibut. It is named for the Kémo River.

[[Lobaye]]

CATEGORIES: Prefectures of the Central African Republic

Lobaye is one of the 16 prefectures of the Central African Republic. Its capital is Mbaïki. 

The prefecture is in the southern part of the country, bordering the Republic of the Congo and the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Besides Mbaïki, other important cities include Boda, in the north, and Mongoumba, by the Ubangi River.

[[Elden, North Dakota]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in North Dakota, North Dakota townships

[[Andrew Salter (entrepreneur)]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 births, Living people, Businesspeople from London

Andrew Salter is a British entrepreneur and Co-Founder and CEO of DIRTEA, the functional mushroom tea brand. He is best known for creating The Feeling Nuts Movement, a social media campaign which encouraged young men to regularly check their testicles for early signs of testicular cancer. He was featured in 30 Under 30 - Europe - Media & Marketing 2020 published by Forbes.

[[Wadi Fira Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Wadi Fira is one of the 23 regions of Chad. Its capital is the town of Biltine.

[[Norman Reedus]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, Actors from Florida, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Models from Florida

Norman Mark Reedus (born January 6, 1969) is an American actor, model and artist. He is known for starring as Daryl Dixon in the AMC series The Walking Dead (2010–present) and Murphy MacManus in the movie The Boondock Saints (1999) and its sequel The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009). He is the host of Ride with Norman Reedus. He performed the motion capture and voice acting for the main character Sam in Hideo Kojima's video game Death Stranding (2019). He has also modeled for companies such as Prada and Levi's.

Reedus was born in Hollywood, Florida. He has a child with Danish model Helena Christensen. He is now in a relationship with German model Diane Kruger. The couple have one child.

[[Sarah Wayne Callies]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Actors from Chicago, Actors from Honolulu, American movie actors, American stage actors, American television actors

Sarah Wayne Callies (born June 1, 1977) is an American actress. She is known for TV roles such as Sara Tancredi in Fox's Prison Break (2005–2009; 2017), Lori Grimes in AMC's The Walking Dead (2010–2013; 2018) and Katie Bowman in USA Network's Colony (2016–2018).

Callies was born in La Grange, Illinois. She grew up in Honolulu, Hawaii. She married Josh Winterhalt in 2002. The couple have two children.

[[Bahr el Gazel (region of Chad)]]

CATEGORIES: 2008 establishments in Africa, Regions of Chad

Barh El Gazel is one of the 23 regions of Chad. Its capital is the town of Moussoro. The region was created in 2008 from the former Barh El Gazel Department of the Kanem Region. The region has 2 departments: Barh El Gazel Nord and Barh El Gazel Sud.

[[Borkou Region]]

CATEGORIES: 2008 establishments in Africa, Regions of Chad

The Borkou region is a region of Chad. Its capital is Faya-Largeau. It was created in 2008 from the Borkou department of the former Borkou-Ennedi-Tibesti region. 

Borkou is in the Sahara Desert. It has parts of the Tibesti Mountains in its north. The highest point in Chad, Emi Koussi, is in Borkou.

The region is divided into 2 departments - Borkou (capital Faya-Largeau) and Borkou Yala (capital Kirdimi).

[[Ennedi-Est Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad, 2010s establishments in Africa, 2012 establishments

Ennedi-Est is a region in Chad. The capital of the region is Amdjarass. It was created in 2012 from Ennedi Region. 

[[Ennedi-Ouest Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad, 2010s establishments in Africa, 2012 establishments

Ennedi-Ouest is a region in Chad. The capital of the region is Fada. It was created in 2012 from the western half of Ennedi Region. 

[[Guéra Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad, 2002 establishments in Africa

Guéra is one of the 23 regions of Chad. The capital is Mongo. It was created in 2002 from the former Guéra prefecture.

Half of the Zakouma National Park is within the region.

[[Kanem Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad, 2002 establishments in Africa

Kanem is one of 23 regions in Chad. The capital is Mao. It is named after the Kanem Empire.

It was created in 2002 from the former Prefecture of Kanem. In 2008, a portion of the Kanem region (the Bahr el Gazel Department) was split off to become the new Bahr el Gazel Region.

Since 2008, the region of Kanem is divided in three departments, namely:

[[Andrew Mills]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people

Andrew Mills  (born 18 June 1981) is an Australian rules footballer who played for Richmond in the Australian Football League (AFL) in 2004 and 2005.

He was drafted from the Murray Bushrangers in the TAC Cup, with the 52nd selection in the 1999 AFL Draft. He played 14 games in four seasons at the Tigers before he was delisted at the end of the 2003 season.

[[Oromia Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia

The Oromia Region is one of the regional states of Ethiopia. The capital city is Addis Ababa (also called Finfinne).

It is the homeland of the Oromo people. It has a population of around 35,000,000; this makes it the largest regional state in terms of population. It is also the largest regional state by land size. 

[[Shingai Shoniwa]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Blues musicians, Electronic musicians, Black English musicians, English pop singers, English songwriters, Singers from London, Living people

Shingai Eizabeth Maria Shoniwa (born 1 September 1981) is a British singer, musician, songwriter and actress. She is signed to Motown and Universal Music Group, became active in 2006, and is a member of the band Noisettes.

[[Needamangalam taluk]]

Needamangalam Taluk is a taluk in India.

[[Dionne Bromfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, British R&B musicians, Black English musicians, English songwriters, Singers from London, London Borough of Tower Hamlets, Living people

Dionne Julia Bromfield (born 1 February 1996) is an English singer, songwriter, TV presenter, and television personality. She rose to fame in 2009 signing to Amy Winehouse's record label Lioness Records.

[[Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings]]

CATEGORIES: Musical groups from New York City, Musicians from Brooklyn, American R&B bands, Funk bands, Musical groups disestablished in 2016, Musical groups established in 1996, Soul bands, 1990s American music groups, 1996 establishments in New York (state), 2016 disestablishments in the United States

Sharon Jones & The Dap Kings were an American soul music band, comprised of Sharon Jones and ever dap king. Sharon Jones was the lead vocalist of the band. The band was formed in 1996 and disbanded in 2016. That was because Sharon Jones died on 18 November that year. The dap kings liked Mark Ronson and Amy Winehouse. They were signed to Daptone Records.

[[Frances Hesselbein]]

CATEGORIES: 1915 births, Living people, American centenarians, Businesspeople from Pennsylvania, People from Johnstown, Pennsylvania, Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients

Frances Hesselbein (born 1 November 1915) is an American businesswoman. She served as the CEO of the Girl Scouts of the USA from 1976 to 1990. In 1998, she was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom for her work with the Girl Scouts of the USA.

Hesselbein was born in Johnstown, Pennsylvania. She turned 100 in 2015.

[[Common (rapper)]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, American hip hop musicians, African-American rappers, American rap musicians from Illinois, Musicians from Chicago, Living people

Lonnie Corant Jaman Shuka Rashid Lynn (born March 13, 1972), better known by his stage name Common, is an American rapper, songwriter, actor, and recording artist. He was born in Chicago, Illinois. His music has been compared to the likes of Kanye West.

[[Arthur L. Thurlow]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, Living people, Canadian centenarians, Canadian lawyers, Canadian politicians, People from Nova Scotia

Arthur Louis Thurlow (born May 5, 1913) is a Canadian politician and judge. He served as a member of the Nova Scotia House of Assembly from 1949 to 1953. He represented the electoral district of Lunenburg County. He was a member of the Nova Scotia Liberal Party.

Thurlow was born in Lunenburg, Nova Scotia. He turned 100 in 2013.

[[Ruth Apilado]]

CATEGORIES: 1908 births, 2021 deaths, American civil rights activists, American novelists, American supercentenarians, Writers from Chicago

Ruth Mosselle Apilado (née Mays; April 30, 1908 – August 15, 2021) was an American writer and anti-racism activist. She was known as the founder of the quarterly magazine America's Intercultural Magazine (AIM). She founded AIM in 1973.

Apilado was born in Chicago, Illinois. She turned 100 in 2008, and 110 in 2018. Apilado died on August 15, 2021 in Federal Way, Washington at the age of 113.

[[Walensee]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of Switzerland, Canton of Glarus, Canton of St. Gallen

The Walensee, also known as Lake Walen or Lake Walenstadt from Walenstadt, is a lake in eastern Switzerland. It is in the cantons of St. Gallen and Glarus. Other towns and villages at the lake include Weesen, Quinten, Quarten, and Murg.

The three main rivers leading to this lake are the Seez, Murgbach, and Linth. The last continues its course from Walensee to Lake Zurich. The Schnittlauchinsel, at the eastern end of the lake, is the only island in the Walensee.

The Churfirsten range raises steeply on the north side from the lake's level at 419 m to 2,306 m above sea level.

[[Ben Peyton]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, British actors

Ben Peyton (born 1977) is a British actor who is best known for portraying PC Ben Hayward in the British police drama series The Bill from 2000 to 2002. He has also appeared in Bridget Jones's Diary, Band of Brothers, Emmerdale, Doctor Who, Holby City, and Hacksaw Ridge.

[[Budaun district]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Uttar Pradesh, Districts of Uttar Pradesh

Budaun district is one of the districts of Uttar Pradesh state of India. Budaun city is the headquarter. It is the part of Bareilly division.

[[Bareilly]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Uttar Pradesh

Bareilly (बरेली) is a city in Bareilly district, Uttar Pradesh, India. It is the capital of Bareilly division. In 2015 Bareilly is selected one of the smartest cities of India.

According to 2011 Census of India, the population of the city is 904,797 out of 477,515 are males and 427,282 are females.

[[Stephen Smale]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, Living people, American computer scientists, American mathematicians, Fields Medalists, People from Flint, Michigan, Wolf Prize winners

Stephen Smale (born July 15, 1930) is an American mathematician. He is known for his research in topology, dynamical systems and mathematical economics. He spent more than 30 years on the mathematics faculty of the University of California, Berkeley (1960–1961 and 1964–1995). He was awarded the Fields Medal in 1966. In 2007, Smale was awarded the Wolf Prize in mathematics. He was born in Flint, Michigan.

[[Kantorovich theorem]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics

In mathematics (especially numerical analysis), the Kantorovich theorem (or the Newton-Kantorovich theorem) is a mathematical statement about the convergence of Newton's method. This theorem was named after Leonid Kantorovich, and it is frequently used in the field of validated numerics.

[[Moshe Brawer]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, Living people, Asian geographers, Israeli Jews, Israeli scientists, People from Jerusalem, Scientists from Vienna, Writers from Vienna, Israeli writers

Moshe Brawer (משה ברוור‎; 3 November 1919 – 28 December 2020) was an Israeli geographer. In 2002, he won the Israel Prize for geography research. He was the author of The Atlas of the World, an Israeli textbook published in at least 67 editions. 

Brawer was born in Vienna, Austria, to a Jewish family. His family moved to Jerusalem in 1920. He turned 100 in 2019. Brawer died on 28 December 2020, aged 101.

[[Junzo Sekine]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Baseball coaches, Japanese baseball players, Sportspeople from Tokyo

Junzo Sekine was a Japanese professional baseball player. He played as a pitcher and outfielder. He played for the Kintetsu Pearls/Buffaloes from 1950 to 1964. He also played for the Yomiuri Giants during the 1965 season. He later managed the Yokohama Taiyo Whales from 1982 to 1984 and the Yakult Swallows from 1987 to 1989. He was added into the Japanese Baseball Hall of Fame in 2003. He was born in Tokyo.

Sekine died on 9 April 2020 in Tokyo, at the age of 93.

[[Bad Kötzting]]

Bad Kötzting (before 2005: Kötzting) is a town of the district of Cham, in Bavaria, Germany.

[[Ammerthal]]

CATEGORIES: Amberg-Sulzbach

Ammerthal is a municipality of the district Amberg-Sulzbach in Bavaria in Germany. As of 31 December 2018, 2,091 people lived there. The mayor is currently Alexandra Sitter.

[[Attenhofen]]

Attenhofen (Bavarian: Attenhofn) is a municipality of the district Kelheim in Lower Bavaria in Germany.

[[Frances Kinne]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, Living people, American academics, American centenarians, American educators, Writers from Jacksonville, Florida, Writers from Iowa

Frances Bartlett Kinne (May 23, 1917 – May 10, 2020) was an American educator, administrator and author. She served as president of Jacksonville University from 1979 to 1989. She was the first female university president to hold office in the state of Florida, and second in the United States. Her memoir, Iowa Girl: The President Wears a Skirt, was published in 2000.

Kinne was born in Story City, Iowa. She turned 100 in 2017. Kinne died on May 10, 2020 in Jacksonville, Florida at the age of 102.

Pacific County is a county in Washington in the United States. The county seat is South Bend. 20,920 people lived there at the 2010 census.

It was also released on the Game Boy Color in October 1999.

[[Del Martin and Phyllis Lyon]]

CATEGORIES: American feminist writers, American LGBT rights activists, Lesbian feminists, American journalists, Writers from San Francisco, Writers from Tulsa, Oklahoma, LGBT people from California

Dorothy Louise Taliaferro "Del" Martin (May 5, 1921 – August 27, 2008) and Phyllis Ann Lyon (November 10, 1924 – April 9, 2020) were an American lesbian couple known as feminist and gay-rights activists.

Martin and Lyon met in 1950, became lovers in 1952, and moved in together on Valentine's Day 1953. They had been together for three years when they co-founded the Daughters of Bilitis (DOB) in San Francisco in 1955. It was the first social and political organization for lesbians in the United States.

They both acted as president and editor of The Ladder until 1963, and remained involved in the DOB until joining the National Organization for Women (NOW) as the first lesbian couple to do so.

They were married on February 12, 2004, in the first same-sex wedding to take place in San Francisco after Mayor Gavin Newsom ordered the city clerk to begin providing marriage licenses to same-sex couples. However, that marriage was voided by the California Supreme Court on August 12, 2004. 

They married again on June 16, 2008, in the first same-sex wedding to take place in San Francisco after the California Supreme Court's decision in In re Marriage Cases legalized same-sex marriage in California.

Martin was born in San Francisco. She died there of problems caused by a fall at the age of 87 in 2008.

Lyon was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma. She died in 2020 at the age of 95.

[[Daughters of Bilitis]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 establishments in California

The Daughters of Bilitis b, also called the DOB or the Daughters, was the first lesbian civil and political rights organization in the United States. 

The organization, formed in San Francisco in 1955 by Del Martin and Phyllis Lyon, was created to be another hangout area for lesbians other than lesbian bars. This was to avoid raids and police harassment. It later gave support to women who were afraid to come out. 

The DOB educated them about their rights, and about gay history.

The Daughters of Bilitis lasted for 14 years, becoming an educational resource for lesbians, gay men, researchers and mental health professionals.

[[The Ladder (magazine)]]

CATEGORIES: American magazines

The Ladder was the first nationally distributed lesbian publication in the United States. It was published monthly from 1956 to 1970, and once every other month in 1971 and 1972. It was the primary publication and method of communication for the Daughters of Bilitis, the first lesbian organization in the country.

[[Pale ale]]

CATEGORIES: Types of beer

Pale ale is a kind of beer. Its mailny made of malt, which is ligher in color.  It is one of the older kinds of beer. At the begiunning of the 19th century, Pale Ale existed in England. While it is common in England, there are also varieties in Belgium (Belgian Pale ale), and in the Noth of France (called bières de garde). Because of its color, the beer is sometimes called amber.

[[Celina, Tennessee]]

Celina is a city in Tennessee in the United States. It is the county seat of Clay County.

Cleveland is a city in Tennessee in the United States. It is the county seat of Bradley County.
