Paulinenaue is a municipality of the district Havelland in the state of Brandenburg in Germany.

[[Hunter Biden]]

CATEGORIES: Joe Biden, 1970 births, Living people, American lawyers, Businesspeople from Wilmington, Delaware

Robert Hunter Biden (born February 4, 1970) is an American lawyer and businessman. He is the second son of U. S. President Joe Biden. In 2009, he co-founded Rosemont Seneca Partners.

Biden was on the board of Burisma Holdings from 2014 to 2019. President Donald Trump tried to pressure the Ukrainian government to investigate Joe Biden and Hunter Biden by ending foreign aid to Ukraine. This caused an impeachment inquiry in September 2019, in which the President was impeached.

[[Miguel Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish footballers, People with cancer

Miguel Jones Castillo (27 October 1938 – 8 April 2020) was a Spanish footballer. He played as a midfielder for SD Indautxu and Atlético Madrid during the 1950s and 1960s. In October 1967, Jones was signed for a season with Osasuna, his last club. After retiring as a player he returned to live in Bilbao and was a director at SD Indautxu. He was born in Santa Isabel, Spanish Guinea (now Malabo, Equatorial Guinea). 

Jones, who had cancer, died on 8 April 2020 in Bilbao from COVID-19 at the age of 81.

[[Norman I. Platnick]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, American educators, American biologists, Scientists from West Virginia, Writers from West Virginia

Norman Ira Platnick (December 30, 1951 – April 8, 2020) was an American biological systematist and arachnologist. He was born in Bluefield, West Virginia. 

He was a Professor Emeritus of the Richard Gilder Graduate School and Peter J. Solomon Family Curator Emeritus of the invertebrate zoology department of the American Museum of Natural History. Platnick described over 1,800 species of spiders from around the world.  

Until 2014 he was also the maintainer of the World Spider Catalog, a website which tracks the arachnology literature.

Platnick died on April 8, 2020 at a hospital in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania of problems caused from a fall, aged 68.

[[Mercer County, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: West Virginia counties

Mercer County is a county on the southeastern border of the U.S. state of West Virginia. At the 2010 census, the population was 62,264. Its county seat is Princeton. The county was originally in the state of Virginia.

[[Princeton, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in West Virginia, County seats in West Virginia

Princeton, is a city in and the county seat of Mercer County, West Virginia, United States. The population was 6,432 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Bluefield, WV-VA micropolitan area.

[[Bière de garde]]

CATEGORIES: Types of beer, France

Bières de garde are beers brewed in the north of France. They are rather light in colors, or amber. Usually, they have more than six percent alcohol. They also have a very malty taste. To many people outside France, the name may be misleading, as it means Beers for safekeeping.

[[Raj K. Aggarwal]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, Kenyan people, British businesspeople, British scientists

Raj Kumar Aggarwal GBR (born 1949) was a Kenyan-British pharmacist, public health expert and businessman. He was born in Nairobi, Kenya. He was the first ever Honorary Consul for India with jurisdiction for Wales. He was responsible for helping to connect Welsh and Indian businesses.

In March 2015, he was appointed president of the Consular Association of Wales. In 1973, he became a member of the Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain.

[[Edgewood, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois

Edgewood is a village in Illinois in the United States.

[[Dmitri Smirnov (composer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Russian composers, British composers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom

Dmitri Nikolaevich Smirnov (Дми́трий Никола́евич Смирно́в; 2 November 1948 – 9 April 2020), also known by his pen names Dmitri N. Smirnov, was a Russian-born British composer. He was born in Minsk. His best known works were Tiriel and The Lamentations of Thel.

His Solo for Harp won First Prize in a competition in Maastricht (1976). His two operas  Tiriel and Thel on a text by William Blake  were premiered in 1989. He was a Composer-in-Residence at University of Cambridge (St John's College), at Dartington, and Visiting Professor at Keele University (1993–8).

Smirnov died of COVID-19 on 9 April 2020 in London at the age of 71.

[[Pat Stapleton (ice hockey)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Boston Bruins players, Canadian ice hockey defencemen, Chicago Blackhawks players, Ice hockey people from Ontario

Patrick James "Whitey" Stapleton (July 4, 1940 – April 8, 2020) was a Canadian ice hockey player. He was a defenceman. Stapleton played 15 seasons in the National Hockey League (NHL) and the World Hockey Association (WHA), mainly for the Chicago Black Hawks. He also played for the Boston Bruins, Chicago Cougars, Indianapolis Racers and Cincinnati Stingers.

Stapleton was born in Sarnia, Ontario, Canada. He was the father of Mike Stapleton, who had a lengthy career in the NHL as well. Stapleton died on April 8, 2020 of stroke-related problems in Strathroy-Caradoc, Ontario, aged 79.

[[Sarnia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ontario

Sarnia is a city in Southwestern Ontario, Canada. It had a 2016 population of 71,594. It is the largest city on Lake Huron and in Lambton County. It is near the St. Clair River.

[[St. Clair River]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Canada, Rivers of the United States, Ontario, Geography of Michigan

The St. Clair River (Rivière Sainte-Claire) is a 40.5 river in central North America flows from Lake Huron into Lake St. Clair. It forms part of the international boundary between the Canadian province of Ontario and the U.S. state of Michigan.  

[[Pete Docter]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, American animators, American movie directors, American movie producers, Living people, Pixar

Peter Hans Docter (born October 9, 1968) is an American animator, director, producer, screenwriter and voice actor.

[[Lake St. Clair]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of Canada, Geography of Ontario, Lakes of the United States, Ontario, Geography of Michigan

Lake St. Clair (Lac Sainte-Claire) is a freshwater lake that lies between the Canadian province of Ontario and the U.S. state of Michigan. It was named in 1679 by French Catholic explorers after Saint Clare of Assisi. 

It is part of the Great Lakes system. It is along with the St. Clair River and Detroit River, Lake St. Clair connects Lake Huron (to the north) with Lake Erie (to the south). It has a total surface area of about 430 and an average depth of just 11.

[[Okanagan]]

CATEGORIES: Valleys, Geography of British Columbia

The Okanagan (oʊ), also called the Okanagan Valley and sometimes as the Okanagan Country, is an area in British Columbia, Canada, that is located around Okanagan Lake and the Okanagan River. It is part of the Okanagan Country, which is also in the United States as Okanogan Country Washington. The region's population is 362,258 in 2016. The largest city is Kelowna.

[[Okanagan Lake]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of Canada, Geography of British Columbia

Okanagan Lake is a large, deep lake in the Okanagan Valley of British Columbia, Canada. The lake is 135 long, between 4 wide, and has a surface area of 348 km2.

[[Lac Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Lac is one of the 23 regions of Chad. Its capital is Bol. The region includes Chad's portion of the shore of Lake Chad.

The region of Lac is divided into two departments - Mamdi (capital Bol) and Wayi (capital Ngouri).

[[Logone Occidental Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Logone Occidental is one of the 23 regions of Chad. Its capital is Moundou. 

[[Logone Oriental Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Logone Oriental is one of the  23 regions of Chad. Its capital is Doba.

[[Mandoul Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Mandoul is one of the 23 regions of Chad. The regional capital is Koumra.

[[Mayo-Kebbi Est Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Mayo-Kebbi Est is one of the 23 regions of Chad. Its capital is Bongor. 

[[Mayo-Kebbi Ouest Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Mayo-Kebbi Ouest is one of the 23 regions of Chad. Its capital is Pala.

The Mayo Kébbi river flows through the north of the region. Lake Léré and the smaller Lake Tréné are in the north-west.

[[Moyen-Chari Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Moyen-Chari is one of the 23 regions of Chad. Its capital is Sarh.

Manda National Park is in the region.

[[Ouaddaï Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Ouaddaï is a region in Chad. The capital city is Abéché.

The region was the heartland of the former Ouaddai Empire, which existed from the early 16th century until 1911. It was defeated by France in the Ouaddai War.

[[Malcolm Dixon (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, English movie actors, English television actors, Actors from County Durham

Malcolm Dixon (September 1953 – 9 April 2020) was an English actor. He was best known as Strutter in the 1981 movie Time Bandits. His height was 4'1" and because of it he often played Ewoks and dwarfs. Dixon worked in Jim Henson's Creature Shop. He also played an Oompa Loompa in Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory (1971). Dixon was born in Crook, County Durham.

Dixon died on 9 April 2020 at the age of 66.

[[Jan Křen]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Czech Republic, Czech politicians, Czech academics, Czech historians, Political activists, Writers from Prague

Jan Křen (22 August 1930 – 7 April 2020) was a Czech historian, academic, and dissident. He was born in Prague. During Czechoslovakia's communist era he became a political dissident. His works focused in the study of Czech-German relations. He was one of the signers of Charter 77. In 1989, Křen founded the Institute of International Studies at Charles University.

In March 2020 during the coronavirus pandemic, Křen was infected with COVID-19. He died from the infection on 7 April 2020 in Prague, at the age of 89.

[[Salamat Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Salamat is one of the 23 regions of Chad. The region's capital is Am Timan. Half of the Zakouma National Park is in the region.

[[Jean-Marie Zoellé]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Germany, French mayors

Jean-Marie Zoellé (16 November 1944 – 6 April 2020) was a French politician. He was Mayor of Saint-Louis, Haut-Rhin from 2011 until his death. He was Deputy Mayor from 1989 until 2011. 

Zoellé died on 6 April 2020 at a hospital in Bonn, Germany from COVID-19, aged 75.

[[Sila Region]]

CATEGORIES: 2008 establishments in Africa, Regions of Chad

Sila or Dar Sila is a region of Chad. The capital of the region is Goz Beïda.

[[André Stordeur]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian composers, Electronic musicians

André Stordeur (1 March 1941 – 7 April 2020) was a Belgian electronic music composer. He was born in Haine-Saint-Paul, Belgium. His musical career started in 1977. In 1979, he worked with Paul-Baudouin Michel on an electroacoustic music composition titled Phraséologie. Also in 1979, he published a solo recording of his electronic music titled 18 Days.

Stordeur died on 7 April 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Tandjilé Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad

Tandjilé is one of the 23 regions of Chad. Its capital is Laï.

[[Tibesti Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Chad, 2008 establishments in Africa

Tibesti Region is a region in Chad. Its capital is Bardaï.

It was created in 2008 when the former Borkou-Ennedi-Tibesti Region was split into three. The Tibesti Department became the Tibesti Region. The region is named for the Tibesti Mountains, one of the most prominent mountain chains in the Sahara Desert.

The area fell under French rule during the Scramble for Africa in the late 19th century. Prior to 1931 much of the region belonged to what is now Niger, as part of the French West Africa colony.

[[Stephen Hahn (oncologist)]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Commissioners of the Food and Drug Administration, Living people

Stephen Michael Hahn (born January 22, 1960) is an American physician. He was the Commissioner of Food and Drugs from December 17, 2019 to January 20, 2021. Before becoming Commissioner, he was a radiation oncologist who was the chief medical executive of the MD Anderson Cancer Center.

On March 1, 2020, Vice President Mike Pence and Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar announced the addition of Hahn to the White House Coronavirus Taskforce.

[[Orthodox Presbyterian Church]]

CATEGORIES: Orthodox Presbyterian Church

The Orthodox Presbyterian Church (OPC) is a confessional Presbyterian denomination located primarily in the northern United States. It was founded by conservative members of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America(PCUSA) who strongly objected to the Modernist theology during the 1930s. It has had an influence on evangelicalism far beyond its size.

[[Orthodox Presbyterian Church of Korea]]

CATEGORIES: Presbyterianism

The Orthodox Presbyterian Church of Korea (OPCK, Founder Ha Seung Moo) is a historic Orthodox Reformed Church's doctrine and historical succession of tradition of the John Knox's  declared the first among Presbyterian denomination in Korea. Launched in January 2012.

[[Surface energy]]

CATEGORIES: Fluid mechanics, Thermodynamics

There is an attraction between molecules in liquids and this is why a liquid stays together. The intermolecular distance in liquid is such that it is attracted to all the surrounding molecules. This attraction causes negative potential energy for the molecule which further depends on the number and distribution of molecules around the chosen one. This is because to collect and disperse such molecules far away from each other in order to evaporate, the heat of evaporation required is quite large. For water, it is 40 kJ/mol.

[[Gabriella Cilmi]]

CATEGORIES: Australian singer-songwriters, Living people, Musicians from Melbourne, Record producers, 1991 births

Gabriella Lucia Cilmi (born 10 October 1991) is an Australian singer-songwriter and record producer. She was born in Melbourne, Victoria, Australia. She was first signed to Warner Records when she was a teenager. She shares a manager with the Sugababes and supported Mutya Buena (who used to be a member of the Sugababes) at the jazz cafe in London. Gabriella's debut album Lessons To Be Learned was produced by Xemonamia, who also worked with Girls Aloud and Cher. Cimli is signed to Island Records. She recently performed the track "Sweet About Me" on prominent UK show Later With Jools Holland.

[[213 (group)]]

CATEGORIES: American rap music groups, Musical groups from Long Beach, California, Musical groups disestablished in 1992, Musical groups disestablished in 2011, Musical groups established in 1990, Musical groups established in 1998, 1990s American music groups

213 (pronounced two-one-three) was an American West Coast hip hop group with Warren G, Snoop Dogg and Nate Dogg. They were based in Long Beach, California. They performed gangsta rap and G-funk. The group was formed in 1990 and ended in 2011 when Nate Dogg died.

[[Tha Eastsidaz]]

CATEGORIES: Musical groups disestablished in 2004, Musical groups disestablished in 2016, Musical groups established in 1997, Musical trios, Musical groups from California, People from Long Beach, California, 1990s American music groups, 1997 establishments in the United States, 2004 disestablishments in the United States, 2010s American music groups, 2014 establishments in California, 2016 disestablishments in the United States

Tha Eastsidaz were an American West Coast hip hop trio. Tray Deee, Snoop Dogg, and Goldie Loc were members of this band. They were based in Long Beach, California and were signed to one of the members' record labels and TVT Records. The group was formed in 1997 and ended in 2016.

[[Master P]]

CATEGORIES: American hip hop musicians, African-American rappers, American rap musicians from Louisiana, American record producers, American songwriters, Living people, Year of birth missing (living people)

Percy Robert Miller, better known by his stage name Master P, is an American rapper, entrepreneur, actor, philanthropist, and former basketball player from New Orleans, Louisiana. He is known for his work on No Limit Records. Master P's first album was The Ghetto Is Trying To Kill Me.

[[Currensy]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, African-American rappers, American songwriters, American rap musicians from Louisiana, Musicians from New Orleans, Louisiana, Living people

Shante Scott Franklin (born April 4, 1981), better known by his stage name Currensy (stylized as Curren$y) is an American rapper, songwriter, and actor. Formely signed to Lil Wayne's record label Young Money Entertainment, he signed himself to No Limit Records as a teenager. After releasing mixtapes he dropped his debut album This Aint No Mixtape in April 2009.

After gaining stream in 2007 he made a shocking move leaving Young Money to do his own thing on an aeroplane. Currensy said "I ain't see nothing coming out of there. I have been on Young Money for like 4 years. We had the "Where The Cash At" video game, you know, that was cool". 

[[Timeline of women in mathematics in the United States]]

CATEGORIES: American mathematicians

There is a long history of women appearances in mathematics in the United States. All women mentioned here are American unless otherwise noted.

[[Jeremih]]

CATEGORIES: American hip hop musicians, African-American rappers, American record producers, American R&B singers, American songwriters, American rap musicians from Illinois, Living people, Musicians from Chicago, 1987 births

Jeremy Phillip Felton (born July 17, 1987) is an American R&B and hip hop music singer, songwriter, rapper, and record producer from Illinois. He plays the vocals, piano, percussion, bass guitar and saxophone. He has worked with other artists like 50 Cent, Hitmaka, PartyNextDoor and Ty Dolla Sign.

[[Timeline of women in mathematics]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics

This article is a timeline of women appearances in mathematics.

[[Sofya Kovalevskaya]]

CATEGORIES: 1850 births, 1891 deaths, Russian people, Mathematicians, Russian mathematicians

Sofya Vasilyevna Kovalevskaya (Софья Васильевна Ковалевская), born Sofya Vasilyevna Korvin-Krukovskaya (15 January – 10 February 1891), was a Russian mathematician who contributed to analysis, partial differential equations and mechanics. She was a pioneer for women in mathematics around the world – the first woman to obtain a doctorate (in the modern sense) in mathematics, the first woman appointed to a full professorship in Northern Europe and one of the first women to work for a scientific journal as an editor.

[[Korea Presbyterian Theological Seminary(KPTS)]]

CATEGORIES: Education in South Korea

Korea Presbyterian Theological Seminary (한국장로회신학교) is a seminary in Gangnam-gu, Seoul, South Korea founded on 17 January 2012.

[[Puttur, Karnataka]]

Puttur is a town in India. It is in the Dakshina Kannada district of Karnataka state. It is 52 km away from the district headquarters, Mangalore. People there speak Tulu and Kannada. This place consist of many notable visiting spots like Shri Mahathobara Mahalingeshwara Temple, Shri Panchamukhi Hanuman Temple Hanumagiri, Viramada mane water park, Camco chocolate factory , etc. This place is famous for its heritage and monuments . Puttur has Karnataka's 2nd largest Bus stand.

Montgomery County is a county in the U.S. state of Indiana. As of 2010, 38,124 people lived there. The county seat is Crawfordsville.

[[Parke County, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1821 establishments in Indiana, Indiana counties

Parke County is a county in the western part of the U.S. state of Indiana along the Wabash River. It was created in 1821. As of 2010, 17,339 people lived there which is an increase of 0.6% from 17,241 in 2000. The county seat is Rockville.

[[Steve Farmer (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, American singer-songwriters, American rock singers, American rock guitarists, American composers, Singers from Detroit, Michigan, Musicians from Detroit, Michigan, Writers from Detroit, Michigan

Steven O. Farmer (December 31, 1948 – April 7, 2020) was an American guitarist, composer and singer-songwriter. He was born in Detroit, Michigan. Farmer was best known for his works with Ted Nugent in 1968. His best known song was "Journey to the Center of the Mind". He also worked with The Amboy Dukes. 

Farmer died on April 7, 2020 in Redford, Michigan, aged 71.

[[Redford, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Michigan

Redford, officially the Charter Township of Redford, is a charter township in Wayne County in the U.S. state of Michigan and a suburb of Detroit.  The population was 48,362 at the 2010 census.

[[Pearland, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas

Pearland (ˈ PAIR) is a city in the U.S. state of Texas, within the Houston–The Woodlands–Sugar Land metropolitan area. Most of the city is in Brazoria County. As of the 2010 census, the city's population was 91,252. 

[[Armando Francioli]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors, Italian centenarians, Actors from Rome

Armando Francioli (October 21, 1919 – April 6, 2020) was an Italian actor. He appeared in more than fifty movies, beginning in 1942. Francioli was born in Rome. His best known roles were in The Pharaohs' Woman, The Opium Den and in Hawk of the Caribbean.

Francioli died in Rome on April 6, 2020 at the age of 100. 

[[Enrique Múgica]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish lawyers, Spanish politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain

Enrique Múgica Herzog (1932 — 10 April 2020) was a Spanish lawyer and politician. He was born in San Sebastián, Guipúzcoa, Spain. A critic of Francisco Franco, he spent three years in prison. He was one of the founders of the Spanish Socialist Party (PSOE).

He was Justice Minister (1988–1991), former congressman (representing Gipuzkoa; 1977–2000) and former Ombudsman (2000–2010).

He died on 10 April 2020 from COVID-19 in Barcelona, aged 88.

[[Nobuhiko Obayashi]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Japanese movie directors, Japanese screenwriters, Editors

Nobuhiko Obayashi was a Japanese director, screenwriter and editor. He was born in Onomichi, Hiroshima, Japan. He was best known as the director of the 1977 horror movie House. His other best movies are Toki o Kakeru Shōjo and Hanagatami.

Obayashi died on April 10, 2020 in Tokyo of lung cancer at the age of 82.

[[Hans Verhagen]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch filmmakers, Dutch journalists, Dutch painters, Dutch poets, People from Vlissingen, Writers from Zeeland

Hans Verhagen (3 March 1939 – 10 April 2020) was a Dutch journalist, poet, painter and filmmaker. He was born in Vlissingen, Netherlands. He won the P. C. Hooft Award in 2009 "for his humour, his engagement, his poetic daring and whimsy." 

Verhagen died on 10 April 2020 in Amsterdam at the age of 81.

[[Tom Webster (ice hockey)]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Boston Bruins players, Detroit Red Wings players, Ice hockey people from Ontario

Thomas Ronald "Hawkeye" Webster (October 4, 1948 – April 10, 2020) was a Canadian professional ice hockey player and coach. He was born in Kirkland Lake, Ontario, Canada. His career lasted from 1968 to 1980. He played for the Boston Bruins, Detroit Red Wings, California Golden Seals and the New England Whalers.

Webster died on April 10, 2020 of brain cancer at the age of 71.

[[Sam Sheppard]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 1970 deaths, Deaths from liver failure, American people convicted of manslaughter, People acquitted of murder, American professional wrestlers, American physicians, Sportspeople from Cleveland, Ohio

Samuel Holmes Sheppard (1923 – 1970) was an American neurosurgeon and professional wrestler. He was born in Cleveland, Ohio. 

Sheppard was known for being accused and later convicted for murdering his wife Marilyn. He was released in 1966 after new evidence questioned his guilty sentence. The case was controversial from the beginning. The U.S. Supreme Court found that the "carnival atmosphere" (media) surrounding Sheppard's first trial had made due process impossible. After ten years in prison he was acquitted at a second trial. There was also evidence that he judge from Sheppard's first trial was unfair. Sheppard was represented by F. Lee Bailey.

In August 1969 at the age of 45, he became a wrestler known as "Killer" Sam Sheppard. Sheppard wrestled over 40 matches before his death in April 1970.

Sheppard died on April 6, 1970 of liver failure after suffering from alcoholism in Columbus, Ohio at the age of 46.

[[The Hidden (1987 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 action movies, 1987 horror movies, 1980s science fiction horror movies, American action movies, American science fiction movies, American horror movies, American independent movies

The Hidden is a 1987 science fiction action horror movie produced and released by New Life Cinema and directed by Jack Sholder. It stars Kyle MacLachlan, Michael Nouri, Ed O'Ross, Clu Gulager, Chris Mulkey, Clarence Felder, Larry Cedar, Claudia Christian and Tony Anholt. A sequel The Hidden II was released in 1993.

[[Bruce Baillie]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American movie directors, American movie producers, American military personnel of the Korean War, American artists, People from Aberdeen, South Dakota, Businesspeople from South Dakota, Businesspeople from San Francisco, Artists from San Francisco

Bruce Baillie (September 24, 1931 – April 10, 2020) was an American avant-garde cinematic artist. He was the founder of Canyon Cinema in San Francisco in 1961. He was born in Aberdeen, South Dakota. His best known movie was Castro Street.

Baillie died on April 10, 2020 at his home in Camano Island, Washington at the age of 88.

[[Philip, South Dakota]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in South Dakota, County seats in South Dakota

Philip is a town in and the county seat of rural Haakon County, South Dakota, United States. The population was 779 at the 2010 census.

[[Hilary Dwyer]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, English movie actors, English stage actors, English television actors, English businesspeople, English movie producers, Actors from Liverpool

Hilary Dwyer (6 May 1945 – April 2020) was an English actress, businessperson and movie producer. She was born in Liverpool, England. She was best known for her acting roles in Witchfinder General (1968) and Wuthering Heights (1970). Dwyer also produced An Awfully Big Adventure (1995) and Nil by Mouth (1997).

Dwyer died of COVID-19 in April 2020 at the age of 74.

[[Fort Sheridan, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Illinois, Suburbs of Chicago, Illinois

Fort Sheridan is a residential neighborhood within the cities of Lake Forest, Highwood, and Highland Park in Lake County, Illinois, United States. 

It was originally created as Fort Sheridan, an Army post named after Civil War cavalry general Philip Sheridan, to honor his services to Chicago.

[[History of Sri Lanka]]

[[Jew's harp]]

CATEGORIES: Musical instruments

The Jew's harp (also known as jaw harp or mouth harp) is a small musical instrument. It is held on the mouth and plucked. The person playing the harp changes the pitch and tone of the sound created by changing the shape of their mouth.

[[Mathematics Genealogy Project]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics, Technology

The Mathematics Genealogy Project is a web-based database for the academic information of mathematicians. It contains information on many mathematical scientists who contributed to research-level mathematics (Mathematics higher than graduate level). The project entry includes PhD course graduation year, PhD thesis title, alma mater, doctoral advisor, and doctoral students.

[[Lucy Joan Slater]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2008 deaths, British mathematicians

Lucy Joan Slater (5 January 1922 – 6 June 2008) was a British mathematician who studied mathematical functions. Many mathematical identities have been named after her. For example, there is the Jackson-Slater identity and the Rogers-Ramanujan-Slater identity. She is also known for her books about special functions and Fortran.

[[Marie Anne de Bourbon]]

CATEGORIES: 1666 births, 1739 deaths, French princesses, House of Bourbon, Smallpox survivors, Deaths from brain cancer, People from Ile-de-France

Marie Anne de Bourbon, ''Légitimée de France (2 October 1666 – 3 May 1739) was the eldest legitimised daughter (fille légitimée de France'') of King Louis XIV of France and his first well known mistress Louise de La Vallière.

[[LGBT rights in India]]

CATEGORIES: LGBT rights by country

Lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people in India may face difficulties from the law and the society. Non-LGBT persons do not commonly face these difficulties. India has removed laws that treated gay sex and transgender people unfairly. But Indian laws do not completely protect from unfair treatment or allow same-sex marriage.

Since 2014, transgender people in India may change their gender without surgery. The constitution also gives them a right to name themselves under a third gender. Some states also protect hijras, who are traditional third gender people in South Asia, through housing programmes, welfare benefits, pension schemes, and free operations in government hospitals. There are about 4.8 million transgender people in India.

In 2018, the Supreme Court of India said that homosexuality was not a crime. It declared that Section 377 of the Indian Penal Code did not follow the constitution when adults had consensual homosexual sex. Homosexuality was never illegal in ancient Indian and traditional codes. It was made a crime by the British during their rule in India.

Though LGBT rights have been spoken for in recent political movements, much homophobia is still present among the people. A poll from 2019 says that around half of Indians object to same-sex relationships. Hindu respondents accept the LGBT community the highest. In 2010s, LGBT people in India gained tolerance and acceptance, especially in large cities. Still, most LGBT people in India remain hidden because they fear unfair treatment from their families who might see homosexuality as shameful.

[[She (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: Indian television series, Netflix webseries

She  is an Indian crime drama based web television series created and written by Imtiaz Ali & author Divya Johry. She is directed by Arif Ali and Avinash Das and Window Seat Films production house. This series is starring Aaditi Pohankar, Vijay Varma and Vishwas Kini. It is a story of female constable who goes undercover to bust an underworld gang . She wias premiered on Netflix on 20 March, 2020 .

It is a story of female constable (Bhumika Pardeshi) from Indian Police who has been inducted in the Anti Narcotics Group to fight a major drug lord.

Andrew Christopher Stanton (born December 3, 1965) is an American movie director, producer, screenwriter and voice actor. He began working at Pixar in 1990.

[[Atauro]]

CATEGORIES: East Timor

Atauro in an island of East Timor. It is about 25 km long and 9 km wide, about 140.1 km2 in area. It had 9,274 people living there at the 2015 Census. The nearest island is the Indonesian island of Liran, 12 km to the northeast.

At 999 m above sea level, Mount Manucoco is the island's highest point.

The island is administratively divided into five sucos, each surrounding a village:

Jaco may refer to:

[[Jaco Island]]

CATEGORIES: East Timor, Uninhabited islands

Jaco Island is an island in East Timor. No people live there. It is within Nino Konis Santana National Park. The Banda Sea and Timor Sea meet at the island.

[[Ali Riahi]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 1970 deaths, Tunisian singers, People from Tunis

 Ali Fethi Ben Mohamed Ben Brahim Riahi (Arabic:علي الرياحي), (March 30, 1912 Tunis – Mars 17, 1970), was a Tunisian singer and composer. He is the grandson of Sidi Brahim Riahi .

[[Oecusse]]

CATEGORIES: Exclaves, Municipalities of East Timor

Oecusse is a Special Administrative Region of East Timor. The capital is Pante Macassar. Oecusse is separated from the rest of East Timor by West Timor.

The province of Nusa Tenggara Timur, Indonesia surrounds Oecusse in all directions except the north, where it borders the Savu Sea.

[[Habiba Msika]]

CATEGORIES: Tunisian singers, Murdered musicians, 1903 births, 1930 deaths, Deaths from fire, People from Tunis

Habiba Msika, also spelled Messika (حبيبة مسيكة), (born 1903 Testour – February 21, 1930 Tunis), was a Tunisian singer, dancer and actress. Born Marguerite Msika, she was the niece of singer Leïla Sfez.

[[Municipalities of East Timor]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of East Timor, Lists of municipalities

East Timor is divided into 12 municipalities (former districts), and one Special Administrative Region (Oecusse). The municipalities are divided into administrative posts (former subdistricts), and further subdivided into sucos.

The borders between Cova Lima and Ainaro and between Baucau and Viqueque were changed in 2003.

[[Camano Island]]

CATEGORIES: Islands of the United States, Unincorporated communities in Washington (state)

Camano Island k is a large island in Possession Sound, a section of Puget Sound. It is part of Island County, Washington, and is located between Whidbey Island and the mainland (Snohomish County).

The island has a total area of 39.77, making it one of the largest in the state of Washington. It has a year-round population of 15,661 as of the 2010 census. It is an unincorporated area with several small communities.

Camano Island is home to two state parks, Cama Beach and Camano Island State Park, and several county and local parks.

[[Island County, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Washington (state) counties, 19th-century establishments in Washington (state), 1852 establishments in the United States

Island County is a county located in the U.S. state of Washington. As of the 2010 census, its population was 78,506. Its county seat is Coupeville, while its largest city is Oak Harbor.

[[Coupeville, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Washington, County seats in Washington

Coupeville is a town on Whidbey Island, in Island County, Washington, United States. It is the county seat of Island County. The population was 1,831 at the 2010 census.

[[Oak Harbor, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Washington (U.S. state)

Oak Harbor is a city located on Whidbey Island in Island County, Washington, United States. The population was 22,075 at the 2010 census.

[[Alojz Uran]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, People from Ljubljana, Bishops

Alojz Uran or Alojzij Uran (22 January 1945 – 11 April 2020) was a Slovenian prelate of the Roman Catholic Church. He was Archbishop of Ljubljana from 4 December 2004 till 28 November 2009. He resigned because of health problems. He was born in Ljubljana.

On 16 December 1992, Uran was appointed Auxiliary Bishop of Ljubljana and Titular Bishop of Abula. 

Uran died on 11 April 2020 in Ljubljana at the age of 75.

[[Kristin Jacobs]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, State legislators of the United States, American mayors, Politicians from San Diego, California, Politicians from Florida, US Democratic Party politicians

Kristin Diane Jacobs (October 17, 1959 – April 11, 2020) was an American Democratic politician. He was a member of the Florida House of Representatives from 2014 until her death in 2020. She represented the 96th District. She was Mayor of Broward County from 2004 to 2005 and again from 2012 to 2013. Jacobs was born in San Diego, California.

Jacobs died on April 11, 2020 in Coconut Creek, Florida of colon cancer at the age of 60.

[[Colby Cave]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage, Boston Bruins players, Edmonton Oilers players, Ice hockey people from Saskatchewan, Ice hockey centres

Colby Cave (December 26, 1994 – April 11, 2020) was a Canadian professional ice hockey centre. He played for the Boston Bruins and Edmonton Oilers of the National Hockey League (NHL). His career lasted from 2015 until his death in 2020. He was born in North Battleford, Saskatchewan, Canada.

Cave had a brain bleed caused by a cyst on April 6–7, 2020. He had emergency surgery on April 7 in Toronto. He died while under a medically induced coma in the early hours of April 11, aged 25.

[[Dunfermline, Illinois]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Illinois

Dunfermline is a village in Illinois in the United States.

[[Jymie Merritt]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from liver cancer, American jazz musicians, American bandleaders, American composers, Musicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Jymie Merritt (May 3, 1926 – April 10, 2020) was an American jazz bassist, bandleader and composer. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. 

In the early 1950s he toured with rock and roll musicians Bullmoose Jackson and Chris Powell moving on to work with bluesman BB King from 1955 to 1957. From 1965 to 1968, Merritt worked with the drummer, composer and activist Max Roach. In 1962, Merritt formed and fronted the Forerunners in Philadelphia.

Merritt died on April 10, 2020 of liver cancer in Philadelphia, aged 93.

[[Grantsville, West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in West Virginia, County seats in West Virginia

Grantsville is a town in and the county seat of Calhoun County, West Virginia, United States. As of 2010, 561 people live in Grantsville.

[[Garfield County, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Washington (state), 1881 establishments in the United States, Washington (state) counties

Garfield County is a county in Washington in the United States. The county seat is Pomeroy. 2,266 people lived there at the 2010 census which makes it the smallest populous county in Washington; with about 3.2, it is also the least densely populated county in Washington.

[[Mateur]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Africa, Settlements in Tunisia

Mateur (ماطر Mater.wav) is a town in northern Tunisia, located 66 kilometers northwest of Tunis. Located in the southwest of the governorate of Bizerte, Mateur is the capital of a delegation with 47,562 inhabitants while the city itself had 34,010 inhabitants in 2014.

[[Rifat Chadirji]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, Writers, Architects, Activists, Photographers, People from Baghdad

Rifat Chadirji (رفعت الجادرجي Rifa’a al-Khādarjī, also Romanized Rifa'at Al Chaderchi; December 6, 1926 – April 10, 2020) was an Iraqi architect, photographer, author and activist. He was born in Baghdad, Iraq. He was often seen as the father of modern Iraqi architecture. He designed more than 100 buildings across the country. His best known work was the The Monument to the Unknown Soldier in Baghdad. 

Chadriji died from COVID-19 in London on April 10, 2020, at the age of 93. 

[[Gribbohm]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Schleswig-Holstein, Steinburg (district)

Gribbohm is a municipality of the district of Steinburg, in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany.

[[Palling]]

Palling is a municipality of the district of Traunstein in Upper Bavaria in Germany.

[[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier (Arlington)]]

CATEGORIES: Arlington National Cemetery

The Tomb of the Unknown Soldier or the Tomb of the Unknowns is a monument dedicated to dead U.S. service members whose remains have not been identified. It is located in Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia, United States.

The World War I "Unknown" is a recipient of the Medal of Honor, the Victoria Cross, and several other foreign nations' highest service awards. The U.S. Unknowns who were buried are also recipients of the Medal of Honor, presented by U.S. Presidents who went to their funerals. 

The monument has no officially designated name.

[[The Monument to the Unknown Soldier]]

CATEGORIES: Monuments and memorials, Buildings and structures in Iraq

The Monument to the Unknown Soldier (نصب الجندي المجهول) is a monument in central Baghdad built by Italian architect, Marcello D'Olivo, based on a concept by Iraqi sculptor, Khaled al-Rahal. It was constructed between 1979 and 1982. 

It was dedicated to the martyrs of the Iran–Iraq War. 

In 1986 the national square of Iraq, Great Celebrations square, was built near the monument, and two other monuments were built close to the square in memory of the matyrs. 

In 1983, the Al-Shaheed Monument on the River, was opened and in 1989 the newly built Victory Arch became the entrances to the square. The monument also has an underground museum.

[[Tunisian Arabic language]]

CATEGORIES: Tunisia, Languages of Africa

Tunisian Arabic, or simply Tunisian, is a set of dialects of Maghrebi Arabic spoken in Tunisia. It is known among its over 11 million speakers Tounsi , "Tunisian" or Derja "everyday language" to distinguish it from Modern Standard Arabic, the official language of Tunisia.

[[Bell, Mayen-Koblenz]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Rhineland-Palatinate

Bell is a municipality of the district of Mayen-Koblenz in Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany. As of 31 December 2018, 1,309 people lived there.

[[Peter Ecklund]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, American jazz musicians, American folk musicians, Musicians from Connecticut

Peter Ecklund (September 27, 1945 – April 8, 2020) was an American jazz cornetist. He was born in Woodbridge, Connecticut. In 1967, Ecklund received a degree from Yale University. He went on tour with singer Paula Lockheart. He started a jazz band and worked with many pop and rock bands in the 1970s and 1980s. He became a substitute for the Nighthawks Orchestra led by Vince Giordano. He was a member of the Orphan Newboys led by Marty Grosz.

Ecklund died on April 8, 2020 from Parkinson's disease-related problems at the age of 74.

[[Woodbridge, Connecticut]]

Woodbridge is a town in New Haven County, Connecticut, United States. The population was 8,990 at the 2010 census.

[[Lars-Eric Lundvall]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish ice hockey players, Swedish Olympians, Olympic silver medalists

Lars-Eric Lundvall (3 April 1934 – 8 April 2020) was a Swedish ice hockey player and coach. Between 1956 and 1965 he played 195 international matches and scored 79 goals. He played for the national team and for Frölunda. He won the world championship in 1962 and a silver medal during the 1964 Winter Olympics.

Lundvall died on 8 April 2020 at the age of 86.

[[Francesco La Rosa]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy, Italian footballers

Francesco La Rosa (franˈtʃesko la ˈrɔːza; 9 December 1926 – 8 April 2020) was an Italian footballer. He played as a forward. He competed in the men's tournament at the 1952 Summer Olympics. He played for the national team in 1952.

Rosa was born in Messina, Italy. died on 8 April 2020 in Milan of COVID-19 at the age of 93.

[[Jim Bolger (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Chicago Cubs players, Cincinnati Reds players, Cleveland Indians players, Philadelphia Phillies players, Sportspeople from Cincinnati, Ohio

James Cyril Bolger (February 23, 1932 - April 9, 2020) was an American professional baseball outfielder. He was born in Cincinnati, Ohio. He appeared in 312 games over all or parts of seven Major League Baseball (MLB) seasons. He played for the Chicago Cubs, Cincinnati Reds, Cleveland Indians and Philadelphia Phillies. 

Bolger died on April 9, 2020 at the age of 88.

[[Lawson (store)]]

CATEGORIES: 1930s establishments in Asia, 1939 establishments, Shops, Companies of Japan, Companies of China, Companies of the Philippines, Companies of South Korea, Companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange

Lawson, Inc is a chain of convenience stores that is in Japan. It can also be found in other Asian countries, like Thailand, China, the Philippines, South Korea and Indonesia. There are only two stores in the United States. Both of these stores are in Hawaii. Lawson is the third biggest chain of convenience stores in Japan. 7-Eleven is the biggest chain and FamilyMart is the second biggest. Lawson has more than 11,000 stores.

[[Local extinction]]

CATEGORIES: Extinction

Local extinction, or extirpation, is when a species or other taxon becomes extinct in a certain area. This is different from being extinct across the world (global extinction) because these species still exist outside of that area. Sometimes when this happens, it can have a very large effect on how the ecosystem works. This might be because that species was important in the food web. The species disappearing might cause more species to go locally extinct or the balance of biomass to change.

There have been many cases when species have been added back, or reintroduced, to that area after going locally extinct. If a species is reintroduced after a long amount of time, this might mean there will be larger effects on the ecology of that area. An example of a species being reintroduced are grey wolves in Yellowstone National Park.

[[Liu Dehai]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Chinese musicians, People from Shanghai

Liu Dehai (刘德海; 13 August 1937 – 11 April 2020) was a Chinese pipa player. He was born in Shanghai. 

Liu studied and began played at the Central Conservatory of Music. He became a professor there in 1957. In 1964 he was transferred to the China Conservatory of Music. He also performed for the Boston Symphony Orchestra. His works include Little Sisters on the Grassland (草原小姐妹, pipa concerto), Music at Sunset Time (夕阳萧鼓, symphonic poem for a pipa player and a symphony orchestra) and other pieces.

Liu died on 11 April 2020 in Beijing at the age of 82.

[[Peeps]]

CATEGORIES: Candy

Peeps are marshmallows sold in the United States and Canada. They are shaped like ducks, bunnies, and other animals. There are also different shapes used for many holidays. 

Peeps are used to fill Easter baskets. In recent years, they have been advertised as "Peeps - Always in Season". They are now used to celebrate Halloween, Christmas and Valentine's Day. 

They are made from sugar, corn syrup, gelatin, various food dyes (never blue dye), and a pinch of salt.

[[Charlotte Le Bon]]

Charlotte Le Bon (born 4 September 1986) is a Canadian actress and artist. She is known for her work in the Canal+ talk show Le Grand Journal, and the movies Yves Saint Laurent, The Hundred-Foot Journey, and The Walk.

[[Caitlin Gerard]]

Caitlin Beverly Gerard (born July 26, 1988) is an American actress. She had a leading role in the first season of the drama series American Crime (2015). She starred as Ashleigh in the 2010 drama The Social Network and as Ashley in 2012 horror movie Smiley.

Gerard was born in Los Angeles, California.

[[Chynna Rogers]]

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, 2020 deaths, Drug-related accidental deaths in the United States, American rap musicians from Pennsylvania, American models, American hip hop musicians, Musicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Chynna Marie Rogers (August 19, 1994 – April 8, 2020), known mononymously as Chynna, was an American rapper, disc jockey, and model. She was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Rogers was signed by Ford Modeling Agency at the age of 14 and worked with the ASAP Mob.

Rogers released the singles "Selfie" (2013) and "Glen Coco" (2014). These were followed by her first EP 'I'm not Here. This isn't happening' (2015), Music 2 die 2 (2016). Her final EP 'In case I die first' was released in 2019.

Rogers was found dead on April 8, 2020, of an accidental drug overdose in Philadelphia, aged 25.

[[Amroha]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Uttar Pradesh

Amroha is a city in the Indian state of Uttar Pradesh. Amroha is located north-west of Moradabad city. As per Census 2011 India, the population of the city is 198,471 out of 103,097 are males and 95,374 are females.

Amroha is known for the production of different types of mangoes. Some of the industries in Amroha includes sugar milling, cotton & textiles, hand-loom weaving and pottery making.

[[List of underwater museums]]

CATEGORIES: Lists of museums

An underwater museum is museum that is made, designated or put underwater, in particular, in a natural body of water.  The category includes naturally or historically occurring settings that have been designated museums.  These museums can be visited by glass-bottomed boats, snorkeling, or scuba diving, depending on the site.  This list includes "preserves," which legally protect submerged ships or other items.

[[RWBY]]

RWBY (pronounced "Ruby") is an American anime web series created by Monty Oum for Rooster Teeth. It follows four girls who live in the supernatural world of Remnant and fight monsters called Grimm. Eight seasons have been uploaded on Rooster Teeth's website. A Japanese dub of RWBY is distributed in Japan by Warner Bros. and airs on Animax.  It is the first American-made anime to air in Japan.

[[Chung Sye-kyun]]

Chung Sye-kyun (정세균) is a South Korean politician. He was the 42nd Prime Minister of South Korea from January 2020 until April 2021. From 2016 to 2018, he was Speaker of the National Assembly of South Korea.

[[National Assembly (South Korea)]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of South Korea

The National Assembly of the Republic of Korea, often shortened to the National Assembly, is the 300-member unicameral national legislature of South Korea. Elections to the National Assembly are held every four years. 

The latest legislative elections were held on 13 April 2016. It is made up of 253 of the assembly's seats, while the remaining 47 are picked by proportional representation. Members serve four-year terms.

CATEGORIES: Speakers of the National Assembly (South Korea)

The Speaker of the National Assembly (국회의장) is the presiding officer of the National Assembly of South Korea.

Moon Hee-sang (Korean: 문희상; Hanja: 文喜相; born 3 March 1945) is a South Korean politician. He is a member of the National Assembly and was the interim leader of New Politics Alliance for Democracy from 2014 to 2015.

On 13 July 2018, he was elected as the new Speaker of the National Assembly.

[[John A. Rocco]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, American mayors, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Politicians from New Jersey, US Republican Party politicians

John A. Rocco (June 25, 1936 – April 8, 2020) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the New Jersey General Assembly from 1980 to 1998. He represented the 6th Legislative District. Rocco also was Mayor of Cherry Hill, New Jersey from 1975 to 1977. Rocco was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Rocco died on April 8, 2020 in Voorhees Township, New Jersey of respiratory failure at the age of 83.

[[Thotsakan Game]]

CATEGORIES: 2003 Thai television series debuts, Television series by Workpoint Entertainment, Thai game shows, 2010 Thai television series endings, 2000s Thai television series, 2010s Thai television series, Channel 9 MCOT HD television programmes

The Thotsakan Game (เกมทศกัณฐ์ in Thai, named for the 10-faced of Ravan, giant in the Ramayana story) is a Thai game show produced by Workpoint Entertainment. It was the 2003 runner-up, and the 2005 winner, of the "best game or quiz show on Asian television" award.

In the original format, a contestant was shown 10 faces.  They have to name them all in order  to win 10 million baht. It was the first game show to have a ten million baht jackpot, the highest at the time.

The show has won a number of awards from many institutions in Thailand and Asia, including runner-up and highly commended of best game or quiz programme in the Asian Television Awards of 2003 and 2005, respectively.

In the one-on-one game, a player tries to score as many points as possible  by telling the name of the given face within one minute. The game continues as far as player gives correct answers, then the other contestant starts. The minimum prize is one million baht when one month later the prize will be add another million until maximum prize of 10 million. Later, the jackpot was fixed at 10 million.

[[Singha]]

Singha (สิงห์; Singha) is a beer brand. It is manufactured in Thailand by the Singha Corporation Co. Ltd.. Singha corp is a subsidiary of its parent company, Boon Rawd Brewery.

[[Muhiuddin Khan]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2016 deaths, Bangladeshi politicians, Bangladeshi Muslims

Maulana Muhiuddin Khan (মাওলানা মুহিউদ্দীন খান; April 19, 1935, Pakundia - June 25, 2016, Kishoreganj), known also as Muhiuddin Khan of the Quran, was a Bangladeshi Muslim politician, scholar and author who wrote numerous books on Islam in Bengali and also noted for the famous Bengali translation of the Quran through the Maariful Quran. He was major in Bengali, Urdu, Persian and Arabic.

He translated for the first time tafseer Maariful Quran into Bengali.

[[Zohurul Hoque]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2017 deaths, People from Assam

Zohurul Hoque (Bengali: জহুুুুুুুুুুুুরুুল হক; Assamese: জহৰুুুুুুুুুুুুুুুুল হক; October 11, 1926 - January 18, 2017), was an Indian Muslim figure from Assam who is the only figure noted for the translation of the Quran in three languages, which is: Bengali, Assamese and English. Along with the translation by Muhiuddin Khan, his Bengali translation of the Quran is one of the most used, but it is not famous in terms of built-up structure of the translation of the certain verses in the Quran, unlike Muhiuddin Khan who did.

[[Trial in absentia]]

CATEGORIES: Law

Trial in absentia (literally in absence in the Latin language) means a person is held responsible for a crime and tried although he or she is not present during the proceedings. It may be because the person is at an unknown location or has escaped justice, for example after paying bail and then refused to return to the court on the date set anyway, or because the person may not be even alive (a famous case is Martin Bormann, who most likely died in May 1945 and was sentenced to death in November 1946, as part of the Nuremberg Trials). It is controversial, especially if a person is convicted and sentenced to a hard punishment, because the basic premise of a trial is thus violated, and everyone has a right to defend oneself. Others point out, however, that this right is waived when one doesn't show up without a good reason and that the court must make its best, through appointing a defender for instance, to determine guilt or innocence even if the person is not present. Most defendants make their case through a defender anyway, especially when the crime is serious. 

Another case is when a court or committee must determine whether a person, such as a suspected terrorist, is going to be surveilled or wire-tapped, and whether there is enough suspicion of criminal activity or intent to do so. In that case, the person himself can of course not be asked to appear, as the idea is to hold the surveillance secret. In that case, a defender is appointed to make the case that the suspected person does not want to and does not deserve to be subjected to surveillance and that it should not be permitted, although he/she doesn't know of the proceedings. Most of such hearings, however, are not a trial in the technical sense of the term, though they may involve a judge and lawyer and so on.

[[Letter bomb]]

CATEGORIES: Terrorism, Explosions, Letters

A letter bomb is a bomb concealed within a letter or package, which is then sent or left for the recipient to find, typically with his or her name and address on, to be opened and then exploded, or exploded within a certain time. 

The first known case of a "modern" letter bomb was the Swedish bombmaker Martin Ekenberg in August 1904. He built a bomb and sent it to a factory owner in Stockholm called Karl Fredrik Lundin. The bomb exploded but nobody was seriously injured. He sent a total of four bombs until 1907 before he was discovered.  

[[Drancy internment camp]]

CATEGORIES: Nazi concentration camps, Buildings and structures in France, The Holocaust

Drancy internment camp was a concentration camp in France during its occupation by Nazi Germany during World War II. It was organised in 1941 to collect French Jews and particularly foreign Jews who had escaped to France before the invasion by the Germans. After that, they were put on railroad carts and sent east, to concentration camps, from which most did not return alive. Nearly 70,000 people were rounded up, including resistance fighters, Roma people, and others considered "undesirable". Until 1943, the camp was administered by French police under German supervision. After this, the French were removed and replaced by German SS men led by Alois Brunner, which increased the efficiency of the deportations. 

When the camp was liberated in 1944, about 1,500 people remained. Brunner was later tried (in absence) and sentenced to death, but remained at large until his death in 2010.

[[History of the Jews in Europe]]

CATEGORIES: Jewish history, History of Europe

Jews have lived in Europe for thousands of years, and their dispersal and relations with governing authorities and peoples have changed greatly. Originally, in the Roman Republic and Roman Empire, there was a Jewish minority which had varying rights and relations with the Romans. After the Roman-Jewish wars in the first and second centuries and the destruction of the Temple, Jews were expelled from Palestine, which greatly increased their numbers in Europe (and North Africa and Asia). In the Middle Ages, with the spread of Christianity and Christian anti-Semitism, conditions were generally bad, and Jews were forbidden from integrating (mingling) with Christians, working most jobs and were often secluded to particular parts of cities, called ghettos. They were allowed to do certain jobs that Christians were not allowed to, such as lending money to people for interest, which was a necessary part of modern economies but considered foul or bad for Christians. This made several Jews wealthy but also increased resistance and persecutions. 

Jews were eventually welcomed in Poland, whose king declared the Statute of Kalisz to protect them. For example, Christians could not testify against Jews for committing crimes, which commonly had led to unjust accusations and punishments. For many Christians, however, this protection increased their resistance. Many Jews, so-called Ashkenazim, gathered in Eastern Europe because of this, however. In Spainand Portugal under Muslim rule, the so-called Al Andalus period, Jews were generally accepted although they could not take part in the government. After Christian rule was re-established on the Iberian peninsula, Jews were rejected and persecuted if they stayed. Some sought refuge in the Ottoman Empire, which was then relatively tolerant to Jews and Christians and allowed them to have their own courts and laws, as long as they payed taxes and did not resist Ottoman rule. 

After the Renaissance and the Early Modern Period, Jews were integrated increasingly and permitted to live openly as Jews in more and more countries. After the French Revolution, France and other European countries affected by French rule through Napoleon I introduced secular laws aimed at abolishing religion in the public sphere and assimilating Jews, i.e. treating them more openly as citizens and members of the public, who could believe whatever they wanted privately and still be members of the community. Other Jews began to discard their religion too, or integrated willingly into the larger community, such as by becoming Christians, like British Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli's father, Isaac d'Israeli. Many European countries had restrictions on Jews until the 19th and 20th centuries, however, such as banning them from certain professions or holding public offices. Many Jews became prominent scientists or public intellectuals, however, such as Karl Marx, Sigmund Freud and Albert Einstein. Only one hundred years before, this would have been impossible. 

With the modern time and the gradual establishment of republics and constitutional monarchies across Europe, conditions were considered much better for Jews. Some preferred to emigrate to the United States and other American countries, however, including Argentina, which to this day has a large Jewish community. Eventually, the United States gathered the largest Jewish population outside of the Russian Empire. After Poland became an independent country again after the Treaty of Versailles, it had the largest Jewish population in Europe, of about 3,000,000 Jews. The Soviet Union, which came about in 1922, had nearly as many. With Adolf Hitler's rise to power in Germany, there was again increased emigration, to the Western European countries and to the United States, supported by the Germans who did not want Jews in German-governed territory. More Jews emigrated to Palestine, which had been taken from the Ottoman Turks by the United Kingdom in 1917, to establish a Jewish homeland for Jews. Hitler temporarily supported this migration, but the British were sceptic, as the greater number of Jews meant conflicts with the local Arabs, who resisted Jewish immigration, and several bloody rebellions were fought between them and the British troops in the region. With World War II, the Nazi-controlled German armies occupied most of Europe and started to deport Jews east, eventually adopting a policy of mass murder known as the Holocaust. After 1942, all Jews under German control (with very few exceptions) would be sent to Eastern Europe and killed or worked to death. In the end, before Nazi Germany's defeat in 1945, this killed about two thirds of the Jewish population in Europe. Only the Jewish communities of Albania, Denmark, Sweden, Switzerland, Spain, Portugal, Britain and Ireland were untouched, and those of Italy, Yugoslavia and Romania much less affected. Many remaining Jews migrated to the United States and Palestine, where Israel was created in 1948 as a Jewish-majority state, which resulted in Europe losing most of its Jewish population and the United States becoming the most Jewish country. Also, later persecution in Communist Poland and other countries led to more refugees. Of the 3,000,000 Jews in Poland, less than 3,000 remain today. In France, the United Kingdom and Russia, however, there are significant communities left comparable to before the war.

[[Shibuya]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Japan, Settlements in Tokyo Prefecture, Wards of Tokyo

Shibuya is a special ward of Tokyo, Japan. It is a very important area for commerce and business. It also has the two busiest railway stations in the world, Shinjuku Station and Shibuya Station. As of 2020, it has an population of about 231,043, and a population density of 15,290.7 people per km2 (39,603/sq mi). The total area is 15.11 km2 (5.83 sq mi).

Shibuya is famous for its scramble crossing, which is called Shibuya Crossing.

[[Hédi Jouini]]

CATEGORIES: 1909 births, 1990 deaths, Tunisian singers, People from Tunis

Hédi Jouini (Arabic:هادي الجويني)( November 1909 – 30 November 1990) was a Tunisian singer, oud player, and composer. In his long career, Jouini composed close to 1,070 songs and 56 operettas.  His songs are inspired by the Andalusian art of flamenco, and found great popularity in Tunisia and the countries of the Mashriq.

[[Leïla Sfez]]

CATEGORIES: Tunisian singers, 1874 births, 1944 deaths, People from Tunis

Leïla Sfez (Arabic: ليلى سفاز), (born 1874 –1944 Tunisia), was a Jewish Tunisian singer and composer She is also the aunt of the famous Habiba Msika to whom she will pass on her musical education. Sh became a celebrated café-concert performer in Tunis in the 1920s. She sang music in both the ma'luf and charqui genres.
