[[Lusaka Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Zambia

Lusaka Province is a province in Zambia. The capital is Lusaka, which is also the national capital. It is the smallest province in Zambia, with an area of 21,896 km². It is also Zambia's most populated and most densely populated province, with a population of 2,191,225 and density of 100 persons per km² as of 2010.

The province is bordered by Zimbabwe and Mozambique, and separated by the Lower Zambezi National Park. Kenneth Kaunda International Airport (in Chongwe District) and Lusaka City Airport (in Lusaka) are the two airports in the province.

[[Northern Province, Zambia]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Zambia

Northern Province is a province in Zambia. The capital is Kasama.

[[North-Western Province, Zambia]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Zambia

North-Western Province is a province in Zambia. The capital is Solwezi. It is the most sparsely populated province in the country.

[[Southern Province, Zambia]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Zambia

Southern Province is a province in Zambia. The capital is Choma. Until 2011, the capital was Livingstone. Victoria Falls is located along that boundary.

[[Muchinga Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Zambia

Muchinga Province is a province in northeastern Zambia. The capital is Chinsali. It borders with Tanzania in the north, Malawi in the east, Eastern Province in the south, Central Province in the southwest, Luapula Province in the west, and Northern Province in the northwest.

[[TD Place Stadium]]

CATEGORIES: Football stadiums in Canada, Rugby, 1976 Summer Olympics, Sport in Ontario, Buildings and structures in Ottawa

TD Place Stadium (originally Lansdowne Park and formerly Frank Clair Stadium) is a stadium in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. It is the home to the Ottawa Redblacks of the Canadian Football League (CFL) and Atlético Ottawa of the Canadian Premier League (CPL). It has a capacity for 24,000 people.

[[Dominique Dunne]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 1982 deaths, American murder victims, Actors from Santa Monica, California, American movie actors, American television actors

Dominique Ellen Dunne (November 23, 1959 – November 3, 1982) was an American actress. She was born in Santa Monica, California. Her parents were Dominick Dunne and Ellen Griffin Dunne. She was best known for her role as Dana Freeling in the 1982 horror movie Poltergeist.

On October 30, 1982, Dunne was strangled by her ex-boyfriend, John Thomas Sweeney, in the driveway of her Los Angeles home. She went into a coma and died five days later, aged 22. Sweeney was convicted of voluntary manslaughter in Dunne's death and went to prison for three and a half years.

[[Bad Hersfeld]]

CATEGORIES: Spa towns in Germany

Bad Hersfeld is the capital of the district Hersfeld-Rotenburg, in the state of Hesse in Germany. It is a well-known festival and spa town. Every summer, the Bad Hersfelder Festspiele (festival) are held here in 1951 at the monastery ruins. It is the largest Romanesque church ruin in Europe.

[[Helmut Krauss]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2019 deaths, German voice actors, Actors from Bavaria, People from Augsburg

Helmut Krauss (11 June 1941 – 26 August 2019) was a German voice actor.

[[Jane Carr]]

CATEGORIES: American voice actors

Jane Carr (born August 13, 1950) is a voice actor.

[[Teefa in Trouble]]

CATEGORIES: Urdu-language movies

Teefa in Trouble is an Urdu language Pakistani movie, directed by Ahsan Rahim.

[[Potsdam Declaration]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 in Germany, Potsdam, World War II

The Potsdam Declaration, or the Proclamation Defining Terms for Japanese Surrender, was a statement that called for the surrender of all Japanese armed forces during World War II. 

On July 26, 1945, United States President Harry S. Truman, United Kingdom Prime Minister Winston Churchill, and Chairman of China Chiang Kai-shek issued the document. It talked about the terms of surrender for the Empire of Japan. These terms were first talked about during the Potsdam Conference. 

The declaration said if Japan did not surrender, it would face "prompt and utter destruction."

[[M. C. Gainey]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from Mississippi, People from Jackson, Mississippi, Living people

Michael Connor Gainey (born January 18, 1948) is an American actor whose distinctive mustache, 6'2" height, and intimidating appearance have landed him supporting roles as Southern or Southwestern thugs and criminals. He is known for playing a major role in the 1997 Con Air action movie.

[[Rob McElhenney]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, American television directors, American Roman Catholics, American television writers, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American television producers, Actors from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Screenwriters from Pennsylvania

Robert McElhenney III (born April 14, 1977) is an American actor, director, producer, and screenwriter. He is known for his role as Mac on the FX/FXX comedy series It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia.

[[List of prime ministers of Togo]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Togo

This is a list of prime ministers of Togo since the creation of the job of Prime Minister in 1960, to the present day.

A total of twelve people have been Prime Minister of Togo.

[[Eugene Koffi Adoboli]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Togo

Eugene Koffi Adoboli (born 3 October 1934) is a Togolese politician. He was Prime Minister of Togo from 21 May 1999 to 31 August 2000. 

In 2011 he was sentenced to five years in jail in absentia for corruption.

[[Chairperson of the African Union Commission]]

CATEGORIES: Chairpersons of the African Union Commission

The Chairperson of the African Union Commission is the head of the African Union Commission. On January 30, 2017, it was announced that Chad's Moussa Faki would become the further Chairperson.

[[Central Africa]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Africa

[[Moussa Faki]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Chairpersons of the African Union Commission, Prime Ministers of Chad, Living people

Moussa Faki Mahamat (موسى فكي محمد ar, born 21 June 1960) is a Chadian politician and diplomat. He has been Chairperson of the African Union Commission since 14 March 2017. He was Prime Minister of Chad from 24 June 2003 to 4 February 2005 and Minister of Foreign Affairs from April 2008 to January 2017.

On 30 January 2017, he was elected as Chairperson of the African Union Commission.

[[Jean Ping]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Gabonese people, Chairpersons of the African Union Commission, Living people, Presidents of the United Nations General Assembly

Jean Ping (ʒɑ̃ piŋ; born 24 November 1942) is a Gabonese diplomat and politician.

He was the Minister of State and Minister of Foreign Affairs, Cooperation and Francophonie of the Gabonese Republic from 1999 to 2008, and was President of the United Nations General Assembly from 2004 to 2005 and Chairperson of the Commission of the African Union from 2008 to 2012. 

Ping was a candidate in the 2016 Gabonese presidential election against the outgoing president Ali Bongo.

[[Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, South African politicians, Political activists, Chairpersons of the African Union Commission

Nkosazana Clarice Dlamini-Zuma (born 27 January 1949), sometimes known by her initials NDZ, is a South African politician and anti-apartheid activist. She has been the Minister of Cooperative Governance and Traditional Affairs since May 2019 during the Cyril Ramaphosa presidency. She also had cabinet jobs during the presidencies of Nelson Mandela, Thabo Mbeki, Kgalema Motlanthe and Jacob Zuma (her ex-husband).

From 1982 to 1998, she was married to Jacob Zuma.

[[Edem Kodjo]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Prime Ministers of Togo

Édouard Kodjovi Kodjo, better known as Edem Kodjo (May 23, 1938 – April 11, 2020), was a Togolese politician and diplomat. He was Secretary-General of the Organisation of African Unity from 1978 to 1983; later. He was Prime Minister from 1994 to 1996 and again from 2005 to 2006. 

Kodjo was President of the Patriotic Pan-African Convergence (CPP).  

Kodjo died on April 11, 2020, in Paris at the age of 81.

[[List of presidents of Togo]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Togo

This is a list of presidents of Togo since the creation of the job of president in 1960, to the present day.

[[Emmanuel Bodjollé]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Presidents of Togo

Emmanuel Bodjollé (born 1928) is a Togolese politician. He was Chairman of the nine-member Insurrection Committee that overthrew the government of Togolese President Sylvanus Olympio on 13 January 1963. For two days in January 1963, he was the interim President of Togo.

[[Christian Poncelet]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, French mayors, Presidents of the Senate (France), MEPs for France, Former MEPs

Christian Poncelet (24 March 1928 – 11 September 2020) was a conservative French politician. He was a member of President Nicolas Sarkozy's Union for a Popular Movement (UMP). He was President of the Senate from 1998 to 2008. He was Mayor of Remiremont (Vosges) and has been the President of the General Council of Vosges. From 1979 to 1980, he was a member of the European Parliament.

Poncelet died on 11 September 2020 in Remiremont, France at the age of 92.

[[Senate (France)]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of France

The Senate (Sénat; pronunciation: seˈna) is the upper house of the French Parliament. It represents territorial collectivities of the Republic and French citizens living abroad. The Senate does not have as much power as the lower house, the directly elected National Assembly. Senators had been elected in thirds every three years; this was also changed to one half of their number every three years.

[[French Parliament]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of France

The French Parliament (Parlement français)  is the bicameral legislature of the French Republic. It is made up of the Senate (Sénat) and the National Assembly (Assemblée nationale). Each assembly has legislative meetings at different places in Paris: the Palais du Luxembourg for the Senate and the Palais Bourbon for the National Assembly.

The National Assembly has more power than the Senate.

[[Silversmith]]

CATEGORIES: Occupations

A silversmith is a person who makes things out of the element silver or creates silverware. Silversmiths are similar to goldsmiths, who make things out of gold or things similar to gold. Silversmithing means making something out of silver. There have been silversmiths since ancient times.

[[Johannes van Knobelsdorff]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch centenarians, Dutch mayors, Dutch nobility, Politicians from The Hague

Johannes van Knobelsdorff (19 September 1917 – 2 April 2020) was a Dutch politician. He was born in The Hague. He was mayor of Goedereede and Stellendam from 1947 to 1961. He was also Mayor of Sassenheim from 1961 to 1974. He was also Dijkgraaf.

Knobelsdorff died on 2 April 2020 at the age of 102.

[[Miguel Ángel Tábet]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy, Venezuelan people, Theologians, Venezuelan educators

Miguel Ángel Tabet Balady (December 24, 1941 – April 7, 2020) was a Venezuelan theologian, Catholic priest, author, and exegete. He was born in Caracas, Venezuela. Tábet lived and worked in Rome, Italy. He was a professor of biblical hermeneutics, the study of the principles of the Bible, at the Pontifical University of the Holy Cross in Rome.

Tabet died from COVID-19 during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic in Rome, Italy, on April 7, 2020, at the age of 78.

[[Paul Gilissen]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Catholic People's Party politicians, Christian Democratic Appeal politicians, Dutch mayors, Dutch Roman Catholics, Politicians from Amsterdam

Paulus Petrus Maria “Paul” Gilissen (28 August 1934 – 9 April 2020) was a Dutch KVP and later CDA politician. Gilissen was born in Amsterdam. He was mayor of Valkenburg-Houthem from 1976 to 1982 and Valkenburg aan de Geul from 1982 to 1990 and again in 1991.

Gilissen died in Maastricht on 9 April 2020, aged 85. 

[[Bert van de Kamp]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch journalists, Writers from Rotterdam

Bert van de Kamp (8 March 1947 – 9 April 2020) was a Dutch music journalist. He was known for his interviews with pop stars in the Dutch Muziekkrant OOR. He was born in Rotterdam. In 1972 van de Kamp won the prize: Wordt Popjournalist en Vlieg naar Londen!.

From 1973 to 1977 he was writer of Muziekkrant OOR. He wrote about many music styles; of hardrock to singer-songwriters. From 1977 to 1980 he was correspondent in London for Muziekkrant OOR and the KRO radio and television magazine Studio. In 1995 he won the first Pop Pers Prijs.

Kamp died in Utrecht on 9 April 2020, aged 73.

[[Iris M. Zavala]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Puerto Rican people, Political writers, Educators, Poets, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain

Iris M. Zavala (27 December 1936 – 10 April 2020) was a Puerto Rican author, scholar, and poet. She had written over 50 works. Her best known work was "Nocturna, mas no funesta", build on and express this belief. 

[[Gus Rodríguez]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Mexican comedians, Mexican television actors, Television producers, Television directors, Mexican voice actors, Mexican journalists

Gustavo Rodríguez (May 27, 1960 – April 11, 2020) was an actor, screenwriter, producer, director, gamer, and video game journalist. He was born in Mexico City. He was a known person in video game journalism in Latin America. 

In December 1991, he founded one of the most important video game magazines in the region, Club Nintendo. The magazine made more than 200 issues, publishing monthly until February 2019.

He dubbed roles in Wreck It Ralph, Shrek 2, Ghostbusters, Pixels and Night at the Museum 2.

In 2019, Rodríguez was diagnosed with lung cancer. He died on April 11, 2020 of the disease in Mexico City, aged 59.

[[Tsvetan Teofanov]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people

Tsvetan Teophanov (Bulgarian: Цветан Теофанов; born July 12, 1952), is a Bulgarian figure who has noted for the very first known and famous Bulgarian translation of the Quran, numerous Bulgarian Islamic religious books, and an Arabist. His rise causes his translation of the Quran the most used in the Balkans that was then known throughout the world.

[[Gregory W. Carman]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, United States representatives from New York, US Republican Party politicians

Gregory Wright Carman (January 31, 1937 – April 5, 2020) was an American judge and politician. He was a United States Judge of the United States Court of International Trade from 1983 to 2014. He was nominated by President Ronald Reagan. He was a Republican member of the United States House of Representatives from New York from 1981 to 1983. 

Carman was born in Farmingdale, New York. He died on April 5, 2020 in Melville, New York, aged 83.

[[Farmingdale, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York

Farmingdale is an incorporated village on Long Island within the Town of Oyster Bay in Nassau County, New York, United States. The population was 8,189 at the 2010 Census.

[[Melville, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York, Census-designated places in New York (state)

Melville is an affluent hamlet and census-designated place (CDP) in the town of Huntington in Suffolk County on Long Island, New York, in the United States. The population was 18,985 at the 2010 census.

[[Carole Baskin]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, American animal rights activists, Businesspeople from Texas

Carole Baskin (née Stairs Jones; born June 6, 1961) is an American animal rights activist. She is the owner of Big Cat Rescue.

Baskin became well known when she was featured in the 2020 Netflix documentary series Tiger King: Murder, Mayhem and Madness about Oklahoma-based private zoo operator Joe Exotic. Following the series' release, Baskin has been targeted by Internet memes related to the disappearance of Don Lewis, her second husband.

[[Disappearance of Don Lewis]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2002 deaths, Missing American people, People declared dead in absentia, Businesspeople from Florida, People from Tampa, Florida

Jack Donald Lewis (April 30, 1938 – legal d. August 19, 2002) is an American missing person who disappeared on August 18, 1997, after leaving his home in Tampa, Florida. The investigation into his disappearance has led from Lewis's Wildlife on Easy Street sanctuary in Tampa, co-owned by his second wife Carole Baskin, to land owned by Lewis in Costa Rica.

No evidence of Lewis being killed has been found, but investigators believe it is unlikely that he disappeared on his own. Lewis left behind over $5 million. He was declared legally dead in 2002.

As of 2020, the case is still open. Lewis's disappearance was covered in 2020 crime documentary series Tiger King: Murder, Mayhem and Madness, which focused on a fight between Baskin and Joe Exotic.

The Hillsborough County Sheriff's Office has used the popularity of Tiger King to help investigate the disappearance. A theory is that his ex-wife Carole fed him to tigers.

[[Muskingum County, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: 1800s establishments in Ohio, 1804 establishments, Ohio counties

Muskingum County is a county located in the U.S. state of Ohio. As of the 2010 census, the population was 86,074. Its county seat is Zanesville. 

[[Eliyahu Bakshi-Doron]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Chief Rabbis of Israel, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Israel, People from Jerusalem

Eliyahu Bakshi-Doron (אליהו בקשי דורון‎; 1941 – April 12, 2020) was an Israeli rabbi. He was Rishon LeZion (Chief Rabbi of Israel) from 1993 to 2003. He was Sephardi Chief Rabbi of Bat Yam from 1972 and Sephardi Chief Rabbi of Haifa from 1972 to 1990. He was born in Jerusalem.

Bakshi-Doron died on April 12, 2020 of COVID-19 in Jerusalem.

[[Glenn Beckert]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Sportspeople from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Chicago Cubs players, San Diego Padres players

Glenn Alfred Beckert (October 12, 1940 – April 12, 2020) was an American professional baseball player. He played in Major League Baseball as a second baseman for the Chicago Cubs for nine seasons from 1965 to 1973. He ended his career with the San Diego Padres in 1975. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. 

Beckert died on April 12, 2020 in Florida at the age of 79.

[[Tim Brooke-Taylor]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom, English comedians, English movie actors, English television actors, English voice actors, English television personalities, English radio personalities, Actors from Derbyshire

Timothy Julian Brooke-Taylor OBE (17 July 1940snd12 April 2020) was an English comedian and actor. He was born in Buxton, Derbyshire, England.

Brooke-Taylor became known for his work on BBC Radio with I'm Sorry, I'll Read That Again. He later moved into television with At Last the 1948 Show. He was best known as a member of The Goodies, starring in the television series throughout the 1970s. He was a panellist on I'm Sorry I Haven't a Clue for almost 50 years.

Brooke-Taylor died of problems from COVID-19 on 12 April 2020, aged 79.

[[Louis van Dijk]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Dutch pianists, Jazz musicians, People from Amsterdam

Louis van Dijk, also spelled Louis van Dyke (27 November 1941 – 12 April 2020), was a Dutch pianist. He was born in Amsterdam. He played with Pim Jacobs and Pieter van Vollenhoven under the name De Gevleugelde Vrienden ("The Winged Friends"). 

In September 2005, he played at a charity concert at the Concertgebouw to raise funds for New Orleans after the city was hit by Hurricane Katrina. He was awarded the honorary title of Knight of the Order of the Netherlands Lion. 

Dijk died in Laren on 12 April 2020 of cancer, aged 78.

[[Alexandria Bay, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in New York

Alexandria Bay is a village in Jefferson County, New York, United States, within the town of Alexandria. It is in the Thousand Islands region of northern New York. The population of the village was 1,078 at the 2010 United States Census.

[[Ted Evans (public servant)]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Economists, Civil servants, Politicians from Queensland

Edward Alfred Evans AUS (4 March 1941 – 12 April 2020) was an Australian senior public servant and economist. He was born in Ipswich, Queensland, Australia. He was a Secretary of the Department of the Treasury from 24 May 1993 through 26 April 2001. 

As secretary of the Treasury, he was ex officio member of the boards of several financial institutions.  He was a director of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia between 1993 and 1996, and a member of the board of the Reserve Bank of Australia from 10 May 1993 to 26 April 2001.

Evans died on 12 April 2020, aged 79.

[[Doug Sanders]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from dementia, American golfers, Sportspeople from Georgia (U.S. state), Sportspeople from Houston, Texas

George Douglas Sanders (July 24, 1933 – April 12, 2020) was an American professional golfer. He won 20 events on the PGA Tour and had four runner-up finishes at major championships. He was born in Cedartown, Georgia. He was a member of the U.S. Ryder Cup team in 1967, which won in Houston.

Sanders died in Houston on April 12, 2020 from dementia-related problems, at the age of 86.

[[Cedartown, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

Cedartown is a city in Polk County, Georgia, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city had a population of 9,750. The city is the county seat of Polk County.

[[Polk County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1850s establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), 1851 establishments in the United States, Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Polk County is a county in the northwestern part of the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 41,475. The county seat is Cedartown. The county was created on December 20, 1851.

[[Wynn Handman]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American educators, Artists from New York City, Writers from New York City

Wynn Handman (May 19, 1922 – April 11, 2020) was an American educator, producer, director and artist. He was the Artistic Director of The American Place Theatre, which he co-founded with Sidney Lanier and Michael Tolan in 1963. He was born in New York City. 

He was a teacher for over 50 years, in his professional acting classes, Handman has trained many actors including: Alec Baldwin, James Caan, Chris Cooper, Michael Douglas, Sandy Duncan, Mia Farrow, Richard Gere, Joel Grey, Allison Janney, Raul Julia, Frank Langella, John Leguizamo, Susan Lucci, Donna Mills, Burt Reynolds, Mira Sorvino, Christopher Walken, Denzel Washington, Lauren Graham and Joanne Woodward.

Handman died on April 11, 2020 in New York City of pneumonia caused by COVID-19 at the age of 97.

[[Everett Lee]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, Living people, African American musicians, American centenarians, American conductors, American pianists, American violinists, Musicians from Cleveland, Ohio, Musicians from West Virginia

Everett Lee (born August 31, 1916) is an American conductor and violinist. He was the first African-American to conduct a Broadway musical. He was also the first African-American to conduct a performance by a major US opera company. In September 1945, he became the main conductor of the musical On the Town. He later conducted at Tanglewood. He served as director of Columbia University's opera department in the early 1950s.

Lee was born in Wheeling, West Virginia. In 1927, he moved with his parents to Cleveland, Ohio. He married Sylvia Olden Lee in 1944. The couple later divorced. He later married his second wife. He lives in Sweden. He turned 100 in 2016.

[[Camillo Ballin]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Bishops, Italian Roman Catholics, Italian writers, Italian educators

Camillo Ballin (June 24, 1944 – April 12, 2020) was an Italian Roman Catholic bishop, writer, missionary, and educator. He was the Roman Catholic Vicar Apostolic of the Apostolic Vicariate of Northern Arabia from 2001 until his death. He was born in Padua, Italy.

Ballin died on April 12, 2020 at the age of 75. 

[[M. V. Rajasekharan]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Indian politicians

Shri M.V. Rajasekharan (12 September 1928 – 13 April 2020) an Indian politician. He was a member of the Indian National Congress party. He  was a member of the Legislative Council Karnataka in the upper house of the Government of Karnataka. He also was a member of the Rajya Sabha.

Rajasekharan died on 13 April 2020 at a hospital in Bangalore at the age of 91.

[[Marion Hartzog Smoak]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2020 deaths, American centenarians, American lawyers, Politicians from South Carolina, US Republican Party politicians

Marion Hartzog Smoak (July 8, 1916 – May 4, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was a Republican. He was Chief of Protocol of the United States under President Richard Nixon from 1972 to 1974. He was a member of the presidential campaign staff and transition team for Ronald Reagan in 1980. He also served as member of the South Carolina Senate from 1967 to 1968.

Smoak was born in Aiken, South Carolina. His wife Mary Frances Meister died in 2015. The couple had three children. He turned 100 in 2016. Smoak died on May 4, 2020, in Palm Beach, Florida. He was 103.

[[George Shapiro]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, American television producers, Businesspeople from New York City

George Shapiro (born May 18, 1931) is an American talent manager and television producer. He is the most successful managers in show business. He is best known for representing Jerry Seinfeld, Carl Reiner and Andy Kaufman. He was a producer for the sitcom Seinfeld. He was born in New York City.

[[Charles Miossec]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, French politicians, People from Brittany

Charles Miossec (25 December 1938 – 12 April 2020) was a French politician. He served as a Deputy from 1978 to 2002. He was born in Lanhouarneau, Finistère.

Miossec died on 12 April 2020 at the age of 81.

[[Cloth facemask]]

CATEGORIES: Health

A cloth facemask is a face covering which is used to cover the mouth and nose. As the name suggests, these masks are made of textiles. Cotton is commonly used. Starting with the 19th century, such masks have been used by healthcare professionals. They are also used to protect against air pollution, although they may not be very effective in protecting against air pollution. 

Depending on the design, they can be effective stopping the transmission of disease spread by droplets of liquid. Today, healthcare professionals often use surgical masks or respirators, which offer better protection. A study done in 2010 found that 40 to 90 percent of particles pass through a cloth facemask.

Cloth face masks are commonly used during the COVID-19 pandemic, especially when surgical and other medical face coverings are not available.

[[George Bass]]

CATEGORIES: 1803 deaths, 1771 births, Pages with unreviewed translations, Australian explorers

George Bass (30 January 1771 – after 5 February 1803) was a British naval surgeon and explorer of Australia.

[[Zdeněk Jičínský]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Czech politicians, Lawyers

Zdeněk Jičínský (26 February 1929 – 9 April 2020) was a Czech lawyer and politician. He served as a member of the Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic from 1996 to 2002 and from 2003 to 2010. He was also a member of the Federal Assembly of Czechoslovakia (1969, 1990–92). He was born in Ostřešany.

Jičínský died on 9 April 2020 at the age of 91.

[[Jan Reijnen]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Catholic People's Party politicians, Christian Democratic Appeal politicians, Dutch mayors, Dutch Roman Catholics, Members of the Senate of the Netherlands, Politicians from North Brabant

Johannes Andreas Maria "Jan" Reijnen (3 February 1927 – 7 April 2020) was a Dutch politician of the Catholic People's Party and its successor the Christian Democratic Appeal. He served as a Senator from 1972 to 1977. He was also mayor of Wervershoof (1964–1969), Oldenzaal (1969–1976) and Heerlen (1976–1986). He was born in Kaatsheuvel, North Brabant.

Reijnen died in Vught, North Brabant on 7 April 2020. He was 93.

[[Respiratory droplet]]

CATEGORIES: Infectious diseases

A respiratory droplet is a droplet of liquid, which is expelled during respiration. They are also produced when sneezing, coughing, or vomiting. They can also be produced artificially. Certain diseases can be transmitted with respiratory droplets.

[[President of the Congress of Deputies]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of the Congress of Deputies (Spain)

The president of the Congress of Deputies (Presidente del Congreso de los Diputados) is the speaker of the Congress of Deputies, the lower house of the Cortes Generales (the Spanish parliament). The president is elected among the members of the Congress and it is, after the king and the prime minister, the highest authority in Spain.

[[Cortes Generales]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Spain

The Cortes Generales (ˈkoɾtes xeneˈɾales; General Courts) are the bicameral legislative chambers of Spain. It is made up of the Congress of Deputies (the lower house), and the Senate (the upper house).

The Congress of Deputies meets in the Palacio de las Cortes. The Senate meets in the Palacio del Senado. Both are in Madrid.

The members of the Cortes Generales serve four-year terms, and they are representatives of the Spanish people.

[[Senate of Spain]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Spain

The Senate (Senado) is the upper house of the Cortes Generales of Spain. It is part of the Cortes Generales along with the Congress of Deputies—the lower chamber. The Senate meets in the Palace of the Senate in Madrid.

The Senate is made-up of senators, each of whom represents a province, an autonomous city or an autonomous community.

[[Meritxell Batet]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, People from Barcelona, Presidents of the Congress of Deputies (Spain)

Meritxell Batet Lamaña (born 19 March 1973) is a Spanish jurist and politician. She is a member of the Socialists' Party of Catalonia. In May 2019, she was elected as President of the Congress of Deputies. Before this, she was Minister for Territorial Policy and Civil Service of the Government of Spain between June 2018 and May 2019.

[[President of the Senate of Spain]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of the Senate of Spain

The President of the Senate of Spain is the speaker of the Spanish Senate, the upper house of Spain's Cortes Generales. It is the fourth leading political figure of the country after the Monarch (Head of State), the Prime Minister (Head of Government) and the President of the Congress of Deputies (Speaker of the Lower House). 

He/She is elected by members of the Senate.

As of the 14th term of the Cortes Generales, the current officeholder is Pilar Llop, a member of the Socialist Parliamentary Group representing Madrid.

[[Pilar Llop]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, Presidents of the Senate of Spain, People from Madrid

María Pilar Llop Cuenca (born 1973) is a Spanish judge and politician. In December 2019, she was elected President of the Senate of Spain. She was member of the Assembly of Madrid from 2015 to 2018 and Government Delegate for Gender Violence of the Government of Spain from 2018 to 2019. 

She entered the judicial career in 1999 and became a magistrate in 2004.

[[Juan José Lucas]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, Presidents of the Senate of Spain, Spanish lawyers

Juan José Lucas Giménez (born 10 May 1944) is a Spanish attorney, professor and politician. He is a member of the People's Party. Lucas was born in Burgo de Osma, Soria, Spain. In 2002, he was elected to the Senate of Spain. Before, he was a member of the Congress of Deputies from 1986 to 1987 and again from 1989 to 1991. From 2002 to 2004, Lucas was the President of the Senate of Spain.

[[Monarchy of Spain]]

CATEGORIES: Politics of Spain, Kings and Queens of Spain

The monarchy of Spain (Monarquía Española), known as The Crown (La Corona), is a constitutional institution and the highest office of Spain.

The Spanish monarchy is currently represented by King Felipe VI, Queen Letizia, and their daughters Leonor, Princess of Asturias, and Infanta Sofía.

[[Ahfazur Rahman]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Pakistani writers, Poets, Journalists, Political writers

Ahfaz-ur-Rahman (احفاظُ الرّحمٰن ) (4 April 1942 – 12 April 2020), was a Pakistani journalist, writer and poet. His works were supportive for freedom of the press and for the rights of working journalists in Pakistan. Rahman wrote many books and translations about the corruption in Pakistan and why freedom of the press should be a law there. 

Rahman died on 11 April 2020 in Karachi, aged 78.

[[Juan Cotino]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish politicians, Spanish businesspeople

Juan Gabriel Cotino Ferrer (26 January 1950 – 13 April 2020), known as Juan Cotino, was a Spanish businessman and politician. He was a member of the People's Party. He was born in Xirivella, Valencia. Cotino was a member of the Congress of Deputies from 2007 to 2014. From 2011 to 2014, he was President of Corts Valencianes. From 1996 to 2002, Cotino was Directorate-General of the Police.

Cotino died of COVID-19 on 13 April 2020 in Spain, aged 70.

[[Ashok Desai]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Indian lawyers, Indian politicians

Ashok H. Desai (1943 – 13 April 2020) was an Indian politician and lawyer. He was the Attorney General  of India from 9 July 1996 to 6 May 1998. He also was the Solicitor General of India from 18 December 1989 to 2 December 1990 . He was awarded the Padma Bhushan.  

Desai died on 13 April 2020 at the age of 77.

[[Landelino Lavilla Alsina]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish lawyers, Presidents of the Congress of Deputies (Spain)

Landelino Lavilla Alsina (6 August 1934 – 13 April 2020) was a Spanish lawyer and politician. He was born in Lerida, Spain. Lavilla Alsina was a member of the Union of the Democratic Centre.

Lavilla Alsina was the Minister of Justice from 1976 to 1979. He was a Senator from 1977 to 1979. He was also a member of the Congress of Deputies from 1979 to 1983 and President of the Congress of Deputies from 1979 to 1982.

Lavilla Alsina died in Madrid of a long-illness on 13 April 2020, aged 85.

[[El Oro Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador

El Oro  is a province in Ecuador. The capital is Machala.

It was named for its historically important gold production. Today it is one of the world's major exporters of bananas.

[[Edmund Wickham Lawrence]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Governors-General of Saint Kitts and Nevis, Living people, Business people, Economists

Sir Edmund Wickham Lawrence GBR (born 14 February 1932) is an economist, businessman and politician. He was the Governor-General of St. Kitts and Nevis from 2013 to 2015. In the 1999 New Year Honours, Lawrence was honored as an Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire (OBE).

[[Governor-General of Saint Kitts and Nevis]]

CATEGORIES: Governors-General of Saint Kitts and Nevis

The Governor-General of Saint Kitts and Nevis is the representative of the monarch of Saint Kitts and Nevis, currently Queen Elizabeth II. 

The appointed governor-general, currently Sir Tapley Seaton, lives in Government House.

[[Clement Arrindell]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2011 deaths, Governors-General of Saint Kitts and Nevis

Sir Clement Athelston Arrindell GBR (19 April 1931 – 27 March 2011) was the first Governor-General of Saint Kitts and Nevis from 1983 to 1995. He also was the country's final colonial governor, from 1981 to 1983.

[[Tapley Seaton]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Governors-General of Saint Kitts and Nevis, Living people

Sir Samuel Weymouth Tapley Seaton, 100% (born 28 July 1950) is the fourth and current Governor-General of Saint Kitts and Nevis. At first, he was Acting Governor-General after Sir Edmund Wickham Lawrence was forced out of office on 20 May 2015. 

On 1 September 2015, he was officially appointed Governor-General by Queen Elizabeth II on advice of Prime Minister Timothy Harris.

[[List of prime ministers of Saint Kitts and Nevis]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Saint Kitts and Nevis

This page is a '''list of prime ministers of Saint Kitts and Nevis.

[[Kennedy Simmonds]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1936 births, Prime Ministers of Saint Kitts and Nevis

Sir Kennedy Alphonse Simmonds, KCMG (born 12 April 1936), is a Saint Kitts and Nevis politician. Simmonds was a founding member of  the People's Action Movement (PAM) party. He was the Premier of Saint Kitts and Nevis from 21 February 1980, until the twin-island state gained independence from the United Kingdom on 19 September 1983. He later became the 1st Prime Minister of Saint Kitts and Nevis. He was Prime Minister from 1983 to 1995.

[[Denzil Douglas]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Saint Kitts and Nevis

Denzil Llewellyn Douglas (born 14 January 1953) is a Saint Kitts and Nevis politician. He is the longest serving Prime Minister. He was in office from 1995 to 2015. He is the leader of the Saint Kitts and Nevis Labour Party (SKNLP).

[[Timothy Harris]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Saint Kitts and Nevis, Current national leaders

Timothy Sylvester Harris (born 14 January 1964) is the 3rd and current Prime Minister of Saint Kitts and Nevis since 2015. 

Harris was Minister of Foreign Affairs from 10 August 2001 to 25 January 2008, Minister for Finance from 2008 to 2010, and Senior Minister for Agriculture from 2010 to 2013.

[[California State Route 15]]

CATEGORIES: Interstate Highways, Roads in California, San Bernardino County, California, San Diego County, California, Riverside County, California

California State Route 15 is a connector from Interstate 8 to Interstate 5 in San Diego, California. It is a short, 7 mile connector.

[[Dinos]]

CATEGORIES: Ancient Greek pot shapes

In the typology of ancient Greek pottery, the dinos (plural dinoi) is a mixing bowl or cauldron. Dinos means "drinking cup," but in modern typology is used (wrongly) for the same shape as a lebes, that is, a bowl with a spherical body meant to sit on a stand. It has no handles and no feet.

The Dinos Painter, one of the ancient Greek artists known for vase painting, takes his name from the type of vase characteristic of his work.

Dinos were used for mixing water and wine, as it was considered rude to drink straight out of the goblet, at the time.

[[Ryo Kawasaki]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Japanese composers, Businesspeople from Tokyo, Bandleaders, Japanese guitarists, Japanese inventors, Jazz musicians, Musicians from Tokyo

Ryo Kawasaki was a Japanese jazz fusion guitarist, composer, software programmer and bandleader. He was born in Tokyo.

Kawasaki was best known as one of the first musicians to create the fusion genre and for helping to develop the guitar synthesizer. His album Ryo Kawasaki and the Golden Dragon Live was one of the first all digital recordings and he created the Kawasaki Synthesizer for the Commodore 64.

During the 1960s, he played with many Japanese jazz groups and also formed his own bands. In the early 1970s, he moved to New York City, where he worked with Gil Evans, Elvin Jones, Chico Hamilton, Ted Curson and Joanne Brackeen.

He also produced several techno dance singles, formed his own record company called Satellites Records, and later returned to jazz-fusion in 1991. His later career was set in Estonia.

Kawasaki died in Tallinn on April 13, 2020 at the age of 73.

[[Tarvaris Jackson]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, 2020 deaths, Road accident deaths in the United States, Minnesota Vikings players, Seattle Seahawks players, Buffalo Bills players, Sportspeople from Alabama, People from Montgomery, Alabama

Tarvaris Jackson (April 21, 1983 – April 12, 2020) was an American football quarterback. He was born in Montgomery, Alabama. Jackson played college football at Arkansas and Alabama State. In the National Football League (NFL), Jackson played for the Minnesota Vikings, Seattle Seahawks, and Buffalo Bills.

Jackson was killed on April 12, 2020 in a car accident in Pike Road, Alabama, aged 36.

[[Duchess Marie-Thérèse of Württemberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Princes and princesses, French royalty

Duchess Marie Thérèse of Württemberg (Marie Therese Nadejda Albertine Rosa Philippine Margarethe Christine Helene Josepha Martina Leopoldine Herzogin von Württemberg; born 12 November 1934) known as Duchess of Montpensier, is a German-born aristocrat. She is a daughter of the claimant to the royal throne of Württemberg. She was the first wife of Prince Henri, Count of Clermont. They were married from 1957 to 1984.

Duchess Marie Thérèse is the mother of Prince Jean, Duke of Vendôme, head of the House of Orléans and Orléanist claimant to the French throne.

[[Battle of Nalapani]]

CATEGORIES: 19th century in Asia, 19th century in the United Kingdom, 1814, Battles involving the United Kingdom, History of Nepal, Uttarakhand, October events, November events

The Battle of Nalapani was the first battle of the Anglo-Nepalese War of 1814–1816. The forces of the British East India Company fought against Nepal, then ruled by the House of Gorkha. The battle took place around the Nalapani fort, near Dehradun.  The British besieged the fort between 31 October and 30 November 1814. The fort's garrison was commanded by Captain Balbhadra Kunwar. Major-General Rollo Gillespie, who had previously fought in the Battle of Java, was in charge of the attacking British troops. Gillespie was killed on the first day of the siege while rallying his men and despite considerable odds, both in terms of numbers and firepower, Balbhadra and his 600-strong garrison successfully held out against more than 5,000 British troops for over a month.

First two costly attempts to seize the fort by direct attack were unsuccessful. The British then tried to force the garrison to surrender by cutting off the fort's water supply. After three days of thirst, on the last day of the siege, Balbhadra refused to surrender. He led the 70 surviving members of the garrison in a charge against the besieging force. Fighting their way out of the fort, the survivors escaped into the nearby hills. Considering the time, effort, and resources spent to capture the small fort, it was a pyrrhic victory for the British. A number of later engagements, including one at Jaithak, unfolded in a similar way; but more than any other battle of the war, the fighting around Nalapani established the Gurkhas' reputation as warriors. As a result, they were later recruited by the British to serve in their army.

[[Reaction speed]]

CATEGORIES: Physiology

The time it takes for a human to react to a change or circumstance. Reaction time of a human is typically around 100 milliseconds but can be faster for people who train to have quicker reactions.

[[Sidi Brahim Riahi]]

CATEGORIES: 1766 births, 1850 deaths, People from Tunis

Ibrahim Riahi, his birth name  Abou Ishak Ibrahim Ben Abdelkader Riahi  (1766  Testour – August 7, 1850), was a Tunisian ambassador, theologian and  saint. A Sunni Muslim scholar, he is also a poet. He is the grandfather of Ali Riahi.

Sidi Brahim is buried with some of his sons, sheikhs and theologians like him, in his mausoleum (zaouia) in the  Sidi Brahim Riahi street in the medina of Tunis named Sidi Brahim Riahi Mausoleum.

Newton County is a county in the U.S. state of Indiana. As of 2010, 14,244 people lived there. The county seat is Kentland.

[[Surgical mask]]

CATEGORIES: Health

A surgical mask, also known as a procedure mask, medical mask or simply as a face mask, is a  mask. It is intended to be worn by health professionals during surgery and during nursing. Such masks are used to catch the bacteria shed in liquid droplets and aerosols from the wearer's mouth and nose. They are not designed to protect the wearer from inhaling airborne bacteria or virus particles and are less effective than respirators, which provide better protection.

There are different qualities of such mask. Despite their name, not all surgical masks should be used during surgeries. Chinese health officials distinguish between medical (non-surgical) and surgical masks.

Surgical masks are made of a nonwoven fabric created using a melt blowing process.  They came into use in the 1960s and largely replaced cloth facemasks in developed countries.  A shortage of surgical masks is a central issue of the ongoing 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic.

Surgical masks are popularly worn by the general public all year round in East Asian countries like China, Japan and South Korea to reduce the chance of spreading airborne diseases to others, and to prevent the breathing in of airborne dust particles created by air pollution. Additionally, surgical masks have become a fashion statement, particularly in contemporary East Asian culture bolstered by its popularity in Japanese and Korean pop culture which have a big impact on East Asian youth culture.

[[Toosie Slide]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 songs, Drake songs

"Toosie Slide" is a song by Canadian rapper Drake.  It was released on April 3, 2020.  It is featured on his mixtape, Dark Lane Demo Tapes (2020). The song was featured in a viral dance challenge of the same name on the social media app TikTok. The viral dance was performed while the song was still unreleased. Drake wrote the song with Nick Kobe and its producer, OZ.

The song entered at number one on the Billboard Hot 100 in the US, giving Drake his seventh US chart-topper and third number-one debut there, after “God’s Plan” and “Nice for What”. This ties the record with Mariah Carey for most songs which entered at number one. He also earned his 37th top-ten hit, giving him the most for a male artist.

[[Loja Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador

Loja Province is a province in Ecuador. The capital city is also named Loja.

Podocarpus National Park is in the province. This park is 1,463 square kilometres. It has an elevation ranging from 1000 m to 3690 m. The park is home to a number of animals like bears and pumas as well as exotic birdlife. Over 40% of the park's 3,000–4,000 plant species are endemic, unique to this area. There are also more than 600 species of birds here.

[[Manabí Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador, 1820s establishments in South America, 1824 establishments

Manabí is a province in Ecuador. The capital city is Portoviejo.

[[Morona-Santiago Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador, 1950s establishments in South America, 1954 establishments

Morona Santiago (moˈɾona sanˈtjaɣo) is a province in Ecuador. The province was created on February 24, 1954. The capital is Macas.

Sangay National Park is in the province.

[[Napo Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador

Napo (ˈnapo) is a province in Ecuador. Its capital is Tena. The province has the Napo River.

In 2000, the province was the only remaining majority-indigenous province of Ecuador, with 56.3% of the province either being of indigenous identity or speaking an indigenous language.

[[Pastaza Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador

Pastaza (pasˈtasa) is a province in the Oriente of Ecuador located in the eastern jungle. The capital is Puyo, founded on May 12, 1899.

[[Santa Elena Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador

The Province of Santa Elena (ˌsanta eˈlena) is a province of Ecuador in the coastal region. It was created in 2007 from territory that belonged to the Guayas Province. It is one of the two newest provinces of Ecuador, along with Santo Domingo de Los Tsáchilas. Its capital city is Santa Elena.

[[Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador

Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas is a province in the Republic of Ecuador. It was created in October 2007 from territory previously in the province of Pichincha.

[[Sucumbíos Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador

Sucumbíos (sukumˈbi.os) is a province in northeast Ecuador. The capital and largest city is Nueva Loja (normally referred to as Lago Agrio).

[[Zamora-Chinchipe Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Ecuador

Zamora Chinchipe (saˈmoɾa tʃinˈtʃipe), Province of Zamora Chinchipe is a province of the Republic

of Ecuador, located at the southeastern end of the Amazon Basin. The provincial capital is the city of Zamora.

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Actors from Seattle, Washington, American stage actors, American video game actors, American radio actors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

Rick May (September 21, 1940 – April 8, 2020) was a voice actor from Seattle. He voiced the Soldier in Team Fortress 2 and Peppy Hare in Star Fox 64. He also voiced many other characters from other video games. May was infected with COVID-19 in March 2020 and later died on April 8. RIP LEGEND 

[[Vicente Magsaysay]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Filipino politicians

Vicente Magsaysay (January 20, 1940 – April 13, 2020) was a Filipino politician. He was the chairman of the board of the Philippine Postal Savings Bank from January 22, 2009 until his death. He was governor of the province of Zambales from 1968 to 1986 and then again from 1998 to 2007. He was a member of the Liberal Party. Magsaysay was born in Castillejos, Philippines.

Magsaysay died on April 13, 2020, aged 80.

[[Moraes Moreira]]

Antônio Carlos Moreira Pires (July 8, 1947 – April 13, 2020), better known as Moraes Moreira, was a Brazilian musician and songwriter. During the 1970s he played guitar and sang in the band Os Novos Baianos. After playing in Os Novos Baianos, Moreira had a solo career where he recorded 29 albums. Moreira was born in Ituaçu, Bahia, Brazil.

Moreira died of a heart attack on April 13, 2020 in Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil at the age of 72.

[[Ann Sullivan (animator)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American animators, People from Fargo, North Dakota, Disney people

Ann Sullivan (April 10, 1929 – April 13, 2020) was an American animator. She worked for Disney Animation. She was born in Fargo, North Dakota. In 1973, she joined Hanna-Barbera. Her best known works were Oliver & Company (1988), The Little Mermaid (1989), The Prince and the Pauper (1990), The Lion King (1994), Pocahontas (1995), Hercules (1997), Tarzan and Fantasia 2000 (both 1999). 

Sullivan died in Los Angeles on April 13, 2020 of COVID-19, aged 91.

[[Bernard Stalter]]

Bernard Stalter (12 March 1957 – 12 April 2020) was a French businessman and politician. He was born in Brumath, France. Stalter was a member of the Regional Council of Grand Est from 2016 until his death. He was also a member of the French Economic, Social and Environmental Council from 2015 until his death.

Stalter died on 12 April 2020 in Strasbourg, France of COVID-19, aged 63.

[[U Pannya Jota Mahathera]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Judges, Bangladeshi politicians, Monks, Buddhists

Ven. U Pannya Jota Mahathera (Burmese: ဦးပညာဇောတမဟာထေရ်, উ পঞ্ঞা জোত মহাথের; 22 December 1955 – 13 April 2020), locally known as Guru Bhante was a Theravada monk in Bangladesh. He was born in Royal Bohmong family at Bandarban, Bangladesh. He worked for the Bangladesh Government as Judge and Magistrate for about eight years. He later became a Theravada Buddhist monk. He was the founder of Buddha Dhatu Jadi. 

He died on 13 April 2020 of cardiac arrest, aged 64.

[[Irena Chalmers]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from esophageal cancer, Cancer deaths in New York, Naturalized citizens of the United States, British educators, American educators, American essayists, American columnists, American chefs, British chefs, Writers from London, Writers from New York City

Irena Chalmers-Taylor (June 5, 1935 – April 4, 2020) was a British-born American cookbook author, food essayist and educator. She was born in London, England. She was nicknamed "the culinary oracle of 100 cookbooks". She was known as an important person in cookbook writing. Her best known essays were published in The Last Word and Chef Magazine. as well as a commentator on WAMC/Northeast Public Radio, Chalmers also worked for the The Culinary Institute of America.

Chalmers died of esophageal cancer on April 4, 2020 in Kingston, New York at the age of 84.

[[Giza Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt

Giza Governorate is one of the governorates of Egypt. Its capital is the city of Giza.  

It is on the west bank of the Nile River opposite Cairo. It includes a stretch of the left bank of the Nile Valley around Giza. The Governorate got a large stretch of Egypt's Western Desert, including Bahariya Oasis when the 6th of October Governorate was merged into it on 14 April 2011.   

The Great Pyramid of Giza is one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and people come from all over the world each year to see it. It is in the Giza pyramid complex. The Giza Governorate is also home to the Great Sphinx.

[[Ismailia Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt

Ismailia Governorate is a governorate in Egypt. The capital city is also named Ismailia. It was named after Ismail Pasha, who as Ottoman Viceroy of Egypt, oversaw the country during the building of the Suez Canal.

[[Kafr El Sheikh Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt, 20th-century establishments in Egypt, 1949 establishments

Kafr El Sheikh Governorate is a governorate of Egypt. The capital city is also named Kafr El Sheikh. 

Kafr El Sheikh Governorate was once part of the Gharbia Governorate. It was created in 1949.

[[Luxor Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt, Establishments in Egypt, 2009 establishments

Luxor Governorate is a governorate in Egypt. The capital city is also named Luxor. It was created in 2009 from part of the Qena Governorate.

[[The Romantic Englishwoman]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 drama movies, British drama movies, French drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Joseph Losey

The Romantic Englishwoman is a 1975 British drama movie directed by Joseph Losey and adapted from the novel by Thomas Wiseman. It stars Michael Caine, Glenda Jackson, Helmut Berger, Michael Lonsdale, Kate Nelligan and Tom Chatto.

[[Matrouh Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt

Matrouh Governorate is a governorate of Egypt. The capital city is Mersa Matruh. 

The interior of the Matrouh Governorate is part of Egypt's Western Desert, including the Siwa Oasis. In the center of the Governorate is the Qattara Depression, descending to 133 metres below sea level.

Matrouh Governorate has many historical sites related to World War II.

Minya Governorate is a governorate of Egypt. The capital city is also named Minya.

[[Hammam Sousse]]

Hammam Sousse (حمّام سوسة) is a coastal town in eastern Tunisia. It is north of Sousse. It has about 42,691 inhabitants (2014 est.). Former President Zine el Abidine Ben Ali.

[[Silent letter]]

CATEGORIES: Linguistics

Silent letters are letters written in words that do not any sound in the word. In English, these include the k in know and knee, the second b in bomb and numb, the s in island, and the e in lame and lime.

Silent letters exist in the spelling systems in many languages, but they are very common in languages with deep orthographies, spelling systems with little one-to-one relationship between letters and sounds, like English, French, Thai, and Mongolian.  

[[Jacques De Decker]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian writers

Jacques De Decker (19 August 1945 – 12 April 2020) was a Belgian writer and author.

In 1985, De Decker published his first novel, La Grande Roue. It was selected for the Prix Goncourt and translated into several languages. He was President of the Organisation Beaumarchais in Paris, and then elected to replace Albert Ayguesparse as President of the Académie royale de langue et de littérature françaises de Belgique in Brussels in 1997. 

In 1998, he helped relaunch the magazine Marginales. In this endeavor, he joined Jean Jauniaux, who also wrote La Faculté des Lettres.

De Decker died on 12 April 2020 in Brussels at the age of 74.

[[Charles Alexander Shaw]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2020 deaths, American judges, American lawyers, Politicians from Tennessee, Politicians from St. Louis, Missouri, US Democratic Party politicians

Charles Alexander Shaw (December 31, 1944 – April 12, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was a Senior United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri. He was nominated to the court by Bill Clinton. Shaw was born in Jackson, Tennessee.

Shaw died on April 12, 2020 in St. Louis, Missouri at the age of 75.

[[2020 Easter tornado outbreak]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in the United States, April 2020 events

A series of tornadoes affected the Southeastern United States on Easter Sunday and Monday, April 12–13, 2020. 15 total watches were produced during the course of the event, two of which were designated Particularly Dangerous Situations. 

With at least 30 deaths reported, it was the deadliest tornado outbreak in the U.S. since the April 2014 tornado outbreak.

[[McQ]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 drama movies, 1970s action movies, 1970s crime drama movies, American action movies, American crime movies, Movies directed by John Sturges

McQ is a 1974 American action crime drama movie directed by John Sturges and produced by Arthur Gardner. It stars John Wayne, Eddie Albert, Diana Muldaur, Colleen Dewhurst, Clu Gulager, David Huddleston, and Al Lettieri. It was distributed by Warner Bros.

Ogooué-Maritime is a province in Gabon. The provincial capital is Port-Gentil.

[[Haut-Ogooué]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Gabon

Haut-Ogooué is a province in Gabon. It is named after the Ogooué River. It has an area of 36,547 km². The provincial capital is Franceville. As of 2013, 250,799 people lived there.

The province is one of the main industries is mining, with manganese, gold and uranium being found in the region.  The uranium-bearing mineral Francevillite takes its name from the main city.

Estuaire is the most populous province in Gabon. The provincial capital is Libreville, which is also Gabon's national capital.

[[Jon Bernthal]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, Actors from Washington, D.C., American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Jewish American actors

Jonathan Edward Bernthal (born September 20, 1976) is an American actor. He is best known for playing Shane Walsh in the AMC horror series The Walking Dead (2010–2012; 2018) and Frank Castle / The Punisher in the Netflix action series Daredevil (2015–2018) and The Punisher (2017–2019).

Bernthal's movie credits include The Wolf of Wall Street (2013), Fury (2014), Sicario (2015), The Accountant (2016), Baby Driver (2017), Wind River (2017), Widows (2018) and Ford v Ferrari (2019).

Bernthal was born in Washington, D.C., to Jewish parents. His grandfather was musician and producer Murray Bernthal. Other notable relatives include his brother, Tom Bernthal, and cousin, Adam Schlesinger. He married Erin Angle in 2010. The couple have three children.

[[Chalmette, Louisiana]]

[[Hank Steinbrenner]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2020 deaths, New York Yankees, Businesspeople from Indiana, Businesspeople from New York City, Deaths from liver disease, Disease-related deaths in Florida

Henry George Steinbrenner III (April 2, 1957 – April 14, 2020) was an American businessman. He was the part-owner and co-chairman of the New York Yankees of Major League Baseball.  He was the older brother of the team's principal owner and managing general partner Hal Steinbrenner. His parents were George Steinbrenner and Joan Steinbrenner. He was born in Culver, Indiana.

Steinbrenner died on April 14, 2020 in Clearwater, Florida of liver disease-related problems, aged 63.

[[Monufia Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt

Monufia Governorate is one of the governorates of Egypt. The capital city is Shibin El Kom.

The governorate is named after Menouf, an ancient city which was the capital of the governorate until 1826. Other main cities are Quesna, Tala, Bagour, and Ashmoun.

Monufia Governorate is the birthplace of two Egyptian presidents: Anwar Sadat (1918–1981), born in Mit Abu El Kom and Hosni Mubarak (1928-2020), born in Kafr El Meselha.

[[New Valley Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt

New Valley Governorate is a governorate in Egypt. The capital is at the Kharga Oasis. Another name used for the governorate is El Wadi El Gedid Governorate.

New Valley is the largest governorate in Egypt. At 440,098 square kilometers in area, it is just slightly larger than the country of Iraq.

[[Orthographic depth]]

CATEGORIES: Language, Writing systems

Orthographic depth how much one-to-one relationship there is between the sounds of a language and the letters used to write them, or how much a word is spelled the way it sounds. Writing systems with a close one-to-one relationship between sounds and letters are called orthographically shallow writing systems. This includes the Spanish alphabet, Japanese kana, the Finnish alphabet, the Turkish alphabet, and the Italian alphabet. In these languages, it is easy to figure out how to speak these languages simply by reading them. Writing systems with little one-to-one relationship between sounds and letters are called orthographically deep writing systems. These would include the English alphabet, French alphabet, Mongolian script, and Thai script.

[[North Sinai Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt

North Sinai Governorate is one of the governorates of Egypt. The capital city is Arish. The governorate is on the northern half of the Sinai Peninsula.

[[Bethsaida]]

CATEGORIES: Archaeological sites in Israel, Geography of Israel

Bethsaida is a town in ancient Israel, near the sea of Galilee.  According to the first chapter of the Gospel of John the apostles Peter, Andrew, and Philip came from there. The Gospel of Mark Chapter 8 says that Jesus healed a blind man there. In the ninth chapter of the Gospel of Luke we are told that Jesus fed 5000 people using only 5 loaves of bread and 2 fish.

Modern archeologists have not been able to prove for sure exactly where Bethsaida was.

[[Reformist socialism]]

CATEGORIES: Socialism, Politics

Within the socialist movement, reformism is the view that gradual changes through existing institutions can eventually lead to fundamental changes in a society's political and economic systems.

[[When You Believe]]

CATEGORIES: Mariah Carey songs, Whitney Houston songs, Best Original Song Academy Award-winning songs, 1998 songs, The Prince of Egypt

“When you Believe” is an Academy Award winning song from the 1998 DreamWorks Animation movie The Prince of Egypt.  Within the movie the song is sung by Miriam and Zippora after the Israelites are freed from slavery.  It was sung by Whitney Houston and Mariah Carey who were the musical voice doubles of Sandra Bullock and Michelle Pfeiffer, who played Miriam and Zippora.

[[El Mdou]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Tunisia

El Mdou is a village in the south of Tunisia located eight kilometers west of Gabès and dependent on the governorate of Gabès.

A regional road crosses it and connects it to Gabès and Matmata, in particular through a bus line. One road goes towards El Hamma and another towards Limaya. The village is home to a school, a mosque and a Antenna  to cover the Gabès region.

[[Flushed Away]]

CATEGORIES: 2006 movies, 2006 computer-animated movies, American action comedy movies, American buddy movies, American movies, British animated movies, British buddy movies, British movies, 2006 comedy movies, Movies set in England, Movies set in London

Flushed Away is a 2006 computer-animated adventure comedy movie directed by David Bowers and Sam Fell, produced by Cecil Kramer, David Sproxton, and Peter Lord, and written by Dick Clement, Ian La Frenais, Chris Lloyd, Joe Keenan and Will Davies. It was the third and final DreamWorks Animation movie co-produced with Aardman Animations following Chicken Run (2000) and Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005), and was the first Aardman project completely made in computer animation as opposed to their usual stop motion standard. The movie stars the voices of Hugh Jackman, Kate Winslet, Andy Serkis, Bill Nighy, Ian McKellen, Shane Richie and Michael Richards. In Flushed Away, a pet rat named Roddy St. James is flushed down the toilet by a sewer mouse, and befriends a scavenger named Rita in order to return home while evading a power-hungry toad and his rat henchmen.

The movie was released in the United States by Paramount Pictures on 3 November 2006, and in the United Kingdom on 1 December 2006. Despite receiving positive reviews, Flushed Away underperformed at the box office, prompting DreamWorks to end their partnership with Aardman. The film received nominations for the BAFTA Award and Critics' Choice Award for Best Animated Feature. It also got 8 nominations at the 34th Annie Awards, winning a leading 5, including Writing in a Feature Production, and Voice Acting in a Feature Production.

[[Diana Sands]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 1973 deaths, Deaths from leiomyosarcoma, Cancer deaths in New York City, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Diana Patricia Sands (August 22, 1934spaced ndashSeptember 21, 1973) was an American actress. She was best known for her role of Beneatha Younger, the sister of Sidney Poitier's character in the original stage and movie versions of Lorraine Hansberry's A Raisin in the Sun (1961). Sands was born in New York City.

Sanders died on September 21, 1973 of leiomyosarcoma in New York City, aged 39.

[[Multiculturalism in Canada]]

CATEGORIES: Canada

Multiculturalism in Canada is a very important part of the culture of Canada. Beginning in the 1970s and 1980s, the Canadian government officially began pushing for multiculturalism in policy. Because of this, the federal government has sometimes been called the "instigator" (or starters) of multiculturalism being an ideology. They often try to bring attention to the importance of immigration to Canada.

[[Pachyderm]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals

Pachyderm (meaning 'thick skin', from the Greek pachys, and derma) is an old term for

elephants, rhinoceroses and hippopotamuses.

Genetics has now shown that rhinos, hippos, and elephants are not closely related to each other. Rhinos are closely related to tapirs, but both rhinos and tapirs are much more closely related to horses than to hippos or elephants. 

[[Jim Frey]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Chicago Cubs managers, Kansas City Royals, Sportspeople from Cleveland, Ohio

James Gottfried Frey (May 26, 1931 – April 12, 2020) was an American manager and coach in Major League Baseball. He led the Kansas City Royals to their first American League championship in 1980. In the World Series, they lost to the Philadelphia Phillies. He also managed the Chicago Cubs.

Frey was born in Cleveland, Ohio. He died on April 12, 2020 in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida at the age of 88.

[[Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in Florida

Ponte Vedra Beach is an unincorporated seaside community in St. Johns County, Florida, United States. 

It is located eighteen miles (29 km) southeast of downtown Jacksonville and 26 north of St. Augustine.

[[Culver, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Indiana

Culver is a town in Marshall County, Indiana,  United States. 

Culver was originally called Union Town, and under the latter name was laid out in 1844. It was later renamed for Henry Harrison Culver, head of the Culver Academies.

FamilyMart can also be found in other countries, like, China, Philippines, Vietnam, and Thailand.

[[South Sinai Governorate]]

CATEGORIES: Governorates of Egypt

South Sinai Governorate  is a governorate in Egypt. The capital city is El Tor. It has the fewest people of any governorate in Egypt. It is on the southern half of the Sinai Peninsula.

Saint Catherine's Monastery, an Eastern Orthodox Church monastery and UNESCO World Heritage site, is in the central part of the governorate. Raithu Monastery is  in El Tor. Other important sites in the governorate are Wadi Mukattab and Wadi Feiran.

[[Suez Governorate]]

Suez Governorate is a governorate in Egypt. The capital city is also named Suez. The governorate is north of the Gulf of Suez.

[[Carl Dobkins Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, American country singers, American pop singers, American rock singers, Singers from Cincinnati, Ohio

Carl Edward Dobkins Jr. (January 13, 1941 – April 8, 2020) was an American singer. He is best known for his rockabilly hit, "My Heart Is an Open Book", released in 1958. The single reached No. 3 on the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 in 1959. The record also won a gold disc as it sold over one million copies. He was born in Cincinnati, Ohio.

Dobkins died on April 8, 2020, at the age of 79.

[[Madeleine Fischer]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Swiss movie actors

Madeleine Fischer (12 November 1935 – 8 April 2020) was a Swiss actress. She worked most notably in Italy. Her movie credits include Le Amiche (1955), The Bachelor (1955), I pappagalli (1955), Lazzarella (1957) and The Day the Sky Exploded (1958). She was born in Romanshorn.

Fischer died on 8 April 2020 in Gubbio, Umbria, Italy. She was 84.

[[Harry Wouters van den Oudenweijer]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Equestrians, Sportspeople from Gelderland

H. J. M. "Harry" Wouters van den Oudenweijer (5 July 1933 – 7 April 2020) was a Dutch equestrian show jumper. At the 1977 European Show Jumping Championships in Rome, he won the European title as part of the Dutch national team. He retired from competing in the sport in 1988. He later had a coaching career. He was born in Elst, Gelderland.

Wouters van den Oudenweijer died on 7 April 2020 at the age of 86.

[[La Libertad Department, El Salvador]]
