La Libertad is a department in El Salvador. The capital city is Santa Tecla.

[[Spaghetti-tree hoax]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 in Europe, 1950s in the United Kingdom, Hoaxes, April events, BBC, Mockumentaries, British television

The spaghetti-tree hoax was a hoax news report made by the BBC on April Fools' Day in 1957. The hoax showed a family in Ticino, Switzerland picking spaghetti from a "spaghetti tree".

About eight million people watched the hoax on April Fools' Day in 1957. At the time, spaghetti was rare in the United Kingdom. It was also sometimes considered a delicacy there. The next day, hundreds of people called the BBC to see if spaghetti trees were real and how to grow them. The BBC told callers to put some spaghetti in a can of tomato sauce and "hope for the best".

The BBC showed the hoax on a television programme called Panorama. A reporter named Charles de Jaeger made the hoax. He remembered how his teachers said his classmates would think spaghetti grew on trees. He got a budget of £100 to make the hoax. The hoax was reported by a trusted reporter named Richard Dimbleby. In 2010, CNN said it is the biggest hoax ever made by a trusted news organisation. It is also one of the first hoaxes on television.

[[Gérard Mannoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, French artists, Sculptors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France

Gérard Mannoni (1 January 1928 – 1 April 2020) was a French sculptor. He was born in Bastia. He studied at the École des Métiers d'Art, the École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts, the Académie Julian, and the Académie de la Grande Chaumière. 

He worked in the workshops of Marcel Gimond, Hubert Yencesse, and Ossip Zadkine. Mannoni made his first group exhibition at the Galerie Breteau in a group with André Bloc, Robert Jacobsen, Marino Di Teana, Claude Parent, and others.

Mannoni died on 1 April 2020 in Viry-Châtillon at the age of 92 of COVID-19.

[[Chalatenango Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of El Salvador, Establishments in El Salvador, 1850s establishments in North America, 1855 establishments

Chalatenango is a department of El Salvador, in the northwest of the country. The capital city is also named Chalatenango. Chalatenango was made a department on February 14, 1855.

The highest point in the country, El Pital with an elevation of 2730.06 m, is in Chalatenango Department. 

[[Jacques Blamont]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, French physicists, Scientists from Paris, Writers from Paris

Jacques Emile Blamont (13 October 1926 – 13 April 2020) was a French astrophysicist and author. He was the founder scientific and technical director of National Centre for Space Studies (CNES-Centre national d'études spatiales). Blamont was known to have worked to the development of Veronique, the first rocket launched by France in 1957. He was born in Paris.

He was an elected fellow of the French Academy of Technologies and a professor emeritus of the Pierre and Marie Curie University (University of Paris VI).

Blamont was honored as Commander of the Legion of Honour and Padma Shri.

Blamont died on 13 April 2020 in Châtillon, Hauts-de-Seine, aged 93.

[[Kerstin Meyer]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Singers from Stockholm

Kerstin Margareta Meyer (3 April 1928 – 14 April 2020) was a Swedish mezzo-soprano. He had an international career on the opera stage and concert platform. Meyer was born in Stockholm. She worked for Hamburg State Opera.

Meyer appeared in the title role of Bizet's Carmen in the Wieland Wagner/Sawallisch production (1959) and creating the roles of Mrs. Claiborne in Gunther Schuller's The Visitation (1966), Alice Arden in Alexander Goehr's Arden Must Die (1967), and Gertrude in Humphrey Searle's Hamlet (1968).

She was the rector of Operahögskolan i Stockholm from 1984 to 1994. 

Meyer died on 14 April 2020 in Stockholm, aged 92.

[[Pip and Jane Baker]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2014 deaths, 2020 deaths, BBC people, English television writers

Philip (1928 – 14 April 2020) and Jane Baker (died 8 September 2014), professionally known as Pip and Jane Baker, were an English husband-and-wife team of television writers. They were known mainly for their works to the BBC science-fiction series Doctor Who. The Bakers worked on four serials for the programme in the 1980s: The Mark of the Rani (1985), The Trial of a Time Lord (1986), Parts 9–12 and 14 (also known as Terror of the Vervoids and The Ultimate Foe); and Time and the Rani (1987). 

Jane Baker died on 8 September 2014. Pip Baker died on 14 April 2020.

[[Hugh Rossi]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Former Conservative MPs (UK), UK MPs 1966–1970, UK MPs 1970–1974, UK MPs 1974, UK MPs 1974–1979, UK MPs 1979–1983, UK MPs 1983–1987, UK MPs 1987–1992

Sir Hugh Alexis Louis Rossi, KCSG, KHS, FKC (21 June 1927 – April 2020) was a British Conservative politician. He was Minister for Disabled People from 1981 to 1983 during the cabinet of Margaret Thatcher.

He was a councillor on Hornsey Borough Council, serving from 1956 to 1965. Rossi was Member of Parliament (MP) for Hornsey from 1966 to 1983, and (after boundary changes) for Hornsey and Wood Green, 1983 to 1992.

Rossi died in April 2020 at the age of 92.

[[Ron Wylie]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Scottish footballers, Sportspeople from Glasgow

Ronald Maurice Wylie (6 August 1933 – 14 April 2020) was a Scottish football player, coach and manager. He played as a right half or inside forward for Notts County, Aston Villa and Birmingham City. He was manager of West Bromwich Albion between 1982 and 1984. Wylie was born in Glasgow.

Wylie died on 14 April 2020 of a long-illness, aged 86.

[[Betty Gilpin]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Elizabeth Folan Gilpin (born July 21, 1986) is an American actress. She was born in New York City. Gilpin is best known for playing Debbie "Liberty Belle" Eagan in the Netflix comedy series GLOW (2017–present).  

[[The Smurfs (TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 television series debuts, 1989 American television series endings, American animated television series, English-language television programs

The Smurfs (syndicated as Smurfs' Adventures) is an American-Belgian animated fantasy-comedy children's television series. It aired on NBC from 12 September 1981 to 2 December 1989. It was created by Hanna-Barbera Productions.

It is based on the Belgian comic series by the same name, created by Belgian cartoonist Peyo and aired for 256 episodes with a total of 418 stories.

[[Danny Goldman]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Los Angeles, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from New York City

Daniel Goldman (October 30, 1939 – April 12, 2020) was an American actor and casting director. He was known as the voice of Brainy Smurf in Hanna-Barbera's The Smurfs (1981–1989) and as the medical student in the opening scene of Young Frankenstein (1974). Goldman was born in New York City.

Goldman died on April 12, 2020 in Los Angeles from problems caused by multiple strokes, aged 80.

[[Hillel Furstenberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, Abel Prize winners, American mathematicians, German Jews, Hebrew University of Jerusalem faculty, Israeli academics, Israeli Jews, Israeli scientists, Jewish American academics, Jewish American scientists, Jewish Wolf Prize winners, Naturalized citizens of Israel, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Princeton University alumni, Refugees from Nazism, Scientists from Berlin, Scientists from New York City

Hillel (Harry) Furstenberg (הלל (הארי) פורסטנברג) (born September 29, 1935) is a German-born American-Israeli mathematician. He is a professor emeritus at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. He is a member of the Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities and the National Academy of Sciences. He is the winner of the Abel Prize and the Wolf Prize in Mathematics. 

He is known for his works on probability theory and ergodic theory methods to other areas of mathematics, including number theory and Lie groups. He was born in Berlin, but was raised in New York City.

[[Grigory Margulis]]

CATEGORIES: Wolf Prize winners, Fields Medalists, Abel Prize winners, 1946 births, Living people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American mathematicians, Russian mathematicians, People from Moscow

Grigory Aleksandrovich Margulis (Григо́рий Алекса́ндрович Маргу́лис, first name often given as Gregory, Grigori or Gregori; born February 24, 1946) is a Russian-American mathematician. He was born in Moscow. Margulis was known for his work on lattices in Lie groups, and the creation of methods from ergodic theory into diophantine approximation. 

He was awarded a Fields Medal in 1978, a Wolf Prize in Mathematics in 2005, and an Abel Prize in 2020, becoming the fifth mathematician to receive the three prizes. 

In 1991, he joined the faculty of Yale University. He is the Erastus L. De Forest Professor of Mathematics.

[[M. S. Narasimhan]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2021 deaths, Indian mathematicians

Mudumbai Seshachalu Narasimhan FRS (7 June 1932 – 16 May 2021) was an Indian mathematician. He was known, along with C. S. Seshadri, for their proof of the Narasimhan–Seshadri theorem. He was elected as a member of the Fellows of the Royal Society. He was the only Indian to receive the King Faisal International Prize in the field of science.

Narasimhan died on 16 May 2021, aged 88.

[[C. S. Seshadri]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, Indian mathematicians

Conjeevaram Srirangachari Seshadri FRS (29 February 1932 – 17 July 2020) was an Indian mathematician. He was the founder and Director-Emeritus of the Chennai Mathematical Institute. He was known for his work in algebraic geometry. The Seshadri constant is named after him. He was a recipient of the Padma Bhushan in 2009, the third highest civilian honor in the country.

Seshadri died on 17 July 2020, aged 88.

Dashrathaa is father of lord Rama in the Hindu mythology

[[SP-network]]

CATEGORIES: Cryptography

In cryptography, an SP-network, or substitution–permutation network (SPN), is a series of linked mathematical operations used in block cipher algorithms such as AES (Rijndael), 3-Way, Kalyna, Kuznyechik, PRESENT, SAFER, SHARK, and Square.

Such a network takes a block of the plaintext and the key as inputs, and applies several alternating "rounds" or "layers" of substitution boxes (S-boxes) and permutation boxes (P-boxes) to produce the ciphertext block. The S-boxes and P-boxes transform (sub-)blocks of input bits into output bits. It is common for these transformations to be operations that are efficient to perform in hardware, such as exclusive or (XOR) and bitwise rotation. The key is introduced in each round, usually in the form of "round keys" derived from it. (In some designs, the S-boxes themselves depend on the key.)

Decryption is done by simply reversing the process (using the inverses of the S-boxes and P-boxes and applying the round keys in reversed order).

An S-box substitutes a small block of bits (the input of the S-box) by another block of bits (the output of the S-box). This substitution should be one-to-one, to ensure invertibility (hence decryption). In particular, the length of the output should be the same as the length of the input (the picture on the right has S-boxes with 4 input and 4 output bits), which is different from S-boxes in general that could also change the length, as in DES (Data Encryption Standard), for example. An S-box is usually not simply a permutation of the bits. Rather, a good S-box will have the property that changing one input bit will change about half of the output bits (or an avalanche effect). It will also have the property that each output bit will depend on every input bit.

A P-box is a permutation of all the bits: it takes the outputs of all the S-boxes of one round, permutes the bits, and feeds them into the S-boxes of the next round. A good P-box has the property that the output bits of any S-box are distributed to as many S-box inputs as possible.

At each round, the round key (obtained from the key with some simple operations, for instance, using S-boxes and P-boxes) is combined using some group operation, typically XOR.

A single typical S-box or a single P-box alone does not have much cryptographic strength: an S-box could be thought of as a substitution cipher, while a P-box could be thought of as a transposition cipher. However, a well-designed SP network with several alternating rounds of S- and P-boxes already satisfies Shannon's confusion and diffusion properties:

Although a Feistel network that uses S-boxes (such as DES) is quite similar to SP networks, there are some differences that make either this or that more applicable in certain situations. For a given amount of confusion and diffusion, an SP network has more "inherent parallelism" and so — given a CPU with many execution units — can be computed faster than a Feistel network. CPUs with few execution units — such as most smart cards — cannot take advantage of this inherent parallelism. Also SP ciphers require S-boxes to be invertible (to perform decryption); Feistel inner functions have no such restriction and can be constructed as one-way functions.

[[Miguel Ángel D'Annibale]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2020 deaths, Cancer deaths in Argentina, Deaths from acute myeloid leukemia, People from Buenos Aires Province, Roman Catholic bishops

Miguel Ángel D'Annibale (27 March 1959 – 14 April 2020) was an Argentine bishop of the Roman Catholic Church. He was born in Florida Este, Buenos Aires. He became a priest in 1985. From 2013 until 2018, he served as bishop of Río Gallegos. From June 2018 until his death in 2020, D'Annibale was bishop of San Martín. 

On 14 April 2020, D'Annibale died due to acute myeloid leukaemia in Buenos Aires. He was 61.

[[Dámaso García]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Atlanta Braves players, Dominican Republic sportspeople, Footballers, Montreal Expos players, New York Yankees players, Toronto Blue Jays players

Dámaso Domingo García Sánchez (7 February 1957 – 15 April 2020) was a Dominican baseball player. He was born in Moca. He is best known for his time spent at Major League Baseball's Toronto Blue Jays from 1980 to 1986. He also played in MLB for the New York Yankees (1978–1979), the Atlanta Braves (1987–1988) and the Montreal Expos (1989). He was also a two-time All-Star (1984, 1985).

Before his professional baseball career, García was a footballer. He captained both Universidad Católica Madre y Maestra and the Dominican Republic national team.

García died in San Pedro de Macorís on 15 April 2020 at the age of 63.

[[Zebedee]]

CATEGORIES: 1st century BC births, 1st century deaths, New Testament people

Zebedee was a fisherman from Galilee who was the father of James and John who were disciples (followers) of Jesus. A story in the Gospel of Matthew and the Gospel of Mark says he was in a boat with his two sons when Jesus called them to follow him. He stayed in the boat with other men who worked for him. This could mean he was rich enough to hire others to help in his fishing work. The two sons were also fishermen when Jesus called them. Other than this short report, not much can be known for sure about Zebedee.

[[Cuscatlán Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of El Salvador, Establishments in El Salvador, 1830s establishments in North America, 1835 establishments

Cuscatlán is a department of El Salvador. The capital city is Cojutepeque.

With a surface area of 756.19, it is El Salvador's smallest department. It was created on 22 May 1835.

[[Adam Alsing]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Sweden, Swedish radio personalities, Swedish television presenters

Rolf Adam Engelbrekt Alsing (12 October 1968 – 15 April 2020) was a Swedish television and radio host. He was best known as the host of the Swedish version of Big Brother (2000–2005; 2014–2015). He also presented his own talk show, Adam Live, as well as the Swedish version of Jeopardy!. He was born in Karlstad.

On 15 April 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Alsing died of COVID-19 in Stockholm. He was 51.

Cabañas is a department of El Salvador. Its capital is Sensuntepeque. It became a department in February 1873.

The department takes its name from the Central-American hero General José Trinidad Cabañas. Later in life he served as a minister in El Salvador.

[[Willie Davis (defensive end)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from renal failure, American football defensive ends, Cleveland Browns players, Green Bay Packers players, Sportspeople from Louisiana, Businesspeople from Louisiana

William Delford Davis (July 24, 1934 – April 15, 2020) was an American football defensive end and businessman. Davis played football at Grambling State University. Davis spent 12 seasons in the National Football League (NFL), playing for the Cleveland Browns and the Green Bay Packers. Davis was born in Lisbon, Louisiana. He was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1981.

Davis died on April 15, 2020 at a hospital in Santa Monica, California of kidney failure, aged 85.

[[Lisbon, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Louisiana

Lisbon is a village in Claiborne Parish, Louisiana, United States. The population was 185 at the 2010 census. Lisbon is located east of the parish seat of Homer.

[[Gary McSpadden]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, American gospel singers, American singer-songwriters, American television presenters, American television producers, Record producers, Singers from Oklahoma, Writers from Oklahoma, Businesspeople from Oklahoma

Gary McSpadden (January 26, 1943 – April 15, 2020) was an American pastor, gospel singer-songwriter, record producer, television host and motivational speaker. He was born in Mangum, Oklahoma. He performed with The Statesmen, The Oak Ridge Boys, The Imperials, The Bill Gaither Trio, and The Gaither Vocal Band.

McSpadden's songs include "Jesus Lord To Me", "Hallelujah Praise The Lamb", and  "No Other Name But Jesus". He has produced albums for many groups. In 1987, he co-hosted PTL Today after Jim Bakker resigned. He also produced and starred in several live music shows in the Branson area during the 1990s and 2000s.

McSpadden died at a hospital in Tulsa, Oklahoma on April 15, 2020 of pancreatic cancer, aged 77.

[[Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Mexican politicians, Deaths from surgical complications

Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza (13 November 1935 – 14 April 2020) was a Mexican politician. He was Governor of the State of Mexico from 1989 to 1993. For a brief time in 1994, he was President of the Institutional Revolutionary Party. Pichardo Pagaza was born in Toluca, State of Mexico, Mexico.

Pichardo Pagaza died in Mexico City on 14 April 2020 from surgery-related problems, aged 84.

[[Haydar Baş]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Turkish businesspeople, Turkish politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Turkey

Haydar Baş (28 January 1947 – 14 April 2020) was a Turkish politician and businessman. He was one of the founders of the Independent Turkey Party and was the party's leader until his death. He was also the leader of the smaller branch of the Qadiriyya tariqa in Turkey. He was also the owner of many media organizations such as Meltem TV, Mesaj TV and Öğüt, Mesaj, İcmal magazines together with Yeni Mesaj newspaper.

He died on 14 April 2020 at a hospital in Trabzon from COVID-19, aged 73.

[[Cyril Lawrence]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, English footballers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom

Cyril Lawrence (12 June 1920 – 14 April 2020) was an English professional footballer. He played as a winger. He played in the English football league for Rochdale and Wrexham. He was born in Salford, England.

Lawrence died of COVID-19 on 14 April 2020 at Royal Bolton Hospital in Farnworth, Greater Manchester, during the 2020 coronavirus pandemic, aged 99.

[[Joel M. Reed]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Screenwriters from New York City, Movie directors from New York City, Movie producers from New York City, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

Joel M. Reed (December 29, 1933 – April 13, 2020) was an American movie director, producer and screenwriter. He was born in New York City. Reed was best known for directing the controversial Blood Sucking Freaks. Reed also directed the movies The G.I. Executioner (Wit's End / Dragon Lady / Wild Dragon Lady), (1971) and Night of the Zombies (Gamma 693 / Sister of Death / Battalion of the Living Dead) (1981). 

Reed died on April 13, 2020, aged 86, in New York City from the COVID-19 virus.

[[Jacques Maury]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, French Christians, Priests

Jacques Maury (10 November 1920 – 12 April 2020) was a French pastor. He was born in Clamart, France. Maury became pastor of the Reformed Church in Lezay after World War II. He was President of the French Federation of Christian Student Associations from 1957 to 1962, and then pastor at the Reformed Church in Poitiers. 

In 1968, Maury was elected President of the Reformed Church of France, then President of the Protestant Federation of France in 1977. He left this job in 1987. He was elected President of Cimade in 1989. He left the job in 1995. From 1981 to 1990, he chaired working group between the World Council of Churches and the Pontifical Council for Promoting Christian Unity.

He was made Officer of the Legion of Honour in 1995.

Maury died on Easter Sunday, 12 April 2020 in Clichy at the age of 99.

[[Simon Barrington-Ward]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, English Roman Catholics, Bishops

Simon Barrington-Ward GBR (27 May 1930 – 11 April 2020) was a bishop in the Church of England. He was the General Secretary of Church Missionary Society (CMS) from 1975 to 1985. From 1985 to 1997, he was the seventh Bishop of Coventry. Barrington-Ward was later a bishop with pastoral care at the University of Cambridge. In 2001, he was made Knight Commander of the Most Distinguished Order of St Michael and St George.

Barrington-Ward died on 11 April 2020, aged 89.

[[Dirk van den Broek]]

Dirk van den Broek (ˈdɪrk vɑn dɛn  bruk; 27 March 1924 – 8 April 2020) was a Dutch businessman. He was the founder of the Samenwerkende Dirk van den Broek Bedrijven. A couple of years later he changed his stores, just into Dirk named after himself. He was founder of travel agent D-reizen. He was born in Amsterdam.

Van den Broek died at the age of 96 on 8 April 2020.

[[IPhone SE (2nd generation)]]

CATEGORIES: IPhone, Mobile phones with 4K video recording, IPhones released in 2020

The second-generation iPhone SE is a smartphone designed by Apple Inc. It is meant as the successor to the iPhone 8, and the first-generation iPhone SE released in March 2016. Apple announced the device on April 15, 2020 with pre-orders set on April 17, 2020. It was released in Apple's online store worldwide on April 24, 2020.

The new iPhone SE uses the A13 chip found in the iPhone 11 Pro and 11 Pro Max devices. Like the iPhone 8, it retains the Touch ID fingerprint sensor inside a physical home button, and a 4.7″ LCD screen (compared to the smaller 4.0″ screen on the original iPhone SE). It is available in the colors black, white, and (Product)RED. All color finishes of the phone have a black front.

[[Conrad Black]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, Fraudsters, Canadian businesspeople, Businesspeople from London, Writers from Montreal, Writers from London

Conrad Moffat Black, Baron Black of Crossharbour KCSG (born August 25, 1944), is a Canadian-born British former newspaper publisher, author, and convicted felon. Black was in charge of Hollinger International. It published The Daily Telegraph (UK), Chicago Sun-Times (U.S.), The Jerusalem Post (Israel), National Post (Canada), and hundreds of community newspapers in North America.

In October 2002, Black became a member of the House of Lords. He was born in Montreal, Quebec.

In 2007, he was found guilty on four counts of fraud in U.S. District Court in Chicago. While two of the criminal fraud charges were dropped on appeal, a conviction for felony fraud and obstruction of justice were upheld in 2010. He was re-sentenced to 42 months in prison and a fine of $125,000.

In 2019, President Donald Trump granted him a full pardon.

[[The Stanley Hotel]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Colorado, Hotels

The Stanley Hotel is a 140-room Colonial Revival hotel in Estes Park, Colorado, United States. It is about five miles from the entrance to Rocky Mountain National Park. It was built by Freelan Oscar Stanley of Stanley Steamer fame and opened on July 4, 1909. It was built as a resort for rich people and a health retreat for tuberculosis victims. 

The hotel and its surrounding structures are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

The Stanley Hotel is the inspiration for the Overlook Hotel in Stephen King's 1977 bestselling novel The Shining and as the filming location for the 1997 TV miniseries, also written by King.

[[Estes Park, Colorado]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Colorado

Estes Park ˈ is a statutory town in Larimer County, Colorado, United States. Estes Park had a population of 5,858 at the 2010 census. Landmarks include The Stanley Hotel and The Baldpate Inn.

[[Ed Genson]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cholangiocarcinoma, Cancer deaths in Chicago, American lawyers, Businesspeople from Chicago

Edward Marvin Genson (June 30, 1941 – April 15, 2020) was an American attorney. He represented high-profile people such as former Republic Windows CEO Richard Gillman, musician R. Kelly, newspaper owner Conrad Black, and Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich. He was born in Chicago, Illinois.

Genson died April 15, 2020 from bile duct cancer in Chicago, aged 78.

[[Bernard Deconinck]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, French cyclists

Bernard Deconinck (26 April 1936 – 15 April 2020) was a French track cyclist. He was born in Lille. He won a silver medal in the amateur motor-paced racing at the 1959 World Championships in Amsterdam. He became professional in 1960.

Deconinck died on 15 April 2020 in Cavaillon. He was 83.

[[Abhimanyu]]

CATEGORIES: Hindu mythology, Mahabharata

Abhimanyu was the son of arjuna. He is described as a great person in the epic mahabharata. He was one of the youngest warrior to be killed in the war. Besides Arjun from pandavas side he only knew about the chakravayuh but not completely. It was the reason of his fall. His uncles tried to save him but after each obstacle in the chakravayuh everyone was left behind. He was the only one to reach in the middle.

His son Parikshit ruled over after Yudhistra.

[[ESC Clermont Business School]]

[[Gérard Mulumba Kalemba]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, People from the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Roman Catholic bishops

Gérard Mulumba Kalemba (8 July 1937 – 15 April 2020) was a Congolese bishop of the Roman Catholic Church. He was born in Kananga. He became a priest in 1967. He served as bishop of Mweka from 1989 until his retirement in 2017. His brother, Étienne Tshisekedi, and nephew, Félix Tshisekedi, both served as president of their country.

On 15 April 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Mulumba Kalemba died of COVID-19 in Kinshasa. He was 82.

[[4Q120]]

CATEGORIES: 1st century BC, Septuagint manuscripts, 1st-century BC biblical manuscripts

4Q120 (also pap4QLXXLevb; VH 46; Rahlfs 802; LDAB 3452) is a Septuagint manuscript (LXX) of the biblical Book of Leviticus, which was found at Qumran. The Rahlfs-No. is 802. Palaoegraphycally it dates from the first century BCE.

[[John McRay]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2018 deaths, University of Chicago alumni

John Robert McRay (17 December 1931 - 24 August 2018) was an archaeologist, and professor emeritus of New Testament at Wheaton College (Illinois). He supervised excavating teams in the Holy Land: Caesarea, Sepphoris, and Herodium. He also was an expert in the languages, cultures, geography, and history of Israel-Palestine.

[[Lloyd Gaston]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2006 deaths

Lloyd Henry Gaston (2 December 1929 – 24 September 2006) was a theologan, biblical scholar, associate professor, and professor emeritus of New Testament at Vancouver School of Theology. He also was a president of the Canadian Society of Biblical Studies and Pastor of First Presbyterian Church (Edmonton).

[[Charles Perrot (priest)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2013 deaths

Charles Perrot, (16 February 1929 - 11 November 2013) was a French priest, honorary professor of the Catholic Institute of Paris, a world-renowned biblist and a specialist in contemporary Judaism of Jesus.

[[Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 5101]]

CATEGORIES: Religious literature, Septuagint manuscripts, 1st-century biblical manuscripts

Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 5101, (designated as P.Oxy.LXXVII 5101, LDAB 140272 https://web.archive.org/web/20190328115912/https://www.trismegistos.org/ldab/text.php?tm or Rahlfs 2227) is a papyrus roll which now only survives as small pieces. It is written in Koine Greek of the  Septuagint (LXX). It has been palaeographycally dated to have been written between 50 and 150 C.E.

The manuscript contains the tetragrammaton to represent the Divine Name of God (Yahweh) written in palaeo-Hebrew script.

[[Bhima]]

CATEGORIES: Mahabharata

Bhima (भीम, IAST: Bhīma) is the second son of the Pandavas. The Mahabharata has many events which shows the strength of Bhima. Bhima is responsible for killing all hundred Kaurava brothers in the Kurukshetra War. He was considered to have the physical strength of around 10,000 elephants.

[[Hans Prade]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Ambassadors, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, Political commentators, Surinamese politicians

Hans Orlando Prade (23 July 1938 – 3 April 2020) was a  Surinamese diplomat. During his early political career, he worked with Ronald Venetiaan. Later Prade became a member of the Progressieve Nationale Partij. During the coup, Prade was a commentator on Suriname radio. 

Prade was the Surinamese ambassador to the Netherlands from 1981 to 1982. In 1991, he tried to run for President of Suriname, but lost the election to Ronald Venetiaan.

Prade died on 3 April 2020 in Rotterdam of COVID-19, aged 81.

[[Frits Flinkevleugel]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, Dutch footballers, Sportspeople from Amsterdam

Frederik Arnoldus Flinkevleugel (3 November 1939 – 10 April 2020) was a Dutch footballer who played as a right back. He was born in Amsterdam. Flinkevleugel played for DWS and FC Amsterdam. He played for the national team from 1964 to 1967.

Flinkevleugel died of COVID-19 on 10 April 2020 at the age of 80.

[[Kim H. Veltman]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Canadian academics, Canadian historians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, Naturalized citizens of Canada, Writers from Friesland

Kim Henry Veltman (5 September 1948 - 1 April 2020) was a Canadian historian of science and art. He is the director of the Virtual Maastricht McLuhan Institute (VMMI). He was known for his works in the fields of "linear perspective and the visual dimensions of science and art," new media, culture and society. He was born in Friesland, Netherlands. His best known work is Studies on Leonardo da Vinci I, (1986). where he focused on the works and legacy of Leonardo Da Vinci.

Kim H. Veltman died of COVID-19 in the Netherlands, aged 71.April 2021

[[Ranjit Chowdhry]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from gastrointestinal hemorrhage, Indian movie actors, Indian television actors, People from Mumbai

Ranjit Chowdhry (19 September 1955 – 15 April 2020) was an Indian actor. He was best known for his roles in television and theatre. He appeared in two episodes of The Office as Vikram. He also starred as Dr. Gudat in Prison Break, Dr. Gupta in Last Holiday and as Sabhi in Baton Baton Mein.

Chowdhry was born in Mumbai. He died at a hospital in Mumbai from gastrointestinal bleeding on 15 April 2020, aged 64.

[[George Curtis Smith]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Deaths from renal failure, American judges, Politicians from Columbus, Ohio, US Republican Party politicians

George Curtis Smith (August 8, 1935 – April 15, 2020) was an American politician and lawyer. He was a Senior United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio. He was nominated to the court in 1987 by President Ronald Reagan and retired in 2002. Smith was born in Columbus, Ohio.

Smith died on April 15, 2020 at a hospital in Columbus from heart and kidney failure at the age of 84.

[[Francesco Di Carlo]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, Mobsters, People from Palermo

Francesco Di Carlo (February 18, 1941 – April 16, 2020) was an Italian mobster. He was a member of Sicilian Mafia who became a state witness (pentito - a mafioso turned informer) in 1996. He was accused of being the killer of the Roberto Calvi. Di Carlo was in charge of Banco Ambrosiano and worked closely with the Vatican Bank. He was born in Altofonte, Italy.

Di Carlo died of COVID-19 in Paris on April 16, 2020, aged 79.

[[Altofonte]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Sicily

Altofonte (Sicilian: Parcu) is a comune (municipality) in the Metropolitan City of Palermo in the Italian region Sicily, located about 9 southwest of Palermo.

[[Milena Jelinek]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American playwrights, American educators, Writers from Prague, Screenwriters from New York City

Milena Jelinek (Czech: Milena Jelínková, née Tobolová) (1935 – April 16,  2020) was a Czech-American screenwriter, playwright and teacher. She wrote the screenplay for the movie Forgotten Light, which was awarded three Czech Lions in 1997. She was an important person during the Czech New Wave. She was married to the late Frederick Jelinek. Jelinek was born in Prague.

Jelinek died on April 16, 2020 of COVID-19 in New York City, aged 84.

[[Sicilian Mafia]]

CATEGORIES: Mafia, Sicily

The Sicilian Mafia, also known as simply the Mafia and also know by its  members as Cosa Nostra (ˈkɔːza ˈnɔstra, ˈkɔːsa -), is an Italian, Mafia-terrorist-type, organized crime syndicate. It began in Sicily.

The basic group is known as a "family", "clan", or cosca. Each family claims sovereignty over a territory, usually a town or village or a neighbourhood of a larger city.

Its members call themselves "men of honour", although the public often calls them as mafiosi. The Mafia often did protection racketeering, "fixed" problems between criminals, and the organizing and oversight of illegal agreements and transactions. 

[[Visteon Dockable Entertainment]]

CATEGORIES: Game Boy, Video game consoles

The Visteon Dockable Entertainment device was a Game Boy Advance-type device resembling a car DVD player.

[[Frederick Jelinek]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2010 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Researchers, Czech scientists, Writers from Prague, Scientists from Baltimore, Maryland, Writers from Baltimore, Maryland

Frederick Jelinek (18 November 1932 – 14 September 2010) was a Czech-American researcher. His works focused in information theory, automatic speech recognition, and natural language processing. He was well known for his quote, "Every time I fire a linguist, the performance of the speech recognizer goes up". 

Jelinek taught for 10 years at Cornell University before being offered a job at IBM Research. In 1961, he married Czech screenwriter Milena Jelinek. After IBM, he went to head the Center for Language and Speech Processing at Johns Hopkins University for 17 years.

Jelinek died of a heart attack in Baltimore, Maryland on 14 September 2010 at the age of 77.

[[Meghan Ory]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Canadian movie actors, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors, Living people, Actors from British Columbia

Meghan Ory (born August 20, 1982) is a Canadian actress. She is best known for her role as Red Riding Hood/Ruby on the ABC fantasy series Once Upon a Time. She also starred in the CBS drama Intelligence as Riley Neal. 

[[Israel Gelfand]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 2009 deaths, Russian mathematicians

Israel Moiseevich Gelfand, also written Israïl Moyseyovich Gel'fand, or Izrail M. Gelfand (ישראל געלפֿאַנד, Изра́иль Моисе́евич Гельфа́нд; 2 September – 5 October 2009) was a famous Soviet mathematician. He worked on many branches of mathematics, including group theory and other areas related to differential equations.

He received many awards, including the Order of Lenin and the first Wolf Prize, he was also a Foreign Fellow of the Royal Society and professor at Moscow State University, and worked at Rutgers University after immigrating to the United States shortly before his 76th birthday.

[[Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi]]

CATEGORIES: 1804 births, 1851 deaths, People from Potsdam, German mathematicians, German Jews

Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi (dʒ; jaˈkoːbi; 10 December 1804 – 18 February 1851) was a German mathematician who contributed to elliptic functions, differential equations, determinants, and number theory. He was the first Jewish mathematician to be appointed professor at a German university.

[[Mario Donatone]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian stage actors, Italian voice actors

Mario Giacinto Donatone (9 June 1933 – 14 April 2020) was an Italian actor. He was born in Tripoli, Libya to Italian parents. He was known for his role as Mosca in The Godfather Part III. He also starred in Phenomena and John Wick: Chapter 2.

Donatone died in Rome on 14 April 2020 at the age of 86.

[[John Wick (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 movies, American action movies, Lionsgate movies

John Wick (also known as John Wick: Chapter 1) is a 2014 American neo-noir action movie directed by Chad Stahelski, in his directorial debut, and written by Derek Kolstad. It stars Keanu Reeves, Michael Nyqvist, Alfie Allen, Adrianne Palicki, Bridget Moynahan, Dean Winters, Ian McShane, John Leguizamo, and Willem Dafoe. It is the first movie in the John Wick movie series.

The movie had strong positive reviews. Many critics called it one of Reeves' best performances and one of the best action movies of 2014. It made $86 million worldwide.

[[Ernst-Georg Schwill]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, German movie actors, German television actors, German stage actors, German voice actors, Actors from Berlin

Ernst-Georg Schwill (30 March 1939 – 9 April 2020) was a German actor. He was born in Berlin. Schwill was best known for his roles as Max in Alarm in the Circus (1954), Strups in A Berlin Romance (1966) and as Gustav in the 1968 miniseries The Shield and the Sword. 

Schwill died of a heart attack on 9 April 2020 in Berlin, aged 81.

[[Danièle Hoffman-Rispal]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2020 deaths, Jewish French politicians, Jewish women politicians, Politicians from Paris, Socialist Party (France) politicians

Danièle Hoffman-Rispal (22 June 1951 – 16 April 2020) was a French politician of Jewish descent. She was a member of the National Assembly of France from 2002 to 2012.  She represented the city of Paris. Hoffman-Rispal was a member of the Socialist Party.

Hoffman-Rispal died either late 15 April or early 16 April 2020 in Paris at the age of 68.

[[Elastic limit]]

CATEGORIES: Materials science

The elastic limit is the maximum amount an object can stretch if the object stretches at all.

[[Ksenia Tripolitova]]

CATEGORIES: 1915 births, 2020 deaths, Russian ballerinas, French ballet dancers, French centenarians

Ksenia Arturovna Tripolitova (7 May 1915 – 9 April 2020) was a Russian-born French ballet dancer. She was born in Vilna, Russian Empire. She began studying in the studio of Lyubov Yegorova. She was known for touring with her husband Nikolai Tripolitov during the 1930s and 1940s. In the 1960s, she began a solo career. Tripolitova was known for performing during World War II when Nazis were fighting in France.  

In 1949 she performed in Switzerland. At the end of the 1950s, she and her husband formed a vocal and dance ensemble "Troika". In the years 1954-1955 she worked in the opera theater in Tunis . In 1957 she performed together with the Ural Cossack choir in Spain.

Tripolitova turned 100 in April 2015. She died in Paris on 9 April 2020, aged 104.

[[Albert Almoznino]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2020 deaths, Israeli artists, Israeli Jews, Jewish artists, Moroccan Jews, Naturalized citizens of Israel

Albert Almoznino (אלברט אלמוזנינו; March 3, 1923 – April 7, 2020) was a Moroccan-born Israeli hand shadow artist. His career began in 1958. He became well known in the 1960s, when he performed his hand shadow skills at Radio City Music Hall in New York, Paris Olympia and during the The Ed Sullivan Show. Almoznino was born in Mogador (Essaouira), Morocco.

Almoznino died on April 7, 2020 at the age of 97.

[[Santiago Lanzuela]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish politicians

Santiago Lanzuela Marina (27 September 1948 – 16 April 2020) was a Spanish politician. He was born in Teruel, Spain. He was the President of the Government of Aragon from 1995 to 1999. He was a member of the Aragonese Party.

Lanzuela died of COVID-19 in Madrid on 16 April 2020, aged 71.

[[Keiji Fujiwara]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Japanese voice actors, Actors from Tokyo

Keiji Fujiwara was a Japanese voice actor. His best known works were Shinnosuke's father Hiroshi Nohara in the long-running anime series Crayon Shin-chan, Maes Hughes in Fullmetal Alchemist, Holland in Eureka Seven, Axel in Kingdom Hearts, Leorio 

in Hunter x Hunter, Shiro Fujimoto in Ao no Exorcist and Esidisi in JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: Battle Tendency. 

In the live action, he was mostly known for dubbing actor Robert Downey Jr. as Iron Man/Tony Stark.

Fujiwara died, aged 55 of cancer on April 12, 2020.

[[President of Suriname]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Suriname

The President of the Republic of Suriname (President van de Republiek Suriname) is, in accordance with the Constitution of 1987, the head of state and head of government of Suriname, and commander-in-chief of the Suriname National Army (SNL).

[[Hendrick Chin A Sen]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 1999 deaths, Presidents of Suriname, Prime Ministers of Suriname

Hendrick Rudolf "Henk" Chin A Sen (陳亞先; 18 January 1934 – 11 August 1999) was a Surinamese politician who was the President of Suriname from 15 August 1980 until 4 February 1982.

[[Fred Ramdat Misier]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2004 deaths, Presidents of Suriname

Lachmipersad Frederik "Fred" Ramdat Misier (28 October 1926 – 25 July 2004) was the 3rd President of Suriname from 1982 to 1988.

[[Ramsewak Shankar]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Presidents of Suriname

Ramsewak Shankar (born November 6, 1937) is a Surinamese politician. He was the 4th President of Suriname from 1988 to 1990. His government was overthrown by Dési Bouterse leading a bloodless military coup. Shankar was Agriculture & Fisheries Minister from 1969 to 1971. 

[[Johan Kraag]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 1996 deaths, Presidents of Suriname

Johannes Samuel Petrus "Johan" Kraag (July 29, 1913 – May 24, 1996) was a Surinamese politician. He was the President of Suriname from December 29, 1990, until September 16, 1991.

[[Jules Wijdenbosch]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Presidents of Suriname, Prime Ministers of Suriname

Jules Albert Wijdenbosch (born 2 May 1942) is a Surinamese politician. He was President of Suriname from 1996 to 2000. He was a member of the National Democratic Party. He was Prime Minister from April 1987 until January 1988, Vice President from January 1991 until September 1991.

[[List of prime ministers of Suriname]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Suriname

Below is a list of prime ministers of Suriname from 1949 to 1988. In 1988 the job of Prime Minister of Suriname was abolished and replaced by a Vice President, who chairs the Council of Ministers ex officio.

[[Wim Udenhout]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Ambassadors to the United States, Prime Ministers of Suriname

Willem "Wim" Alfred Udenhout (born 29 September 1937) is a Surinamese politician. He was the Prime Minister of Suriname from February 1984 to July 1986. He was a teacher and, for a time, and a Black Power activist. He was an ambassador to the United States.

[[Daniel Davis]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Arkansas

Daniel Davis (born November 26, 1945) is an American actor. Davis is best known for playing Niles the butler on the sitcom The Nanny (1993 to 1999) and for his two guest appearances as Professor Moriarty on Star Trek: The Next Generation.

[[Charles Shaughnessy]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, Living people, Emmy Award winning actors, English movie actors, English stage actors, English television actors, English voice actors, Actors from London

Charles George Patrick Shaughnessy, 5th Baron Shaughnessy (born 9 February 1955) is a British actor. Shaughnessy is known for his roles on American television, as Shane Donovan on the soap opera Days of Our Lives, as Maxwell Sheffield on the sitcom The Nanny, and as the voice of Dennis the Goldfish on Stanley. He was born in London.

[[Monterey Bay]]

CATEGORIES: Bays of the United States, Pacific Ocean, Monterey County, California, Santa Cruz County, California

Monterey Bay is a bay of the Pacific Ocean located on the coast of the U.S. state of California. The bay is south of the major cities of San Francisco and San Jose. The county-seat city of Santa Cruz is located at the north end of the bay. The city of Monterey is on the Monterey Peninsula at the south end.

[[Rick Carlisle]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, American basketball players, National Basketball Association coaches, Portland Trail Blazers, Boston Celtics players, New York Knicks players, New Jersey Nets players, Sportspeople from New York, Living people

Richard Preston Carlisle (ˈ KAR; born October 27, 1959) is an American basketball coach and former player who is the head coach of the Dallas Mavericks of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He has also served as head coach of the Indiana Pacers and Detroit Pistons. As a player, Carlisle played for the Boston Celtics, New York Knicks and New Jersey Nets. He is also one of only 11 people to win an NBA championship both as a player and as a coach.

[[Cocoon (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy-drama movies, 1980s science fiction movies, American comedy-drama movies, American science fiction movies, Movies directed by Ron Howard

Cocoon is a 1985 American science-fiction comedy-drama movie directed by Ron Howard. It is about a group of elderly people being brought back to their youth by aliens.  The movie stars Don Ameche, Wilford Brimley, Hume Cronyn, Brian Dennehy, Jack Gilford, Steve Guttenberg, Maureen Stapleton, Jessica Tandy, Gwen Verdon, Herta Ware, Tahnee Welch, and Linda Harrison.

[[Linda Harrison (actress)]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American movie directors, American movie producers, Actors from Maryland, Businesspeople from Maryland

Linda Melson Harrison (born July 26, 1945) is an American actress, director and producer. She is known for her roles as Nova in the science fiction movie classic Planet of the Apes (1968) and the first sequel, Beneath the Planet of the Apes.

[[Berlin, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maryland

Berlin is a town in Worcester County, Maryland, United States. It is part of the Salisbury, Maryland-Delaware Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population was 4,485 at the 2010 census.

[[Worcester County, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Maryland counties

Worcester County ˈ is the easternmost county of the U.S. state of Maryland. As of the 2010 census, the population was 51,454. Its county seat is Snow Hill.

[[Snow Hill, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Maryland, County seats in Maryland

Snow Hill is a town in and the county seat of Worcester County, Maryland, United States. The population was 2,103 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Salisbury, Maryland-Delaware Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Nathalie Baye]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors, French voice actors

Nathalie Marie Andrée Baye (born 6 July 1948) is a French actress. She is known for her roles in Every Man for Himself (1980), Strange Affair (1981), La Balance (1982), and The Young Lieutenant (2005). 

In 2009, she was made a Chevalier of the Legion of Honour. 

Her other movie roles include Day for Night (1973), Catch Me If You Can (2002), Tell No One (2006) and The Assistant (2015).

[[Congregational church]]

CATEGORIES: Christian movements and denominational families

Congregationalism is a way to organize Christian (usually Protestant) churches. With Congregationalism, each church or community has a lot of autonomy. Anabaptist, baptist, and pentecostal movements are often organised this way. It is different from presbyteranism, where a number of elders govern the churches, and from Episcopalism, where a number of bishops govern the churches. Originally, Congregationalism was part of the Anglican church, who took some of the teachings of Jean Calvin and Huldrych Zwingli, in the 16th and 17th century.  Those who wanted congregationalism usually were Puritans.

[[James River Valley, North Dakota]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in North Dakota, North Dakota townships

James River Valley, North Dakota is a township in Dickey County, North Dakota, United States. The population was 40 at the 2010 census.

[[Kent (township), North Dakota]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in North Dakota, North Dakota townships

Kent, North Dakota is a township in Dickey County, North Dakota, United States. The population was 29 at the 2010 census.

[[Usulután Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of El Salvador, Establishments in El Salvador, 1865 establishments in North America

Usulután is a department of El Salvador. The capital city is Usulután. The department was created on June 22, 1865.

The department is home to Jiquilisco Bay and Port El Triunfo.

[[San Miguel Department (El Salvador)]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of El Salvador, Establishments in El Salvador, 1820s establishments in North America, 1824 establishments

San Miguel is a department in the eastern part of El Salvador. The capital city is also named San Miguel.

[[Morazán Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of El Salvador, Establishments in El Salvador, 1875 establishments in North America

Morazán is a department of El Salvador. The capital city is San Francisco Gotera.

[[La Unión Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of El Salvador, Establishments in El Salvador, 1865 establishments in North America

 La Unión is a department of El Salvador. The capital city is also named La Unión. The department was created on June 22, 1865.

Some of the tourist sites are the Conchagua Temple, built in 1693, and ruins in Intipucá and Meanguera.

[[Departments of El Salvador]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of El Salvador

El Salvador is divided into 14 departments for administrative purposes. The departments are divided into a total of 262 municipalities. The country is a unitary state.

[[Spanish alphabet]]

CATEGORIES: Writing systems, Latin alphabet, Language

The Spanish alphabet is a Latin alphabet of 27 letters used to write the Spanish language. It has the same letters as the ISO Basic Latin Alphabet with the additional letter ñ, which is named eñe (pronounced EN-yay). In addition to letters, the alphabet also uses accent marks to mark stressed syllables. The Spanish alphabet is fairly phonemic, which means words are usually spelled the way the sound. While different accents exist in Spanish like with any living language, pronunciation is usually fits well with spelling.

[[Annobón Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Equatorial Guinea, Islands of Equatorial Guinea, Volcanoes of Africa, 1474 establishments, Establishments in Africa

Annobón is a province of Equatorial Guinea. It is the island of Annobón and its associated islets in the Gulf of Guinea. The capital city is San Antonio de Palé. The other town on the island is Mabana.

The island's main industries are fishing and forestry.

Annobón is an extinct volcano. The main island measures about 4 long by 2 wide. Its highest peak is Quioveo, which rises 598.

[[Bioko]]

CATEGORIES: Islands of Equatorial Guinea

Bioko is an island 32 off the west coast of Africa. It is the northernmost part of Equatorial Guinea. It is in the Bight of Bonny part of the Gulf of Guinea.

Bioko has a total area of 2017. It is 70 long and about 32 across. Its highest peak is Pico Basile at 3012.

[[Corisco]]

CATEGORIES: Islands of Equatorial Guinea

Corisco is a small island of Equatorial Guinea. It is also called Mandj.

It has an area of just 14. Its highest point is 35 above sea level.

[[Allen Daviau]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, American cinematographers, BAFTA Award winners, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, People from New Orleans, Louisiana

Allen Daviau, A.S.C. (June 14, 1942 – April 15, 2020) was an American cinematographer.  He was known for his works with Steven Spielberg. He worked on E.T. the Extra Terrestrial (1982), The Color Purple (1985), and Empire of the Sun (1987). He was nominated for five Academy Awards. Daviau was born in New Orleans, Louisiana.

Daviau died on April 15, 2020 from COVID-19 in Los Angeles, aged 77.

[[Christophe (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, Deaths from COPD, French singers, French songwriters, Record producers, Musicians from Paris, Writers from Paris

Daniel Bevilacqua, (13 October 1945 – 16 April 2020), better known by the stage name Christophe, was a French singer-songwriter, keyboardist and record producer. He was born in the Paris. Christophe became famous in the early 1960s with his first hit being "Aline". In 1971, with Francis Dreyfus, he created the Motors record label (Disques Motors). He wrote the song "Boule de flipper" for Corynne Charby.

Christophe was hospitalized under critical condition for COVID-19 and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in Paris. He died on 16 April 2020, aged 74.

[[James H. Wilkinson]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 1986 deaths, British mathematicians

James Hardy Wilkinson FRS (27 September 1919 – 5 October 1986) was a British expert in the field of numerical analysis. His name is used for the "James H. Wilkinson Prize in Numerical Analysis and Scientific Computing" and "J. H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software" given by the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics.

[[Maharashtra Day]]

It is celebrated on 1st May.On this day state of Maharashtra was formed on 1st May,1969.

[[Bill Gaither (gospel singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, American gospel singers, American singer-songwriters, Record producers, Singers from Indiana, Musicians from Indiana, Businesspeople from Indiana

William James Gaither (born March 28, 1936) is an American gospel singer-songwriter. He is known for his works with his wife Gloria. He is also known for performing as part of the Bill Gaither Trio and the Gaither Vocal Band (GVB).

[[Gloria Gaither]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, American songwriters, American screenwriters, American educators, American television presenters, People from Battle Creek, Michigan, Writers from Michigan

Gloria Gaither (born March 4, 1942) is a Christian songwriter, editor, educator and screenwriter. She is the wife of Bill Gaither. They have written more than 700 songs. She performed, traveled and recorded with the Bill Gaither Trio from 1965 through 1991. She became the narrator for the Gaither Homecoming series of television broadcasts in 1991.

[[Kyuya Masuda]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2018 deaths, Japanese mathematicians, University of Tokyo faculty

Kyuya Masuda (1937–2018) is a Japanese mathematician and honored professor at the University of Tokyo. He studied about partial differential equations such as the Navier–Stokes equations and reaction-diffusion equations.

[[Clare, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan

Clare is a city in Clare and Isabella counties in the U.S. state of Michigan. The population was 3,118 at the 2010 census. 

[[Clare County, Michigan]]

Clare County is a county in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 census, the population was 30,926. The county seat is Harrison.

[[Harrison, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan, County seats in Michigan

Harrison is a city in the U.S. state of Michigan.  The population was 2,114 at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Clare County.

The city is named after U.S. President William Henry Harrison.

[[Isabella County, Michigan]]

Isabella County is a county located in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 census, the population was 70,311. Its county seat is Mount Pleasant.

Gladwin County is a county located in the U.S. state of Michigan. As of the 2010 census, the population was 25,692. The county seat is Gladwin.

[[Baranwal]]

CATEGORIES: Social groups of Uttar Pradesh, Bania communities

Baranwal (also spelled Barnwal, Burnwal, Bernwal, Varanwal, Varnwal, Barnawal) is a Hindu community found throughout northern India, including Bihar, Jharkhand, West Bengal, Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat along with a sprinkled presence in Rajasthan, Haryana, Madhya Pradesh. The name of the caste derives from "Baran" or "Barn", a former name of the Bulandshahr city. The community derives from ancient legendary king Ahibaran.

The Central Slovenia Statistical Region (Osrednjeslovenska statistična regija) is a statistical region in central Slovenia.

[[Zardoz]]

Zardoz is a 1974 Irish-American science fiction movie directed, produced and written by John Boorman. It stars Sean Connery, Charlotte Rampling, Sara Kestelman, John Alderton, and Niall Buggy. The movie was shot by cinematographer Geoffrey Unsworth and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

Thieves Like Us is a 1974 American crime thriller movie directed by Robert Altman and starring Keith Carradine, Shelley Duvall, Louise Fletcher and Tom Skerritt. The was based on the novel of the same name  by Edward Anderson. It was distributed by United Artists.

Career Opportunities is a 1991 American romantic comedy movie starring Frank Whaley, Jennifer Connelly, Dermot Mulroney, Kieran Mulroney and John Candy. It was directed by Bryan Gordon and is based on the John Hughes script. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Wetter (Ruhr)]]

CATEGORIES: Ennepe-Ruhr Rural District

Wetter (Ruhr) is a town of the district Ennepe-Ruhr-Kreis in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia, in the Ruhr Area and has about 27,800 inhabitants.

[[Cruising (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 drama movies, 1980s crime movies, 1980s thriller movies, 1980s LGBT movies, 1980s erotic movies, American crime thriller movies, German drama movies, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by William Friedkin

Cruising is a 1980 American erotic crime drama movie directed by William Friedkin. It stars Al Pacino, Karen Allen, Paul Sorvino, Ed O'Neill, Powers Boothe and it is based loosely on the book of the same name by Gerald Walker about a serial killer who stalks on gay men. It was nominated for three Razzies at the 1st Golden Raspberry Awards in 1981.

[[Porta Westfalica]]

Porta Westfalica is a city of the district of Minden-Lübbecke in the German state of North Rhine-Westphalia. It has about 37,000 inhabitants.

The name "Porta Westfalica" is Latin and means "gate to Westphalia".

[[Escape to Athena]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 comedy movies, 1970s war movies, 1970s adventure movies, British movies, Movies directed by George P. Cosmatos

Escape to Athena is a 1979 World War II adventure comedy movie starring Roger Moore, Telly Savalas, David Niven, Stefanie Powers, Sonny Bono, and Elliott Gould. It was directed by George P. Cosmatos, and is set during World War II is German-occupied Greek island.

Tumbes is a region in Peru. The capital is the city of Tumbes.

[[NBA Most Valuable Player Award]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 establishments in the United States, Most valuable player awards, National Basketball Association, Sports trophies and awards

The National Basketball Association Most Valuable Player Award (MVP) is an annual National Basketball Association (NBA) award given since the 1955–56 season to the best performing player of the regular season. The winner receives the Maurice Podoloff Trophy, which is named in honor of the first commissioner (then president) of the NBA, who served from 1946 until 1963. Until the 1979–80 season, the MVP was selected by a vote of NBA players. Since the 1980–81 season, the award is decided by a panel of sportswriters and broadcasters throughout the United States and Canada.

Each member of the voting panel casts a vote for first to fifth place selections. Each first-place vote is worth 10 points; each second-place vote is worth seven; each third-place vote is worth five, fourth-place is worth three and fifth-place is worth one. Starting from 2010, one ballot was cast by fans through online voting. The player with the highest point total wins the award. As of June 2019, the current holder of the award is Giannis Antetokounmpo of the Milwaukee Bucks.

Every player who has won this award and has been eligible for the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame has been inducted. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar won the award a record six times. He is also the only player to win the award despite his team not making the playoffs back in the 1975–76 season. Both Bill Russell and Michael Jordan won the award five times, while Wilt Chamberlain and LeBron James won the award four times. Russell and James are the only players to have won the award four times in five seasons.Moses Malone, Larry Bird and Magic Johnson each won the award three times, while Bob Pettit, Karl Malone, Tim Duncan, Steve Nash and Stephen Curry have each won it twice. Only two rookies have won the award: Chamberlain in the 1959–60 season and Wes Unseld in the 1968–69 season. Hakeem Olajuwon of Nigeria, Duncan of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Nash of Canada, Dirk Nowitzki of Germany, and Giannis Antetokounmpo of Greece are the only MVP winners considered "international players" by the NBA.

Curry in 2015–16 is the only player to have won the award unanimously. Shaquille O'Neal in 1999–2000 and James in 2012–13 are the only two players to have fallen one vote shy of a unanimous selection, both receiving 120 of 121 votes. Since the 1975–76 season, only two players have been named MVP for a season in which their team failed to win at least 50 regular-season games—Moses Malone (twice, 1978–79 and 1981–82) and Russell Westbrook (2016–17).

[[Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 1007]]

CATEGORIES: Septuagint manuscripts

Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 1007 (LXXP.Oxy.VII.1007) is a fragment of a Septuagint manuscript (LXX). The manuscript was discovered in Oxyrhynchus, modern El-Bahnasa, Egypt. The manuscript has been palaeographically dated to the 3rd century CE. The manuscript is currently kept in the department of manuscripts in the British library, London (Inv. 2047).

[[Orange County, Indiana]]

Orange County is a county in the U.S. state of Indiana. As of 2010, 19,840 people lived there which is an increase of 2.8% from 19,306 in 2000. The county seat is Paoli.

[[Bruce M. Metzger]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2007 deaths, American academics, American Presbyterians, Bible translators, Christian ministers, Christian writers, Scientists from Pennsylvania, Writers from Pennsylvania

Bruce Manning Metzger (1914–2007) was an American biblical scholar, Bible translator and textual critic, a longtime professor at Princeton Theological Seminary and Bible editor of the American Bible Society and United Bible Societies. He was a scholar of Greek, and New Testament textual criticism, and wrote prolifically on these subjects. Metzger was one of the most influential New Testament scholars of the 20th century.

[[Andrew Klavan]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, American Christians, American novelists, Bloggers, Jewish American writers, Jews who converted to Christianity, Screenwriters from New York City, Writers from New York City, American bloggers

Andrew Klavan (born July 13, 1954) is an American writer, novelist and journalist. Klavan was born Jewish but converted to Christianity.  By his own description, Klavan started out as a liberal Democrat but after the Cold War ended he concluded that Ronald Reagan was the reason that it ended.  And because of that Klavan became a Republican.  In an interview with Dave Rubin, Klavan said that the reason that he was a conservative was that he supported classical liberalism. Klavan has complained about Hollywood movies being too left-wing though he has praised some movies like The Dark Knight and Toy Story 3 for being right-wing.  Klavan was critical of the media saying that it refused to ask necessary questions about the attack on the American embassy in Benghazi.  Klavan also said that Barak Obama didn’t understand economics.  Klavan was also critical of conservatives who opposed the election of Donald Trump.  Klavan also writes for the website The Daily Wire run by Ben Shapiro. Klavan also filmed a video for Prager University about fake news.

[[The Daily Wire]]

CATEGORIES: News media

The Daily Wire is a conservative website run by Ben Shapiro. It was created by Shapiro and Jeremey Boreing when Shapiro still worked at Breitbart News.  It was extremely critical of Donald Trump when Trump was running for President of the United States, though it generally reported on him more positively after he became president.  The Daily Wire has published work by Ben Shapiro, Michael Knowles, Andrew Klavan, Dennis Prager, Michelle Malkin and John Hawkins.  They have promoted Prager University, criticized the media for being too left-wing, and promoted Steven Crowder.

[[Arne Nilsen]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Norwegian politicians

Arne Nilsen (21 January 1924 – 16 April 2020) was a Norwegian politician. He was a member of the Labour Party. He was Minister of Local Government from 1978 to 1979 and Minister of Social Affairs from 1979 to 1981. He was also President of the Odelsting from 1981 to 1985.

Nilsen died in Bergen, Norway on 16 April 2020 at the age of 96.

[[Carlos Contreras Guillaume]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Chilean footballers

Carlos Raúl Contreras Guillén (7 October 1938 – 17 April 2020) was a Chilean football defender. He played for Chile in the 1962 FIFA World Cup. He played for the team from 1959 to 1966. He also played for Club Universidad de Chile to 1958 to 1969. He was born in Santiago, Chile.

Contreras Guillaume died in Puente Alto, Chile on 17 April 2020 of Alzheimer's disease-related problems, aged 81.

[[Luis Parodi Valverde]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Vice Presidents of Ecuador, Engineers, People from Guayaquil

Luis Parodi Valverde (12 August 1936 – 14 April 2020) was an Ecuadorian engineer and politician. He was born in Guayaquil. From 10 August 1988 to 10 August 1992, Parodi Valverde was the Vice President of Ecuador during the Rodrigo Borja Cevallos presidency. He was replaced by Alberto Dahik.

Parodi Valverde died on 14 April 2020 in Guayaquil of a short-illness, aged 83.

[[Eddie Cooley]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2020 deaths, American singer-songwriters, American R&B singers, Singers from Atlanta, Georgia, Writers from Atlanta, Georgia

Edward James Cooley (April 15, 1933 – April 15, 2020) was an American R&B singer-songwriter. He co-wrote the song "Fever" and the 1956 song with "Priscilla". Cooley was born in Atlanta, Georgia. 

Cooley died on April 15, 2020 in Meridian, Mississippi at the age of 87.

Schaffner and it stars Laurence Olivier, Gregory Peck, James Mason, Denholm Elliott and Steve Guttenberg. [[Remy Bonjasky]]

[[Wele-Nzas]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Equatorial Guinea

Wele-Nzas Province is a province in Equatorial Guinea. Its capital is Mongomo. Other major cities include Aconibe, Añisoc, and Nsok.

Two national parks, Altos de Nsork National Park and Monte Temelón Natural Reserve, are in the province.

The city of Mengomeyén is home to the province's main airport, President Obiang Nguema International Airport. 

[[Semivowel]]

CATEGORIES: Language, Linguistics

Semivowels are consonants that almost sound like vowels. In English, the semivowels are written as W and Y (written as /w/ and /j/ in IPA). In Latin, even though semivowels are phonemes, or unique sounds, they have no special letters used to write them. The letters V and I were used to write the sounds /w/ and /j/, and these same letters were also used to write the vowels /u/ and /i/ in the same order. For example, Gaius Julius Caesar was written as Gaivs Ivlivs Caesar and wine was written as vinvm. The letter J was added after the fall of the Roman Empire to write the semivowel /j/ to show the difference between /j/ and /i/.

[[Central Region (Eritrea)]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Eritrea, 1996 establishments in Africa

Central Region is an administrative region (or zoba) in central Eritrea. The capital is Asmara, which is also the capital of Eritrea. The region was formed on 15 April 1996. It is also known as the Ma'ekel or Maakel Region.

The region is divided into subregions:

[[Chicken tikka masala]]

CATEGORIES: Indian food, British food, Chicken as food

Chicken Tikka Masala is a curry in Indian cuisine that is made up of roasted marinated chicken (chicken tikka) in a curry sauce full of spices. Chicken tikka is made up of boneless pieces of chicken marinated in spices and yogurt, then roasted in an oven. The sauce is usually creamy and orange-coloured. Even though a sauce made of tomato and coriander is commonly used, there is no specific recipe for the sauce that everyone uses.

Chicken tikka masala is very popular in the United Kingdom, and it has been called a "true British national dish", as declared by British Minister Robin Cook. It is growing in popularity in the USA and Canada as well. Even though some consider it to have been originated by a Pakistani, the dish is unknown in most Pakistan. It can be found in restaurants in various parts of the world, due to its demand, not authenticity.

The oldest reference to Chicken Tikka Masala is found in 1960s, where a Bangladeshi Chef, Ali Ahmad Aslam, created the dish in his restaurant in Glasgow, on request of a customer who was unhappy with the dry Chicken Tikka.

[[San Martín Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Peru

San Martín is a region in northern Peru. Most of the region is in the upper part of the Peruvian Amazon rainforest. Its capital is Moyobamba and the largest city in the region is Tarapoto.

[[Ucayali Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Peru

Ucayali is a region in Peru. The capital is the city of Pucallpa. It is in the Amazon rainforest and is bordered by the Brazilian state of Acre on the east; the department of Madre de Dios on the southeast; Cusco on the south; Junín, Pasco and Huánuco on the west; and Loreto on the north.

The name Ucayali comes from the Ucayali River.

[[Madre de Dios Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Peru

Madre de Dios is a region in Peru. The capital is the city of Puerto Maldonado. It is on the borders with Brazil and Bolivia. The name Madre de Dios comes from the Madre de Dios River.

[[Lima Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Peru

The Lima Province is a province in the central coast of Peru. It is the only province in the country that does not belong to any of the twenty-five regions. Its capital is Lima, which is also the nation's capital.

[[Steuben County, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1830s establishments in Indiana, 1837 establishments in the United States, Indiana counties

Steuben County is a county in the U.S. state of Indiana. As of 2010, 34,185 people lived there. The county seat is Angola.Steuben County covers roughly 1397 square miles with a population of approximately 100,000 people living in rural agricultural areas, quaint small towns, and small city communities. Many of theirs streets, towns, rivers, and lakes in the area, like Keuka Lake, have names which reflect the influence of the Seneca Indians who lived here long before it became Steuben County.

[[A Change of Seasons (movie)]]

A Change of Seasons is a 1980 comedy drama movie starring Anthony Hopkins, Shirley MacLaine, Bo Derek, Mary Beth Hurt and Michael Brandon. It was directed by Stephen Frears and  written by Erich Segal and was nominated for three Razzies at the 1st Golden Raspberry Awards in 1981. The movie is rated M in New Zealand.

It was distributed by 20th Century Fox with the screenplay by W.D. Richter and based on the 1969 novel Accomplices to the Crime: The Arkansas Prison Scandal by Tom Murton and Joe Hyams.
