The movie and plot reference the Sam Peckinpah 1974 movie Bring Me the Head of Alfredo Garcia.

[[Lucien Szpiro]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, French mathematicians, Deaths from heart failure

Lucien Szpiro (23 December 1941 – 18 April 2020) was a French mathematician. He was known for his work in number theory, arithmetic algebraic geometry, and commutative algebra. He was a Distinguished Professor at the CUNY Graduate Center. He helped create Szpiro's conjecture.

In 2014, he was made a member of the Academia Europaea.

Szpiro died on 18 April 2020 from heart failure in Paris, aged 78.

[[Jesús Vaquero]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish scientists, People from Madrid

Jesús Vaquero Crespo (1950 – 17 April 2020) was a Spanish neurosurgeon. He was a known person on the treatment of medullary injuries. He was born in Madrid. He became chief of Neurosurgery of the Hospital Puerta de Hierro in 1992. He was a professor of the Autonomous University of Madrid (UAM).

Vaquero died on 17 April 2020 due to COVID-19 in Madrid, aged 70.

[[Robin Seymour (DJ)]]

CATEGORIES: People from Detroit, Michigan, American radio personalities, 1926 births, 2020 deaths

Robin Henry Seymour (March 8, 1926 – April 17, 2020) was an American radio personality and disc jockey. He worked at  CKLW and WKMH. He was also the host of the television series Teen Town and Swingin' Time. He was one of the country's longest-serving top ten disc jockeys. Seymour was born in Detroit, Michigan.

Seymour died in San Antonio, Texas on April 17, 2020, at the age of 94.

[[Ulrich Kienzle]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, German journalists, People from Baden-Württemberg

Ulrich Kienzle (9 May 1936 – 16 April 2020) was a German journalist and author. He worked mainly in the area of politics and culture of the Middle East. He worked for many broadcasters, including German public television networks ARD and ZDF. He was one of few Western journalists to interview Muammar Gaddafi in the 1970s. He also interviewed Saddam Hussein in 1990. Kienzle also appeared in Frontal, a ZDF series of political discussions with broadcast journalist Bodo Hugo Hauser.  

Kienzle was born in Neckargröningen, Remseck, Württemberg. He died on 16 April 2020 in Wiesbaden, Hesse. He was 82.

[[Giuseppi Logan]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American jazz musicians, American saxophonists, Musicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Giuseppi Logan (May 22, 1935 – April 17, 2020) was a jazz musician. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He began playing with Earl Bostic and later studied at the New England Conservatory. 

Logan played alto and tenor saxophone, bass clarinet, flute, piano and Pakistani oboe. He collaborated with Archie Shepp, Pharoah Sanders and Bill Dixon. Logan was a member of Byard Lancaster's band and toured with and appeared on records by Patty Waters.

Logan died on April 17, 2020 in New York City from COVID-19, aged 84.

[[Abba Kyari (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria, Nigerian politicians

Abba Kyari OON (23 September 1952 – 17 April 2020) was a Nigerian politician. He was Chief of Staff to President Muhammadu Buhari. He was Chief of Staff from 2015 to 2020. Kyari was born in Borno State, Nigeria.

Kyari was diagnosed with COVID-19 on 24 March 2020 in Lagos, Nigeria. He died from the infection on 17 April 2020, aged 67.

[[Sergio Fantoni]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Actors from Rome

Sergio Fantoni (7 August 1930 – 17 April 2020) was an Italian actor. He was born in Rome. He was known for his role as Haman in Esther and the King. Fantoni was also known for his television role in The Manageress. 

Fantoni died on 17 April 2020 in Rome, aged 89.

[[Henry Grimes]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American jazz musicians, American violinists, American poets, Musicians from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Writers from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Henry Grimes (November 3, 1935 – April 15, 2020) was an American jazz double bassist, violinist, and poet. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. He retired in 1970, however many people thought he died. He started his career again in 2002. 

Grimes performed with most of the music's important names, including pianist Cecil Taylor, trumpeter Don Cherry, saxophonists Steve Lacy, Pharoah Sanders, Archie Shepp, and Albert Ayler. He released one album, The Call, as a trio leader for the ESP-Disk record label in 1965. 

Grimes died on April 15, 2020 of COVID-19 in New York City, aged 84.

[[Margit Feldman]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American educators, American political activists, Holocaust survivors, Hungarian Jews, People from Budapest

Margit Buchhalter Feldman (June 12, 1929 – April 14, 2020) was a Hungarian-American public speaker, educator, activist, and Holocaust survivor. Feldman and her family put in a concentration camp in 1944, where her parents were killed. She survived after lying about her age, in which the Nazis put her in a work camp. She was freed from Bergen-Belsen concentration camp on April 15, 1945. She was born in Budapest.

Feldman died on April 14, 2020 in Somerset, New Jersey of COVID-19, aged 90.

[[Susanna Ramel]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2020 deaths, Swedish movie actors, Swedish television actors, Swedish stage actors, Centenarians, Actors from Stockholm

Susanna Ragnarsdotter Ramel (née Östberg; previously Gillgren) (1 April 1920 – 4 April 2020) was a Swedish actress. She appeared in many movies like Skanör-Falsterbo (1939) and Livet på en pinne (1942). Her daughter is actress Lotta Ramel. She was born in Stockholm. She starred in the 1986 television series Affären Ramel. 

Ramel turned 100 on 1 April 2020. She died three days later in Stockholm.

[[Eagle, Colorado]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Colorado, County seats in Colorado

Eagle is a statutory town that is the county seat of Eagle County, Colorado, United States. The population was 6,508 at the 2010 census. 

[[Big Trouble in Little China]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy movies, 1986 action movies, 1980s fantasy movies, American action movies, Movies directed by John Carpenter, Trucker movies

Big Trouble in Little China is a 1986 American action fantasy comedy movie directed by John Carpenter and stars Kurt Russell, Kim Cattrall, James Hong, and Dennis Dun. It was written by W.D. Richter and was a commercial failure upon release and since has become a cult classic. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Dennis G. Peters]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, American chemists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Scientists from Los Angeles, California, Scientists from Indiana, Writers from Los Angeles, California, Writers from Indiana, People from Bloomington, Indiana

Dennis Gail Peters (April 17, 1937 – April 13, 2020) was an American analytical chemist. He worked in electrochemistry and was named the Herman T. Briscoe Professor at Indiana University in 1975. Peters' research focused on the electrochemical behavior of halogenated organic compounds. He authored over 210 publications and 5 analytical chemistry textbooks. He was born in Los Angeles, California.

Peters died of COVID-19 on April 13, 2020 in Bloomington, Indiana at the age of 82.

[[Bob Lazier]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American racecar drivers, Sportspeople from Minneapolis, Minnesota

Robert Lazier (December 22, 1938 – April 18, 2020) was an American race car driver. He raced in the CART series in 1981 and was CART's Rookie of the Year. He had fourth-place finishes at Watkins Glen International and Mexico. Lazier also competed in the 1981 Indianapolis 500, finishing 19th after a blown engine caused him to retire the Penske PC-7 after 154 laps. He competed in Formula 5000 in the 1970s.

Lazier was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota. He died on April 18, 2020 from COVID-19 during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, aged 81.

Year of the Gun is a 1991 political thriller movie directed by John Frankenheimer and based on the novel of the same name by Michael Mewshaw. It stars Sharon Stone, Andrew McCarthy, Valeria Golino and John Pankow.

[[Looking for Mr. Goodbar (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 drama movies, 1970s LGBT movies, 1970s crime drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Richard Brooks

Looking for Mr. Goodbar is a 1977 crime drama movie based on the book of the same name by Judith Rossner. It was directed by Richard Brooks and stars Diane Keaton, Tuesday Weld, William Atherton, Richard Gere, LeVar Burton, Brian Dennehy and Tom Berenger. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures and was nominated for two Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1978.

[[Flag of Yugoslavia]]

CATEGORIES: Yugoslavia, National flags

The flag of Yugoslavia was adopted in 1946 and abandoned in 1992. It features a horizontal triband of blue, white and red with a gold-bordered red star in the center.

[[The Goat Horn]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 drama movies, Bulgarian movies

The Goat Horn (Козият рог, translit. Koziyat rog) is a 1972 Bulgarian drama movie set in 17th century Bulgaria during the Ottoman Empire. It was directed by Metodi Andonov and stars Anton Gorchev and Katya Paskaleva.

[[Flag of Serbia and Montenegro]]

CATEGORIES: Serbia, Montenegro, National flags

The flag of Serbia and Montenegro was originally adopted on 27 April 1992 as the flag of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and was used as such from 1992 to 2003. After the country was renamed to the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro in February 2003, it was still used as the national flag until the country's dissolution in June 2006. Aside from a different aspect ratio, it is almost the same flag that used by the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (1943–1992) but without the red star in the center. It was like an inverted Dutch flag.

All the Way Up is a 1970 British comedy movie based on the 1962 play Semi-Detached and was directed by James MacTaggart and starred Warren Mitchell, Pat Heywood, Richard Briers, Terence Alexander, Frank Thornton and Larry Dann.

[[Bob Miller (baseball, born 1926)]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, American baseball players, Philadelphia Phillies players, Sportspeople from Detroit, Michigan

Robert John Miller (June 16, 1926 – November 27, 2020) was an American professional baseball player. He was a right-handed pitcher. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1949 to 1958 for the Philadelphia Phillies. He was a member of the 1950 "Whiz Kids", only the second Phillies team to win a National League (NL) pennant. He was born in Detroit, Michigan.

Miller died on November 27, 2020, in West Bloomfield Township, Michigan. He was 94.

It stars Nicholas Rowe, Alan Cox, Sophie Ward, Anthony Higgins, Susan Fleetwood and Freddie Jones and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1986.

It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[European polecat]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of Europe, CS1 maint: Multiple names: authors list, Mustelids

The European polecat (Mustela putorius)  is a species of mustelid native to western Eurasia and north Morocco. It is also known as  common ferret, black or forest polecat, foumart, or fitch.  It is dark brown , with a pale underbelly and a dark mask across the face. Occasionally, there are other color variations, such as albinos. The family it is in also contains minks and other weasels.  Compared to them,  the polecat has a shorter, more compact body; a more powerfully built skull and teeth;  and is less agile. It is well known for its ability to secrete a particularly foul-smelling liquid to mark its territory.

It is much less territorial than other mustelid. Animals of the same sex frequently share home ranges. Like other mustelids, the European polecat is polygamous, with pregnancy occurring after mating, with no induced ovulation. It usually gives birth in early summer to litters consisting of five to ten kits, which become independent at the age of two to three months. The European polecat feeds on small rodents, birds, amphibians and reptiles. It occasionally cripples its prey by piercing its brain with its teeth and stores it, still living, in its burrow for future consumption.

The European polecat originated in Western Europe during the Middle Pleistocene. its closest living relatives are the steppe polecat, the black-footed ferret and the European mink.  It can produce fertile offspring with the steppe polecat and the black-footed ferret. Hybrids of polecat and mink  tend to be sterile, and are distinguished from their parent species by their larger size and more valuable pelts.

The European polecat is the only ancestor of the ferret, which was domesticated more than 2000 years ago for hunting vermin. The species has otherwise been historically viewed negatively by humans. In the British Isles especially, the polecat was persecuted by gamekeepers, and became synonymous with promiscuity in early English literature. During modern times, the polecat is still scantly represented in popular culture when compared to other rare British mammals, and misunderstandings of its behaviour still persist in some rural areas. 2008, it is classed by the IUCN as Least Concern due to its wide range and large numbers.

[[White County, Indiana]]

White County is a county in the U.S. state of Indiana. As of 2010, 24,643 people lived there. The county seat is Monticello.

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Indiana, 1844 establishments in the United States, Indiana counties

Ohio County is a county in the U.S. state of Indiana. As of 2010, 6,128 people lived there and has an area of 87.43 which makes it the smallest county in Indiana in both area and population. The county seat and only incorporated municipality is Rising Sun. The county was created in 1844.

[[Brunsbüttel]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Schleswig-Holstein

Brunsbüttel is a town of the district of Dithmarschen, in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It is the location of the western entrance to the Kiel Canal, the busiest artificial waterway in the world. As of 31 December 2018, 12,554 people lived there.

[[Keith Thomas (historian)]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Academics of the University of Oxford, British academics, British historians, Companions of Honour, Knights Bachelor, Welsh writers

Sir Keith Vivian Thomas GBR (born 2 January 1933) is a Welsh historian. His area of focus is the history of the early modern world. He is best known for writing Religion and the Decline of Magic and Man and the Natural World. From 1986 to 2000, he was president of Corpus Christi College, Oxford.

Thomas was born in Wick, Glamorgan. He is married to Lady Valerie Thomas and has two children.

[[Sullivan County, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Indiana, 1844 establishments in the United States, Indiana counties

Tipton County is a county in the U.S. state of Indiana, north of the state capital of Indianapolis. As of 2010, 15,936 people lived there which is a decrease of 3.9% from 16,577 in 2000. The county seat is Tipton.

[[Sean Arnold]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Actors from Gloucestershire, English movie actors, English television actors

Sean Arnold (30 January 1941 – 15 April 2020) was an English actor. He is best known for his roles as Mr Llewelyn in the children's TV series Grange Hill and as Barney Crozier in the BBC series Bergerac. He also appeared in TV's James the Cat and Merseybeat. His movie credits include North Sea Hijack (1979), Remembrance (1982), Haunters of the Deep (1984), Speaking of the Devil (1991) and Red Rose (2004).

Arnold was born in Wickwar, Gloucestershire. He died on 15 April 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Vanderburgh County, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1818 establishments in Indiana, Indiana counties

Vanderburgh County is a county in the U.S. state of Indiana. As of 2010, 179,703 people lived there which makes it the seventh-largest county by population in the state. The county seat is Evansville. It is also the eighth-smallest county by area in Indiana. The county was founded on January 7, 1818.

[[Gash-Barka Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Eritrea

Gash-Barka is a region in Eritrea. The capital city is Barentu. Other towns include Agordat (the former capital), Molki, Sebderat and Teseney. 

The region also includes the following subregions: 

[[Southern Region (Eritrea)]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Eritrea, 1996 establishments in Africa

Southern Region is a region of Eritrea. It is also known as Debub Region. The capital city is Mendefera. The region was formed on 15 April 1996, from the historical provinces of Serae and Akele Guzai.

Mount Soira 3018, the highest point in Eritrea, is in the region.

The region has the following subregions:

[[Northern Red Sea Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Eritrea, 1996 establishments in Africa

The Northern Red Sea Region is a region in Eritrea. The capital city is Massawa.

It is along the northern three quarters of the Red Sea, and includes the Dahlak Archipelago. The lowest point in Eritrea, Lake Kulul, is in this region.

The region also includes the following subregions: 

[[Southern Red Sea Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Eritrea, 1996 establishments in Africa

The Southern Red Sea Region is a region of Eritrea. The capital city is Assab.

The Southern Red Sea Region extends over 500 along Red Sea coast but is only around 50 wide. It forms the major part of the Danakil Desert.

The region has the following subregions: Are'eta Subregion, Central Denkalya Subregion and Southern Denkalya Subregion.

[[Rikhakot]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in India

Rikhakot is a village in Nainital district, Uttarakhand, India. It has the population of 479 people.

[[Supersessionism]]

Superssessionism is the idea that one religion was true but that it stopped being true after another religion showed up to supersede it. For example, Christianity believes that Judaism was true once but that because the Jews rejected Jesus they stopped being the Chosen People and that the New Testament and a faith-based religion replaced Jewish Law.  Islam also believes that God gave the Torah (or something similar to it) to the Israelites at Mount Sinai but that the Quran ultimately replaced it. 

[[Convent, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Louisiana, Parish seats in Louisiana

Convent is a census-designated place in Louisiana in the United States. It is the parish seat of St. James Parish.

[[ǁKaras Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Namibia

ǁKaras is a region in Namibia. The capital is Keetmanshoop. It was originally called "Karas Region" until the name was changed in August 2013 to include the "ǁ" symbol.

Aletta Fredericks became Governor in 2020.

The Karas mountain range is in the southern part. Fish River Canyon is also in the region.

There are 7  constituencies:

[[Heiligenstedtenerkamp]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Schleswig-Holstein, Steinburg (district)

Heiligenstedtenerkamp is a municipality of the district Steinburg, in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It is the municipality with the second longest name in Germany with its 21 characters, after Gottfriedingerschwaige with its 22 characters.

[[Brokdorf]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Schleswig-Holstein, Steinburg (district)

Brokdorf is a municipality of the district Steinburg, in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. The Brokdorf Nuclear Power Plant is in the municipality.

[[Khomas Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Namibia

Khomas is a region in Namibia. The capital is Windhoek, which is also the national capital of Namibia.

There are 10 constituencies:

[[Kunene Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Namibia

Kunene is a region in Namibia. The capital city is Opuwo.

The name comes from the Kunene River. It forms the northern border with Angola. Kunene's western edge is the Atlantic Ocean.

The region has seven constituencies:

[[Omusati Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Namibia

Omusati is a region in Namibia. The capital city is Outapi.

The region is home to the Ruacana Falls. Omusati is also home to the Omugulugwombashe Heritage Site. This is where the Namibian struggle for independence started in 1966.

The region has twelve constituencies:

[[Zombie High]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 comedy movies, 1987 horror movies, American horror movies, American comedy movies

Zombie High (also known as The School That Ate My Brain) is a 1987 horror comedy movie directed by Ron Link and stars Virginia Madsen, Paul Feig, Sherilyn Fenn, Clare Carey and Scott Coffey.

[[Less Than Zero (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 romance movies, 1987 drama movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, 1980s LGBT movies, American romantic drama movies, American LGBT movies

Less Than Zero is a 1987 drama movie directed by Marek Kanievska and is adapted from the Bret Easton Ellis 1985 novel of the same name. It stars Andrew McCarthy, James Spader, Robert Downey Jr., and Jami Gertz. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Black Widow (1987 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 crime movies, 1980s mystery movies, 1980s thriller movies, American crime thriller movies

Black Widow is a 1987 mystery crime thriller movie directed by Bob Rafelson and stars Debra Winger, Theresa Russell, Sami Frey, Dennis Hopper, and Terry O'Quinn. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Stardust Memories]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies directed by Woody Allen

Stardust Memories is a 1980 comedy drama movie directed by Woody Allen (who also stars) and starring Charlotte Rumping, Daniel Stern, Sharon Stone, Jessica Harper, and Cynthia Gibb. It was distributed by United Artists.

[[Down by Law (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy movies, 1980s road movies, American comedy movies, German movies, Movies directed by Jim Jarmusch, American independent movies

Down by Law is a 1986 independent movie directed by Jim Jarmusch and stars Tom Waits, John Lurie, Roberto Benigni, and Ellen Barkin. It was distributed by Island Pictures.

[[He Said, She Said]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 comedy movies, 1991 romance movies, 1990s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by Ken Kwapis

He Said, She Said is a 1991 romantic comedy movie directed by Ken Kwapis and Marisa Silver and stars Kevin Bacon, Elizabeth Perkins, Nathan Lane, Sharon Stone, and Anthony LaPaglia. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Children of a Lesser God]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 drama movies, 1986 romance movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, American romantic drama movies, American independent movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Randa Haines

Children of a Lesser God is a 1986 romantic drama movie directed by Randa Haines and based on the Tony Award winning stage play of the same name by Mark Medoff. It stars Marlee Matlin in her Oscar winning role, William Hurt, Piper Laurie, Philip Bosco and it was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Cobra (1986 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 action movies, American action movies, Movies based on books, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by George P. Cosmatos

Cobra is a 1986 action movie. It was directed by George P. Cosmatos. The movie is based on the 1978 novel Fair Game by Paula Gosling. It was remade in 1995 as Fair Game. Cobra stars Sylvester Stallone, Brigitte Nielsen, Reni Santoni, Brian Thompson, and John Herzfeld. It was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Chinese food]]

CATEGORIES: Chinese food

Chinese food is a term that talks about the food that comes from all over China and the cuisine of China. It is an important part of Chinese culture. This food comes from many different parts of China and also the food made by Overseas Chinese that live in other parts of the world. Because there are a lot of Chinese immigrants around the world, and because China was very important in the past, many food from other countries in Asia have been affected by Chinese food. Important parts of Chinese food are rice, soy sauce, noodles, tea, and tofu. Tools like chopsticks and the wok are also very important.

The four most important types of Chinese food are Sichuan food (Chuan), Shandong food (Lu), Guangdong food (Yue), and Huaiyang food. They each represent the food made in the western, northern, southern, and eastern parts of the country.

[[Never Cry Wolf (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 drama movies, 1980s adventure movies, Disney movies, Movies based on books

Never Cry Wolf is a 1983 adventure drama movie directed by Carroll Ballard and is based on the 1963 autobiographical novel by Farley Mowat. It stars Brian Dennehy and Charles Martin Smith and was distributed by Walt Disney Studios.

[[Alipur, Delhi]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in India, Delhi

Alipur is a town in the state of Delhi, India. In 2001, there were 16,623 people living there.

[[Nighthawks (1981 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 action movies, 1980s crime movies, 1981 thriller movies, American action thriller movies

Nighthawks is a 1981 action thriller movie directed by Bruce Malmuth and stars Sylvester Stallone, Billy Dee Williams, Lindsay Wagner, Nigel Davenport, Rutger Hauer, and Robert Pugh. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Bad Timing]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 drama movies, 1980s erotic movies, British drama movies, Movies directed by Nicolas Roeg

Bad Timing is a 1980 British psychological drama movie directed by Nicolas Roeg. It stars Harvey Keitel, Art Garfunkel, Theresa Russell, Denholm Elliott and Daniel Massey.

[[Blue Collar (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, 1970s crime drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies directed by Paul Schrader

Blue Collar is a 1978 crime drama movie directed by first time director Paul Schrader and stars Harvey Keitel, Yaphet Kotto and Richard Pryor. It was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Stir Crazy (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 comedy movies, 1980s criminal comedy movies, American comedy movies

Stir Crazy is a 1980 American comedy movie directed by Sidney Poitier, produced by Hannah Weinstein and stars Gene Wilder, Richard Pryor, JoBeth Williams, Craig T. Nelson, and Barry Corbin. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and was a major success led to the unsuccessful TV series by CBS in 1985.

[[Peter Beard]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, American photographers, Diarists, Unexplained deaths, Writers from New York

Peter Hill Beard (January 22, 1938 – March 31 or April 2020) was an American artist, photographer, diarist and writer. He lived and worked in New York and Kenya. His photographs of Africa and African animals were widely shown and published since the 1960s.

Beard was born in New York. He was married three times. His second wife was supermodel Cheryl Tiegs. He had a child with his third wife.

On March 31, 2020, Beard wandered away from his home in Montauk, New York. At the time of his disappearance, he was suffering from dementia and ill health after a stroke. On April 19, 2020, he was found dead in a wooded area by a hunter. He was 82.

[[Brewster's Millions (1985 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Walter Hill

Brewster's Millions is a 1985 sports comedy movie directed by Walter Hill and it is seventh adaption of the 1902 novel of the same name by George Barr McCutcheon. The movie stars Alec Baldwin, John Goodman, Jerry Orbach, Lonette McKee and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Harry Davenport (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1866 births, 1949 deaths, American movie actors, American silent movie actors, American stage actors, Actors from Pennsylvania, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Harold George Bryant Davenport (January 19, 1866 – August 9, 1949) was an American actor. His roles include Dr. Meade in Gone with the Wind (1939) and Grandpa in Meet Me in St. Louis (1944).

[[Canton, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania

Canton is a borough in Bradford County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 1,976 at the 2010 census.

[[Towanda, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania, County seats in Pennsylvania

Towanda is a borough and the county seat of Bradford County in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania. It is located 66 northwest of Wilkes-Barre. As of the 2010 census the population of Towanda was 2,919.

[[Trevor Platt]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, British biologists, People from Greater Manchester

Trevor Charles Platt, FRS, FRSC (August 12, 1942 – April 6, 2020) was a British biological oceanographer. He was known for his fundamental works to quantifying primary production by phytoplankton at many scales of space and time in the ocean. He was born in Salford, Greater Manchester, England. 

Platt worked with the Partnership for Observation of the Global Ocean (POGO). He was a visiting Professor there in 2005, and then as its Executive Director from 2008 to 2015.

Platt died on April 6, 2020 in Plymouth, Devon, England at the age of 77.

[[Jean-François Bazin]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, French politicians, French journalists

Jean-François Bazin (26 July 1942 – 17 April 2020) was a French politician, journalist, and writer. He was born in Dijon, France. Bazin was Municipal Councillor for Dijon from 1971 to 2008. A journalist, he worked for Les Echos, Le Moniteur Universel, Le Nouvel Économiste, and Le Spectacle du Monde. 

Bazin died on 17 April 2020 in Dijon, aged 77.

[[Mr. Smith Goes to Washington]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 movies, American comedy-drama movies, English-language movies, Movies directed by Frank Capra

Mr. Smith Goes to Washington is a 1939 American political comedy-drama movie directed by Frank Capra. It stars Jean Arthur and James Stewart, and featuring Claude Rains, Harry Carey and Edward Arnold. The movie is about a newly appointed United States Senator who fights against a corrupt political system. It was written by Sidney Buchman, based on Lewis R. Foster's unpublished story "The Gentleman from Montana". 

The movie was controversial when it was first released, but successful at the box office, and it made Stewart a major star. It was also loosely based on the life of Montana U.S. Senator Burton Wheeler.

Mr. Smith Goes to Washington was nominated for eleven Academy Awards, winning for Best Original Story. It is thought to be one of the greatest movies of all time. It was selected by the Library of Congress for preservation in the United States National Film Registry in 1989.

[[Burton K. Wheeler]]

CATEGORIES: 1882 births, 1975 deaths, American lawyers, United States senators from Montana, Politicians from Massachusetts, US Democratic Party politicians

Burton Kendall Wheeler (February 27, 1882spaced ndashJanuary 6, 1975) was an American politician and lawyer. He was a member of the Democratic Party in Montana. He was a United States Senator from 1923 until 1947. He was Robert M. La Follette's running mate for the 1924 election.

[[Montauk, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in New York (state)

Montauk (ˈ MON) is a census-designated place (CDP) in Suffolk County, New York, on the eastern end of the South Shore of Long Island. As of the 2010 United States Census, the CDP's population was 3,326.

[[Some Girls (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 comedy movies, 1988 drama movies, 1988 romance movies, American romantic comedy movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies directed by Michael Hoffman

Some Girls is a 1988 coming of age romantic comedy drama movie directed by Michael Hoffman and stars Patrick Dempsey, Jennifer Connelly, Sheila Kelley. It was distributed by United Artists.

[[Ronald J. Kurth]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, American educators, American military personnel of the Vietnam War, People from Madison, Wisconsin

Ronald James Kurth (July 1, 1931 – April 10, 2020) was a rear admiral of the United States Navy. His career included service in the Cold War and Vietnam War. He was a naval aviator and Russian area studies scholar fluent in the Russian language. He was Chief of Naval Operations from 1981 to 1983 and was President of the Naval War College from 1987 to 1990. 

Kurth was born in Madison, Wisconsin. He died on April 10, 2020 at the age of 88.

[[John A. Baldwin Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, American military personnel of the Vietnam War, American educators, People from Baltimore, Maryland

John Ashby Baldwin Jr. (born April 20, 1933) is a vice admiral of the United States Navy. He was active during the Cold War.  

He commanded destroyers and a carrier battle group. He worked on the staffs of the Chief of Naval Operations, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Secretary of the Navy, and the Secretary of Defense.

He was President of the Naval War College and of the National Defense University from 1986 to 1987.

[[Edmond Baraffe]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, French footballers, French football managers

Edmond Baraffe (19 October 1942 – 19 April 2020) was a French professional football striker and manager. He was born in Annoeulin, France. He played for the national team from 1964 to 1966. He also played for Toulouse. He managed Le Touquet from 1985 to 1989. 

Baraffe died on 19 April 2020, aged 77.

[[2020 Nova Scotia attacks]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 in North America, 2020s crimes in North America, 21st century in Canada, April 2020 events, Mass murder in 2020, Mass murder in North America, Mass shootings in North America, Mass shootings in the 2020s, Murder in Canada, Nova Scotia

On April 18–19, 2020, fifty-one-year-old Gabriel Wortman committed multiple shootings and set fires at 16 places in the Canadian province of Nova Scotia. He killed twenty-two people and injured three others before the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) shot and killed him in Enfield.

The attack lasted for thirteen hours. Wortman impersonated a police officer for part of the attack by driving a car he had made to look like a police car and wearing a police uniform. The killings were not terrorism, but police do not yet know the reason Wortman did these killings. He had guns even though he didn't have a licence, so police are trying to find out how he got the guns.

Police did not use Canada's Alert Ready system, which could have sent messages to the phones of people in the area of Wortman to stay inside. Many people think they should have used it, and police are trying to find out why it wasn't used. 

It is the deadliest attack of its kind in Canadian history.

[[Noach Dear]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Noach Dear (November 20, 1953 – April 19, 2020) was an American attorney, Democratic politician, and jurist. He was a New York Supreme Court judge. Dear was elected in 2008 as a civil court judge, in 2010 as an Acting Supreme Court Justice. In 2015, he was made a permanent justice to the court. He was a member of the New York City Council from 1983 to 2001.

Dear was born in New York City. He died on April 19, 2020 of COVID-19 in New York City, aged 66.

[[Papyrus Fouad 266]]

CATEGORIES: 1st-century BC biblical manuscripts, Septuagint manuscripts

Papyrus Fouad 266 (signed as LXXP. Fouad Inv. 266; Rahlfs 847, 848 and 940;  TM nr: 62290; LDAB id: 3451: VH: 0056) is a copy of the Book of Deuteronomy in Koine Greek of the Hebrew Bible known as the Septuagint. It is a papyrus manuscript in roll form. The manuscript has been assigned palaeographically to the 1st century BC (50 BCE). The manuscript has survived in a fragmentary condition. It has been discussed whether if this manuscript is or is not a later recension of the standard Septuagint text.

[[Claude Lafortune]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Canada, Canadian television presenters, Canadian sculptors, Costume designers, People from Montreal

Claude Lafortune (5 July 1936 – 19 April 2020) was a Canadian television host and artist. He was born in Montreal, Quebec. He had an exhibit dedicated to his work, Colle, papier, ciseaux, at the Musée des cultures du monde in Nicolet, Quebec. He hosted the children's television show Sol et Gobelet from 1968 to 1971.

Lafortune died on 19 April 2020 in Longueuil, Quebec of COVID-19, aged 83.

[[Papyrus Oxyrhynchus 3522]]

CATEGORIES: 1st-century BC biblical manuscripts, Septuagint manuscripts

The Papyrus LXX Oxyrhynchus 3522, (signed as P.Oxy.L 3522: Rahlfs 857) – is a small fragment of the Greek Septuagint (LXX) written on papyrus. It is a scroll. This manuscript was discovered at Oxyrhynchus, about160 south of Cairo. It has been catalogued with the number 3522. Palaeographically it has been dated to the 1st century CE.

This fragment contains Job 42,11-12, and the tetragrammaton in paleo-Hebrew (). According to Philip Wesley Comfort, YHWH was written from right to left.

Greek text according to A. R. Meyer:

κ]αι εθαυμασαν οσα επ[ηγα

γε]ν ο  επαυτον εδ[ωκε

δε ]αυτω εκαστος αμναδα μι

αν] και τετραχμον χρυσουν

α]σημον ο δε ‎‎ ευλογη

σ]εν τα εσχατα ϊωβ η τα [εμ

π]ροσθεν ην δε τα κτ[ηνη

αυτου προβα]τα μυρια[ τε 232

[[Philippe Nahon]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors, French voice actors, Actors from Paris

Philippe Nahon (na.ɔ̃; 24 December 1938 – 19 April 2020) was a French actor. He was born in Paris. His best known roles were in High Tension, I Stand Alone and in Calvaire. He also starred as the nameless butcher in three movies by Gaspar Noé – Carne, I Stand Alone, and Irréversible (cameo).

Nahon died of COVID-19 in Paris on 19 April 2020, aged 81.

[[Alexander Vustin]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Russian composers

Alexander Kuzmich Vustin, also Voustin or Wustin (Алекса́ндр Кузьми́ч Ву́стин, 24 April 1943 – 19 April 2020) was a Russian composer. His best known opera was The Devil in Love. His career began in 1962. He also worked for the BBC Symphony Orchestra. 

Vustin died on 19 April 2020 from pneumonia, aged 76.

[[Jo Jo Dancer, Your Life Is Calling]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 comedy movies, 1986 drama movies, 1980s biographical movies, American movies

Jo Jo Dancer, Your Life Is Calling is a 1986 biographical comedy drama movie directed by and starring Richard Pryor as Jo Jo Dancer a popular stand up comedian, who is burned himself alive while freebasing cocaine.

[[Ha Jae-se]]

CATEGORIES: 1885 births, 1944 deaths, Korean educators, Civil rights activists

Ha Jae-se(河在世, August 26, 1885 ~ January 28, 1944) is a Confucian and educator of the Korean Empire. It is a direct descendant of Sir. Ha Yeon, who was an able premier and a prime minister during the Sejong the Great period.

[[The Last American Hero]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 drama movies, American sports drama movies

The Last American Hero (also known as Hard Driver) is a 1973 sports drama movie based on the true story NASCAR driver Junior Johnson. It was directed by Lamont Johnson and stars Jeff Bridges, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Ned Beatty, Gary Busey, Ed Lauter and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Boxcar Bertha]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 drama movies, 1970s crime drama movies, 1970s romance movies, American crime drama movies, Movies directed by Martin Scorsese, Movies based on books

Boxcar Bertha is a low budget 1972 romantic crime drama based on the novel Sister of the Road by Ben L. Reitman. It was directed by Martin Scorsese, produced by Roger Corman and starred Barbara Hershey, David Carradine, John Carradine, Barry Primus, and Bernie Carey.

[[Lady Sings the Blues (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Sidney J. Furie

Lady Sings the Blues is a 1972 biographical drama movie about jazz singer Billie Holiday and was directed by Sidney J. Furie and stars Diana Ross, Richard Pryor, and Billy Dee Williams. It was nominated for 5 Oscars in 1973.

[[Lars Ahlfors]]

CATEGORIES: 1907 births, 1996 deaths, Academics, Finnish scientists, Mathematicians, People from Helsinki, Wolf Prize winners

Lars Valerian Ahlfors (18 April 1907 – 11 October 1996) was a Finnish mathematician known for his work in the field of complex analysis.

[[Kiyoshi Oka]]

CATEGORIES: 1901 births, 1978 deaths, People from Osaka, Japanese mathematicians, Kyoto University alumni, Kyoto University faculty

Kiyoshi Oka was a Japanese mathematician who made the theory of complex analysis with several variables. Therefore, there are some theorems named after him in this field.

[[Green Army]]

CATEGORIES: History of Ukraine

The Green Army was an organisation of militias in Ukraine during the Russian Civil War. They occupied small parts of land, but rarely launched actual campaings against any of the sides. They never achieved their goal of gaining Ukrainian independance. They dissolved in 1922 after the Soviet Union was established.

[[Amberg (CDP), Wisconsin]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Wisconsin

Amberg is a census-designated place (CDP) in Wisconsin in the United States.

[[Kavango East]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s establishments in Africa, 2013 establishments, Regions of Namibia

Kavango East is a region in Namibia. The capital is Rundu. The region was created in 2013, when the Kavango Region was split into Kavango East and Kavango West.

The region has the western half of the Caprivi Strip.

There are 6 constituencies:

[[Heherson Alvarez]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Philippines, Filipino politicians

Heherson "Sonny"  Turingan Alvarez (October 16, 1939 – April 20, 2020) was a Filipino politician. He was born in Santiago, Isabela. He served as a member of the House of Representatives (1998–2001) and the Senate of the Philippines (1987–1998). Alvarez was also Minister of Agrarian Reform (1986–1987) and Secretary of Environment and Natural Resources (2001–2002). 

On April 20, 2020, during the 2019–20 coronavirus pandemic, Alvarez died of COVID-19. He was 80.

[[Rudratej Singh]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, 2020 deaths, BMW, Cardiovascular disease deaths in India, Chief executives, Deaths from cardiac arrest, Indian businesspeople, People from New Delhi

Rudratej Singh (1973 or 1974 – 20 April 2020) was an Indian businessman. He was the first Indian president and CEO of BMW India from 2019 until his death in 2020. Singh is also known for positions as global president of Royal Enfield (India) and vice-president of Unilever in Singapore.

Singh grew up in New Delhi. On 20 April 2020, he died due to cardiac arrest at the age of 46.

[[The Other Side of Midnight (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 drama movies, 1970s romance movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Charles Jarrott

The Other Side of Midnight is a 1977 drama movie directed by Charles Jarrott and adapted from the 1973 novel of the same name by Sidney Sheldon. It stars Susan Sarandon, John Beck, Marie-France Pisier, Clu Gulager, Christian Marquand and was nominated for an Oscar in 1978. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Cries and Whispers]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 drama movies, Swedish movies, Swedish-language movies, Movies directed by Ingmar Bergman

Cries and Whispers (Whispers and Cries) is a 1972 Swedish period drama movie directed by Ingmar Bergman and stars Harriet Andersson, Liv Ullmann, Kari Sylwan, Ingrid Thulin. It was nominated for 5 Oscars and won for Best Cinematography in 1974.

[[Paul Scully-Power]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, Living people, American astronauts, Australian astronauts, NASA, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Oceanographers, Order of Australia, People from Sydney

Paul Desmond Scully-Power AM (born 28 May 1944) is an Australian-American oceanographer and astronaut. In 1984, he flew aboard NASA Space Shuttle mission STS-41-G as a payload specialist. At the time, he was a civilian employee of the United States Naval Undersea Warfare Center. He was the first Australian-born person to journey into space. He was also the first astronaut with a beard.

During his time in space, Scully-Power was able to confirm spiral eddies existed. He also saw them with the naked eye.

Scully-Power was born in Sydney, New South Wales. He is married and has six children.

[[Andy Thomas]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, American astronauts, American engineers, Australian astronauts, NASA, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Oceanographers, Order of Australia, People from Adelaide

Andrew Sydney Withiel Thomas AO (born 18 December 1951) is an Australian-American aerospace engineer and NASA astronaut. He flew aboard a number of Space Shuttle missions. He has 177 days logged in space. His first mission was STS-77 (1996). His final mission was STS-114 (2005), the first Space Shuttle mission following the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster of 2003.

Thomas was born in Adelaide, South Australia. He is married to fellow astronaut Shannon Walker.

[[Sunday Bloody Sunday]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 drama movies, 1970s LGBT movies, British drama movies, Movies directed by John Schlesinger

Sunday Bloody Sunday is a 1971 British drama movie directed by John Schlesinger and written by Penelope Gilliatt. It stars Peter Finch, Glenda Jackson, Murray Head, Peggy Ashcroft, and Daniel Day-Lewis. It was nominated for four Oscars in 1972 and was distributed by United Artists.

[[Eliza Scanlen]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 births, Living people, Actors from Sydney, Australian movie actors, Australian stage actors, Australian television actors, Twin people from Australia

Eliza Jane Scanlen (born 6 January 1999) is an Australian actress. She first became known for her role as Tabitha Ford in the Seven Network soap opera Home and Away (2016). She then notably played Amma Crellin in the HBO miniseries Sharp Objects (2018). Her movie credits include Babyteeth (2019), Little Women (2019) and The Devil All the Time (2020).

Scanlen was born in Sydney, New South Wales. She has a fraternal twin sister named Annabel.

[[Stephen Amell]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, Actors from Toronto, Canadian movie actors, Canadian movie producers, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors

Stephen Adam Amell (born May 8, 1981) is a Canadian actor and producer. He is best known for playing Oliver Queen / Green Arrow in The CW superhero series Arrow (2012–2020). He has also appeared as the character in The Flash (2014–2019), Vixen (2015–2016), DC's Legends of Tomorrow (2016–2020),  Supergirl (2017–2019) and Batwoman (2019). His other credits include the HBO series Hung (2011) and the movies Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016) and Code 8 (2019).

Amell was born in Toronto, Ontario. He is a first cousin of actor Robbie Amell. He was married to Carolyn Lawrence from 2007 to 2010. He married actress and model Cassandra Jean in 2012. The couple's daughter was born in 2013.

[[Robbie Amell]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, Actors from Toronto, Canadian child actors, Canadian movie actors, Canadian movie producers, Canadian television actors, Canadian voice actors, Naturalized citizens of the United States

Robert Patrick Amell IV (born April 21, 1988) is a Canadian actor and producer. He is known for playing Stephen Jameson in The CW series The Tomorrow People (2013–2014) and Ronnie Raymond / Firestorm in The CW series The Flash (2014–2017). 

Amell also played Fred Jones in the movies Scooby-Doo! The Mystery Begins and Scooby-Doo! Curse of the Lake Monster, and Max in The Babysitter (2017) and, its sequel, The Babysitter: Killer Queen (2020). His other TV roles include series such as Life with Derek, True Jackson, VP, Unnatural History and Revenge. His movie other credits The Hunters (2013), The DUFF (2015) and Code 8 (2019).

Amell was born in Toronto, Ontario. He is a first cousin of actor Stephen Amell. He is married to fellow Canadian actor Italia Ricci. The couple have a son. In January 2020, Amell and Ricci became citizens of the United States.

[[Arsen Yegiazarian]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2020 deaths, Armenian sportspeople, Chess grandmasters, People from Yerevan

Arsen Yegiazarian (Արսեն Եղիազարյան; 18 May 1970 – 20 April 2020) was an Armenian chess player. He was born in Yerevan. He became a Grandmaster in 2000, and a FIDE senior trainer in 2010–11. He was part of winning team of 1995's European Chess Club Cup. He also competed at the Chess Olympiad in 1994 and 1996.

Yegiazarian died on 20 April 2020 at the age of 49.

[[Wau, South Sudan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Africa, South Sudan

Wau (واو, Wāw), also known as Wow, Waw or Wau Town, is a city in northwestern South Sudan. It lies on the western bank of the Jur River and is the capital of Western Bahr el Ghazal (and formerly Wau State).

[[Alek Wek]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, British models, People from Wau, South Sudan

Alek Wek (born 16 April 1977) is a South Sudanese-British model and designer. She began her fashion career at the age of 18 in 1995. She has been praised for her influence on the perception of beauty in the fashion industry.

Wek was born in Wau, Sudan (now South Sudan). She is from the Dinka ethnic group. She fled to Britain in 1991 to escape the civil war in Sudan. As of 2009, she lives in Brooklyn, New York, United States.

[[Thon Maker]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, Living people, Australian basketball players, Detroit Pistons players, Milwaukee Bucks players, Naturalised citizens of Australia, People from Perth, Western Australia, People from Wau, South Sudan

Thon Marial Maker (born 25 February 1997) is a South Sudanese-born Australian professional basketball player. He plays as a centre and power forward. He currently plays for the Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He also plays for the Australian national team. He formerly played for the Milwaukee Bucks (2016–2019).

Maker was born in Wau, Sudan (now South Sudan). He grew up in Perth, Western Australia from around age five. He also attended high school in the United States and Canada.

[[The Simpsons (season 31)]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons seasons, 2019 television seasons, 2020 television seasons

The 31st season of The Simpsons first started showing on television on September 29, 2019 with the episode "The Winter of Our Monetized Content".  It was first announced on February 6, 2019. It is the last season to show Russi Taylor because she died on July 26, 2019. She had been with the show since the first season and voices characters like Martin Prince, Sherri and Terri, and Üter Zörker. The episode "Thanksgiving of Horror" is the last episode to have her voice in it.

The episodes and writers "Go Big or Go Homer" (John Frink), "Livin' La Pura Vida" (Brian Kelley), and "Thanksgiving of Horror" (Dan Vebber) were nominated for Outstanding Writing in Animation for the 72nd Writers Guild of America Awards. On February 1, 2020, Dan Vebber and the episode "Thanksgiving of Horror" won.

[[Keith Thomas (English footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, English footballers, People from Oswestry, Sportspeople from Shropshire

Walter Keith Thomas (born 28 July 1929) is an English former footballer. He played as a right winger.

Thomas was born in Oswestry, Shropshire. He was also a schoolteacher. During the 1950s, Thomas made 97 appearances in the Football League for Sheffield Wednesday, Cardiff City, Plymouth Argyle and Exeter City. He rejoined his youth club Oswestry Town as player-manager in 1957. In 1959, he joined Welsh side Pwllheli in the same position.

[[British Landlords Association]]

CATEGORIES: Organisations based in the United Kingdom

British Landlords Association (BLA) is a national association of landlords in the UK.  It supports and represents the interest of landlords in England, Wales, and Scotland. The association has a daily online newspaper called The British Landlord Association Daily.

[[Danny McCarthy (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2019 deaths, Welsh footballers

Daniel John Anthony McCarthy (26 September 1942 – July 2019) was a Welsh professional footballer. He played as a winger. He made seven appearances in the Football League for Cardiff City. He also played for Abergavenny Thursdays and Merthyr Tydfil.

McCarthy was born in Abergavenny. He died in July 2019 at the age of 76.

[[Stephen Graham]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, Actors from Lancashire, English movie actors, English television actors, People from Merseyside

Stephen Joseph Graham (born 3 August 1973) is an English actor. He is best known for playing Andrew "Combo" Gascoigne in the movie This Is England (2006) and its television sequels This Is England '86 (2010), This Is England '88 (2011) and This Is England '90 (2015). His other movie roles include Tommy in Snatch (2000), Shang in Gangs of New York (2002), Baby Face Nelson in Public Enemies (2009), Scrum in the Pirates of the Caribbean movies On Stranger Tides (2011) and Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017), and Anthony "Tony Pro" Provenzano in The Irishman (2019).

On television, Graham has starred as Al Capone in the HBO series Boardwalk Empire (2010–2014), John Corbett in the BBC One series Line of Duty (2019) and as Jacob Marley in the BBC/FX miniseries A Christmas Carol (2019).

Graham was born in Kirkby, Lancashire. He has Jamaican and Swedish ancestry. He is married to Hannah Walters. The couple have two children. He is a fan of Liverpool Football Club.

[[Ronan O'Rahilly]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2020 deaths, Irish businesspeople, Deaths from vascular dementia, Irish movie producers

Ronan O'Rahilly (21 May 1940 – 20 April 2020) was an Irish businessman. He is known for the creation of the British radio station, Radio Caroline. For a time he was the manager of Australian actor George Lazenby. While filming On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969), O'Rahilly convinced Lazenby to turn down a contract of seven James Bond movies. He also served as an executive producer of The Girl on a Motorcycle (1968) and Universal Soldier (1971).

O'Rahilly died of vascular dementia on 20 April 2020. He was 79.

[[Gabriel Retes]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2020 deaths, Actors from Mexico City, Mexican movie directors, Mexican screenwriters, Movie producers, Writers from Mexico City

José Ignacio Gabriel Jorge Retes Balzaretti (25 March 1947 – 20 April 2020) was a Mexican movie director, writer, producer and actor. His movie, Paper Flowers (1977), was entered into the 28th Berlin International Film Festival. Two of his other movies, Broken Flag (1979) and A Sweet Scent of Death (1999), were both entered into the Moscow International Film Festival.

Retes died on 20 April 2020 at the age of 73.

[[Phyllida Law]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Actors from Glasgow, Officers of the Order of the British Empire, Radio actors, Scottish movie actors, Scottish stage actors, Scottish television actors, Scottish voice actors

Phyllida Ann Law GBR (born 8 May 1932) is a Scottish actress. Her movie credits include Peter's Friends (1992), Much Ado About Nothing (1993), Emma (1996), The Winter Guest (1997) and Nanny McPhee (2005).

Law was born in Glasgow. She was married to actor Eric Thompson from 1957 until his death in 1982. Their daughters, Emma and Sophie Thompson, are both actresses.

[[Atlantic sailfish]]

CATEGORIES: Articles with 'species' microformats, Perciformes

The Atlantic sailfish (Istiophorus albicans) is a species of marine fish in the family Istiophoridae of the order Perciformes. It is found in the Atlantic Oceans and the Caribbean Sea,  from the surface to depths of 200.  It does not occur in large areas of the central North Atlantic and the central South Atlantic. The Atlantic sailfish is related to the marlin.

Tests in the 1920s estimated that the Atlantic sailfish was capable of short sprints of up to 111 kilometres per hour; however, more conservative estimates of 37 to 55 kilometres per hour are more widely accepted. More recent studies even suggest sailfish do not exceed swimming speeds of 36.

Atlantic sailfish hunt schooling fish, such as sardines, anchovies and mackerel although they also feed on crustaceans and cephalopods.

[[Sestertius]]

CATEGORIES: Ancient Rome

A Sestertius (sometimes called sesterce in English was an Ancient Roman coin. It was frequently used in trade. Its value was two and a half asses, another Roman coin. Four sestertii (or setercves) were worth a denarius, another oin worth ten Asses.

[[Zambezi Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Namibia

Zambezi is a region in Namibia. The capital is Katima Mulilo. It is named after the Zambezi River that runs along its border.

Until 2013, it was known as Caprivi.

The region is home to 450 animal species, including elephants. The wildlife is protected by several national parks: Bwabwata National Park, Mamili National Park, and Mudumu National Park.

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Washington (state), 1911 establishments in the United States, Washington (state) counties

Pend Oreille County is a county in Washington in the United States. The county seat is Newport. 13,001 people lived there at the 2010 census. It is along the Canada–US border.

[[Church Stretton]]

CATEGORIES: Market towns in Shropshire, Civil parishes in Shropshire

Church Stretton, or simply Stretton, is a small market town in the county of Shropshire, England. It is situated 13 miles (21 km) south of Shrewsbury and 15 miles (24 km) north of Ludlow. The population of the town in 2011 was 4,671.

It is located in the Shropshire Hills Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty.

The town was nicknamed "Little Switzerland" in the late Victorian and Edwardian period for its landscape, and became a health resort.

The town has a railway station that provides direct trains to Shrewsbury, Manchester, North Wales and South Wales.

[[Fort Apache, The Bronx]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 drama movies, 1980s crime drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies directed by Daniel Petrie

Fort Apache, The Bronx is a 1981 American crime drama movie directed by Daniel Petrie and starring Paul Newman, Ed Asner, Ken Wahl, Danny Aiello, Pam Grier, Miguel Piñero. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[The Neptune Factor]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 science fiction movies, American science fiction movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Daniel Petrie

The Neptune Factor is a 1973 American science fiction movie directed by Daniel Petrie and stars Ernest Borgnine, Yvette Mimieux, Walter Pidgeon, Stuart Gillard. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Craven Arms]]

CATEGORIES: Market towns in England, Towns in Shropshire, Civil parishes in Shropshire

Craven Arms  is a small market town and civil parish in the county of Shropshire, England. It is located south of the county town of Shrewsbury and north of Ludlow. The population of the town in the 2011 census was 2,289.

It is a relatively new town (compared to other places in Shropshire), being only a small village called Newton on a 1695 map.

It is located in the Shropshire Hills Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty and is the site of the Shropshire Hills Discovery Centre. The River Onny flows to the town's east.

The town has a railway station that provides direct trains to Shrewsbury, Manchester, North Wales and South Wales. The Heart of Wales railway line joins the Welsh Marches line just outside the town's station.

[[Gobowen]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Shropshire

Gobowen is a village in the ceremonial county of Shropshire, England. It is situated around 3 miles north of the town of Oswestry. The population of the village in 2011 was 3,270.

The village was previously called Bryn-y-Castell ("Hill of the Castle" in English). The name changed to Gobowen, this name is believed to originate from Gob (a pillow) and Owen (Owain Glyndŵr) who was believed to have rested here.

The village's population grew up around the railway. The mainline route between Chester and Shrewsbury was built through Gobowen after permission was denied to build it through nearby Oswestry. Gobowen railway station is a Grade II listed building. Today, the station provides direct trains to North Wales, Chester, Shrewsbury, Birmingham and South Wales.

[[A Touch of Class (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 comedy movies, 1970s romance movies, British romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by Melvin Frank

A Touch of Class is a 1973 British romantic comedy movie directed by Melvin Frank and stars Glenda Jackson, George Segal, Paul Sorvino, K Callan, Simon Rouse. It was distributed by Warner Bros.. It was nominated for 5 Oscars and won for Best Actress in 1974.

[[Wem]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Shropshire, Market towns in England

Wem is a small market town in the ceremonial county of Shropshire, England. It is situated 9 miles north of the county town of Shrewsbury.

[[The Music Lovers]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 drama movies, 1970s LGBT movies, British biographical movies, British drama movies, Movies directed by Ken Russell

The Music Lovers is a 1971 British biographical drama movie directed by Ken Russell and stars Glenda Jackson, Richard Chamberlain, Max Adrian, Christopher Gable, Kenneth Colley with direction from Enrique Peña Nieto. It was distributed by United Artists and suffered from bad reviews and since become a cult favourite.

[[Shrewsbury railway station]]

CATEGORIES: 1840s establishments in England, 1848 establishments in Europe, Listed buildings, Railway stations in England, Buildings and structures in Shrewsbury, Shropshire

Shrewsbury railway station is the only railway station in the county town of Shrewsbury, Shropshire, England. Built in 1848, it was designated a grade II listed building in 1969.

The station is 43 miles (69 km) north west of Birmingham New Street. Many services starting at or passing through the station are bound for Wales as it is managed by Transport for Wales, although the station is also served by Avanti West Coast and West Midlands Trains services. The station is one of Transport for Wales' key network hubs.

It is the busiest station in Shropshire and was the 14th busiest in the West Midlands in 2014-15.

[[The Incredible Sarah]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 drama movies, British drama movies, Movies directed by Richard Fleischer

The Incredible Sarah is a 1976 British period drama movie directed by Richard Fleischer and starring Glenda Jackson, Daniel Massey, Yvonne Mitchell, David Langton, John Castle, Edward Judd and Peter Sallis. It was nominated for two Oscars in 1977.

[[The Devils (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 thriller movies, American thriller movies, British thriller movies, Movies directed by Ken Russell

The Devils is a 1971 British American thriller movie directed by Ken Russell and stars Vanessa Redgrave, Oliver Reed, Brian Murphy, Dudley Sutton, Max Adrian, Georgina Hale, Kenneth Colley. It was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[New Meadow]]

CATEGORIES: 2007 establishments in England, Football stadiums in England, Buildings and structures in Shrewsbury, Shropshire

New Meadow, currently known as the Montgomery Waters Meadow for sponsorship reasons, is a football stadium located in the county town of Shrewsbury, Shropshire, England. It is the home ground of Shrewsbury Town FC. 

The stadium opened in July 2007, replacing Gay Meadow as the club's home ground.

The stadium can hold 9,875 spectators and is all seated. It has four stands, one on each side of the pitch. In June 2017, Shrewsbury Town applied to the Sports Grounds Safety Authority for permission to turn a section of the stadium into a safe standing area. They were given permission, making them the first club in the English Football League to have a safe standing section at their stadium.

Unlike Gay Meadow, the stadium is not located within Shrewsbury town centre and is instead in Meole Brace, a suburb in the south-east of the town. It can be difficult for fans to get to. The club has a matchday travel plan that asks spectators to walk, cycle or use organised transport where they can. Shrewsbury railway station is just over two miles from the stadium. The Meole Brace Park and Ride bus service is close to the stadium.

The stadium's highest ever attendance is 10,210. This was the attendance of a League Cup match against Premier League club Chelsea on 28 October 2014. The tournament's sponsor at the time, Capital One, provided two temporary stands which were placed in two corners of the stadium to make room for more fans for the match.

[[Hodnet, Shropshire]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Shropshire, Civil parishes in Shropshire

Hodnet is a village and civil parish in the county of Shropshire, England. It lies 5.7 miles (9.2 km) south-west of the town of Market Drayton.

The civil parish currently has a population of 1,534.

Hodnet's name has Celtic origins derived from the Welsh hawdd meaning pleasant or peaceful and nant, a glen or valley in Old Welsh. Evidence of a Bronze Age burial site was discovered during construction of the bypass in 2002. Hodnet is recorded in the Domesday Book as Odenet, and the village's 17th-century Hundred House was named for this reason.

The village lies is on the A53 road from Shrewsbury to Newcastle-under-Lyme. It is served by the 511 bus route, operated by Arriva Midlands, between Shrewsbury and Market Drayton.

[[Audrey Rose]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 drama movies, 1977 horror movies, American horror movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Robert Wise

Audrey Rose is a 1977 American psychological horror drama movie directed by Robert Wise and based on the 1975 novel of the same name by Frank De Felitta. It stars Anthony Hopkins, Marsha Mason, Norman Lloyd, Susan Swift and was distributed by United Artists.

[[Market Drayton]]

CATEGORIES: Market towns in England, Civil parishes in Shropshire, Towns in Shropshire

Market Drayton, known locally as simply Drayton, is a market town and civil parish in the county of Shropshire, England. It is located near the Cheshire and Staffordshire borders. 

It lies on the River Tern, between Shrewsbury and Stoke-on-Trent.

The town was formerly known as Drayton in Hales around 1868 and earlier simply as Drayton around 1695. Drayton is recorded in the Domesday Book as a manor in the hundred of Hodnet. It was held by William Pantulf, Lord of Wem, from Roger de Montgomery, 1st Earl of Shrewsbury. It is listed as having a population of just 5 households in 1086, putting it in the smallest 20% of settlements recorded.

Now, the town has a population of 11,773.

The town had a railway station, however it closed in 1963 during the Beeching cuts. The site of the former station is now a Morrisons supermarket.

The town has a semi-professional football club, Market Drayton Town FC.

[[Goodbye, Norma Jean]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 drama movies, American drama movies

Goodbye, Norma Jean is a 1976 American biographical movie directed by Larry Buchanan and stars Misty Rowe playing the part of Marilyn Monroe.

[[Fighting Mad]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 drama movies, 1970s action movies, American drama movies, American action movies, Movies directed by Jonathan Demme

Fighting Mad is a 1976 American action drama movie directed by Jonathan Demme and produced by Roger Corman. It stars Peter Fonda, Lynn Lowry, John Doucette, Scott Glenn, Philip Carey and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Fatma Boussaha]]

CATEGORIES: Tunisian singers, 2015 deaths, 1942 births, People from Tunis

Tunisian Mezwed singerFatma Boussaha (فاطمة بوساحة) (born January 22 1942 in Zaghouan - died October 27 2015) was a Tunisian Mezwed singer. Fatma Boussaha performed several titles like Ya ami echiffour (Hey my uncle the driver) and Ya karhebt Kamel (Hey the car of Kamel). She was known for her song Achchibani wassa (Laisse passer le Vieuxard) in 1999. Her last title, Trabek ghali ya touness, (Your dust is precious, Tunis) dates from 2012.  At one time, she was banned from broadcasting on Tunisian television as were other mezoued artists. Boussaha died on Tuesday October 27, 2015 at her home.

At the end of her life, touched by cancer, she found herself alone facing her fight, leading the Ministry of Culture to take charge of her care within the framework of her program of assistance to artists.

[[Zaghouan]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Tunisia, Towns in Africa

Zaghwan (or Zaghouan; زغوان no) is a town in the northern half of Tunisia.

Situated on a low ridge of the Dorsale Mountains, the town has a mild climate and presents a green aspect. Cold water from here was taken by aqueduct to Carthage. The town is famous for its roses, originally cultivated by Muslim refugees from Spain in the seventeenth century. The town is located around 100 km due south of Tunis and around 50 km inland (west) from the Gulf of Hammamet and has an estimated population of around 20,837 (2014). It is the capital of the Zaghouan Governorate.

On the mountain south of the city is the Roman Water Temple Djebel Zaghouan (Temple de Eaux), source of an aqueduct which used to take water to the city of Carthage over 100 km away. The ruins here are illustrated in Fisher's Drawing Room Scrap Book, 1840, as 'Temple and Fountain of Zagwhan', the subject of a poem by Letitia Elizabeth Landon.

[[Larbi Ben Salah Abid]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, People from Tunis, Tunisian politicians

Larbi Ben Salah Abid (العربي بن صالح عبيد; born june 30 1953 in Korba) is a Tunisian politician, he was second vice-president of the Constituent Assembly between 2011 and 2014. He obtained his Bachelor of Arts in 1974 from Carthage Présidence Lyceum, a Masters in Private Law in 1981 and the Certificate of aptitude for the profession of Lawyer , before starting his professional career in the insurance sector , before joining the legal profession after five years.He was also à member of the National Bar Association in Tunisia from 2001 to 2004. He has been a member of the Tunisian Human Rights League and the National Council for Liberties in Tunisia  since their creation.

Oulaya (علية‎; 4 November 1936 – 19 March 1990), Born "Beya Bent Béchir Ben Hédi Rahal", was a Tunisian singer and actress.

[[Yentl]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 romance movies, 1983 drama movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, 1980s musical movies, 1980s LGBT movies, American romantic drama movies, American musical movies, American LGBT movies

It also stars Amy Irving, Mandy Patinkin, Nehemiah Persoff and was nominated for 5 Oscars including one win at the Academy Awards in 1984.

[[Weird Science (movie)]]

It was distributed by Universal Pictures and was spun off into TV series in 1994.

[[Hend Sabry]]

CATEGORIES: Hend Sabry, 1979 births, Living people, Egyptian actors, Tunisian actors, People from Tunis

Hend Sabry (هند صبري; born Hend Mohamed El-Moldy Sabry on 20 November 1979) is a Tunisian actress and lawyer working in Egypt. Hend starred as "'Ola" in the Egyptian television drama Ayza Atgawiz as a character obsessed with getting married, who goes through dozens of prospective fiancés.

In 2010 she was appointed an ambassador against hunger by the UN World Food Programme. Arabian Business listed her among the "100 most powerful Arab women" in 2013.

Sabry is married to an Egyptian businessman and has dual-nationalities of her home country Tunisia and her country of residence Egypt. She was on the cover of the Tunivisions people magazine in June 2011.

[[Hiiumaa]]

CATEGORIES: Islands of Europe, Geography of Estonia

Hiiumaa is the second largest island in Estonia. It is part of the West Estonian archipelago, in the Baltic Sea. It has an area of 989 km2 and is 22 km from the Estonian mainland. Its largest town is Kärdla. It is in Hiiu County.

Elk, red deer, roe deer, wild boars, foxes, lynxes and martens. Wolves have started to come back to the island after being made locally extinct. Minks were also reintroduced in 2000. The bird species found on the island include black storks, golden eagles, cranes, avocets and swans.

[[Ida-Viru County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Ida-Viru County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is Jõhvi.

Ida-Virumaa County is divided into eight municipalities. Four are urban and four are rural. There are 217 villages in Ida-Virumaa.
