CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Jõgeva County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is also named Jõgeva.

The county is divided into municipalities. There are three rural municipalities:

[[Laisenia Qarase]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, Prime Ministers of Fiji

Laisenia Qarase (4 February 1941 – 21 April 2020) was a Fijian politician. He served as the sixth Prime Minister of Fiji from 2000 to 2006. In 2001, he founded the political party, Soqosoqo Duavata ni Lewenivanua (SDL). He was born in Vanua Balavu, Lau Islands.

Qarase died in Suva on 21 April 2020 at the age of 79.

[[Ashley Mattingly]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 births, 2020 deaths, Suicides in the United States, Models from Texas, People from Dallas, Texas

Ashley Mattingly (September 10, 1986 – April 15, 2020) was an American model. She was  the Playboy Playmate of the Month for March 2011. Mattingly was born in Dallas, Texas.

In 2016, she was charged with a DUI after driving her golf cart into four parked cars.

Mattingly died by suicide on April 15, 2020 in Austin, Texas at the age of 33.

[[Prime Minister of Fiji]]

CATEGORIES: Prime Ministers of Fiji

The Prime Minister of the Republic of Fiji is the head of government of Fiji. The Prime Minister is appointed by the President. In 2007, Frank Bainimarama became the current Prime Minister.

[[Bob Oliver]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, African-American sportspeople, American baseball players, Baltimore Orioles players, California Angels players, Kansas City Royals players, New York Yankees players, People from Shreveport, Louisiana, Pittsburgh Pirates players, Sportspeople from Louisiana

Robert Lee Oliver (February 8, 1943 – April 19, 2020) was an American professional baseball player. He played as a first baseman and outfielder. He batted and threw right-handed. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Pittsburgh Pirates (1965), Kansas City Royals (1969–1972), California Angels (1972–1974), Baltimore Orioles (1974) and New York Yankees (1975).

Oliver was born in Shreveport, Louisiana. He was the father of baseball player Darren Oliver. He died on April 19, 2020, in Rio Linda, California. He was 77.

[[Jioji Konrote]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Living people, Current national leaders, Presidents of Fiji

Jioji Konousi "George" Konrote, OF, MC (born 26 December 1947) is a Fijian politician and retired Major-General of the Fiji Military. He has been President of Fiji since 2015.

[[Järva County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Järva County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is Paide. Besides Paide, municipalities are Türi Parish and Järva Parish.

[[Rio Linda, California]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in California, Settlements in Sacramento County, California

Rio Linda is a census-designated place (CDP) in Sacramento County, California, United States. As of the 2010 census, the CDP had a population of 15,106.

[[Parliament of Fiji]]

CATEGORIES: Fiji

The Parliament of the Republic of Fiji is the unicameral legislature of the Republic of Fiji. It is made up of 51 members elected every 4 years using open list proportional representation. It is the country's only body of government. In 2019, Epeli Nailatikau became the Speaker of Parliament. 

[[Willy Quadackers]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch footballers, People from Heerlen, Sportspeople from Limburg (Netherlands)

Willy Quadackers (26 July 1937 – 18 April 2020) was a Dutch footballer. He played as a right back.

Quadackers was born in Heerlen, Limburg. He played club football for Fortuna'54 (1961–1966) and MVV (1966–1971). He also played one match for the Dutch national team in 1964.

Quadackers died on 18 April 2020 at the age of 82.

[[President of Fiji]]

CATEGORIES: Presidents of Fiji

The president of the Republic of Fiji is the head of state of Fiji. The President is appointed by the Parliament of Fiji for a three-year term under the terms of the 2013 Constitution of Fiji. 

[[Allan Gotlieb]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Ambassadors of Canada, Canadian lawyers, Canadian writers, Cancer deaths in Ontario, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Order of Canada, People from Winnipeg

Allan Ezra Gotlieb CAN (February 28, 1928 – April 18, 2020) was a Canadian public servant, author and lawyer. He served as the Canadian Ambassador to the United States from 1981 to 1989. He was born in Winnipeg, Manitoba.

On April 18, 2020, Gotlieb died due to cancer and Parkinson's disease in Toronto, Ontario. He was 92.

[[Lääne County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Lääne County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is Haapsalu. 

There is one urban municipality and 2 rural municipalities:

[[Horacio Fontova]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine movie actors, Argentine television actors, Voice actors, Argentine comedians, Argentine singers, Argentine writers, Songwriters, Actors from Buenos Aires, Cancer deaths in Argentina

Horacio González Fontova (30 October 1946 – 20 April 2020) was an Argentine actor, singer-songwriter and comedian. He was born in Buenos Aires. He was known for his roles in The Plague (1992), Aballay (2011) and Underdogs (2013). He appeared in the Argentine historical television series Algo habrán hecho por la historia argentina.

Fontova died of cancer in Buenos Aires on 20 April 2020, aged 73.

[[Lääne-Viru County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Lääne-Viru County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is Rakvere.

The county is divided into municipalities. There is one urban municipality and seven rural municipalities in Lääne-Viru County.

[[Some Kind of Wonderful]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 romance movies, 1987 drama movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies directed by Howard Deutch

Some Kind of Wonderful is a 1987 American romantic drama movie directed by Howard Deutch and starring Eric Stoltz, Mary Stuart Masterson, Craig Sheffer, Pamela Anderson. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures and was one of several successful movies by John Hughes in the 1980s.

[[Batura Muztagh]]

CATEGORIES: Karakoram, Gilgit-Baltistan, Mountains of Pakistan

The Batura Muztagh is a group of mountains in the Karakoram mountain range. It was what is called a subrange, or a smaller mountain range inside of a larger one. It is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, in Pakistan.

Batura Muztagh is the most western of the Karakoram subranges. It runs from Chalt village in Bar Valley in the east to Kampir Dior in the Kurumbar Valley in the west. This subrange included Muchu Chhish, which is the second highest unclimbed mountain in the world.

[[Tamezret]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Tunisia

Tamezret or Tamazrat (تامزرط) is a Tunisian Berber village located in the south-east of the country, about ten kilometers from Matmata and forty kilometers southwest of the capital of the governorate of Gabès on which it depends. Ridge village built on the four slopes of one of the highest hills of the Matmata mountains.(480 m altitude).

[[National Lampoon's Vacation]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 comedy movies, 1980s road movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Harold Ramis

National Lampoon's Vacation is a 1983 American comedy movie directed by Harold Ramis and written by John Hughes. It stars Chevy Chase, Beverly D'Angelo, Randy Quaid, John Candy, Anthony Michael Hall, Christie Brinkley, Jane Krakowski and distributed by Warner Bros. and spawned four sequels.

[[Hédi Berkhissa]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, 1997 deaths, Tunisian footballers, People from Tunis

Hédi «Balha» Berkhissa (June 28, 1972, Kerkennah, Tunisia – January 4, 1997, Tunis, Tunisia) was a Tunisian footballer who played for Espérance and the Tunisian National Team as a defender. On January 4, 1997, in a friendly match between Espérance and French side Olympique Lyon at Stade Chedli Zouiten, Berkhissa had a heart attack on the field in the last minutes of the game and died.

[[The Ploughman's Lunch]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 drama movies, British drama movies

The Ploughman's Lunch is a 1983 British drama movie directed by Richard Eyre and stars Jonathan Pryce, Tim Curry, Frank Finlay, Rosemary Harris.

[[Rakaposhi-Haramosh Mountains]]

CATEGORIES: Karakoram, Gilgit-Baltistan, Mountains of Pakistan

The Rakaposhi-Haramosh Mountains is a group of mountains in the Karakoram range. It was what is called a subrange, or a smaller mountain range inside of a larger one. It is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, in Pakistan.

The Barpu and the Chogo Lungma Glaciers are the northern border for these mountains. In the east, the Shigar River is the border. The Gilgit and Indus Rivers form the border in the south. The Hunza River is the border in the west.

The subrange is named after two mountains, Rakaposhi and Haramosh. These have some of the largest Topographic prominence in the world.

[[Ian Whitcomb]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2020 deaths, British record producers, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Los Angeles, Deaths from stroke, English singer-songwriters, Musicians from Surrey, People from Woking

Ian Timothy Whitcomb (10 July 1941 – 19 April 2020) was an English singer-songwriter, musician and record producer. He was part of the British Invasion. His hit song "You Turn Me On" reached No. 8 in the U.S. Billboard Hot 100 chart in 1965. He wrote many books on popular music, starting with After the Ball. He recreated the music played aboard the Titanic which earned him a Grammy Award nomination.

At age 60, Ian became a California State employee. Dr. Kevin Starr, the State Librarian, appointed him Roving Minstrel (officially, California State Music Librarian) in his own chautauqua, traveling every other month to rural libraries in order to give entertaining and educational lecture-concerts on the subject of popular music. Regina accompanied him, as did Rollo (their dog). He very much enjoyed these trips: seeing the California he loves so much, meeting new people, making discoveries. He introduced so many families to American Popular Song highlighting that the books and recordings are available in the libraries.

Whitcomb was born in Woking, Surrey. He lived in the United States with his wife, Regina. On 19 April 2020, Whitcomb died in Los Angeles, California, of stroke-related problems. He was 78.

[[The Osterman Weekend (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Sam Peckinpah

The Osterman Weekend is a 1983 American suspense thriller movie directed by Sam Peckinpah in his final movie before his death in 1984 and was adapted from the 1972 novel of the same name by Robert Ludlum. It stars Rutger Hauer, John Hurt, Burt Lancaster, Craig T. Nelson, Dennis Hopper, Chris Sarandon and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Spantik-Sosbun Mountains]]

CATEGORIES: Karakoram, Gilgit-Baltistan, Mountains of Pakistan

The Spantik-Sosbun Mountains are a group of mountains in the Karakoram range. They are what is called a subrange, or a smaller mountain range inside of a larger one. This subrange is located in Gilgit-Baltistan, in Pakistan.

The highest mountain is Spantik, which is 7,027 high. The other mountain after which the subrange is named is Sosbun Brakk, which is 6,413 high.

The Spantik-Sosbun Mountains are about 120 long, going mostly east–west. The northern border is the Hispar and Biafo Glaciers. On the southwest, the Barpu Glacier and the Chogo Lungma Glacier separate these mountains from the Rakaposhi-Haramosh Mountains. On the southeast, the Braldu River is the border between this subrange and the Mango Gusor Mountains.

[[Krystyna Łybacka]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Polish politicians

Krystyna Maria Łybacka (10 February 1946 – 20 April 2020) was a Polish politician. She was the  Minister of National Education from 2001 to 2004. She also served as a member of the national parliament (Sejm) from 1991 to 2014. She was born in Jutrosin.

Łybacka died on 20 April 2020 at the age of 74.

[[The Island (1980 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 horror movies, American horror movies, Movies based on books, Movies set in islands, Movies directed by Michael Ritchie

The Island is a 1980 American horror movie directed by Michael Ritchie and is based on the novel of the same name by Peter Benchley who also wrote the screenplay. It stars Michael Caine, David Warner, Dudley Sutton, Frank Middlemass and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was nominated 2 Razzies at the 1st Golden Raspberry Awards.

[[Better Off Ned]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons (season 31) episodes, 2020 television episodes

"Better Off Ned" is the 16th episode of the 31st season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on television on the Fox network on March 15, 2020. In the episode, Homer becomes Nelson's mentor to make Bart jealous when Ned takes care of him. The episode was dedicated to Max von Sydow who died on March 8, 2020. He guest starred in the episode "The War of Art" as Klaus Ziegler. 

[[Demon Seed]]

Demon Seed is a 1977 American science fiction horror movie directed by Donald Cammell and is based on the best selling novel by Dean Koontz. It stars Julie Christie, Fritz Weaver, Lisa Lu and was distributed by United Artists.

Tipas is a 6670 volcano in the Andes range, in Argentina. It is the 9th highest mountain in the Andes. It is also known as Cazadero and Cerro Walther Penck.

Meaulne-Vitray is a commune. It is in the Allier department in the center of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Meaulne (the seat) and Vitray.

[[Nice Dreams]]

Nice Dreams is a 1981 American adventure comedy movie directed by Tommy Chong. It is the third movie out of Cheech & Chong's movie series and stars Tommy Chong, Cheech Marin, Stacey Keach, Paul Reubens, Evelyn Guerrero, Peter Jason. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Paul Winchell]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2005 deaths, Actors from New York City, American movie actors, American inventors, American stage actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Comedians from New York City, Humanitarians

Paul Winchell (born Paul Wilchinsky; December 21, 1922 – June 24, 2005) was an American actor, comedian, humanitarian, inventor and ventriloquist. He was born on December 21, 1922 in New York City. From 1950 to 1954, he hosted The Paul Winchell Show. From 1965–1968, Winchell hosted the children's television series Winchell-Mahoney Time. In animation, he was the original voice of Tigger, Dick Dastardly, Gargamel and other characters.

He had three children; including actress April Winchell.

Winchell died on June 24, 2005 in Los Angeles, aged 82.

[[Dick Dastardly]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional characters introduced in the 1960s, Fictional criminals, Fictional British people, Television characters, Movie characters

Dick Dastardly is a fictional character and antagonist who appeared in many animated series by Hanna-Barbera Productions from 1968 onward. 

Dastardly's most famous appearances are as a main character in the series Wacky Races and its spin-off, Dastardly and Muttley in Their Flying Machines where he appeared as a good guy. 

He is partly based on the English actor Terry-Thomas.

[[Terry-Thomas]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 1990 deaths, People with Parkinson's disease, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, English radio actors, English voice actors, Comedians from London, Actors from London

Terry-Thomas (born Thomas Terry Hoar Stevens; 14 July 1911spaced ndash8 January 1990) was an English comedian and actor. He was born in London.

Some of his best known roles were in Private's Progress (1956), The Green Man (1956), Blue Murder at St Trinian's (1957), I'm All Right Jack (1959) and Carlton-Browne of the F.O. (1959).

From the early 1960s Terry-Thomas began appearing in American movies such as Bachelor Flat, It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World and How to Murder Your Wife. 

In 1971 Terry-Thomas was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. He died at a nursing home on 8 January 1990 in Godalming, Surrey at the age of 78.

[[Lovers and Other Strangers]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 comedy movies, 1970s romance movies, American romantic comedy movies, American independent movies

Lovers and Other Strangers is a 1970 American romantic comedy movie directed by Cy Howard and based on the 1968 play of the same name by Renée Taylor and Joseph Bologna. It stars Beatrice Arthur, Gig Young, Cloris Leachman, Richard S. Castellano, Diane Keaton, Sylvester Stallone and the film was nominated for three Oscars and won one Academy Awards in 1971.

Michael James Bailey (born 6 April 1988) is an English actor. He is best known for playing Sid Jenkins in the first two series of the E4 teen comedy-drama Skins (2007–2008). Bailey was born in Bristol.

[[Up in Smoke]]

Up in Smoke is a 1978 American comedy movie directed by Lou Adler. It is the first movie out of Cheech & Chong's movie series and Tommy Chong, Cheech Marin, Edie Adams, Stacy Keach, Tom Skeritt, Ellen Barkin. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Ofrenda]]

CATEGORIES: Mexico

An ofrenda (Spanish: "offering") is a collection of objects placed on a display during the annual and traditionally Mexican Día de Muertos celebration.  An ofrenda, which can be large is usually created for an individual person who has died and is intended to welcome them. They are filled with the deceased personal objects, picture of the person and food.

[[Edgar Buchanan]]

CATEGORIES: 1903 births, 1979 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in California, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American radio actors, Deaths from stroke, Deaths from pneumonia, Singers from Missouri, Actors from Missouri

William Edgar Buchanan II (March 20, 1903 – April 4, 1979) was an American actor and singer. He was known for his role as Uncle Joe Carson on the television sitcoms Petticoat Junction, Green Acres, and The Beverly Hillbillies of the 1960s. He was born in Humansville, Missouri.

Buchanan died on April 4, 1979 in Palm Desert, California of a stroke caused by pneumonia, aged 76.

[[Mitch Hewer]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 births, Living people, Actors from Bristol, English movie actors, English television actors

Mitchell Scott Hewer (born 1 July 1989) is an English actor. He is best known for playing Maxxie Oliver in the first two series of the E4 teen comedy-drama Skins (2007–2008). He has also appeared in Britannia High and Casualty. Hewer was born in Bristol.

[[Humansville, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri

Humansville is a city in Polk County, Missouri, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 1,048.

[[Bolivar, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Bolivar is a city and county seat of Polk County, Missouri, United States.  As of the 2010 census, the city population was 10,325.

[[Petticoat Junction]]

CATEGORIES: CBS network shows, 1960s sitcoms, English-language television programs

Petticoat Junction is an American sitcom that originally aired on CBS from September 1963 to April 1970. The series takes place at the Shady Rest Hotel, which is run by Kate Bradley, her three daughters Billie Jo, Bobbie Jo, and Betty Jo, and her uncle Joe Carson.

The series is one of three unrelated shows about rural characters created by Paul Henning. Petticoat Junction was created after the success of Henning's sitcom The Beverly Hillbillies (1962–1971). The success of Petticoat Junction led to a spin-off, Green Acres (1965–1971).

[[Jeannine Riley]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from California, Living people

Jeannine Brooke Riley (born October 1, 1940) is an American actress. She was born in Madera, California. She is known for her role as Billie Jo Bradley on the first two seasons of the CBS sitcom Petticoat Junction (1963–1965). Riley's movie roles include The Big Mouth (1967), Fever Heat (1968), The Comic (1969) and Electra Glide in Blue (1973).

[[Paul Henning]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 2005 deaths, People from Independence, Missouri, American songwriters, American television producers, American television writers, Writers from Missouri

Paul William Henning (September 16, 1911 – March 25, 2005) was an American producer and screenwriter. He was known for creating The Beverly Hillbillies. He also helped create Petticoat Junction  (1963–1970) and Green Acres (1965–1971) for CBS. He was one of the staff writers for George Burns. Henning was born in Independence, Missouri. 

Henning died on March 25, 2005 in Burbank, California at the age of 93.

[[Joe Dempsie]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people, Actors from Liverpool, Actors from Nottinghamshire, English movie actors, English television actors

Joseph Maxwell Dempsie (born 22 June 1987) is a British actor. He is best known for his roles as Chris Miles in the E4 teen comedy-drama Skins (2007–2008) and Gendry Baratheon in Game of Thrones (2011–2019).

Dempsie was born in Liverpool. He grew up in West Bridgford, Nottinghamshire.

[[The Manhattan Project (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 science fiction movies, 1986 thriller movies, American science fiction movies, American thriller movies

The Manhattan Project is a 1986 American science fiction thriller movie directed by Marshall Brickman and stars John Lithgow, Cythnia Nixon, Christopher Collet. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was a box office bomb.

[[Ketty Lester]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Actors from Arkansas, African-American movie actors, African-American singers, African-American television actors, People from Hope, Arkansas, Singers from Arkansas

Ketty Lester (born Revoyda Frierson; August 16, 1934) is an American singer and actress. She is best known for her 1962 hit single "Love Letters". The song reached the top 5 of the charts in the U.S. and the UK. She is also known for her role as Hester-Sue Terhune in the television series Little House on the Prairie (1977–1983).

Lester was born in Hope, Arkansas. She is an African-American.

[[Abdurrahim El-Keib]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Prime Ministers of Libya

Abdurrahim Abdulhafiz El-Keib (عبد الرحيم عبد الحفيظ الكيب‎; 1950 – 21 April 2020) was a Libyan politician. He served as interim Prime Minister of Libya from November 2011 to November 2012. He was born in Tripoli.

On 21 April 2020, El-Keib died of a heart attack. He was 70.

[[Mohamed Akkari]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, 2017 deaths, Tunisian actors, People from Tunis

Mohamed Akkari (محمد العكاري, born  1978 in Tunis - death April 28 2017 in Mahdia) was a Tunisian actor and Radio personality.  Mohamed Akkari died of a heart attack following surgery. He  is buried in the Mahdia Marine Cemetery in the presence of a good number of actors and fans.Rabaa Essefi said that the last sequence of the Dawama soap opera filmed with Mohamed was carried out in Sfax a week before his death.

[[Conrack (1974 movie)]]

Conrack is a 1974 American autobiographical drama movie directed by Martin Ritt and based on the 1972 autobiographical book The Water is Wide by Pat Conroy. It stars Jon Voight, Paul Winfield, Tina Andrews, Antonio Fargas and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[David Ossman]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, American television writers, Screenwriters from California, Movie directors from California, Movie producers from California, Comedians from California, Actors from Santa Monica, California

David Ossman (born December 6, 1936) is an American writer, actor and comedian. He was born in Santa Monica, California. He is best known as a member of the Firesign Theatre and screenwriter of such movies as Zachariah. He also voiced Cornelius in A Bug's Life.

[[Altered States]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s science fiction horror movies, 1980s fantasy movies, American science fiction horror movies, 1980 horror movies, 1980s science fiction movies, 1980s thriller movies, American drama movies, American fantasy movies, American thriller movies, Body horror movies, Cult movies, Movies about drugs, Movies based on books, Movies set in Boston, Massachusetts, Movies set in Massachusetts, Movies set in the 1970s, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Ken Russell

Altered States is a 1980 American science fiction fantasy horror movie directed by Ken Russell and written by Paddy Chayefsky. It stars William Hurt, Blair Brown, Charles Haid, Drew Barrymore, John Larroquette and distributed by Warner Bros.. It was nominated for two Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1981.

[[Doug Kershaw]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, American singer-songwriters, American guitarists, American country musicians, American folk musicians, American country singers, American folk singers, Record producers, Singers from Louisiana, Musicians from Louisiana, Businesspeople from Louisiana

Douglas James Kershaw (born January 24, 1936) is an American fiddle player, record producer and singer-songwriter. He was born in Cameron Parish, Louisiana. He  began his career as part of the duo Rusty and Doug, along with his brother, Rusty Kershaw. He also had a solo career that included fifteen albums and singles that charted on the Hot Country Songs charts.

In 2009, he became a member of the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame.

[[Cameron Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1870s establishments in Louisiana, 1870 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Cameron Parish (Paroisse de Cameron) is a parish in the southwestern section of the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 6,839. The parish seat is Cameron.

[[Harrisonburg, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Louisiana, Parish seats in Louisiana

Harrisonburg is a village in and the parish seat of Catahoula Parish, Louisiana, United States. The population was 348 as of the 2010 census. 

[[Catahoula Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1800s establishments in the Territory of Orleans, 1808 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Catahoula Parish (Paroisse de Catahoula) is a parish in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 10,407. Its parish seat is Harrisonburg.

[[Livingston, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Louisiana, Parish seats in Louisiana

Livingston is the parish seat of Livingston Parish, Louisiana, United States. The population was 1,769 at the 2010 census.

[[Livingston Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Louisiana parishes, 1830s establishments in Louisiana, 1832 establishments in the United States

Livingston Parish (French: Paroisse de Livingston) is a parish located in the U.S. state of Louisiana. Livingston Parish is known as one of the six Florida Parishes, a region of the State of Louisiana that was bought from Spanish Florida.

Livingston Parish is part of the Baton Rouge, LA Metropolitan Statistical Area. As of the 2010 census, the population was 128,026. Its parish seat is located in the City of Livingston. 

[[Pointe à la Hache, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Parish seats in Louisiana, Unincorporated communities in Louisiana, Census-designated places in Louisiana

Pointe à la Hache (ˌ POYNT)  is a census-designated place (CDP) and unincorporated community in Plaquemines Parish, Louisiana, United States.

Located on the east bank of the Mississippi River, the village has been the seat for Plaquemines Parish. As of the 2010 census, its population was 187.

[[Zee and Co.]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 drama movies, 1970s LGBT movies, British drama movies

Zee and Co.  is a 1972 British drama movie. It is also called X, Y and Zee or Zee and Company. It was directed by Brian G. Hutton. The movie is based on the novel by Edna O'Brien. It stars Elizabeth Taylor, Michael Caine, Susannah York and Margaret Leighton.

[[St. Joseph, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Louisiana, Parish seats in Louisiana

St. Joseph, often called St. Joe, is the parish seat of Tensas Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. It is in the delta of the Mississippi River. The population was 1,176 at the 2010 census. The town had an African-American majority of 77.4 percent in 2010.

[[Tensas Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1840s establishments in Louisiana, 1843 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Tensas Parish (Paroisse des Tensas) is a parish located in the northeastern section of the State of Louisiana. Its eastern border is the Mississippi River. As of the 2010 census, the population was 5,252. It is the least populated parish in Louisiana. The parish seat is St. Joseph. 

[[Assumption Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1807 establishments in the Territory of Orleans, Louisiana parishes

Assumption Parish (Paroisse de l'Assomption) is a parish located in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 23,421. Its parish seat is Napoleonville. 

[[Beauregard Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Louisiana, 1913 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Beauregard Parish (Paroisse de Beauregard) is a parish located in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 35,654. The parish seat is DeRidder.

[[Calcasieu Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1840s establishments in Louisiana, 1840 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Calcasieu Parish (ˈ; Paroisse de Calcasieu) is a parish located on the southwestern border of the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 192,768. The parish seat is Lake Charles.

[[Caldwell Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Louisiana parishes, 1830s establishments in Louisiana, 1838 establishments in the United States

Caldwell Parish (Paroisse de Caldwell) is a parish located in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 10,132. The parish seat is Columbia. 

[[DeSoto Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1840s establishments in Louisiana, 1843 establishments in the United States, DeSoto Parish, Louisiana

DeSoto Parish (French: Paroisse DeSoto) is a parish located in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 26,656. Its parish seat is Mansfield. The parish was formed in 1843.

[[Clun]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Shropshire, Villages in Shropshire

Clun (Welsh: Colunwy) is a small town in the south of the county of Shropshire, England.

A 2011 census recorded just 680 people living in the town.

Clun takes its name from the river upon which it stands. The name derives from an earlier Colunwy and shares its very early British root with the Colne rivers, in Lancashire and Essex, each of which has a town of the same name on its banks.

The A488 and B4368 roads cross in the town. Craven Arms, Bishop's Castle (6 miles (10 km) to the north) and Ludlow are the neighbouring Shropshire towns, and Knighton, which is in Powys, Wales, is 7 miles (11 km) to the south.

In A Shropshire Lad, A. E. Housman wrote the verse:

"Clunton and Clunbury,

Clungunford and Clun,

Are the quietest places

Under the sun."

[[East Carroll Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1870s establishments in Louisiana, 1877 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

East Carroll Parish (Paroisse de Carroll Est) is a parish located in the Mississippi Delta in northeastern Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 7,759. The parish seat is Lake Providence.

East Feliciana Parish (Paroisse de Feliciana Est, Parroquia de East Feliciana) is a parish in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 20,267. The parish seat is Clinton.

Evangeline Parish (Paroisse d'Évangéline) is a parish in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 33,984. The parish seat is Ville Platte.

[[Grant Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Louisiana, 1869 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Grant Parish (Paroisse de Grant) is a parish located in the North Central portion of the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 22,309. The parish seat is Colfax. The parish was founded in 1869 and named after President Ulysses S. Grant.

[[Iberville Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1807 establishments in the Territory of Orleans, Louisiana parishes

Iberville Parish (Paroisse d'Iberville) is a parish located south of Baton Rouge in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 33,387. Its seat is Plaquemine. The parish was formed in 1807.

[[Jefferson Davis Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 20th-century establishments in Louisiana, 1913 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Jefferson Davis Parish (Paroisse de Jefferson Davis) is a parish located in the U.S. state of Louisiana. As of the 2010 census, the population was 31,594. The parish seat is Jennings. Jefferson Davis Parish is named after the president of the Confederacy during the American Civil War, Jefferson Davis.

[[Lafourche Parish, Louisiana]]

[[Madison Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 1830s establishments in Louisiana, 1839 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Madison Parish (French: Paroisse de Madison) is a parish located on the northeastern border of the U.S. state of Louisiana. It is in the delta lowlands along the Mississippi River. As of the 2010 census, the population was 12,093. Its parish seat is Tallulah. The parish was formed in 1839.

[[Equus (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 drama movies, American drama movies, British drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Sidney Lumet, American independent movies

Equus is a 1977 British American drama movie directed by Sidney Lumet and based on the play of the same name by Peter Shaffer. It stars Richard Burton, Peter Firth, Colin Blakely, Joan Plowright, Eileen Atkins, Jenny Agutter and was distributed by United Artists. It was nominated for 3 Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1978.

[[Richland Parish, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Louisiana, 1868 establishments in the United States, Louisiana parishes

Richland Parish is a parish located in the North Louisiana Delta Country in the U.S. state of Louisiana. The parish seat and largest community is Rayville. The parish was officially created on September 29, 1868.

[[The Buddy Holly Story]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Steve Rash

The Buddy Holly Story is 1978 American biographical movie about Buddy Holly and was directed by Steve Rash. It stars Gary Busey, Don Stroud, Charles Martin Smith, Conrad Janis, Maria Richwine and was distributed by Columbia Pictures. It was nominated for three Oscars and won one Academy Award in 1979.

[[LaPlace, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Louisiana

LaPlace (l lə) is a census-designated place (CDP) in St. John the Baptist Parish, Louisiana, United States. It is near the east bank of the Mississippi River. The population was 32,134 at the 2010 census.

[[Andrahlu]]

[[Alexanderplatz]]

CATEGORIES: Town squares, Geography of Berlin

Alexanderplatz is a square on the northeastern edge of the historic center of Berlin. The rectangular square in the Mitte district goes back to the square in front of King Thor and was given its current name after the Russian Tsar Alexander I in 1805. In the Berlin vernacular, he is usually only called "Alex".

[[José María Calleja]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2020 deaths, Spanish writers, Political activists, Journalists, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain

José María Fernández Calleja (16 May 1955 – 21 April 2020) was a Spanish journalist, political prisoner and anti-ETA activist. He was born in León, Spain. He worked for CNN+ from 1999 to 2010. He was a professor of journalist at Charles III University of Madrid. From 1973 to 1974, he was a political prisoner under the Francisco Franco dictatorship.

Calleja was diagnosed with COVID-19 in March 2020. He died from the infection at a Madrid hospital on 21 April 2020, aged 64.

[[Shōmei Yokouchi]]

CATEGORIES: Japanese politicians, 1942 births, 2020 deaths

Shōmei Yokouchi was a Japanese politician. He represented the Yamanashi Prefecture electoral district and later Yamanashi District No. 3 in the House of Representatives from 1993 until 2002. He was Governor of Yamanashi Prefecture from 2007 until 2015. Yokouchi was born in Nirasaki, Yamanashi.

Yokouchi died on 21 April 2020, aged 78.

[[Leonie Kooiker]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2020 deaths, Dutch children's writers, Writers from Overijssel

Leonie Kooiker (20 October 1927 – 16 April 2020) was a Dutch children's writer. She was born in Markelo, Netherlands. She published for the children's magazine Kris Kras. Her first book (Het malle ding van bobbistiek)), won her the Gouden Griffel. Her book Het Oerlanderboek, won her the Vlag en Wimpel award.

Kooiker died in Papendrecht, Netherlands on 16 April 2020, aged 92.

[[Els Pelgrom]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Dutch children's writers, People from Arnhem, Writers from Gelderland

Els Pelgrom (born 2 April 1934), pseudonym of Else Koch, is a Dutch children's writer. Pelgrom is the only author to have received the Gouden Griffel award three times. She was born in Arnhem, Netherlands. Her best known books are  De kinderen van het achtste woud, Kleine Sofie en Lange Wapper and De eikelvreters.

[[Thé Tjong-Khing]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, Living people, Cartoonists, Comics artists, Dutch artists, Dutch writers, Illustrators, Indonesian people, Naturalised citizens of the Netherlands

Thé Tjong-Khing (鄭宗瓊; born August 4, 1933) is a Chinese-born Dutch children's book illustrator and writer. He was born in Purworedjo, Java. 

He was a freelance illustrator providing illustration to many children's book authors such as van Guus Kuijer, Els Pelgrom, Sylvia Vanden Heede and Dolf Verroen. Tjong-Khing won the Gouden Penseel (Golden Brush) award three times, and in 2005 won the Woutertje Pieterse Prijs for his book Waar is de taart? (Where is the cake?). 

In 2010 he won the Max Velthuijs-prijs (Max Velthuijs Prize).

[[Ditherington Flax Mill]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Shrewsbury, Industrial buildings completed in 1797, Shropshire, Textile mills in England, Listed buildings

[[Dolf Verroen]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, Dutch children's writers, People from Delft, Writers from South Holland

Dolf Verroen (born 20 November 1928) is a Dutch children's writer. He was born in Delft, Netherlands. Verroen made his debut in 1955 with the poetry collection In los verband. His first children's book Het boek van Jan-Kees was published in 1958. He won the Zilveren Griffel award four times.

In 1999 he became Ridder in the Order of the Netherlands Lion.

In 2006 he won the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis for his book Wie schön weiß ich bin.

[[Jan Reehorst]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, Living people, Aldermen of the Netherlands, Dutch councillors, Dutch mayors, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Labour Party (Netherlands) politicians, Politicians from Rotterdam

Jan Reehorst (born 21 March 1923 in Rotterdam) is a former Dutch politician. He is a member of the Labour Party. From 1953 until 1973 he was a member of the municipal council, and from 1967 to 1973 also an alderman of Rotterdam. Between 1956 and 1967 he was a member of the House of Representatives. In 1973 he became mayor of Velsen and from 1977 till 1984 he was mayor of Haarlem.

[[Harrie Geelen]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, Animators, Dutch artists, Dutch movie directors, Dutch poets, Illustrators, People from Heerlen, Translators, Writers from Limburg (Netherlands)

Harrie Geelen (born 10 January 1939) is a Dutch illustrator, movie director, animator, translator, writer and poet.  In 2014, he was made a knight of the Order of the Dutch Lion. Geelen was born in Heerlen, Netherlands. His best known novel series Kunt u mij de weg naar Hamelen vertellen, mijnheer?, were published in the 1970s.

He studied in Amsterdam, which is where he met his wife Imme Dros. Geelen wrote several well known television children's programs and translated Disney movies into Dutch.

[[Imme Dros]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, Dutch children's writers, Writers from North Holland

Imme Dros (born 26 September 1936) is a Dutch children's writer. She was born in Oudeschild, Texel. She studied Dutch in Amsterdam. There she met her husband Harrie Geelen. She wrote her first book in 1971. Her husband has illustrated several of her books. Dros' works were mainly about fables or Odysseus during the Trojan War.

[[Church Stretton railway station]]

CATEGORIES: Railway stations in England, Shropshire

Church Stretton railway station is a railway station serving the market town of Church Stretton in Shropshire, England.

It is located on the Welsh Marches line, 12 3⁄4 miles (20.5 km) south of Shrewsbury railway station; though trains on the Heart of Wales line also stop at the station. All trains services are operated by Transport for Wales, who also manage the station.

The station opened on 20 April 1852 as part of the newly created Shrewsbury and Hereford Railway.

It is the highest station in Shropshire, 613 ft (187 m) above sea level.

[[Guus Kuijer]]

CATEGORIES: Writers from Amsterdam, 1942 births, Living people

Guus Kuijer (ɣys ˈkœyər; born 1 August 1942) is a Dutch author. He wrote books for children and adults. He is best known for the Madelief series of children's books. He won the Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award from the Swedish Arts Council in 2012. He was one of five finalists for the biennial, international Hans Christian Andersen Award in 2008. Kuijer was born in Amsterdam.

[[Platoon]]

CATEGORIES: Military

A platoon is small military unit. A platoon is made from two or more squads or sections. It is usually the smallest military unit which is commanded by an officer.

[[Halloween Kills]]

CATEGORIES: 2021 movies, Upcoming sequel movies, Halloween movies, 2020s horror movies, Movies set in 2018

Halloween Kills is an upcoming American horror movie directed by David Gordon Green and written by Green, Danny McBride and Scott Teems. It is a sequel to 2018's Halloween and the twelfth installment in the Halloween franchise. 

The movie stars Jamie Lee Curtis and Nick Castle replaying their roles as Laurie Strode and Michael Myers. Judy Greer, Andi Matichak, Kyle Richards, Charles Cyphers and Nancy Stephens reprise their roles from the 2018 and 1978 movies, with Anthony Michael Hall also joining. 

Halloween Kills is scheduled to be released in the United States on October 15, 2021, by Universal Pictures. Another sequel, Halloween Ends, is scheduled to be released on October 15, 2021.

[[David Gordon Green]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, People from Little Rock, Arkansas, People from Charleston, South Carolina, American movie directors, American screenwriters, American movie producers, American television producers, American television directors, American television writers, Businesspeople from Arkansas, Businesspeople from South Carolina, Writers from Arkansas, Writers from South Carolina

David Gordon Green (born April 9, 1975) is an American movie director, producer and screenwriter. He directed the dramas George Washington (2000), All the Real Girls (2003), and Snow Angels (2007).

Green also directed comedy movies such as Pineapple Express (2008), Your Highness and The Sitter (both 2011). Green also directed the horror movie Halloween (2018), and will return to direct the sequels Halloween Kills (2020) and Halloween Ends (2021).

Green also directed episodes of the comedy series Eastbound & Down (2009–2013), Red Oaks (2014–17), Vice Principals (2016–17), and The Righteous Gemstones (2019–present).

Briançon is a commune. It is found in the Hautes-Alpes department in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region in the southeastern part of France.

[[The Hidden Oracle]]

CATEGORIES: Rick Riordan

The Hidden Oracle is the first book in Trials of Apollo. It features Apollo, brought down to Earth as a human, Lester, who is enslaved to Meg Mcaffery, Daughter of Demeter. They must fix the Oracle of Delphi, so that it can once again speak of prophecies and legends. 

There are 5 books in the series.

The Dark Prophecy #2

The Burning Maze #3

[[Sutton Coldfield]]

CATEGORIES: Birmingham, Civil parishes in England, Royal Towns in the United Kingdom, Towns in the West Midlands (county)

Sutton Coldfield, officially the Royal Town of Sutton Coldfield, is a suburban town and civil parish located in the Borough of Birmingham in the county of the West Midlands, England. However, it used to be part of Warwickshire. It is about 7 miles (11 km) northeast of Birmingham city centre. The 2011 census revealed the parish has a population of 95,107 people.

It is a very old town. There are still examples of Roman roads and old architecture.

It is a royal town because King Henry VIII granted it a Charter of Incorporation and named it a royal town in 1528 due to the influence of Bishop Vesey who was born in Sutton Coldfield. He became Henry VIII's chaplain and then became Bishop of Exeter.

The area is seen as one of the most expensive places to live in the United Kingdom.

Sutton Coldfield railway station is on the Cross-City Line. Passengers can get direct trains to Birmingham, Redditch and Bromsgrove.

[[Barnet]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in London

Barnet is a small town located in North London. In 2018, it had a population of 392,140 people

[[Jugend musiziert]]

CATEGORIES: Austrian culture, Germany, Music competitions

Jugend musiziert is a very common music competition for childrens and young people in Germany and Austria. Almost a million childrens and young people have in 57. years participated at Jugend Musiziert. For many of them, this was the first step in a very successful music career.

[[Köthen]]

Köthen (Anhalt) (1885–1927 officially Cöthen) is a city in the state of Saxony-Anhalt in Germany. It is the capital of the district of Anhalt-Bitterfeld. As of 31 December 2018, 25,911 people lived there.

[[Transport for Wales Rail Services]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s establishments in the United Kingdom, 2018 establishments in Europe, Train operating companies

Transport for Wales Rail Services (TfW Rail Services) was a British train company. It runs trains throughout Wales and parts of England. It is owned by Keolis/Amey Wales Cymru Limited. The company is also known as: Transport for Wales and TfW Rail (Welsh: Trafnidiaeth Cymru and TrC Trenau) for their day-to-day operations. It was replaced by Transport for Wales Rail Limited (owned by the Welsh Government) in February 2021.

They were awarded the contract for the Wales and Borders franchise by the (commercially separate) government body Transport for Wales in 2018. TfW Rail Services commenced rail operations on 14 October 2018, taking over from Arriva Trains Wales.

The company runs trains throughout Wales and into parts of England, mainly Cheshire, Shropshire, Herefordshire, Manchester, Liverpool and Birmingham. 

They run local stopping services between Cardiff and towns throughout South Wales, including Swansea, Carmarthen, Bridgend and Merthyr Tydfil, as well as longer distance services between Wales and Manchester, Shrewsbury and Birmingham. Some local services also extend to Gloucester and Cheltenham.

[[Põlva County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Põlva County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is also named Põlva.

The county is divided into municipalities. There are 3 rural municipalities in Põlva County.

[[Pärnu County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Pärnu County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is also named Pärnu. It is on the coast of the Gulf of Riga.

The county is divided into municipalities. There is one urban municipality and six rural municipalities in Pärnu County.

[[Livarot-Pays-d'Auge]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Calvados

Livarot-Pays-d'Auge is a commune that is in the region Normandy in the Calvados department in the northwest of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 and consists of the 22 former communes of Livarot (the seat), Auquainville, Les Autels-Saint-Bazile, Bellou, Cerqueux, Cheffreville-Tonnencourt, La Croupte, Familly, Fervaques, Heurtevent, Le Mesnil-Bacley, Le Mesnil-Durand, Le Mesnil-Germain, Meulles, Les Moutiers-Hubert, Notre-Dame-de-Courson, Préaux-Saint-Sébastien, Sainte-Marguerite-des-Loges, Saint-Martin-du-Mesnil-Oury, Saint-Michel-de-Livet, Saint-Ouen-le-Houx and Tortisambert.

[[Cesny-les-Sources]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 establishments in France, Communes in Calvados

Cesny-les-Sources is a commune. It is found in the region Normandy in the Calvados department in the northwest of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2019 and consists of the former communes of Acqueville, Angoville, Cesny-Bois-Halbout, Placy and Tournebu.

[[Order of Santiago]]

CATEGORIES: Catholicism, Organizations

The order of Santiago, or Saint James the sword, is an order who's entrance is granted to people of legitimate and noble blood. (By maternal and paternal grandparents.) Santiago is the patron saint of Spain. It was created in the 1100s, and is a religious and military order. It was originally made to defend Christendom, but has evolved into one of the most acclaimed military orders in the world.

Oelixdorf is a municipality of the district Steinburg, in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany.

Wettolsheim is a commune. It is found in the Haut-Rhin department in eastern France. 

[[Brewster, Nebraska]]

[[Interiors]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Woody Allen

Interiors is a 1978 American drama movie directed by Woody Allen and stars Geraldine Page, Diane Keaton, Mary Beth Hurt, Maureen Stapleton, Sam Waterston, Kristin Griffin. It was distributed by United Artists and was nominated for 5 Oscars in 1979.

[[Hedda (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 drama movies, British drama movies

Hedda is a 1975 British drama movie directed by Trevor Nunn and was adapted by Henrik Ibsen's play Hedda Gabler. It stars Glenda Jackson in her Oscar nominated performance, Peter Eyre, Timothy West, Patrick Stewart and Pam St. Clement.

[[Adagio (music)]]

CATEGORIES: Music theory

Adagio is a tempo in music. Usually it is one of the slower tempos but not as slow as Lento.

[[Little Murders]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 comedy movies, American comedy movies

Little Murders is a 1971 American black comedy movie. It is directed by and stars Alan Arkin. The movie is based on the play by Jules Feiffer. Other actors include Elliott Gould, Marcia Rodd, Doris Roberts, Alan Arkin, Vincent Gardenia, and Donald Sutherland. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Night of the Creeps]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 horror movies, 1986 science fiction movies, 1986 comedy movies, 1980s science fiction horror movies, American science fiction horror movies

Night of the Creeps is a 1986 American science fiction horror comedy movie. It was the first movie Fred Dekker directed. It stars Jason Lively, Shane Black, Jill Whitlow, and Tom Atkins. It was distributed by TriStar Pictures.

The movie did not make very much money in theaters. Since then, it has become a cult favorite.

no variety is recognized jet i.e. E a. var polygona Wight

[[Atlantic City (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 drama movies, 1980s crime movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, Canadian romance movies, Canadian drama movies, French crime movies, French romance movies, French drama movies, Movies directed by Louis Malle

Atlantic City is a 1980 Canadian French romantic crime drama movie. It was directed by Louis Malle. Actors include: Susan Sarandon, Burt Lancaster, Al Waxman, Kate Reid, Hollis McLaren, and Robert Goulet. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

Atlantic City was nominated for 5 Oscars at the Academy Awards in 1982.

[[Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex* (*But Were Afraid to Ask) (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Woody Allen, Movies based on books

Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex* (*But Were Afraid to Ask) is a 1972 American comedy movie directed by Woody Allen (who also stars) and based on the 1969 novel of the same name by David Reuben. It also stars John Carradine, Lou Jacobi, Burt Reynolds, Lynn Redgrave, Tony Randall, Anthony Quayle, Gene Wilder and was distributed by United Artists.

[[Saare County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Saare County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is Kuressaare. The county is Saaremaa, the largest island of Estonia, and several smaller islands near it. Notable islands are Muhu, Ruhnu, Abruka and Vilsandi.

[[Saaremaa]]

CATEGORIES: Islands of Europe, Geography of Estonia

Saaremaa is the largest island in Estonia. It is 2673. The island is in the Baltic Sea, south of Hiiumaa island and west of Muhu island. It belongs to the West Estonian Archipelago.

The highest point on Saaremaa is 54 m above sea level. One feature found on the island is the Kaali crater. The island has lots of forested land. One of the symbols of the island is the juniper.

[[Robert Biedroń]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1976 births, Polish politicians, Mayors, MEPs for Poland, LGBT politicians

Robert Biedroń (born 13 April 1976) is a Polish politician. He was the mayor of the city of Słupsk from 2014 to 2018.

In 2011, he was elected to the Sejm as a member of the Palikot's Movement party, becoming first coming out gay Member of Parliament in Poland. He gave up his seat before just before swearing in office of mayor, whom he was in years 2014–2018. He is the chairman of Spring ("Wiosna") since 2019. He has been also a Member of the European Parliament (2019–present). He was one of the candidates for the Polish presidential election 2020.

[[Shrewsbury Castle]]

CATEGORIES: Listed buildings, Castles in England, Buildings and structures in Shrewsbury

Shrewsbury Castle is a medieval castle located in the county town of Shrewsbury in Shropshire, England. It is built out of red sandstone and stands on a hill in the neck of the meander of the River Severn. It is directly above Shrewsbury railway station and is a Grade I listed building.

[[Ystradgynlais]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Powys

Ystradgynlais  (ˌəstradˈɡənlais, lang) is a town in the south-west of the county of Powys, Wales. It is the second largest town in Powys, the largest being Newtown. It is situated on the banks of the River Tawe in the historic county of Brecknockshire.

The town was first recorded in 1372. The place-name "Ystradgynlais", meaning "vale of the river Cynlais" – may derive from cyn (a chisel) and glais (a stream). Cynlais may also be a personal name.

Ystradgynlais is one of the few areas within the historic county Brecknockshire that has a reasonably high proportion of speakers of the Welsh language. According to the 2001 census, more than half of all the Welsh-speakers within the Brecknock district live in Ystradgynlais.

Parc-yr-Orsedd in the town has a monument dedicated to fallen heroes of both World Wars from Ystradgynlais, Abercraf, Cwmtwrch, Cwmgiedd, Glyntawe and Coelbren.

[[Newtown, Powys]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Powys

Newtown  (Welsh: Y Drenewydd) is a new town in the county of Powys, Wales. Its population of 11,357 makes it the largest town in Powys. It lies on the River Severn in the historic county of Montgomeryshire.

Newtown lies about 8 miles (13 km) from the border with England.

At the end of the 13th century, Edward I commissioned Roger de Montgomery to construct a centre for the hamlet of Llanfair-yng-Nghedewain. Situated near a River Severn ford below the Long Bridge and close to the church of St Mary in Bettws Cedewain gave Newtown its original Welsh name. The town grew in the 18th and 19th centuries around the textile and flannel industry, accompanied by the completion of the Montgomeryshire Canal. In 1838, the town saw Wales's first Chartist demonstration.

The town has a mainline railway station on the Cambrian Line between Shrewsbury and Aberystwyth. Managed and served by Transport for Wales, trains run roughly two-hourly each way.

The town also has a semi-professional football club, Newtown AFC, who are currently members of the Welsh Premier League, and a rugby club, Newtown RFC.

Newtown is twinned with:

[[Welshpool]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Powys

Welshpool  (Welsh: Y Trallwng) is a small town and community in the unitary authority of Powys, Wales. It is the fourth largest town in Powys, with a population of 6,664. It lies on the banks of the River Severn and is in the historic county of Montgomeryshire. It is known for its Georgian architecture.

The town is situated around 4 miles (6.4 km) from the border with Shropshire in England. Its name in the Welsh language, Y Trallwng, means "the marshy or sinking land". In English, it was initially known as Pool but its name was changed to Welshpool in 1835 to differentiate it from the Dorset town of Poole.

It served briefly as the capital of Powys Wenwynwyn after its prince was forced to flee the traditional Welsh royal site at Mathrafal in 1212, by the prince of Gwynedd. Assistance from the English crown (the enemies of the Gwynedd prince) restored the Wenwynwyn dynasty to their lands.

The town has a mainline railway station on the Cambrian Line between Shrewsbury and Aberystwyth. Managed and served by Transport for Wales, trains run roughly two-hourly each way.

[[Tartu County]]

CATEGORIES: Counties of Estonia

Tartu County is a county in Estonia. The capital city is also named Tartu.

Tartu is between Lake Võrtsjärv and Lake Peipsi. The Emajõgi river is in the county. Nature preserves take up about 10% of the county's land. The biggest of them being Emajõe Suursoo and Alam-Pedja.

[[Jack Wallace (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: Drama Desk Award winners, 2020 deaths, 1933 births, American stage actors, American television actors, American movie actors, Actors from Chicago

Jack Wallace (August 15, 1933 – April 16, 2020) was an American actor. He was born in Pekin, Illinois and was raised in Chicago. He had also appeared in such movies as Death Wish (1974), House of Games (1987), Above the Law (1988) and Boogie Nights (1997). In television, he appeared on Law & Order and Six Feet Under.

Wallace was a co-recipient of the 1984 Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Ensemble, which he shared with the rest of the cast members in the Broadway production of David Mamet's Glengarry Glen Ross. 

Wallace died on April 16, 2020 at his home in Los Angeles, aged 86.

[[Derek Jones (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, 2020 deaths, American rock singers, American rock guitarists, Singers from California, Musicians from California

Derek Jones (June 5, 1984 – April 21, 2020) was an American guitarist. He was best known as the rhythm and lead guitarist and often co-lead vocalist for the American post-hardcore band Falling in Reverse. He was also the guitarist of the American band A Smile From the Trenches. 

Jones died on April 21, 2020 at the age of 35.

[[Lewis MacAdams]]

CATEGORIES: American poets, American critics, People from San Angelo, Texas, Writers from Los Angeles, California, Journalists from Texas, Journalists from California, American political activists, 1944 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease

Lewis MacAdams (October 12, 1944 – April 21, 2020) was an American poet, journalist, political activist, and filmmaker. He was born in San Angelo, Texas. He was the co-founder of FoLAR. In 2001, he published his Birth of The Cool, a cultural history of the idea of cool.

MacAdams was a contributing editor of the L.A. Weekly and wrote regularly on culture and ecology for Rolling Stone, Men’s Journal, and The Los Angeles Times. MacAdams was the director of the Poetry Center at San Francisco State University from 1975 to 1978.

MacAdams died on April 21, 2020 in Los Angeles of Parkinson's disease-related problems, aged 75.

[[Angie Craig]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 births, Living people, LGBT politicians, Lesbians, United States representatives from Minnesota, Politicians from Arkansas, US Democratic Party politicians

Angela Dawn Craig (born February 14, 1972) is an American politician. She is the United States Representative from MN since 2019. She is a member of the Democratic Party.

Craig is openly lesbian.

Eagan (ˈ) is a city in Dakota County, Minnesota, United States. The city is south of Saint Paul. The population of Eagan was 64,206 at the 2010 census. 

[[Veronica Escobar]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, Living people, United States representatives from Texas, Politicians from El Paso, Texas, US Democratic Party politicians

Veronica Escobar (born September 15, 1969) is an American politician. She is the U.S. Representative for TX since 2019. She is a member of the Democratic Party. She was an El Paso County Commissioner from 2007 to 2011 and the El Paso County Judge from 2011 until 2017.

[[Marcia Fudge]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people, African American politicians, United States representatives from Ohio, United States Secretaries of Housing and Urban Development, Politicians from Cleveland, Ohio, US Democratic Party politicians

Marcia Louise Fudge (born October 29, 1952) is an American politician. Fudge is the 18th and current United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development since 2021. She was the U.S. Representative from OH from 2008 until 2021. She is a member of the Democratic Party.  

Fudge was Chair of the Congressional Black Caucus in the 113th Congress.

In December 2020, Fudge was nominated by President-elect Joe Biden to serve as the United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. She was confirmed by the United States Senate on March 10, 2021.

[[Warrensville Heights, Ohio]]

Warrensville Heights is a city located in Cuyahoga County, Ohio, United States. It is an East Side suburb of Cleveland. The population was 13,542 at the 2010 U.S. Census.

[[Jacques Pellen]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 deaths, 1957 births, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, French musicians, Jazz musicians, Guitarists, People from Brest, France

Jacques Pellen (1957 – 21 April 2020) was a French jazz guitarist. Pellen worked with many musicians over the years such as Peter Gritz, Kenny Wheeler, Bruno Nevez, Henri Texier, Riccardo Del Fra, and violinist Didier Lockwood. Pellen was born in Brest, France.

Pellen died of COVID-19 on 21 April 2020, aged 63.

[[Los Alamos, New Mexico]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New Mexico, County seats in New Mexico

Los Alamos (Los Álamos, meaning "The Cottonwoods" or "The Poplars") is a town in Los Alamos County, New Mexico, United States. The town is located on four mesas of the Pajarito Plateau, and has a population of 12,019. It is the county seat and one of two population centers in the county known as census-designated places (CDPs); the other is White Rock.
