[[Teruyuki Okazaki]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Japanese martial artists, Japanese educators

Teruyuki Okazaki (岡崎 照幸, June 22, 1931 – April 21, 2020) was a tenth degree black belt in Shotokan Karate. He was the founder and chief instructor of the International Shotokan Karate Federation (ISKF). Along with Gichin Funakoshi and Masatoshi Nakayama, Okazaki helped found the Japan Karate Association's instructor training program. He was born in Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan.

Okazaki died on April 21, 2020 of COVID-19 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania at the age of 88.

[[Masatoshi Nakayama]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 1987 deaths, Japanese martial artists, Japanese writers, Japanese educators

Masatoshi NakayamaA was a famous

Japanese master of Shotokan karate. He helped create the Japan Karate Association (JKA) in 1949, and wrote many textbooks on karate.

For almost 40 years, until his death in 1987, Nakayama worked to spread Shotokan karate around the world. He was the first master in Shotokan history to attain the rank of 9th dan while alive.

Nakayama died on April 15, 1987 in Tokyo, aged 74.

[[Murphy's Romance]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, 1985 romance movies, 1980s romantic comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by Martin Ritt

Murphy's Romance is a 1985 American romantic comedy movie directed by Martin Ritt and is based on the 1980 novella by Max Schott. It stars James Garner, Sally Field, Corey Haim, Brian Kerwin, Carole King, Anna Levine. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures and was nominated for two Oscars.

[[Central nervous system disease]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Central nervous system diseases, also known as central nervous system disorders, are a group of neurological disorders that affect the structure or function of the brain or spinal cord. They form the central nervous system (CNS).

[[The Fan (1981 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 horror movies, American horror movies, Movies based on books

The Fan is a 1981 American slasher fan directed by Edward Bianchi and based on the novel of the same name by Bob Randall. It stars Lauren Bacall, James Garner, Maureen Stapleton, Michael Biehn, Hector Elizondo, Griffin Dunne, Dana Delany and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Legislative Yuan]]

CATEGORIES: Taiwan

The Legislative Yuan is the unicameral legislature of the Republic of China now based in Taiwan. It is one of the five branches (五院) of government. The parliament of the republic includes all three of the National Assembly (now abolished), the Legislative Yuan, and the Control Yuan.

[[Liu Ping-wei]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from oral cancer, Taiwanese politicians

Liu Ping-wei (劉炳偉; 30 November 1952 – 21 April 2020) was a Taiwanese politician. He was first elected to the Taiwan Provincial Assembly in 1981 until 1998. Liu was speaker of the provincial assembly between 1994 and 1998. For a single term, he was a member of the Legislative Yuan from 1999 to 2002. Liu was born in Banqiao, Taipei County.

Liu died of oral cancer in Banqiao on 21 April 2020, aged 67.

[[Jacques Rosny]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors, French voice actors, French comedians, Actors from Paris

Jacques Rosny (25 March 1939 – 18 April 2020) was a French actor and comedian. He was born in Tarbes, France. In 1973, he bought Théâtre de l'Athénée. His best known roles were in The Tenant, Catherine & Co. and L.627. In 1985, he won the Prix du Brigadier.

Rosny died on 18 April 2020 of COVID-19 in Nogent-sur-Marne, France, aged 81.

[[Eio Sakata]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2010 deaths, Japanese Go players

Eio Sakata was a 9-dan Japanese professional Go player at Nihon Ki-in. He has the honorary Honinbo (本因坊) title and the honorary NHK Cup title.

[[Bill Morris, Baron Morris of Handsworth]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Trade unionists, British businesspeople, British activists

William Manuel Morris, Baron Morris of Handsworth, OJ, DL (born 19 October 1938), generally known as Bill Morris, is a former British trade union leader. He was General Secretary of the Transport and General Workers' Union from 1992 to 2003. He was the first black leader of a major British trade union. Morris became a member of the House of Lords in 2006. He is a member of the Labour Party.

[[The Beyond]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 horror movies, Italian horror movies, Movies directed by Lucio Fulci

The Beyond is a 1981 Italian horror movie directed by Lucio Fulci, and starring Catriona MacColl, David Warbeck, Cinzia Monreale. It is the second of the Fulci's trilogy of "Gates of Hell" trilogy.

[[Marguerite Higgins]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 1966 deaths, Infectious disease deaths in the United States, American war correspondents, American columnists, Pulitzer Prize winners

Marguerite Higgins Hall (September 3, 1920spaced ndashJanuary 3, 1966) was an American reporter and war correspondent. She was born in Hong Kong. Higgins reported on events during World War II, the Korean War, and the Vietnam War. She wanted equal access for female war correspondents. 

She had a long career with the New York Herald Tribune (1942–1963), and later became a columnist for Newsday (1963–1965). She was the first woman to win a Pulitzer Prize for Foreign Correspondence.

Hall died on January 3, 1966 of leishmaniasis in Washington, D.C. at the age of 45.

[[Peter Arnett]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, CNN people, American war correspondents, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Officers of the New Zealand Order of Merit, New Zealand writers, Pulitzer Prize winners

Peter Gregg Arnett, ONZM (born 13 November 1934) is a New Zealand-born American journalist. He is known for his coverage of the Vietnam War and the Gulf War. He was awarded the 1966 Pulitzer Prize in International Reporting for his work in Vietnam from 1962 to 1965. He worked for the Associated Press.

[[Kaku Takagawa]]

CATEGORIES: 1915 births, 1986 deaths, Japanese Go players

Kaku Takagawa, also known as Shūkaku Takagawa, was one of the greatest professional Go player of the 20th century. He has the honorary Honinbo (本因坊) title.

[[John Pilger]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, War correspondents, Australian journalists, Australian critics, Australian movie directors, Writers from New South Wales

John Richard Pilger (ˈ; born 9 October 1939) is an Australian journalist, writer, and documentary filmmaker. 

Pilger is a strong critic of American, Australian, and British foreign policy. He is against imperialist and colonialist agenda. 

He first drew international attention for his reports on the Cambodian genocide.

His career as a documentary film maker began with The Quiet Mutiny (1970). Other works include Year Zero (1979), about the aftermath of the Pol Pot regime in Cambodia, and Death of a Nation: The Timor Conspiracy (1993). 

Pilger worked at the Daily Mirror from 1963 to 1986, and wrote a regular column for the New Statesman magazine from 1991 to 2014.

Pilger won Britain's Journalist of the Year Award in 1967 and 1979. 

[[Robert Elegant]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, Living people, American novelists, British novelists, British war correspondents, American war correspondents, Writers from New York City

Robert Sampson Elegant (born March 7, 1928) is a British-American author and journalist. He was born in New York City. He spent many years in Asia as a journalist. He covered both the Korean and the Vietnam Wars.

[[Frances FitzGerald]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Pulitzer Prize winners, American political writers, American historians, American war correspondents, Journalists from New York City

Frances FitzGerald (born October 21, 1940) is an American journalist and historian. She is known for her written work Fire in the Lake: The Vietnamese and the Americans in Vietnam (1972), which is about the Vietnam War. It won the Pulitzer Prize, Bancroft Prize, and National Book Award. She was born in New York City.

[[Michael Herr]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2016 deaths, American war correspondents, American political writers, American autobiographers, American screenwriters, Writers from Kentucky

Michael David Herr (April 13, 1940 – June 23, 2016) was an American writer and war correspondent. He was known as the author of Dispatches (1977). He was a correspondent for Esquire magazine (1967–1969) during the Vietnam War. 

[[Volunteers (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 comedy movies, American comedy movies

Volunteers is a 1985 American comedy movie directed by Nicholas Meyer and starred Tom Hanks, John Candy, Rita Wilson, Gedde Watanabe, Allan Arbus. It was distributed by TriStar Pictures.

[[Delhi, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Delhi (ˈ DEL) is a town in Delaware County, New York, United States. The population was 5,117 at the 2010 census.

[[Wharton, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: County seats in Texas, Cities in Texas

Wharton is a city in and the county seat of Wharton County, Texas, United States.  This city is 60 southwest of Houston. The population was 8,832 at the 2010 census. 

[[Stanley Karnow]]

CATEGORIES: Pulitzer Prize winners, 1925 births, 2013 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, American historians, American war correspondents, American political writers, Journalists from New York City

Stanley Abram Karnow (February 4, 1925 – January 27, 2013) was an American journalist and historian. He is best known for his writings on the Vietnam War. He was born in Brooklyn, New York. In 1990, he won a Pulitzer Prize.

Karnow died on January 27, 2013 in Potomac, Maryland of congestive heart failure, aged 87.

[[Neil Sheehan]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Pulitzer Prize winners, American war correspondents, Writers from Massachusetts, People from Holyoke, Massachusetts

Cornelius Mahoney "Neil" Sheehan (October 27, 1936 – January 7, 2021) was an American journalist. He worked for The New York Times in 1971. Sheehan obtained the classified Pentagon Papers. His series of articles revealed a secret United States Department of Defense history of the Vietnam War and led to a Supreme Court case.

He received a Pulitzer Prize and a National Book Award for his 1988 book A Bright Shining Lie. He was born in Holyoke, Massachusetts.

Sheehan died at his Washington, D.C. home on January 7, 2021 from problems caused by Parkinson's disease, aged 84. 

[[Hideyuki Fujisawa]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2009 deaths, Japanese Go players

Hideyuki Fujisawa, also known as Shuko Fujisawa, was a Japanese professional Go player. He has the honorary kisei (Board Master) title and several students who has become professional players.

[[Pentagon Papers]]

CATEGORIES: Vietnam War, Lyndon B. Johnson

The Pentagon Papers, officially titled Report of the Office of the Secretary of Defense Vietnam Task Force, is a United States Department of Defense history of the United States' political and military involvement in Vietnam from 1945 to 1967. 

The papers were released by Daniel Ellsberg, who had worked on the study. They were first brought to the attention of the public on the front page of The New York Times in 1971. 

A 1996 article in The New York Times said that the Pentagon Papers had showed, among other things, that the Johnson Administration "systematically lied, not only to the public but also to Congress."

[[Don McCullin]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, British war correspondents, British photojournalists, Writers from London

Sir Donald McCullin, CBE, Hon FRPS (born 9 October 1935), is a British photojournalist. He is known for his war photography. His career, which began in 1959, has been about examining the underside of society. His photos also covered the Vietnam War-era. 

[[Richard Butler (diplomat)]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Governors of Tasmania, Order of Australia, Politicians from New South Wales

Richard William Butler AC (born 13 May 1942) is a retired Australian public servant. He served as the 25th Governor of Tasmania from 2003 to 2004. He was Australian Ambassador to the United Nations from 1992 to 1997

Butler was born in Coolah, New South Wales. He was married to government official Susan Ryan from 1963 to 1972. The couple have two children.

[[Co Rentmeester]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, Dutch journalists, Dutch Olympians, Photojournalists, Rowers, Sportspeople from Amsterdam, War correspondents, Writers from Amsterdam

Jacobus Willem Rentmeester (born 28 February 1936), nicknamed "Co" or "Ko", is a Dutch rower. He later became a photojournalist and covered the Vietnam War among other newsworthy events. He was born in Amsterdam.  He competed in the 1960 Olympics.

[[Wolfen (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s crime movies, 1981 horror movies, American horror movies

Wolfen is a 1981 American crime horror movie directed by Michael Wadleigh and based on the 1978 novel by Whitley Strieber. It stars Albert Finney, Diane Venora, Gregory Haines, Edward James Olmos, Tom Waits, Tom Noonan and was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[Nick Ut]]

CATEGORIES: Pulitzer Prize winners, 1951 births, Living people, Vietnamese people, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American war correspondents, American photojournalists

Huỳnh Công Út, known professionally as Nick Ut (born March 29, 1951) is a Vietnamese American photographer. He worked for the Associated Press (AP). He won both the 1973 Pulitzer Prize for Spot News Photography and the 1973 World Press Photo of the Year for "The Terror of War". The picture showed children running away from a napalm bombing during the Vietnam War. 

His best-known photo, it features a naked 9-year-old girl, Phan Thị Kim Phúc, running toward the camera from a South Vietnamese napalm strike  that mistakenly hit Trảng Bàng village instead of nearby North Vietnamese troops. 

On March 29, 2017, he retired from AP.

[[Max Hastings]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, British war correspondents, BBC people, Writers from London

Sir Max Hugh Macdonald Hastings GBR (ˈ; born 28 December 1945) is a British journalist. He has worked as a foreign correspondent for the BBC, editor-in-chief of The Daily Telegraph, and editor of the Evening Standard. He was born in London.

[[Bernard Kalb]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, Living people, American critics, American war correspondents, American educators, Writers from New York City

Bernard Kalb (born February 4, 1922) is an American journalist, moderator, media critic, lecturer, and author. He was born in New York City. He covered international affairs for more than thirty years at CBS News, NBC News and The New York Times. His brother, Marvin Kalb, is also a journalist. 

In 1984, Kalb was appointed Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs and spokesman for the State Department. It was the first time that a journalist who covered the State Department had been named as its spokesperson.

[[Phase IV]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s science fiction movies, 1974 horror movies, American science fiction horror movies, British science fiction movies, British horror movies

Phase IV is a 1974 British American science fiction horror movie directed by Saul Bass and starred Nigel Davenport, Michael Murphy, Lynne Frederick. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures and was a box office disappointment.

[[Julian Pettifer]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, BBC people, British war correspondents, British television presenters, Living people, Writers from Wiltshire

Julian Pettifer OBE (born 21 July 1935) is an British television journalist. He was born in Malmesbury, Wiltshire. He is known for his coverage during the Vietnam War. He was President of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds and is Vice President of the Royal Society of Wildlife Trusts and the RSPB. He was voted BAFTA 'Reporter of the Year' in 1968. He was the host for the British television show Busman's Holiday from 1985 to 1988.

[[Pierre Schoendoerffer]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2012 deaths, French movie directors, French screenwriters, French educators, War correspondents, French military people

Pierre Schoendoerffer (Pierre Schœndœrffer; 5 May 1928 – 14 March 2012) was a French movie director, screenwriter, war reporter and educator. He was a First Indochina War veteran. He was president of the Académie des Beaux-Arts for 2001 and for 2007. In 1967, he was the winner of the Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature for The Anderson Platoon. He was born in Chamalières, France.

Schoendoerffer died on 14 March 2012 in Clamart, France, aged 83.

[[Mézidon Vallée d'Auge]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in France, Communes in Calvados

Mézidon Vallée d'Auge is a commune. It is found in the region Normandy in the Calvados department in the northwest of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Mézidon-Canon (the seat), Les Authieux-Papion, Coupesarte, Crèvecœur-en-Auge, Croissanville, Grandchamp-le-Château, Lécaude, Magny-la-Campagne, Magny-le-Freule, Le Mesnil-Mauger, Monteille, Percy-en-Auge, Saint-Julien-le-Faucon and Vieux-Fumé.

[[National symbols of Bangladesh]]

CATEGORIES: National symbols of Bangladesh, Bangladeshi culture

The National symbols of Bangladesh (Bengali:বাংলাদেশের জাতীয় প্রতীকসমূহ); consisting most of symbols to represent Bangladeshi traditions and ideals that reflect the different aspects of the cultural life and history. Bangladesh has several official national symbols including a historic document, a flag, an emblem, an anthem,  memorial towers as well as several national heroes. There are also several additional other patriotic symbols including the national animal, bird, flower and tree... They are listed here respectively.

[[Caged Heat]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 drama movies, 1974 crime movies, 1970s LGBT movies, American action movies, American crime drama movies, Movies directed by Jonathan Demme

Caged Heat, also known as Renegade Girls, is a 1974 prison action drama movie directed by first time director Jonathan Demme and stars Erica Gavin, Roberta Collins, Barbara Steele.

[[Aleksandr Kapto]]

CATEGORIES: Russian scientists, Russian politicians, Russian journalists, Ukrainian writers, Ukrainian scientists, Ukrainian politicians, Sociologists, 1933 births, 2020 deaths, Ambassadors of Russia, Political scientists

Aleksandr Semenovich Kapto (April 14, 1933 – April 19, 2020) was a Russian-Ukrainian scientist, sociologist, political scientist,  journalist and politician. In 2008, he became head of the UNESCO International Board of the Institute of Socio-Political Research under the Russian Academy of Sciences (RAS). He was born in Dnipropetrovsk Oblast, Ukrainian SSR, USSR. 

He was a Soviet Ambassador to Cuba from 1985 to 1990, and the last Soviet and first Russian Ambassador to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea.

[[The Brink's Job]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s crime drama movies, 1978 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by William Friedkin

The Brink's Job is a 1978 American crime comedy drama movie directed by William Friedkin and based on the novel Big Stick-Up at Brinks by Noel Behn. It stars Peter Falk, Peter Boyle, Allen Garfield, Warren Oates, Gena Rowlands, Paul Sorvino. It was distributed by Universal Pictures and was nominated for an Oscar in 1979.

[[Rhett & Link]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, 1978 births, Living people, American television presenters, Internet celebrities, Duos, Entertainers from North Carolina, Entertainers from Georgia (U.S. state), People from Macon, Georgia, American bloggers

Rhett & Link are an American comedy duo with Rhett McLaughlin (born October 11, 1977) and Charles Lincoln "Link" Neal (born June 1, 1978). They call themselves "Internetainers" (portmanteau of "Internet" and "entertainers"). They are known for creating and hosting the YouTube series Good Mythical Morning.

Their other known projects include comedic songs and sketches, Independent Film Channel series Rhett & Link: Commercial Kings, and their YouTube Premium series Rhett and Link's Buddy System (Season 1 and Season 2).

Rhett was born in Macon, Georgia. Link was born in Boone Trail, North Carolina. They met while in elementary school in North Carolina.

[[Islam in UAE]]

CATEGORIES: Islam by country

Islam is official religion recognized in all the seven emirates of UAE . Almost all the Emirati citizens are muslims  but the United Arab Emirates have often advocated freedom of religion. Today about 80%  of the local population of UAE is Muslim. There are about 8% Hindus, 5% Christians and Sikh and Buddhist minorities 

Islam is the religion of all UAE nationals since the Islamic conquest of Arabia in 7th century . The UAE population is mostly Sunni (80% of Muslims) and a large Shiite minorities(20% population of the muslim population). Islam has influenced UAE culture it shows in their political system ,their the sense of dressing ,their culture and tradition. Mosques flourish across the emirates you can spot a mosque anywhere from a small street to large street. The law in UAE is based on Sharia laws and there are both civil courts as well as Sharia Court . Flogging is the punishment for adultery, alcohol consumption lashes can range from 80 to 200. Stoning is form of capital punishment and is legal in UAE . Kissing is not allowed in public and punishable by law with imprisionment and lashes. Homosexuality is a criminal offence and is punishable by law . Apostasy and disrespecting and insulting Islam is criminal offence in UAE . According to article 1 and article 33 of UAE penal code it is punishable by death sentence .Pork is considered haram in Islam and is forbidden by Muslims However Non Musliim can eat it on his own will Publicly eating and drinking during Ramadan from sunrise to sunset is illegal irrespective of the faith and the violators shall face severe punishment. Everyone has right to practice their religion in UAE but they are not allowed to convert Muslim into their faith . However they can convert into Islam on their own will. Israeli citizens and the person holding an Israeli visa is not allowed in UAE due to tensions between Israel and Arab World

[[Murphy's War]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s war movies, 1971 drama movies, British drama movies, World War II movies, Movies directed by Peter Yates

Murphy's War is a 1971 World War II drama movie directed by Peter Yates and based on the 1969 novel of the same name by Max Catto. It stars Peter O'Toole, Siân Phillips, Philippe Noiret, Horst Janson, John Hallam and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Llandudno Junction]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Conwy

Llandudno Junction (Welsh: Cyffordd Llandudno), once known as Tremarl, is a town in the Conwy County Borough, Wales. It is part of the ancient parish of Llangystennin and is located south of the seaside resort of Llandudno. It adjoins the small town of Deganwy and is to the east of Conwy, which is on the opposite side of the River Conwy.

The town grew up around, and is named after, Llandudno Junction railway station, which is a junction between the North Wales Coast Line and the Conwy Valley line. There are regular direct trains to Manchester, Llandudno, Holyhead, Blaenau Ffestiniog, Birmingham and South Wales, as well as a few trains a day to London. 

The Old Station Hotel stands opposite the station. It is known locally as "The Killer" or in Welsh "Y Killer". One version of the myth on how it got its name is that train drivers would get drunk there, then drive trains, effectively turning them into possible 'Killers'. Another version states that this is where the railway workers would spend their lunch breaks, i.e. 'killed time'.

It currently has a population of 6,722.

[[The Hot Rock (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1972 comedy movies, 1972 crime movies, American criminal comedy movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Peter Yates

The Hot Rock is a 1972 American crime comedy caper movie directed by Peter Yates from the screenplay by William Goldman and based on the novel of the same name by Donald E. Westlake. It stars Robert Redford, George Segal, Ron Leibman, Paul Sand, Moses Gunn, Zero Mostel, Christopher Guest and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Vire-Normandie]]

The Friends of Eddie Coyle is a 1973 American crime drama movie directed by Peter Yates and based on the 1970 novel of the same name by George V. Higgins. It stars Robert Mitchum, Peter Boyle, Steven Keats, Alex Rocco and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[White-breasted waterhen]]

CATEGORIES: Birds of Asia, Gruiformes

The white-breasted waterhen (Amaurornis phoenicurus) is a waterbird of the rail and crake family, Rallidae, that is widely distributed across South and Southeast Asia.

[[Jimmy Goodfellow]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, English footballers, English football managers, Sportspeople from County Durham

James Goodfellow (16 September 1943 – 22 April 2020) was an English professional footballer and manager. He played as a midfielder.

Goodfellow was born in Bishop Auckland. In the Football League, he played for Port Vale, Workington, Rotherham United and Stockport County. He scored 33 goals in 479 league games in a 13-year career in the Football League. He later managed Cardiff City in 1984.

Goodfellow died in Newport, Wales, on 22 April 2020. He was 76.

[[Höfner 500/1]]

CATEGORIES: Bass guitars

The Höfner 500/1 Violin Bass (also called the "Beatle bass" or "Cavern bass") is an electric bass guitar made by Höfner since 1955. It became very popular in the 1960s when Paul McCartney of The Beatles started using it.

[[Marcos Mundstock]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Argentine comedians, Argentine musicians, Argentine writers, Cancer deaths in Argentina, Deaths from brain cancer, People from Santa Fe, Argentina, Spanish actors, Spanish musicians

Marcos Mundstock (25 May 1942 – 22 April 2020) was an Argentine musician, writer and comedian. He is best known as a founding member of comedy musical group Les Luthiers. He was born in Santa Fe, Argentina. He became a Spanish citizen in 2012.

Mundstock died of brain cancer on 22 April 2020 in Buenos Aires. He was 77.

[[Hafþór Júlíus Björnsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, Icelandic movie actors, People from Reykjavík, Television actors, Strength athletes

Hafþór Júlíus Björnsson (ˈhafθour ˈjuːlijʏs ˈpjœr̥sɔːn; born 26 November 1988) is an Icelandic professional strongman and actor. In 2018, he became the first person to have won the Arnold Strongman Classic, Europe's Strongest Man and World's Strongest Man. He also played Gregor "The Mountain" Clegane in the HBO series Game of Thrones for five seasons.

Hafþór was born in Reykjavík. In March 2017, he was diagnosed with Bell's palsy. He is married to Canadian Kelsey Henson. The couple have one child.

[[Catherine Paysan]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2020 deaths, French poets, French screenwriters, French playwrights, French novels, French educators

Annie Hausen (4 August 1926 – 22 April 2020), known by her pen name Catherine Paysan, was a French writer. She won the Grand prix de littérature de la SGDL for her lifetime’s writing. Paysan wrote novels, poems, screenplays and plays. Paysan was born in Aulaines, France. 

She published several novels, five autobiographical works, two collections of poetry and two plays. She also adapted several of her works for movies. In 1977, she received the Grand prix de littérature de la SGDL for the whole of her work.

Paysan was named an Officier in the French Legion of Honour in 2011.

Paysan died on 22 April 2020 in Le Mans, France at the age of 93.

[[Le Malesherbois]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Loiret

Le Malesherbois is a French commune. It is in the Loiret department. The municipality was created on 1 January 2016 and consists of the former communes of Malesherbes (the seat), Coudray, Labrosse, Mainvilliers, Manchecourt, Nangeville and Orveau-Bellesauve.

[[Malesherbes, Loiret]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Loiret

Malesherbes is a former French commune. It is in the Loiret department. On 1 January 2016, it became a part of the new commune of Le Malesherbois.

[[Kuyavian-Pomeranian Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: Voivodeships of Poland

Kuyavian-Pomeranian Voivodeship is one of the 16 voivodeships of Poland. The capitals are Bydgoszcz and Toruń.

[[Lublin Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: Voivodeships of Poland, 1990s establishments in Poland, 1999 establishments in Europe

Lublin Voivodeship is one of the 16 voivodeships of Poland. It can be found in the southeast Poland and in west Lesser Poland. The capital city is also named Lublin.

It was created on January 1, 1999. Polesie National Park and Roztocze National Park are both in the voivodeship.

[[Łódź Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: Voivodeships of Poland

Łódź Voivodeship is one of the 16 voivodeships of Poland. The capital city is also named Łódź.

[[Joule per mole]]

CATEGORIES: SI units

The joule per mole (symbol: J·mole−1 or J/mol) is an SI derived unit of energy per amount of material. Energy is measured in joules, and the amount of material is measured in moles. In other words, joule per mole is a unit for how much energy is in a certain amount of matter.

[[Avogadro's law]]

CATEGORIES: Gases

Avogadro's law is a gas law in chemistry that states "equal volumes of all gases, at the same temperature and pressure, have the same number of molecules". This means that if two gases have the same volume and pressure, and temperature, they will have the same number of molecules. 

[[Goessel, Kansas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Marion County, Kansas

Goessel is a city in Marion County, Kansas, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 539.  It is located about 11 miles north of North Newton.

[[North Newton, Kansas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Kansas

North Newton is a city in Harvey County, Kansas, United States. As of the 2010 census, the city population was 1,759.  The city of Newton is located south.

[[Conwy]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Conwy

Conwy, traditionally known in English as Conway, is a walled coastal market town in Conwy County Borough, North Wales. It faces the smaller town of Deganwy across the River Conwy. Historically, it was located in Gwynedd and before that, Caernarfonshire.

The town's name originates from the old Welsh words "cyn" (chief) and "gwy" (water). The river of the same name was also originally called the Cynwy.

The community, which also includes the smaller towns of Llandudno Junction and Deganwy, has a population of 14,723. The town itself has a population of 4,065.

The town is a popular tourist destination and is famous for its castle, built between 1283 and 1289, beach and town walls.

[[Van Tuong Nguyen]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 births, 2005 deaths, Australian criminals, Australian drug dealers, Australian prisoners, People executed by hanging, People from Melbourne, Twin people from Australia

Van Tuong Nguyen (Nguyễn Tường Vân; 17 August 1980 – 2 December 2005) was an Australian man convicted of drug trafficking. In 2002, he was arrested in Singapore during an international flight stopover from Phnom Penh to Melbourne. He admitted to bringing 396.2 grams of heroin into the country. He was sentenced to death in 2004. Singapore rejected pleas for clemency from the Australian government, Amnesty International, the Holy See and others. 

On 2 December 2005, Nguyen was executed by hanging at Changi Prison in Changi, Singapore. He was 25.

Nguyen was born at a refugee camp in Songkhla, Thailand. His parents were Vietnamese. He had a twin brother, Khoa Nguyen.

[[Rubem Fonseca]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Translators, Brazilian writers

Rubem Fonseca (May 11, 1925 – April 15, 2020) was a Brazilian writer and translator. He was born in Juiz de Fora, in the state of Minas Gerais. His stories were known as dark and gritty, filled with violence and sexual content. He started his career by writing short stories. His first popular novel was A Grande Arte (High Art), but "Agosto" is usually considered his best work.

Fonseca died of a heart attack on April 15, 2020 in Rio de Janeiro, aged 94.

[[Richard Akinjide]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2020 deaths, Nigerian politicians, Nigerian lawyers, Judges

Chief Osuolale Abimbola Richard Akinjide, SAN (4 November 1930 – 21 April 2020) was a Nigerian lawyer and politician. He was born in Ibadan, Western Region. He worked under Prime Minister Tafawa Balewa and President Shehu Shagari. From 1979 to 1983, Akinjide was Minister of Justice.

Akinjide died on 21 April 2020 in Ibadan, aged 89.

[[Yakubu Gowon]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Presidents of Nigeria, Generals

General Yakubu "Jack" Gowon (born 19 October 1934) is a Nigerian politician and general. He was the head of state of Nigeria from 1966 to 1975. He ruled during the deadly Nigerian Civil War. He took power after the 1966 Nigerian counter-coup and was overthrown in the 1975 Nigerian coup d'état.

[[Ernest Shonekan]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, Presidents of Nigeria, Nigerian lawyers, Nigerian businesspeople

Oloye Ernest Adegunle Oladeinde Shonekan (born 9 May 1936) is a Nigerian politician, lawyer and businessman. He was appointed the interim President of Nigeria by General Ibrahim Babangida on 26 August 1993. Babangida resigned after the 1993 election was annulled.

[[Ibrahim Babangida]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Presidents of Nigeria, Generals

General Ibrahim Badamasi Babangida (born 17 August 1941) popularly known as IBB, is a Nigerian politician and military general. He was military President of Nigeria from 1985 until his resignation in 1993. He also was the Chief of Army Staff from January 1984 to August 1985.  

[[Lubusz Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Poland, 1999 establishments in Europe, Voivodeships of Poland

Lubusz Voivodeship is a voivodeship (province) in western Poland. The functions of regional capital are shared between two cities: Gorzów Wielkopolski and Zielona Góra.

It was created on January 1, 1999, out of the former Gorzów Wielkopolski and Zielona Góra Voivodeship.

[[Deganwy]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Conwy

Deganwy, or Degannwy in Middle Welsh, is a small town and electoral ward on the Creuddyn Peninsula in Conwy County Borough, Wales.

It is a relatively small town most notable for Deganwy Castle, situated 110 m above the town. In the 6th century, it was fortified as the stronghold of Maelgwn Gwynedd, king of Gwynedd.

Nowadays, it is located in Conwy County Borough but historically it was located in Caernarfonshire.

The town currently has a population of 3,936.

The town has a railway station on the Llandudno Branch Line and the Conwy Valley line. Transport for Wales provide direct trains to Llandudno, Blaenau Ffestiniog, Chester, Manchester and Crewe.

[[Mike Curtis]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2020 deaths, American football linebackers, American autobiographers, Indianapolis Colts players, Seattle Seahawks players, Washington Redskins players, Writers from Maryland, People from Rockville, Maryland, Sportspeople from Maryland

James Michael Curtis (March 27, 1943 – April 20, 2020) was an American professional football player for the Baltimore Colts, the Seattle Seahawks and the Washington Redskins. He played 14 seasons from 1965 to 1978 in the National Football League (NFL). He was a four-time Pro Bowler in 1968, 1970, 1971 and 1974. Curtis was born in Rockville, Maryland.

Curtis died on April 20, 2020 in St. Petersburg, Florida, aged 77.

[[Podlaskie Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Poland, 1999 establishments in Europe, Voivodeships of Poland

Podlaskie Voivodeship  is a Voivodeship (province) in Poland. The capital of Podlasie Province is Białystok. The province was created on 1 January 1999.

Białowieża Forest and Knyszyń Forest are in Podlaskie.

[[Pomeranian Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Poland, 1999 establishments in Europe, Voivodeships of Poland

Pomeranian Voivodeship is a voivodeship, or province, in northwestern Poland. The provincial capital is Gdańsk.

The voivodeship was made on January 1, 1999, out of the former voivodeships of Gdańsk, Elbląg and Słupsk.

There are two national parks in Pomerania: Słowiński National Park and Tuchola Forest National Park.

[[Podkarpackie Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Poland, 1999 establishments in Europe, Voivodeships of Poland

Podkarpackie Voivodeship is a voivodeship, or province, in Poland. It is also known as Subcarpathian Voivodeship. Its administrative capital and largest city is Rzeszów. 

Podkarpackie was created on 1 January 1999. Bieszczady National Park, and part of Magura National Park, are in the voivodeship.

[[Fender Precision Bass]]

CATEGORIES: Bass guitars

The Fender Precision Bass (sometimes shortened to P-Bass) is an electric bass that has been made by Fender since 1951. It was the first popular electric bass to be made and has four strings with one split-coil humbucking pickup. It was also the first bass guitar to have a solid body.

[[Fender Jazz Bass]]

CATEGORIES: Bass guitars

The Fender Jazz Bass (sometimes known as a J-Bass) is an electric bass that has been made by Fender since 1960. It was the second bass to be made by Fender, after the Fender Precision Bass. The original version has four strings and two single-coil pickups.

[[Warmian-Masurian Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Poland, 1999 establishments in Europe, Voivodeships of Poland

Warmian-Masurian Voivodeship is a voivodeship (province) in Poland. Its capital and largest city is Olsztyn. 

It was created on January 1, 1999.

[[West Pomeranian Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s establishments in Poland, 1999 establishments in Europe, Voivodeships of Poland

West Pomeranian Voivodeship is a voivodeship (province) in northwestern Poland. Its capital and largest city is Szczecin.

It was created on January 1, 1999.

West Pomeranian Voivodeship is along the Baltic Sea coast, with many beaches, lakes and woodlands. Szczecin, Świnoujście and Police are important ports. Other major seaside towns include Międzyzdroje, Dziwnów, Kołobrzeg, and Mielno.

[[Cabo Delgado Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Cabo Delgado is a province of Mozambique. The capital is Pemba.

[[Gaza Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique, 1954 establishments

Gaza is a province of Mozambique. The capital is Xai-Xai. The province was created on October 20, 1954.

Most of the district is in the basin of the Limpopo River. It empties into the Indian Ocean near Xai-Xai. The Changane River forms part of the province's eastern border. The Save River forms the northern border.

Limpopo National Park and Banhine National Park are in the province.

[[Amilly, Loiret]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Loiret

Amilly is a French commune. It is in the Loiret department.

[[Groesbeck, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, County seats in Texas

Groesbeck is a city in the U.S. state of Texas.

[[Butte, Nebraska]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Nebraska, County seats in Nebraska

Butte is a village in Nebraska in the United States. It is the county seat of Boyd County.

[[Labrosse, Loiret]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Loiret

Labrosse is a former French commune. It is in the Loiret department. On 1 January 2016, it became a part of the new commune of Le Malesherbois.

[[Le Moulinet-sur-Solin]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Loiret

Le Moulinet-sur-Solin is a French commune. It is in the Loiret department.

[[George Ezra]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, English singer-songwriters, English pop singers, People from Hertfordshire, Living people, English musicians, British musicians, English rock singers

George Ezra Barnett (born 7 June 1993), known professionally as George Ezra, is an English singer, songwriter and guitarist from Hertford, Hertfordshire.

He rose to fame with his 2014 single Budapest which reached number one in several countries.

In February 2019, he won the Brit Award for British Male Solo Artist.

[[Inhambane Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Inhambane is a province of Mozambique. The capital is Inhambane.

The region was visited by Vasco da Gama in 1498. He claimed Inhambane Bay for Portugal. The Portuguese created a trading post at Inhambane in 1534.

The province has two of Mozambique's national parks: Zinave National Park in the northwest and Bazaruto National Park on the Bazaruto Archipelago. There is also Pomene National Reserve.

As of 2017, approximately 113,288 people live there. 

[[Wewelsfleth]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in Schleswig-Holstein, Steinburg (district)

Wewelsfleth is a municipality of the district Steinburg, in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany.

[[Andonville]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Loiret

Andonville is a French commune. It is in the Loiret department.

[[Wahkiakum County, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Washington (state), 1854 establishments in the United States, Washington (state) counties

Wahkiakum County is a county in Washington in the United States. The county seat is Cathlamet. 3,978 people lived there at the 2010 census.

[[Lewis County, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: 19th-century establishments in Washington (state), 1845 establishments in the United States, Washington (state) counties

Lewis County is a county in Washington in the United States. The county seat is Chehalis. 75,455 people lived there at the 2010 census.

[[Ardon, Loiret]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Loiret

Ardon is a French commune. It is in the Loiret department.

[[Michael Müller]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, Mayors of Berlin, Politicians from Berlin

Michael Müller (born December 9, 1964 in West Berlin) is a German politician (SPD). In 2014, he became mayor of Berlin. From November 2017 to October 2018 he was President of the Federal Council, from November 2018 to October 2019 First Administration.

[[Porthmadog]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Gwynedd

Porthmadog (p; pɔrθˈmadoɡ) is a coastal town and community in Gwynedd, Wales.

The 2011 census revealed that the town has a population of 4,185.

Until 1974, it was also known by its anglicised name of Portmadoc and was known locally as Port. The town came into existence after William Madocks built a sea wall, the Cob, between 1808 and 1811.

[[Potsdamer Platz]]

CATEGORIES: Town squares, Geography of Berlin

Potsdamer Platz is a place-like traffic junction in Berlin's Mitte and Tiergarten districts in the Mitte district between the old city center in the east and the new Berlin west. As a double-site facility, it connects to Leipziger Platz to the west.

[[Steinway D-274]]

CATEGORIES: Piano

D-274 (or D) is the model name of the largest concert grand from Steinway & Sons. It was first built in its current version in 1884. This instrument is the first choice of most concert pianists and dominates both concert halls and recordings. A company author estimated that more than 90% of the concert grand worldwide are Steinway D-274.

With the dimensions 274 cm length, 157 cm width and a weight of 500 kg (status: 2020) the concert grand of the D category is too large for most private environments.

[[Jadranka Đokić]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1981 births, Croatian actors

Jadranka Đokić (born 14 January 1981) is a Croatian actress. For her roles in theatre, television and film, she is considered one of the greatest Croatian actresses of her generation.

[[Paradise (George Ezra song)]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 songs, Songs

Paradise is a song by English singer-songwriter George Ezra. It is the second single from his 2018 studio album "Staying at Tamara's".

The song was written by Ezra himself and was produced by Cam Blackwood. It was officially released digitally on 19 January 2018. A music video was released a week later, on 24 January. Ezra performed the track live for the first time on British TV show The Graham Norton Show on 2 February 2018.

The song reached the top ten in Austria, Belgium, Ireland, and the United Kingdom, and also peaked at number one in Scotland.

Ezra has said the song was aiming to capture "a feeling that takes over when you've fallen in love", and was dedicated to his girlfriend and the early days of their relationship.

[[Paradise Alley]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Sylvester Stallone

Paradise Alley is a 1978 American sports drama movie directed and written by first time director Sylvester Stallone (who also starred) about professional wrestling. It also stars Armand Assante, Anne Archer, Kevin Conway, Joe Spinell, Tom Waits, Frank Stallone and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Tom Grennan]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 births, English singer-songwriters, English pop singers, English guitarists, English rock singers, People from Bedfordshire, Living people, English musicians

Tom Bevin Grennan (born 8 June 1995) is an English musician from Bedford, Bedfordshire who is currently based in London.

Grennan first found fame as a featured vocalist on Chase & Status' single "All Goes Wrong". The song was the "Hottest Record" on DJ Annie Mac's BBC Radio 1 show, giving Grennan a chance to experience the BBC Radio 1 Live Lounge.

Grennan is of partly Irish origin. He is a big fan of football and is a big supporter of Manchester United. At the age of 18, Grennan was mugged by a group of strangers on the street and was left with four metal plates and screws in his jaw that he has stated "still hurt when winter comes".

[[Lugu Lake]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of China, Sichuan, Yunnan

Lugu Lake (泸沽湖) is a lake in the Yunnan plateau in China. The lake is part of the border between Ninglang County, Yunnan and Yanyuan County, Sichuan. It is an alpine lake. Because it is at an elevation of 2685, it is the highest lake in all of Yunnan. The lake is surrounded by mountains. It has five islands, four peninsulas, fourteen bays, and seventeen beaches.

[[Crazy Mama]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s action movies, 1975 comedy movies, American action comedy movies, Movies directed by Jonathan Demme

Crazy Mama is a 1975 American action comedy movie directed by Jonathan Demme and stars Cloris Leachman, Stuart Whitman, Linda Purl, Ann Sothern, Bill Paxton, Dennis Quaid, Sally Kirkland, John Milius. It was distributed by New World Pictures.

[[The 1975]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s British music groups, 2010s British music groups, English rock bands, Musical groups established in 2002, Musical groups from Manchester

The 1975 are an English pop rock band from the town of Wilmslow, Cheshire who are currently based in Manchester.

The band currently consists of lead vocalist and rhythm guitarist Matthew Healy, lead guitarist Adam Hann, bassist Ross MacDonald, and drummer George Daniel. Healy is the son of actors Denise Welch and Tim Healy.

The band members all met while attending Wilmslow High School and played together as teenagers. Organised gigs by a council worker led to the band formally signing with Dirty Hit and Polydor Records.

As of May 2019, they had won 10 awards from 40 nominations.

[[Gordon's War]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 movies, 1970s action movies, American action movies, Blaxploitation movies

Gordon's War is a 1973 action movie directed by Ossie Davis. It stars Paul Winfield, David Downing, Gilbert Lewis, Ralph Wilcox, Nathan Heard, Grace Jones and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Wilmslow]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Cheshire

Wilmslow is a small town and civil parish in the ceremonial county of Cheshire, England. It falls within the Cheshire Golden Triangle and is one of the most sought-after places to live in the UK after Central London.

The 2011 census revealed that the population of Wilmslow was 24,497.

The name "Wilmslow" derives from the Anglo-Saxon "Wīghelmes hlāw" meaning "mound of a man called Wīghelm".

The town has a railway station on the Crewe–Manchester line. The station has direct trains to Manchester Airport, Manchester itself, London, Liverpool, Crewe, Shrewsbury and South Wales.

Mathematician, computer scientist and logician Alan Turing died in the town. However, the actual reason for his death, which is said to be suicide, is still disputed.

[[Sorcerer (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s adventure movies, 1977 thriller movies, American thriller movies, American adventure movies, Movies directed by William Friedkin, Trucker movies

Sorcerer is a 1977 American adventure thriller movie directed by William Friedkin and based on the Georges Arnaud's 1950 novel Le Salaire de la peur and remake of the 1953 movie The Wages of Fear. It stars Roy Scheider, Bruno Cremer, Francisco Rabal, Amidou, Ramon Bieri and distributed by Paramount Pictures and Universal Pictures. It was a commercial failure and being released around the same time as ''Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope.

[[Masao Sugiuchi]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2017 deaths, Japanese Go players

Masao Sugiuchi was a 9-dan professional Go player. He reached to 800 career wins, and he was the oldest professional player in Japan from 2004 to 2017.

[[Two Door Cinema Club]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s British music groups, 2010s British music groups, Northern Irish bands, Musical groups established in 2007, Musical groups from Northern Ireland

Two Door Cinema Club are a Northern Irish pop-rock band from Bangor, County Down.

The band formed in 2007 and consists of three main members; Alex Trimble, Kevin Baird and Sam Halliday. Trimble and Halliday met while attending Bangor Grammar School. The two later met Kevin Baird while he was flirting with girls who Trimble and Halliday knew. The three first performed as a band at the age of 16 on Northern Irish television programme ATL Rock School under the name Life Without Rory. However, the band finished in last place.

On 18 January 2011, the band appeared on the American late night talk show, Late Night with Jimmy Fallon, performing the song, "What You Know". The song would go on to become the biggest hit of the 2010 album "Tourist History".

[[Manica Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Manica is a province of Mozambique. The capital city is Chimoio.

The Save River creates the southern border. There is also the Zambezi river in the northeast. The highest mountain in Mozambique, Mount Binga (2436 m), is in this province near the border with Zimbabwe.

[[Maputo Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Maputo is a province of Mozambique. Its capital is the city of Matola. The province does not include the national capital of Maputo.

The Maputo Bay area to the southeast of Maputo is an important conservation area with many reefs and lakes. Of particular note is the Maputo Elephant Game Reserve, which has lakes such as Lagoa Chingute and Lagoa Piti. There is also the Machangulo Private Nature Reserve in the Machangulo Peninsula. The largest river of the province is the Maputo River. Inhaca Island is part of the province.

[[Nampula Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Nampula is a province in northern Mozambique. The capital city is also named Nampula.

The island Ilha de Moçambique, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is part of the province.

The Lúrio River forms the northern border. Mountains in the province include Mount Inago (1804 m), Mount Ribaue, Mount Panda and Mount Nairucu.

[[Luke Steele (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, Australian pop singers, Australian rock singers, Australian singer-songwriters, Electronic musicians, People from Perth, Western Australia

Luke James Steele (born 13 December 1979) is an Australian musician, singer and songwriter. He is best known as one half of the electronic music duo Empire of the Sun. He is also the vocalist and main songwriter of the alternative rock band The Sleepy Jackson. He was born in Perth, Western Australia. His sister, Katy Steele, is also a musician.

[[Nick Littlemore]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, Australian pop musicians, Australian rock musicians, Electronic musicians, Musicians from Sydney, Record producers

Nicholas George Littlemore (born 6 May 1978) is an Australian musician and record producer. He is known as a member of the musical trio Pnau (with Peter Mayes and Sam Littlemore) and duo Empire of the Sun (with Luke Steele). He was also a member of the band Teenager with New Zealand-born Pip Brown. He was born in Sydney, New South Wales.

[[The Holy Mountain]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s fantasy movies, 1973 drama movies, 1970s LGBT movies, Mexican movies, Movies directed by Alejandro Jodorowsky

The Holy Mountain (La montaña sagrada) is a 1973 Mexican fantasy drama movie directed by Alejandro Jodorowsky (who also stars and produces). It also stars Juan Ferrara, Horacio Salinas, and Ramona Saunders.

[[El Topo]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 drama movies, 1970s western movies, Mexican movies, Movies directed by Alejandro Jodorowsky

El Topo is a 1970 Mexican western movie directed, produced and starring Alejandro Jodorowsky, Brontis Jodorowsky, Alfonso Arau, Agustín Isunza.

[[The Owl and the Pussycat]]

CATEGORIES: 1970s romance movies, 1970 comedy movies, American romantic comedy movies, Movies directed by Herbert Ross

The Owl and the Pussycat is a 1970 American romantic comedy movie directed by Herbert Ross, based on the play of the same name by  and written by Buck Henry. It stars Barbra Streisand, George Segal, Robert Klein, Marilyn Chambers, Roz Kelly, Allen Garfield and was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[Koos van den Berg]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, Dutch Calvinists, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Politicians from The Hague, Reformed Political Party politicians

Jacobus Teunis "Koos" van den Berg (18 September 1942 – 21 April 2020) was a Dutch politician. He was born in The Hague. He was a member of the Reformed Political Party (SGP). He served as a member of the House of Representatives from 1986 to 2002.

On 21 April 2020, during the COVID-19 pandemic, van den Berg died due to the disease. He was 77.

[[Niassa Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Niassa is a province of Mozambique. The capital city is Lichinga.

The Ruvuma River forms much of the northern boundary of the province with Tanzania. Lake Niassa forms the western border of the province, separating it from Malawi. The province shares the Niassa National Reserve with neighboring Cabo Delgado Province.

[[Masao Kato]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 deaths, 1947 births, Japanese Go players

Masao Kato (加藤 正夫, Katō Masao, March 15, 1947 – December 30, 2004), also known as Kato Kensei (加藤剱正 Katō Kensei),  was a Japanese professional go player at Nihon Ki-in and former president of the International Go Federation. He won 46 titles, including the Oza (王座, King) eight times in a row. He also became the 2nd player to reach 1,200 career wins.

[[Sofala Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Sofala is a province of Mozambique. Beira is the capital of the province.

Rivers flowing through the province include the Chiveve River, the Buzi River, the Save River. Gorongosa National Park, at the southern end of the Great African Rift Valley,  covers several thousand square kilometres. The park has the 1863 Mount Gorongosa, a mountain which is considered sacred to the people of the country.

[[Magic (1978 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 horror movies, American horror movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Richard Attenborough

Magic is a 1978 American psychological horror drama movie directed by Richard Attenborough and based on the 1976 novel of the same name by William Goldham. It stars Anthony Hopkins, Ann-Margaret, Burgess Meredith, Ed Lauter, David Ogden Stiers and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Tete Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Tete is a province of Mozambique. The capital city is also named Tete.

The Cahora Bassa Dam is in this province.

[[Zambezia Province]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of Mozambique

Zambezia is a province in Mozambique. The capital city is Quelimane.

Bons Sinais River is in the province.

[[Thanksgiving of Horror]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 television episodes, The Simpsons (season 31) episodes, Thanksgiving television episodes, Treehouse of Horror

"Thanksgiving of Horror" is the 8th episode of the 31st season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on television on the Fox network on November 24, 2019. The episode is a Thanksgiving themed spin-off of the Treehouse of Horror series. This is the last episode to have Russi Taylor because she died on July 26, 2019. She was a voice actor for characters like Martin Prince, Sherri and Terri, and Üter Zörker.

[[An Unmarried Woman]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 comedy movies, 1978 drama movies, 1970s comedy-drama movies, American comedy-drama movies, Movies directed by Paul Mazursky

An Unmarried Woman is a 1978 American comedy drama movie directed and written by Paul Mazursky. It stars Jill Clayburgh, Alan Bates, Michael Murphy, Cliff Gorman and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for three Oscars in 1979.

[[The Fury (1978 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 thriller movies, 1970s science fiction movies, American science fiction movies, American thriller movies, Movies directed by Brian De Palma

The Fury is a 1978 American supernatural thriller movie directed by Brian De Palma and based on the 1976 novel of the same name by John Farris. It stars Kirk Douglas, Amy Irving, John Cassavetes, Carrie Snodgress, Charles Durning, Dennis Franz, Daryl Hannah and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Afar Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia

The Afar Regional State is one of the nine regional states of Ethiopia. It is the homeland of the Afar people. The capital city is Semera.

Danakil Depression is in the north of the region. It has the lowest point in Ethiopia and one of the lowest in Africa. The southern part of the region has the valley of the Awash River. Other notable landmarks include the Awash and Yangudi Rassa National Parks.

[[Amhara Region]]

CATEGORIES: Regions of Ethiopia

Amhara Region is a region of Ethiopia. It is the homeland of the Amhara people. The capital city is Bahir Dar.

Ethiopia's largest inland body of water, Lake Tana, is in Amhara. The region also has the Semien Mountains National Park. The park includes Ras Dashan, the highest point in Ethiopia. 

[[MacArthur (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 drama movies, 1970s war movies, American biographical movies, American drama movies, World War II movies, Movies directed by Joseph Sargent

MacArthur is a 1977 World War II biographical drama movie directed by Joseph Sargent with Gregory Peck playing the part of Douglas MacArthur and stars Ed Flanders and Dan O'Herlihy.

[[Double Negative]]

CATEGORIES: 1980 movies, 1980s thriller movies, Canadian thriller movies

Double Negative  (also known as Deadly Companion) is a 1980 Canadian thriller movie directed by George Bloomfield and based on the novel by Ross Macdonald. It stars John Candy, Susan Clark, Anthony Perkins, Howard Duff, Al Waxman, Kenneth Welsh, Kate Reid.

[[Loot (1970 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 comedy movies, 1970s crime movies, British comedy movies, British plays adapted into movies, Movies directed by Silvio Narizzano

Loot is a 1970 British crime comedy movie directed by Silvio Narizzano and based on the Joe Orton play of the same name. It stars Richard Attenborough, Lee Remick, Hywel Bennett, Milo O'Shea, Roy Holder, Dick Emery, Aubrey Woods, Harold Innocent and Stephen Yardley.

[[Illampu]]

CATEGORIES: Mountains of Bolivia, Andes

Illampu is a 6368 mountain in the Andes range, in Bolivia. It is the 27th highest mountain in the Andes.

[[Chopicalqui]]

CATEGORIES: Mountains of Peru, Andes

Chopicalqui is a 6345 mountain in the Andes range, in Peru. It is the 28th highest mountain in the Andes. 

[[Siula Grande]]

CATEGORIES: Mountains of Peru, Andes

Siula Grande is a 6344 mountain in the Andes range, in Peru. It is the 29th highest mountain in the Andes.

[[Solimana]]

CATEGORIES: Mountains of Peru, Andes

Solimana is a 6320 mountain in the Andes range, in Peru. It is the 32nd highest mountain in the Andes. 

[[Ampato]]

CATEGORIES: Mountains of Peru, Andes

Ampato is a 6310 mountain in the Andes range, in Peru. It is the 33rd highest mountain in the Andes. 

[[Endless Love (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 romance movies, 1981 drama movies, 1980s romantic drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Franco Zeffirelli

Endless Love is a 1981 American romantic drama movie directed by Franco Zeffirelli and based on the 1979 novel of the same name by Scott Spencer. It stars Brooke Shields, Martin Hewitt, Shirley Knight, Don Murray, Beatrice Straight, Ian Ziering, James Spader, Penelope Milford, Tom Cruise in his movie debut and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was nominated for 1 Oscar and 6 Razzies in 1982 and was remake in 2014.

[[The Phantom of Liberty]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 comedy movies, French comedy movies, Italian comedy movies, Movies directed by Luis Buñuel

The Phantom of Liberty is a 1974 French Italian comedy movie directed by Luis Buñuel. It stars Adriana Asti, Julien Bertheau, Jean-Claude Brialy, Adolfo Celi, Anne-Marie Deschodt, Michael Lonsdale.

[[Gajiginahal, Siruguppa]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in India

Gajiginahal is a village in the southern state of Karnataka, India. It is located in the Siruguppa taluk of Bellary district in Karnataka.

[[Nihon Ki-in]]

CATEGORIES: Japan, Board games, Culture, Non-profit organizations of Asia, Go organizations

The Nihon Ki-in (日本棋院), also known as the Japan Go Association, is the main (non-profit) organization for Go in Tokyo, Japan. It maintains Japan's professional player system and gives diplomas for amateur rankings.

[[Bengal Subah]]

CATEGORIES: Mughal Empire, West Bengal

Bengal Subah, sometimes called Mughal Bengal, was a part of the Mughal Empire between 1500 and 1700. It included places like Bangladesh and the Indian state of West Bengal. At one time, this area was one of the wealthiest parts of the world.

[[Mainvilliers, Loiret]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Loiret

Mainvilliers is a former French commune. It is in the Loiret department. On 1 January 2016, it became a part of the new commune of Le Malesherbois.

[[Aure sur Mer]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in France, Communes in Calvados

Aure sur Mer is a commune. It is found in the region Normandy in the Calvados department. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Sainte-Honorine-des-Pertes (the seat) and Russy.

[[Saadat Husain]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2020 deaths, Bangladeshi people, Civil servants, Deaths from kidney disease

Sadat Hussain (24 November 1946 – 22 April 2020) was a Bangladeshi civil servant. He notably served as chairman of the Bangladesh Public Service Commission from 2007 to 2011. He was born in Noakhali District.

On 22 April 2020, Husain died of kidney disease and other causes at a Dhaka hospital. He was 73.

[[Seulline]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 establishments in France, Communes in Calvados

Seulline is a commune. It is found in the region Normandy in the Calvados department in the northwest of France.

[[Aurseulles]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in France, Communes in Calvados

Aurseulles is a commune. It is in the region of Normandy in the Calvados department. This is in the northwest of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Anctoville (the seat), Longraye, Saint-Germain-d'Ectot and Torteval-Quesnay.

[[Hartwig Gauder]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Deaths from renal failure, Organ transplant recipients, German Olympic gold medalists, German architects, Sportspeople from Baden-Württemberg

Hartwig Gauder (10 November 1954 – 22 April 2020) was a German race walker and architect. He won a gold medal in the Men's 50 kilometres walk at the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow. He was born in Vaihingen an der Enz, Baden-Württemberg, West Germany.

In 1996, he had a viral heart infection that almost killed him. He recovered after having a heart transplant, but became disabled. Afterwards, he became an architect.

Gauder died while undergoing dialysis on 22 April 2020, aged 65. The cause of death was a heart attack caused by kidney failure.

[[Terence Frisby]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2020 deaths, British playwrights, British stage actors, Screenwriters from London

Terence Frisby (28 November 1932 – 23 April 2020) was a British playwright, actor, stage director and producer. He was best known as the author of the play There's a Girl in My Soup. He also helped write the screenplay for the movie version of the play. Frisby was born in London. 

Frisby died on 23 April 2020, aged 87.

[[Pomona, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Unincorporated communities in New Jersey, Census-designated places in New Jersey

Pomona is an unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) located within Galloway Township, in Atlantic County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the CDP's population was 7,124. 

[[Galloway Township, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in New Jersey

Galloway Township is a township in Atlantic County, New Jersey, United States. At 115.2 of total area, Galloway Township is the largest municipality in the State of New Jersey. As of the 2010 United States Census, the township's population was 37,349.

[[Kim Yo-jong]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, North Korean politicians, People from Pyongyang

Kim Yo-jong (김여정, born 26 September 1988) is a North Korean politician. She is the youngest daughter of former supreme leader Kim Jong-il. Her brother is Kim Jong-un, the current supreme leader.

She is an alternate member of the Politburo (Political Bureau) and vice director of the Propaganda and Agitation Department of the Workers' Party of Korea (WPK).

[[Jimmy Carter rabbit incident]]

CATEGORIES: Jimmy Carter, 1979 in the United States

The Jimmy Carter rabbit incident, also known as a "killer rabbit attack" by the press, involved a swamp rabbit that swam toward then–U.S. President Jimmy Carter's fishing boat on April 20, 1979. 

The incident became popular in the media after Carter's press secretary, Jody Powell, mentioned the event to a correspondent months later.

President Carter was fishing in his hometown of Plains, Georgia on April 20, 1979, alone in a flat-bottomed boat while staff were on land nearby. Carter said a rabbit being chased by hounds "jumped in the water and swam toward my boat. When he got almost there, I splashed some water with a paddle".

When Carter returned to his office, his staff did not believe his story, saying rabbits could not swim, or that one would never approach a person threateningly. A White House photographer took a picture of the incident, which was released by a later administration.

[[Swamp rabbit]]

CATEGORIES: Mammals of North America, Lagomorphs

The swamp rabbit (Sylvilagus aquaticus), or swamp hare, is a large cottontail rabbit found in the swamps and wetlands of the Southern United States. Other common names for the swamp rabbit include marsh rabbit and cane-cutter. The species likes to live in wet areas, and can swim.

[[Jody Powell]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2009 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, White House Press Secretaries, Politicians from Georgia (U.S. state), US Democratic Party politicians

Joseph Lester "Jody" Powell, Jr. (September 30, 1943 – September 14, 2009) was the White House Press Secretary during the presidency of Jimmy Carter from 1977 to 1981. Powell later co-founded a public relations firm. He was born in Cordele, Georgia.

Powell died on September 14, 2009 of a heart attack in Cambridge, Maryland, aged 65.

[[Cordele, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

Cordele is a city in Crisp County, Georgia, United States. The population was 11,147 at the 2010 census. The city is the county seat of Crisp County.

[[Crisp County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1905 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Crisp County is a county in the center of the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 23,439. The county seat is Cordele. The county was created on August 17, 1905.

[[Dooly County, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: 1821 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state), Georgia (U.S. state) counties

Dooly County is a county located in the central portion of the U.S. state of Georgia. As of the 2010 census, the population was 14,918. The county seat is Vienna.

[[Vienna, Georgia]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Georgia (U.S. state), County seats in Georgia

The city of Vienna (v) is the county seat of Dooly County, Georgia, United States. The population was 4,011 at the 2010 census. It is named after Vienna, in Austria.

[[Hamilton Jordan]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2008 deaths, Deaths from mesothelioma, White House Chiefs of Staff, Politicians from Charlotte, North Carolina, US Democratic Party politicians

William Hamilton McWhorter Jordan (September 21, 1944 – May 20, 2008) was an American politician. He was the Chief of Staff to President of the United States Jimmy Carter from 1979 to 1980. He was born in Charlotte, North Carolina.

Jordan died on May 20, 2008 in Atlanta, Georgia of mesothelioma at the age of 63.

[[Jack Watson (presidential adviser)]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, White House Chiefs of Staff, Politicians from El Paso, Texas, US Democratic Party politicians

Jack Hearn Watson Jr. (born October 24, 1938) is an American political strategist and political aide. He was White House Chief of Staff to President Jimmy Carter from 1980 to 1981.

[[Pete Rouse]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, White House Chiefs of Staff, Politicians from New Haven, Connecticut, US Democratic Party politicians

Peter Mikami Rouse (born April 15, 1946) is an American political consultant. He was interim White House Chief of Staff to U.S. President Barack Obama from 2010 to 2011. Rouse spent many years on Capitol Hill, becoming known as the "101st senator" during his tenure as Chief of Staff to Senate Democratic leader Tom Daschle.

After Daschle lost his election, Rouse later became Chief of Staff for then-Senator Obama.

[[John Podesta]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, American political commentators, White House Chiefs of Staff, American educators, Politicians from Chicago, Businesspeople from Chicago, US Democratic Party politicians

John David Podesta Jr. (born January 8, 1949) is an American political consultant. He was White House Chief of Staff to President Bill Clinton from October 20, 1998, until January 20, 2001, and as Counselor to President Barack Obama from January 1, 2014, until February 13, 2015.

He is the former president, and now Chair and Counselor, of the Center for American Progress (CAP), a think tank in Washington, D.C. He is a  Visiting Professor of Law at the Georgetown University Law Center.

Podesta was chairman of Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign.

[[Mack McLarty]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, White House Chiefs of Staff, Businesspeople from Arkansas, Politicians from Arkansas, People from Hope, Arkansas, US Democratic Party politicians

Thomas F. "Mack" McLarty, III (born June 14, 1946) is an American businessman and politician. He was President Bill Clinton's first White House Chief of Staff from 1993 to June 1994. He later was Counselor to the President and Special Envoy for the Americas.

He was chairman and CEO of Arkla, Inc. (1983-1992), a natural gas company. During that time, he was appointed by President George H.W. Bush to the National Petroleum Council and the National Council on Environmental Quality.

He is the Chairman of McLarty Associates, an international strategic advisory firm headquartered in Washington, DC, and chairman of the McLarty Companies, based in Little Rock, Arkansas.

[[James R. Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, White House Chiefs of Staff, Ambassadors of the United States to Mexico, United States representatives from Oklahoma, US Democratic Party politicians

James Robert Jones (born May 5, 1939) is an American lawyer and Democratic politician. He was a U.S. Congressman from Oklahoma between 1973 to 1987. He was the U.S. Ambassador to Mexico from 1993 to 1997. 

From 1968 to 1969, he was acting White House Chief of Staff for the Lyndon B. Johnson administration.

In 1972, after returning to Oklahoma, Jones ran for Oklahoma's 1st congressional district. He won the election and was re-elected six times. During his tenure in Congress, which lasted until 1987, Jones served four years as the Chairman of the House Budget Committee.

[[Dragon Force]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 video games, 1997 video games, Sega Saturn games, Role-playing video games, Video games developed in Japan

Dragon Force is a fantasy role-playing video game in the Dragon Force series. It was made by Sega CS and published by Sega for the Sega Saturn in 1996. It is followed by Dragon Force 2.

[[Kenneth O'Donnell]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 1977 deaths, American political commentators, People from Worcester, Massachusetts, White House Chiefs of Staff, Deaths from gastrointestinal hemorrhage, Politicians from Boston, Massachusetts, US Democratic Party politicians

Kenneth Patrick O'Donnell (March 4, 1924 – September 9, 1977) was an American political consultant. He was the special assistant and appointments secretary to President John F. Kennedy from 1961 until Kennedy's assassination in November 1963. O'Donnell was a close friend of President Kennedy and his younger brother Robert F. Kennedy.

O'Donnell also was an aide to President Lyndon B. Johnson from 1963 to 1965. He later was an adviser to Robert Kennedy's 1968 presidential campaign.

He died of gastrointestinal hemorrhage due to alcoholism in September 1977, aged 53.

[[Saint-Pierre-en-Auge]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in France, Communes in Calvados

Saint-Pierre-en-Auge is a commune. It is in the region Normandy in the Calvados department in the northwest of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Saint-Pierre-sur-Dives (the seat), Boissey, Bretteville-sur-Dives, Hiéville, Mittois, Montviette, L'Oudon, Ouville-la-Bien-Tournée, Sainte-Marguerite-de-Viette, Saint-Georges-en-Auge, Thiéville, Vaudeloges and Vieux-Pont-en-Auge.

Wilton Burton "Jerry" Persons (January 19, 1896 – September 5, 1977) was an American politician. He was the White House Chief of Staff to President Dwight D. Eisenhower from October 7, 1958 until January 20, 1961.

CATEGORIES: 1998 video games, Sega Saturn games, Role-playing video games, Video games developed in Japan

Dragon Force 2 is a fantasy role-playing video game in the Dragon Force series. It was made and published by Sega for the Sega Saturn in 1998. It was only released in Japan.

It is a sequel to Dragon Force.

[[Devonport High School for Boys]]

[[Jerald terHorst]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2010 deaths, American journalists, Deaths from congestive heart failure, White House Press Secretaries, Writers from Grand Rapids, Michigan

Jerald Franklin "Jerry" terHorst (July 11, 1922 – March 31, 2010) was an American journalist. He was the twelfth White House Press Secretary during the first month of Gerald Ford's presidency. He resigned in protest of Ford's pardon of former President Richard Nixon.

[[Méry-Bissières-en-Auge]]

Méry-Bissières-en-Auge is a commune. It is found in the region Normandy in the Calvados department in the northwest of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Méry-Corbon (the seat) and Bissières.

[[Akira Kume]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Actors from Tokyo

Akira Kume was a Japanese actor. He was born in Tokyo. His career began in 1947. His best known roles were in The Insect Woman (1963), Tora-san's Sunrise and Sunset (1976) and in The Resurrection of the Golden Wolf (1979). He also voiced dubbed King Triton in the Japanese version of Disney's The Little Mermaid (1989).

Kume died of heart failure in Tokyo on April 23, 2020, aged 96.

[[Belle Vie en Auge]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments in France, Communes in Calvados

Belle Vie en Auge is a commune. It is found in the region Normandy in the Calvados department in the northwest of France. The municipality was created on 1 January 2017 and consists of the former communes of Biéville-Quétiéville (the seat) and Saint-Loup-de-Fribois.

[[Shigeru Tsuyuguchi]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Actors from Tokyo

Shigeru Tsuyuguchi is a Japanese actor. He was born in Tokyo. His career began in 1955. He became known for playing thief in Shohei Imamura's Unholy Desire. His best known roles were as Hyōgo Furukawa in the first season of Mito Kōmon and Fujiwara no Hidesato in the taiga drama Kaze to Kumo to Niji to.

He also voiced "Baron Humbert von Gikkingen" in the original Japanese version of the Studio Ghibli anime movie Whisper of the Heart in 1995.

[[Melrose, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota

Melrose is a city in Stearns County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 3,598 at the 2010 census. It is part of the St. Cloud Metropolitan Statistical Area.

[[Gaylord Nelson]]

CATEGORIES: United States senators from Wisconsin, Governors of Wisconsin, American environmentalists, US Democratic Party politicians, Deaths from heart failure, 1939 births, 2005 deaths

Gaylord Anton Nelson (June 4, 1916 – July 3, 2005) was an American Democratic politician and environmentalist. He was born in Clear Lake, Wisconsin.

Nelson was the 35th Governor of Wisconsin from 1959 to 1963. Then, he became a United States Senator and founded Earth Day in 1970. He left the U.S. Senate in 1980. He then worked in a non-profit organization called The Wilderness Society.

In 1995, President Bill Clinton honored Nelson with the Presidential Medal of Freedom for his work helping the environment.

Nelson died on July 3, 2005 in Kensington, Maryland of heart failure, aged 89. The Gaylord Nelson Wilderness was named after him, in honor of his role in creating the park.

[[Akira Terao]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, Singers from Kanagawa Prefecture, Japanese movie actors, Living people

Akira Terao is a Japanese musician, singer and actor. He is the only male actor to have received both the Japan Record Award and the Japan Academy Award for Outstanding Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role. He was born in Yokohama (Kanagawa Prefecture) in Japan. He starred as "I" in Dreams. He also starred in Half a Confession.

[[Chieko Baisho]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, Living people, Japanese singers, Japanese movie actors, Actors from Tokyo

Chieko Baisho is a Japanese  actress and singer.

She sang many pupular songs, mostly in her younger days. She is also known for her roles as Sakura in the Otoko wa Tsurai yo series from 1969 until 1995. She acted in many movies directed by Yōji Yamada. She won the award for best actress at the 5th Hochi Film Award for A Distant Cry from Spring.

[[Gin Maeda]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from Tokyo, Living people, 1944 births

Gin Maeda (born February 21, 1944) is a Japanese actor. He is known for his regular role in the Otoko wa Tsurai yo movies. He was born in Tokyo.

[[Asao Sano]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, Living people, Japanese movie actors

Asao Sano is a Japanese actor. He is known for playing the role of Tokugawa Mitsukuni on the television jidaigeki series Mito Kōmon. He was born in Yokohama, Japan.
